meaning_mnemonic: Lying on the <radical>ground</radical> is something that looks just like the ground, the number <kanji>One</kanji>. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.
reading_mnemonic: As you're sitting there next to <kanji>One</kanji>, holding him up, you start feeling a weird sensation all over your skin. From the wound comes a fine powder (obviously coming from the special bullet used to kill One) that causes the person it touches to get extremely <reading>itchy</reading> (いち).

meaning_mnemonic: Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is <radical>seven</radical> and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also <kanji>seven</kanji>. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.
reading_mnemonic:
You know this kanji means <kanji>seven</kanji>, so let's use that to remember the reading too. <kanji>Seven</kanji> is a lucky number, usually, but this time it isn't so good: 

<kanji>Seven</kanji> percent is all she got on her test after <reading>she chea</reading>ted (しち) on it.

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine <radical>one</radical> and <radical>two</radical> together and what do you get? <kanji>Three</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Three</kanji> is the number of chances you get with <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん). He has a list, and when you get to three "naughty things" lines, that's it. You're on Santa-san's three strikes and you're out list.

kunyomi: うえ, あ, のぼ, うわ, かみ
meaning_mnemonic: You find a <radical>toe</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>. It's weird, because it's <kanji>above</kanji> the ground, not where toes belong.
reading_mnemonic: Of course when you find a toe <kanji>above</kanji> the ground, you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it, you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand, <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう).

kunyomi: した, さ, くだ, お, しも, もと
meaning_mnemonic: There's the <radical>ground</radical>, and there's a <radical>toe</radical> just <kanji>below</kanji> it. Yep, you know this means "below" because the ground has a toe below it in this kanji.
reading_mnemonic: You keep digging in the ground for the toe <kanji>below</kanji>, but instead you hit something hard and metallic. You try to dig around it, but it's huge. Turns out it's a <reading>car</reading> (か). Keep digging until you unearth the car below. (Inside, you find the toe you were looking for.)

meaning_mnemonic: Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is <radical>nine</radical> and the kanji is <kanji>nine</kanji>, making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.
reading_mnemonic:
Although this kanji has two on'yomi to learn, the pronunciations of those two on'yomi are very similar, so that should make them easier to remember.

When you were <kanji>nine</kanji> your favorite foods were <reading>coo</reading>kies (く) and <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう). Yum yum!

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji <kanji>two</kanji> and the radical <radical>two</radical> are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!
reading_mnemonic: How do you count to <vocabulary>two</vocabulary>? Just use someone's <reading>knee</reading> (に), and then their other knee. There — two knees!

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant <radical>person</radical> because it looks like a person with their arms down and their legs spread out? Well this is a <kanji>person</kanji> too!
reading_mnemonic: Only one <kanji>person</kanji> at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (にん) complained about the new <reading>jean</reading>s (じん) policy, and that person was you.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>enter</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>enter</kanji> as well.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out, after you <kanji>enter</kanji> the tent (remember how the person in the radical is entering one?), you're given a <reading>new</reading> (にゅう) one! Why? No idea, but hey — it's new!

meaning_mnemonic: This isn't exactly the same as the <radical>fins</radical> radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly "modified radical" version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? <kanji>Eight</kanji> fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each.
reading_mnemonic: After you count and smell all <kanji>eight</kanji> of your fins, it's time to put them away. You open a large <reading>hatch</reading> (はち) and put them in. This is where you keep your fins, always putting in eight at a time because that's what the boss wants.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are <kanji>power</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Who has the most power of anyone? It's the <kanji>Power</kanji> Rangers. They are battling their arch enemy <reading>Ricky</reading> (りき). They defeat him and <reading>lock</reading> (りょく) him up, so that he can't hurt anyone ever again.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>cross</radical> is the symbol for the number <kanji>ten</kanji>. A good way to remember this is to think about all the religions that have crosses and also important sets of tens.
reading_mnemonic: This cross in particular has <kanji>ten</kanji> <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう) on it. Two on each arm and two in the middle. That's ten jewels!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> radical and the <kanji>mouth</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic:
Do you remember seeing the construction worker こういち earlier in the 工 mnemonic? If you haven't yet, not to worry!

For kanji with こう readings (there are a lot of them!) we will use the character こういち every time. He's one of the people who started this website, so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Anyways, remember that whenever you see こう, think こういち.

Everyone agrees, the <kanji>mouth</kanji> is <reading>こう</reading>いち's best feature. You stare at it lovingly as he whispers sweet kanji readings to you.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>big</radical> radical and the <kanji>big</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: There's this big guy (that's how you remember the radical, remember?), and he's wearing a huge <reading>Tie Dye</reading> (たい, だい) shirt. Because he's so huge, the tie dye shirt is also super huge. Everything about him is pretty big, but the tie dye stands out more than anything.

onyomi: じょ, にょ, にょう
meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>woman</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>woman</kanji> are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: When you think of a <kanji>woman</kanji>, think of <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (じょ), though she usually goes by just "Jo."

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> radical and the <kanji>mountain</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: Think about <kanji>mountains</kanji> talking to each other, calling each other by their names and adding the Japanese name-ender <reading>san</reading> (さん) to each of their names. "Hello, Everest-<reading>san</reading>." "Oh hi, Fuji-<reading>san</reading>."

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>river</radical> radical and the <kanji>river</kanji> kanji are the same as each other!
reading_mnemonic: You're standing next to a <kanji>river</kanji> that's actually used as a <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>wa</reading>sh (かわ).

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>construction</radical> radical and the <kanji>construction</kanji> kanji are the same!

This kanji also means <kanji>industry</kanji>, which is what construction is, if you think about it. It's all part of the construction industry.
reading_mnemonic:
Every time a kanji uses the こう reading (there are a lot!), we'll use the character こういち. He's one of the people who started this website, so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Like this:

You see some <kanji>construction</kanji> in front of you. There, standing shirtless (only suspenders and a hard hat) is <reading>こう</reading>いち, looking back at you.

other_meanings: Repetition, Reduplication, Iteration Mark, Kanji Repeater, Repeater Kanji
meaning_mnemonic:
This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. It repeats what comes before it.

To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a <radical>prison</radical> with <radical>drop</radical>s of water dripping over and over in it. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again, driving the prisoners nuts. But it never stops. It just repeats over and over.
reading_mnemonic:
This symbol doesn't really have a name, but it's sometimes called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way:

Your mom is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. She is trying to force feed you over and over again until you explode (literally). You keep yelling "<reading>No ma</reading> (のま)!" but she doesn't stop. She's on a repeating track, never stopping, repeating forever.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>street</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: So you're walking down this <kanji>street</kanji>, and off in the distance you see the silhouette of somebody. A lady. Big, black curly hair and red eyes. It is the street-woman, Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう).

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <reading>middle</reading> and the kanji <kanji>middle</kanji> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word Chewbacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory.

If you remember back to the radical 中, a stick was stuck in the middle of the mouth of something. Let's say it was your mouth, and when you look up to see who did it, there stands <reading>Chew</reading>bacca. He's even doing his Chewbacca yell. And it isn't a stick in your mouth, it's an arrow from his bowcaster. It just so happens Chewbacca's bowcaster looks just like this kanji too. Go figure.

meaning_mnemonic: What's something with <radical>nine</radical> sides? Just add a <radical>drop</radical> and you'll have something that's almost a <kanji>circle</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should check it out. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worthwhile. When you think about a circle, think about Maru all rolled up in a little circle, being super adorable. Don't tell me it doesn't melt your heart just thinking about it. Alternatively, you could also look at this kanji and think of Maru inside of a box, with his little tail sticking out of it. Whatever works best for you, just get yourself to "Maru."

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>five</radical> radical and the <kanji>five</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Five</kanji> is the number of buildings <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) will knock down. Oh, look! There he goes now.

meaning_mnemonic: Just imagine a beast with a <radical>lid</radical> for a head and <radical>fins</radical> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <kanji>six</kanji> is the devil's number.
reading_mnemonic:
Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word <reading>rock</reading>. 

So, think about the devil and the devil's number. What is often associated with those things? Why, <reading>rock</reading> (ろく) and roll is. Imagine the lid-head fin-legged beast suddenly blasting out rock music in the middle of his destructive mayhem.

meaning_mnemonic: Here we have a <radical>head</radical> with a <radical>lid</radical> in it, near the top. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <kanji>yen</kanji> coins, the currency of Japan. Jackpot! And all those yen coins have a nice <kanji>round</kanji> shape, naturally.
reading_mnemonic: What does the word <kanji>yen</kanji> sound like? It sounds like <reading>えん</reading>. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a "ye" sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an "e" sound, which is why yen = えん!

meaning_mnemonic: There are two <radical>mountains</radical> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <kanji>exit</kanji> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.
reading_mnemonic: As you're trying to <kanji>exit</kanji> this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he <reading>shoots you</reading> (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is <radical>sword</radical>, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese <kanji>sword</kanji>? That's right, the most common is a <kanji>katana</kanji>, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
reading_mnemonic: So now you have this sweet <kanji>katana</kanji> in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to <reading>とう</reading>きょう (Tokyo). とうきょう has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to とうきょう.

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is the same as the radical you learned, so it means <kanji>thousand</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the thousand people going down the slide on a cross in the radical 千? Turns out each one of them was carrying a <kanji>thousand</kanji> <reading>cen</reading>ts (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what a thousand times a thousand cents would come out to. It's quite a lot, actually.

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Narwhal</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s are on the <kanji>right</kanji> side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.

See how the "mouth" radical is to the right of the "narwhal" radical? That should help you remember that this means <kanji>right</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: How did we know to look from the <kanji>right</kanji>, though? Because the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) figured it out. Youths think in ways that older people usually don't. That's why they can see the swirls on cereal, hear the music behind noise, and of course, look at things from the right side.

meaning_mnemonic: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <radical>mouth</radical> now has your <radical>legs</radical> inside it. You've bent your body in all the wrong ways to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <kanji>four</kanji> sides.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you have <kanji>four</kanji> sides, you look like a four-sided animal: the <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Look at yourself in the mirror and see an adorable four-sided sheep looking back at you. Imagine yourself with perfectly square wool. (You can only see four sides because mirrors aren't 3D. So you're a flat, cartoonish sheep.)

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> radical and the <kanji>dirt</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Who spends a lot of time in <kanji>dirt</kanji>? <reading>Do</reading>gs (ど) do! Dogs dig in dirt, they roll in dirt, sometimes they try to eat dirt (which isn't so great).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>evening</radical> radical and the <kanji>evening</kanji> kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>evening</kanji> is when all the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) come outside to play.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>heaven</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>heaven</kanji>, making this an easy kanji to memorize.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Heaven</kanji>... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only <reading>ten</reading> (てん) percent!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>child</radical> radical and the <kanji>child</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic:
The main reading here is し, so to remember it we'll use this mnemonic:

There is a <kanji>child</kanji> standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again, there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in front of you. A sheep?! You yelp, blink again, and it's back to being a child. Are… are all children really just sheep?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>small</radical> radical and the <kanji>small</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>small</kanji> kanji would be the perfect gift to give to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). The Shougun loves little things, and the <kanji>little</kanji> kanji represents all of that.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Narwhal</radical>s do <radical>construction</radical> with their <kanji>left</kanji> hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!
reading_mnemonic: In their <kanji>left</kanji> hands, the narwhals all hold <reading>saw</reading>s (さ). That's because the ice for their homes is already there, so they just need to saw away at them to make the shapes they want. Narwhal construction is actually very simple.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hand</radical> radical and the <kanji>hand</kanji> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading て we will use the word "television." You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little <reading>te</reading>levisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical> you put <radical>barb</radical>s at the bottom of a <radical>slide</radical>. This is your special <kanji>talent</kanji>. When you go down the slide, you fly right past the barbs like some kind of daredevil. Any normal kid would land on the barbs and get hurt, but you have this talent.
reading_mnemonic: But then people start to say that no human could have so much <kanji>talent</kanji>, that you must be a <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). Are you really a talented cyborg?

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>writing</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>writing</kanji> as well.
reading_mnemonic:
This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You always put <kanji>writing</kanji> on your <reading>bun</reading>s (ぶん) to keep them from getting eaten by the bun <reading>mon</reading>ster (もん). What kind of writing? Usually it's just an X to show the monster these buns are off-limits. (In fact, it kind of looks like the X part in 文. Hmm…)

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> radical and <kanji>sun</kanji> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <kanji>day</kanji> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
reading_mnemonic:
There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち. 

The <kanji>sun</kanji> is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich <reading>Nietzsche</reading> (にち), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> kanji is made up of the <radical>moon</radical> radical. This kanji is also used to mean <kanji>month</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> really <reading>gets</reading> (げつ) to your <reading>guts</reading> (がつ). Staring at the moon for too long will give you terrible indigestion, so be careful!

meaning_mnemonic: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <radical>tree</radical> and <kanji>tree</kanji> are the same in looks and meaning.
reading_mnemonic: You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Suddenly, you trip and fall. The trees start to <reading>mock</reading> (もく) you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked as you pull yourself up off the ground.

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>book</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>book</kanji> as well.

Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are <kanji>origin</kanji>, <kanji>real</kanji>, and <kanji>main</kanji>. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Book</kanji>s are one of the best ways to <reading>hone</reading> (ほん) your intellect, you know?

meaning_mnemonic: There is a line on the <radical>ground</radical> so you <radical>stop</radical>, making a giant sign pop up that says <kanji>CORRECT</kanji>! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.
reading_mnemonic: You did the <kanji>correct</kanji> thing, so here's your reward: a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) from the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) himself!

visually_similar_kanji: 泳, 球, 永, 氷, 求
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>water</radical> radical and the <kanji>water</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine a lake (i.e. a whole bunch of <kanji>water</kanji>). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very <reading>swee</reading>t. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fire</radical> radical and the <kanji>fire</kanji> kanji are the same as each other.
reading_mnemonic:
Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word <reading>car</reading>.

For this kanji, when we think <kanji>fire</kanji>, we ought to think of something on fire. What's on fire? It's obviously your very own <reading>car</reading> (か)! Oh Goddd NOOO!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dog</radical> radical and <kanji>dog</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: Every <kanji>dog</kanji> likes to <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>noo</reading>dles (いぬ). Like that movie where the dogs share a noodle and end up kissing, right? So when you see 犬, just imagine how those two eat noodles.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> has a big <radical>drop</radical> of liquid in his hand... but then he bounces it! The drop was really a <kanji>ball</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: When he's done playing with it, the king gives his <kanji>ball</kanji> to <reading>Tama</reading>ra (たま), the resident ball girl, for safekeeping.

visually_similar_kanji: 主, 往, 注, 住, 柱
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> radical and the <kanji>king</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>king</kanji> you need to say, "<reading>Oh</reading> (おう) King! Oh King, oh no, oh why are you looking at me like that? Oh King... you aren't going to chop off my head are you? OH NO!"

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice paddy</radical> radical and the <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading た, we use the word "taco."

You're in the rice field... but when you lean down to examine the rice more closely, you see that it's not rice that's growing, it's a bunch of little <reading>ta</reading>cos (た), blossoming out of the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>white</radical> and the kanji <kanji>white</kanji> are the same.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>white</kanji> team was the first to be able to <reading>hack</reading> (はく) the <kanji>white</kanji> iPhone.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> radical and <kanji>eye</kanji> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>eyes</kanji> are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "<reading>Mehhhhhh</reading> (め)!"

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>stand</radical> and the kanji <kanji>stand</kanji> are the same thing, so now you know them both.
reading_mnemonic: Think of someone who has to <kanji>stand</kanji> up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the <reading>Ritz</reading> (りつ).

meaning_mnemonic: You cut the <radical>leaf</radical> with your <radical>sword</radical> into <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> pieces!
reading_mnemonic: Now that you have <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> pieces of tiny leaf paper, you decide to turn them into a <reading>man</reading>ga (まん)! Each little leaf piece will become a panel.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>now</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>now</kanji> as well.
reading_mnemonic: Right <kanji>now</kanji> the <reading>con</reading>dors (こん) are in danger! Not next week, not next year, right now! Haven't you heard that deforestation and pollution are killing all of the condors?!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>head</radical> has a <radical>person</radical> <kanji>inside</kanji> it!
reading_mnemonic: You know this kanji means <kanji>inside</kanji>, so you can keep thinking about the person that's inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a <reading>kni</reading>fe (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational.

meaning_mnemonic: You’ve got a <radical>winter</radical> with lots of <radical>ice</radical>. But doesn't any winter have lots of ice? Exactly. That's why this is just <kanji>winter</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Winter</kanji> is also the time of year you give out presents: "One fu' you, one fu' you and… one <reading>fu' you</reading> (ふゆ)!"

other_meanings: Minute, Divide, Portion, Separate, Understand, Sort, Split, Classify, Share
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fins</radical> that fell onto my <radical>sword</radical> were sliced into many <kanji>part</kanji>s. Following this logic, this also means <kanji>minute</kanji>, which is part of an hour, and <kanji>divide</kanji>, which is the action of splitting something into many parts.
reading_mnemonic: Now that the fins have been cut into neat <kanji>part</kanji>s, it's time to cut something else: <reading>bun</reading>s (ぶん).

meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>seven</radical> <radical>swords</radical>, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to <kanji>cut</kanji> something.
reading_mnemonic: Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You <kanji>cut</kanji> them into pairs, and give <reading>sets</reading> (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is the same as the radical — it means <kanji>north</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You go north, and notice that everyone has a keytar (きた). You know, those keyboards that people hold and play like a guitar?

visually_similar_kanji: 年, 矢, 失, 朱, 件, 牛, 生
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> at <kanji>noon</kanji>. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Noon</kanji> also happens to be the time <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) decided to attack for the same reasons: it's dry and kids are using the slide.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>triceratops</radical> is lying out to <radical>dry</radical>. But it's so big, and it's lying on its side, so only <kanji>half</kanji> of it gets dry.
reading_mnemonic: "You're half wet and half dry! I will cut you in <kanji>half</kanji> with my laser blaster so you're proper again," a voice says. It is  <reading>Han</reading> Solo (はん), the anti-establishment guy who hates when things aren't even.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> is your <kanji>friend</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "Hi <kanji>friend</kanji>," says the narwhal. "I must warn you about all the <reading>you</reading>ths." (ゆう)

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>old</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>old</kanji> as well.

Note: This "old" does not refer to people. Think of it as "old things" instead.
reading_mnemonic:
<kanji>Old</kanji> things are misunderstood by the <reading>子</reading>s (こ) of the world.

*Note:* Come up with a 子 character you can use for all the こ reading mnemonics going forward. This child will show up many times throughout your mnemonic journey, and it will help if you imagine the same character the whole time.

other_meanings: Big Machine, Big Device, Device, Stand
meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>private</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> that's a <kanji>machine</kanji>. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.
reading_mnemonic: To make sure they can't tell what's <kanji>machine</kanji> and what's human, you <reading>dye</reading> (だい) the mouth to make it look like skin. You find dye the same shade as your normal mouth and just slap it on there.

meaning_mnemonic: You're known to get the ailment <radical>evening</radical> <radical>toe</radical>, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go <kanji>outside</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You go <kanji>outside</kanji> (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, <reading>Guy</reading> (がい) Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him!

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is the same as the radical, so this means <kanji>fat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine a <kanji>fat</kanji> person who loves to sleep on <reading>futo</reading>n (ふと).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> <radical>child</radical> stands upon the roof, holding up a single <kanji>letter</kanji>, a single <kanji>character</kanji>, a single <kanji>symbol</kanji> for the world to see.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>character</kanji> that is being shown is "J," which stands for <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this <kanji>letter</kanji> and <kanji>symbol</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>small</radical> <radical>slide</radical>. The thing about small slides is that <kanji>few</kanji> people can use them. Not everyone can fit their bum in a small slide — only a few small ones can make it down.
reading_mnemonic: Another reason so <kanji>few</kanji> people can use it is that the <reading>Sho</reading>gun (しょう) is trying to go down the slide. We're talking a grown man who's way too big for this little slide, so a few people have to wait behind him — it's a slide traffic jam.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a manhole <radical>lid</radical> and a <radical>towel</radical>, both with the name of a <kanji>city</kanji> on them. Decorative manhole lids and souvenir towels — two things cities love to slap their names on, especially in Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>city</kanji> must have a lot of <reading>shee</reading>p (し) because, besides the manhole lid and the towel, all you can see are sheep. There are sheep everywhere. It's a sheep city.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>canopy</radical> you use in <radical>private</radical> is very <kanji>wide</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You like being <kanji>wide</kanji> because it makes you feel like a different person. But not just any person, like a super <reading>hero</reading> (ひろ)!

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <radical>bow</radical> and a <radical>stick</radical> you need to <kanji>pull</kanji> the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything.
reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>pull</kanji> the bow back, your body strains and you feel an immense <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) rise inside of you. You keep pulling and the heat grows hotter and hotter.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>heart</radical> and the kanji <kanji>heart</kanji> are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji>, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your <kanji>heart</kanji> is stored in your <reading>shin</reading> (しん).

meaning_mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>door</kanji> are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You open the <kanji>door</kanji> and immediately get it closed back on your <reading>toe</reading> (と), literally causing your toe to explode.

meaning_mnemonic:
The radical and the kanji for <kanji>direction</kanji> are the same! Huzzah!

There is also another meaning too, though. This can also mean <kanji>way</kanji> as well. Think of it this way: When you move in one direction in your life, you are developing your own way. "The way of [your name here]."
reading_mnemonic: What <kanji>direction</kanji> do you always know? Which direction do you always want to go? <reading>Ho</reading>me (ほう). Something about your home always stays with you, no matter how far away you go. So if you're lost and you don't know which direction to go, just think of home!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bright</radical> radical and the <kanji>bright</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: What do you say when you see something <kanji>bright</kanji>? "<reading>Ah</reading> (あ)!" Like when you open the curtain and the sunshine hits your eyes, or someone shines a flashlight right into your face. Ahhhh, so bright!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>stop</radical> radical is the same as the <kanji>stop</kanji> kanji.
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>stop</kanji> because there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone breaks part of your <radical>window</radical>. Who did this? It was your <kanji>mother</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly your <kanji>mother</kanji> points her bloodied finger at you and laughs, "<reading>Haha</reading> (はは)!" She keeps laughing, haha haha haha, over and over. You feel even more alarmed.

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Fur</kanji> and <radical>fur</radical> are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean <kanji>hair</kanji>, too, though more like furry hair.
reading_mnemonic: With <kanji>fur</kanji>, whisk your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it's fur). You're surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel and smell like? Now it's time to get rid of it. There's just too much <kanji>hair</kanji>! To get rid of it, you'll need to <reading>mow</reading> (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they're loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think "fur → in the fur → get rid of the fur → mow the fur," in that order. That'll get you to "mow," which will help you to remember the on’yomi.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>father</kanji> are the same.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine your father is <reading>Cheech</reading> (ちち) from Cheech and Chong.

visually_similar_kanji: 年, 朱, 矢, 失, 午, 件, 生
meaning_mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>cow</kanji> are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.
reading_mnemonic: Have you ever heard of わ<reading>ぎゅう</reading> (wagyu) beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう.

kunyomi: い, なま, う, は, き
visually_similar_kanji: 午, 牛, 矢, 先, 年, 失, 朱
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>life</radical> radical and the <kanji>life</kanji> kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
reading_mnemonic: You can save <kanji>life</kanji> or take it away with your new <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). This is the saber you got from doing the correct thing (remember?), and now you need to figure out how to use it with this life. So what do you do?

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>task</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>task</kanji> as well.
reading_mnemonic: Today, your <kanji>task</kanji> is to eat <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). It's nutritious, it's delicious, and I'm telling you to do it, so you have to. A task is basically just something you have to do, so that's what this is.

visually_similar_kanji: 生, 午, 牛, 朱, 失, 株, 先
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>arrow</radical> radical and the <kanji>arrow</kanji> kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!).

What is this arrow doing? It’s following around all the <reading>Ya</reading>nkee (や) baseball players, stalking them, waiting to make its move (I’ll let you decide what its “move” is).

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>not</radical> and the kanji <kanji>not</kanji> are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!
reading_mnemonic:
To remember ふ we'll use the word "fool."

Think of those jokes, where someone says something, then ends with a loud "<kanji>NOTTTT</kanji>!" Someone is doing that to you, over and over. What is that person? That person is a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ).

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>world</radical> radical and the <kanji>world</kanji> kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: <kanji>generation</kanji>. 

Think of it this way: the world is just made up of many different generations of people, plants, and animals all getting along together.
reading_mnemonic: It's your job to protect the <kanji>world</kanji> and every <kanji>generation</kanji> with your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). It was given to you to uphold correctness, and you'll pass it on to the next generation when it's time. Then they'll watch out for the world when you're gone.

kunyomi: おも, ぬし, あるじ
visually_similar_kanji: 王, 玉, 住, 注, 往, 柱
meaning_mnemonic:
The radical <radical>master</radical> and the kanji <kanji>master</kanji> have the same meanings!

This kanji also means <kanji>main</kanji> because the master is the main person of a dojo or household or business.
reading_mnemonic: Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the <kanji>master</kanji> is floating a water drop above his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master sends the drop of water into a <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ) and it goes careening through an intricate series of them.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> <radical>samurai</radical> didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by <kanji>doing</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: He was <kanji>doing</kanji> things with <reading>shee</reading>p (し). He is the leader of the sheep clan, and he was able to do more with sheep than anyone else. That's why he's the leader.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>alligators</radical>... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the <kanji>Other</kanji> Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading た, we use the word "Taco"

Then there's the <kanji>other</kanji>s of the others. These are the <reading>ta</reading>co (た) worshipers. They're really strange.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> is next to the <radical>tree</radical>. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, <kanji>rest</kanji>ing.
reading_mnemonic: As he <kanji>rest</kanji>s, he suddenly gets hungry and pulls a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう) off the tree and bites into it. A good rest isn't complete without some crunchy tree cucumbers.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>origin</radical> radical and the <kanji>origin</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic:
The <kanji>origin</kanji> of everything can be found in <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). Genji is the name of the main character in the world's first ever novel, "The Tale of Genji." 

Picture him as a rich, pretty boy who cares a ton about his looks and gets along really well with all the ladies. He's also really great at poetry, which helps the lady situation.

visually_similar_kanji: 失, 矢, 生, 朱, 夫, 去
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Slide</radical> some <radical>dirt</radical> on your <radical>legs</radical> so you can feel like you're from a <kanji>previous</kanji> time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs.
reading_mnemonic: As you sit there, pretending you're in a <kanji>previous</kanji> time you see a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん)! That's right! Centaurs are from wayyyy in the <kanji>past</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>forehead</radical> of this <radical>beggar</radical> is on the <radical>ground</radical>. Except it's not exactly the ground, it's a giant <kanji>copy</kanji> machine, and he's making copies of his forehead!
reading_mnemonic: This ground <kanji>copy</kanji> machine can only be the work of one person: a <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ)!

meaning_mnemonic: If someone tries to dig up <radical>dirt</radical> on your <radical>private</radical> life, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the <kanji>past</kanji>. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading きょ, we'll use "Little Kyoto." This will differentiate きょ from きょう, which is regular-sized Kyoto. Get it? You decide to bury all this private dirt from your <kanji>past</kanji> in Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ). That stuff is from when you were just a little <reading>子</reading> (こ) and you don't like to think about it.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>mouth</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical> (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of <radical>prison</radical> you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of <kanji>number</kanji>s that you don't understand.
reading_mnemonic:
"You want to know the <kanji>number</kanji> to the hatch?" yells an old voice from inside. You say "yes," and the voice gives you the numbers and you're in! You go down into the prison, where there is one prisoner: Grandpa <reading>ごう</reading>いち.

Note: For the ごう reading mnemonics, we use Grandpa ごういち because こういち is used for the こう reading. So just remember that ごう comes from Koichi's grandpa ごういち.

meaning_mnemonic: What is the <radical>evening</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so <kanji>famous</kanji> that everybody knows his <kanji>name</kanji> (“Evening Mouth.”).
reading_mnemonic: So, when does “Evening Mouth” appear? Turns out, “Evening Mouth” only comes out to talk in <reading>May</reading> (めい). You know this because it’s just starting to be spring, and when you look around (you’re watching “Evening Mouth” again) you see some spring flowers come up.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>center</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>center</kanji> are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: Remember that guy from the 央 radical fastening his belt across the <kanji>center</kanji> of his body? This guy always secures his belt at the center — not slightly to the left, not slightly to the right, but dead center. His precision is so mind-blowing that everyone watching can't help but say, "<reading>Ohh</reading>!"(おう).

meaning_mnemonic: Under his <radical>roof</radical>, the <radical>king</radical> stares into a <radical>drop</radical> of water containing his greatest <kanji>treasure</kanji>. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.
reading_mnemonic: All of this <kanji>treasure</kanji> is kept in the king's <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). He can't let other people see how much treasure he has, or they'll get mad. Or worse, ask him to share some with his people. Yuck. The treasure stays at home.

onyomi: へい, ひょう, びょう
meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>dry</radical> your <radical>horns</radical> you need to lay them <kanji>flat</kanji>. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's <kanji>peace</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Being <kanji>flat</kanji> isn't enough, so you cover the whole thing in <reading>hay</reading> (へい). Hay absorbs water, so you add a flat layer of it.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>gun</radical> and a <radical>cow</radical>, which must mean it's that time of the <kanji>year</kanji>! Every year on New Year's Eve, you get asked to shoot a cow, as per tradition. You really don't want to though, so you deliberately miss every time.
reading_mnemonic: It seems everyone has caught on to the fact that you deliberately miss every <kanji>year</kanji>, so this year you make a <reading>nen</reading>doroid (ねん) decoy in the shape of a cow.

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical> to the <radical>street</radical> to <kanji>hit</kanji> some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting!
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>hit</kanji> one chump after another, suddenly your <reading>da</reading>d (だ) comes marching out of your house. Uh oh. Dad caught you hitting, which, honestly, isn't a very nice thing to do, so he has every right to stop you.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> is over the <radical>cross</radical> it's time to go to church... which is so darn <kanji>early</kanji>. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be <kanji>fast</kanji>, otherwise you'll be too late.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the そう reading we use the word "soul."

When you're forced to get up <kanji>fast</kanji> and <kanji>early</kanji> you can feel it in your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). You're so tired and it's so early, your soul cries out, "Please don't make me go this fast this early. I'm gonna leave your body if you keep this up!"

visually_similar_kanji: 竹, 付, 対, 材
meaning_mnemonic: Someone's taking <radical>tree</radical> <radical>measurements</radical>… Why are they taking measurements of trees? Because they're planning to cut them down to make their <kanji>village</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: They take all the wood back to where they're building their <kanji>village</kanji>, and once they construct the village center they paint a <reading>mura</reading>l (むら) on the side of it. The mural is of the forest where they got the trees from, to honor the village's origins.

meaning_mnemonic: These days <radical>energy</radical> is the greatest <radical>treasure</radical>. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine finding some in a literal treasure chest. As soon as you open it, out bursts the <kanji>energy</kanji> in a kind of <kanji>spirit</kanji> ball.
reading_mnemonic: As you reach inside the <kanji>energy</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> ball, you feel something hard inside. It's a large <reading>key</reading> (き) that gives you access to another treasure.

visually_similar_kanji: 泳, 来, 米, 球, 永, 水, 求
meaning_mnemonic: Add a <radical>drop</radical> of something magical to <radical>water</radical> and suddenly it turns into big block of <kanji>ice</kanji>, just like that.
reading_mnemonic: When you think of <kanji>ice</kanji>, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named <reading>Corey</reading> (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice.

meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>cross</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical>, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say, you <kanji>say humbly</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As you're saying all these humble things, you're also <reading>mow</reading>ing (もう) your neighbor's lawn. Your neighbors love you so much, because you're so humble, and you mow their lawn for them.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>man</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>man</kanji> are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: When you think of a <kanji>man</kanji>, think of <reading>dawn</reading> (だん), because that man has to get up at dawn to power his rice paddy every day.

meaning_mnemonic: When you see both a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and a <radical>street</radical> in the same place, you have the makings of a whole <kanji>town</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: You go to visit this nice little <kanji>town</kanji>. But then, there she is... Every time you walk down the street, the street-woman Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) arrives to ruin your day.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>leaf</radical> growing out of the <radical>sun</radical>! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a <kanji>hundred</kanji>! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.
reading_mnemonic: You fly closer, counting all one <kanji>hundred</kanji> leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH <reading>HYUCK</reading> (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>plate</kanji> kanji and the <radical>plate</radical> radical are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.
reading_mnemonic: The person washing all the <kanji>dish</kanji>es was named <reading>Sarah</reading> (さら). She was named that because of her large head, which was shaped like Sarah Jessica Parker’s head (very big).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>stone</radical> radical and <kanji>stone</kanji> kanji are the same thing!
reading_mnemonic: You throw a <kanji>stone</kanji> through a window... and, now you can see something very <reading>sexy</reading> (せき).

meaning_mnemonic: What do you get if you lend a <radical>spirit</radical> your <radical>umbrella</radical>? <kanji>Thanks</kanji>, of course! Especially if that spirit is Totoro, the spirit of the forest.
reading_mnemonic: So what did you receive as a <kanji>thanks</kanji>? You open it up, and there's a <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun inside!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hole</radical> radical and the <kanji>hole</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Ana</reading> (あな) fell into a <kanji>hole</kanji>. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bamboo</radical> radical and the <kanji>bamboo</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: Today is free <kanji>bamboo</kanji> day, so just <reading>take</reading> (たけ) all the bamboo you want.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> radical and <kanji>thread</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
reading_mnemonic: You have some <kanji>thread</kanji>... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to <reading>eat</reading> (いと) the thread.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ear</radical> radical and <kanji>ear</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.
reading_mnemonic: Put your hand to your <kanji>ear</kanji> and sing... "<reading>Mimi</reading>mimimimiiiii!" (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear.

meaning_mnemonic: All these <radical>flowers</radical> were planted by your <radical>leader</radical> with nothing but a <radical>spoon</radical>. Now the whole place is absolutely full with beautiful <kanji>flower</kanji>s. Flowers everywhere.
reading_mnemonic: But for some reason, the leader just can't stop planting <kanji>flower</kanji>s... He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? Now there’s only one person that can save him: <reading>Hannah</reading> (はな).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>insect</radical> radical and <kanji>insect</kanji> are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
reading_mnemonic: It's an <kanji>insect</kanji>! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A <reading>mush</reading> (むし) sound.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>see</radical> and the kanji <kanji>see</kanji> are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: You see something. It's walking towards you, but you need to see better. When the person comes close, you realize "That person is <reading>me</reading> (み)!"

visually_similar_kanji: 見, 具, 負, 頁
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>shellfish</radical> radical and the <kanji>shellfish</kanji> kanji are the same! It can be just the <kanji>shell</kanji> part too.
reading_mnemonic: To get some <kanji>shellfish</kanji>, all you have to do is hop in your <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) and get some. Shellfish live in the water.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>red</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>red</kanji> are the same thing!
reading_mnemonic: This kanji means <kanji>red</kanji>, <reading>AKA</reading>, also known as, あか.

meaning_mnemonic:
The radical for <radical>foot</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>foot</kanji> are exactly the same.

That being said, there's also another meaning you should keep in mind, which is <kanji>sufficient</kanji>. If you think about it, one foot should be sufficient enough to walk around with if you hop.
reading_mnemonic: What do you wear on your <kanji>foot</kanji>? You wear a <reading>sock</reading> (そく).

visually_similar_kanji: 重, 垂, 東, 京, 束, 軍
meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>car</radical> and the kanji <kanji>car</kanji> are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic:
When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use "shaman".

There's a <kanji>car</kanji>. It's the nicest car you've ever seen. Exquisite, beautiful. Wouldn't you be surprised to learn it belongs to a <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ)? Well it does. This shaman charges a premium for his shaman services so he can afford fancy cars like this.

meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>father</radical>. But, he won't taste good alone, so you <kanji>mix</kanji> in some other ingredients. They <kanji>mingle</kanji> inside the pot with him.
reading_mnemonic: With a <kanji>mix</kanji> of your father and other ingredients <kanji>mingl</kanji>ing in your cooking pot, you lift up the lid... your father pops up. Your father is <reading>こう</reading>いち. He stares back at you with a big smile.

kunyomi: か, かわ, よ, しろ
meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>leader</radical> for the <radical>ceremony</radical> can't come so you need a <kanji>substitute</kanji> to <kanji>replace</kanji> them ASAP!

This kanji has another meaning too. The leader can't come to the ceremony because they forgot what <kanji>period</kanji> of time it was. If they think they're in the wrong <kanji>age</kanji>, they won't come because they're trying to lead some monkeys in the ceremony instead.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>substitute</kanji> leader is wearing the wrong color clothes, so you have to <reading>dye</reading> (だい) them, like they did in the olden <kanji>age</kanji>s.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>meet</radical> radical and the <kanji>meet</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: What better way to <kanji>meet</kanji> new people than to start <reading>kay</reading>aking (かい)! Get into your kayak and just float out into the water. You'll eventually bump into someone else in a kayak and boom, you're meeting someone new!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>book</radical> all about the human <kanji>body</kanji>. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.
reading_mnemonic: The leader's <kanji>body</kanji> book also taught her about something very body specific: how to tie a <reading>tie</reading> (たい). You can't have a tie on your body, no no. Those are for the leader and her smart body.

visually_similar_kanji: 阿, 荷, 河, 同, 旬, 伺, 可, 司, 洞, 句, 詞, 飼, 向, 苛
meaning_mnemonic: Our <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>lip ring</radical>. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? <kanji>WHAT</kanji>??
reading_mnemonic: The leader with his lip ring is now eating some <reading>naan</reading> (なん) and curry. It's delicious, of course... but then he gets it caught on his lip ring, and tears half his lip off. He screams: "<reading>Nannnnn eeeeeeeeeehhh</reading>!!" (なに) in anger at the naan and curry.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical>'s <radical>key</radical> is the key that <kanji>make</kanji>s all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.
reading_mnemonic: The leader <kanji>make</kanji>s all the keys and puts them in a <reading>sack</reading> (さく) to distribute them to the underlings, who then cut them into shape with a <reading>saw</reading> (さ).

other_meanings: Big Brother, Elder Brother, Big Bro
meaning_mnemonic: Who's someone who's just a <radical>mouth</radical> with <radical>legs</radical>? That's your know-it-all <kanji>older brother</kanji>, who won't shut up about anything.
reading_mnemonic: You wish you could box your loud-mouth <kanji>older brother</kanji> up and send him far away to <reading>きょう</reading>と. きょうと is super far away from where you currently live, so just ship your older bro off so he can never bother you again.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>triceratops</radical> in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly <radical>pi</radical> shaped (that is, circular, like a pie). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much <kanji>light</kanji> as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.
reading_mnemonic: As you watch this majestic beast absorbing <kanji>light</kanji>, suddenly several dozen feral <reading>こう</reading>いちs burst out from the wilderness, spears in hand. Oh no! Those こういちs are hunting this rare piceratops!

visually_similar_kanji: 旬, 句, 伺, 可, 司, 詞, 飼, 向, 何, 洞, 阿, 荷, 河, 銅, 胴, 苛
meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>mustache</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the <kanji>same</kanji> as yours!
reading_mnemonic:
When we need to remember the reading どう, we use the word "doughnut".

While this is already strange enough, you notice something stranger. Over a couple feet away is a <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (どう) who also has the <kanji>same</kanji> mustache as you (and the one that fell on the ground). The doughnut looks at you for a moment, then scampers off. This doughnut must be a mutant because normally doughnuts don't move.

other_meanings: Revolve, Number Of Times, Time, Counter For Times, Times Counter
meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>mouth</radical> inside a <radical>mouth</radical>. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of <kanji>times</kanji> there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means <kanji>revolve</kanji> too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.
reading_mnemonic: If you're having a hard time wrapping your head around the infinite number of <kanji>times</kanji> these mouths <kanji>revolve</kanji>, just picture yourself in a little <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) going around and down through the mouths.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>mouth</radical> full of two massive <radical>drop</radical>s and… <radical>treasure</radical>?! Upon closer inspection, they appear to form some sort of <kanji>diagram</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: After decades of analyzing the <kanji>diagram</kanji>, scientists found out it leads to… a <reading>zoo</reading> (ず)?!

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>samurai</radical> with a <radical>flag</radical> on a <radical>stick</radical>. On his flag is the symbol 声, the kanji for <kanji>voice</kanji>. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to join the samurai’s protest for more <vocabulary>voice</vocabulary> but immediately notice… they’re all <reading>子, eh</reading> (こえ)?!

meaning_mnemonic: How many <radical>evenings</radical> are there? There are <kanji>many</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading た we use the word "taco."

Let's start with the kanji meaning: <kanji>many</kanji>. You go outside in the evening (because that's what this kanji is made up of) and are surprised when you're hit by <kanji>many</kanji> <reading>ta</reading>cos (た) flying from the sky. For some reason it's raining tacos, and of course you have no idea why.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>night</radical> radical and the <kanji>night</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: You call your friend at <kanji>night</kanji> and say "<reading>Yo, Lou</reading> (よる)!"

meaning_mnemonic: You have a wild <radical>viking</radical> <radical>child</radical> you have to take care of. He won't do anything but <kanji>study</kanji>, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.
reading_mnemonic: This crazy viking child who prefers <kanji>study</kanji> over pillaging (and other viking activities)... the other vikings just stop and <reading>gawk</reading> (がく) at him when they walk by.

visually_similar_kanji: 沸, 弓, 第, 弔
meaning_mnemonic: There is someone wearing <radical>horns</radical>, holding a <radical>bow</radical>, and going down a <radical>slide</radical> held up by a <radical>stick</radical>. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your <kanji>younger brother</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>younger brother</kanji> loves playing dress-up so much that he's now started <reading>dye</reading>ing (だい) his hair all kinds of colors.

meaning_mnemonic: What superhero is most like a <radical>triceratops</radical>? …If you said <radical>Wolverine</radical>, you're <kanji>correct</kanji>! Why is that the <kanji>right</kanji> answer? Because the triceratops has three horns, and Wolverine has three blades coming out of his hands. It's obvious, isn't it? But you knew that of course.
reading_mnemonic: Because you got the answer <kanji>correct</kanji>, you win a free trip to <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Congrats!

meaning_mnemonic: You're walking at night when you discover a <radical>lantern</radical> covered entirely in <radical>hair</radical>, making it a very strange <kanji>shape</kanji>. In fact, this is a <kanji>form</kanji> you'd never expect a lantern to take.
reading_mnemonic: You stare at the <kanji>shape</kanji> until you finally recognize it: <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)! Well, it's hairy, glowing cake, but it's still shaped like a big slice of cake.

other_meanings: Bread Loaf Counter, Ax, Loaf of Bread Counter
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>axe</radical> radical and the <kanji>axe</kanji> kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji>, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
reading_mnemonic: You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an <kanji>axe</kanji> to be a <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji> for the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ground</radical> is scattered with <radical>rice</radical>, which will cause the Predator to <kanji>come</kanji> because he loves rice. Then once he's gone, the <kanji>next</kanji> Predator will come to eat.
reading_mnemonic: When they come, though, they're all disappointed. It turns out it's <reading>rye</reading> (らい) grains, and rye grains taste terrible. Yuck.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>tree</radical> and another <radical>tree</radical>. You basically have yourself a <kanji>forest</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: So, now you have this <kanji>forest</kanji> and you want to cut it down (so much money!). But, you don't have any tools, only your hands. You think... I've done karate for a while, so I can probably chop it down that way. You get in a chopping stance, then do your battle cry and hit: "<reading>HAYA ... .SHI******</reading>!" (はやし)

visually_similar_kanji: 悔, 敏, 梅, 海
meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>gun</radical> and you see some <radical>windows</radical>. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... <kanji>every</kanji> single one of them. <kanji>Each</kanji> and every one.
reading_mnemonic: Now that <kanji>every</kanji> window is broken, you feel pretty stupid because <reading>mi</reading>ce (まい) are pouring in through <kanji>each</kanji> one. You've made a way for mice to get into your house. That wasn't smart.

visually_similar_kanji: 波, 反, 被, 破, 彼, 疲, 披
meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>slide</radical> down a <radical>branch</radical> and your <kanji>skin</kanji> scrapes right off — ouch! Lucky for you, it was just your old outer layer of skin, and now you've got a fresh shiny layer. Yay for exfoliation! You're not sure what to do with this big, floppy layer of old skin, though…
reading_mnemonic: Without your rough old <kanji>skin</kanji> to protect you, you feel the full <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) of the sun now. It burns… it burns! Yeah, you better protect that fresh new skin from the heat.

meaning_mnemonic: Plant a <radical>spirit</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> before you start your <kanji>company</kanji> and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!
reading_mnemonic: Where did you learn about this method of <kanji>company</kanji> growing? From a <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ), of course. Shamans aren't just spouting nonsense, they know what they're talking about. And spirits are right up their shaman alley.

kunyomi: そら, あ, から, す
meaning_mnemonic: What was the biggest <radical>hole</radical> in the <radical>construction</radical> of the world? The <kanji>sky</kanji>. If you think about it, the sky is like a big hole someone forgot to fill in. That's why this kanji also means <kanji>empty</kanji>! Makes sense — nothing is more empty than the sky.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sky</kanji> is usually empty until clouds stage a <reading>coup</reading> (くう). Basically you can think of the sky as the site for one coup after another as the weather changes.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice</radical> radical and <kanji>rice</kanji> kanji are the same in looks and meaning. This kanji can also mean <kanji>America</kanji>, maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
reading_mnemonic: A ton of <kanji>rice</kanji> is grown in <kanji>America</kanji>. And yet you never see rice in American cuisine. So where's all that unused rice going? Actually, it all gets dumped into a big <reading>bay</reading> (べい). They have too much rice and no place to store it, so they've started using bays to store it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>feathers</radical> radical and <kanji>feather</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
reading_mnemonic: You've gathered <kanji>feather</kanji> after feather, like some kind of wannabe birdman or birdwoman, and now you're ready to fly. But as soon as you're about to take off, someone dumps <reading>honey</reading> (はね) on you, making your feathers all goopy.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>coffin</radical> there's a <radical>beggar</radical>, doing his begging. But it doesn't work, nobody helps him. So, he just begins to <kanji>think</kanji>: Why am I in this situation? How could I have avoided it? How will I get out? Think, dammit, think!!
reading_mnemonic: What does the beggar <kanji>think</kanji> of? A thought bubble appears near his head. In it is a picture of <reading>こう</reading>いち! He's thinking that if こういち were here, he'd save him. Oh, if only こういち could save us all!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>meat</radical> radical and <kanji>meat</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
reading_mnemonic: You know who loves <kanji>meat</kanji>? <reading>Nick</reading> (にく). You probably know a Nick — imagine him eating some succulent meat right now.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>self</radical> radical and <kanji>self</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
reading_mnemonic:
When we need to remember じ we use the word "Jesus."

Who said you should always look at your <kanji>self</kanji> before tossing stones (or whatever) at others? <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) did. So, make sure you look at your own self before being a jerk.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>color</radical> radical and <kanji>color</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
reading_mnemonic: You already have <kanji>color</kanji> on the mind because you know the meaning of this kanji, so think of something colorful about yourself. Imagine your <reading>ear</reading> (いろ) being a weird color... green, purple, red, whatever. Just make it really bright and standing out.

meaning_mnemonic: You plant your <radical>flowers</radical> in the light of the <radical>sun</radical> in the shape of a <radical>cross</radical>, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with <kanji>grass</kanji>. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>grass</kanji> on top is brown and burned from the sun, so you need to take a <reading>cool saw</reading> (くさ) and hack the tops off. The saw is actually physically cool to the touch, to help heal the grass' sunburned bits. It just happens to look cool too.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>go</radical> radical and the <kanji>go</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: "Oh, did he <vocabulary>go</vocabulary> again?" When <reading>こう</reading>いち is not around, that's what people often say because he goes to the <reading>gyo</reading>za (ぎょう) restaurant almost every day. こういち just loves gyoza so much, you always know where he is when he is not home.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>west</radical> radical and the <kanji>west</kanji> kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?
reading_mnemonic: You go off to the <vocabulary>west</vocabulary>. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a <reading>niche</reading> (にし) for your snake oil business.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>angle</radical> radical and the <kanji>angle</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: To see those kanji angles from every <kanji>angle</kanji>, you <reading>cock</reading> (かく) your head to the side.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>say</radical> radical and the <kanji>say</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: If you aren't sure what to <kanji>say</kanji>, just think about <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん) and ask yourself, "What would Genji say?"

visually_similar_kanji: 合, 会, 浴, 沿, 容, 裕, 溶, 鉛, 俗
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Fins</radical> decorate a <radical>hat</radical>, with (presumably fish) <radical>mouths</radical> stitched to it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the <kanji>valley</kanji> people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of Los Angeles, California. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.
reading_mnemonic: Hanging around with all the <kanji>Valley</kanji> Girls in the sunny area of LA is also a robot. It's WALL-E's distant (and lazy, lounging) relative, <reading>TAN-E</reading> (たに). He sits around getting a tan in LA with the Valley Girls while his cousin picks up trash.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>moon</radical> is bright, it's easy to see that a <radical>pig</radical> is indeed a <kanji>pig</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Legend has it that if you catch a <kanji>pig</kanji> in moonlight, it will tell you its secrets. Sure enough, this pig tells you it's from <reading>Bhuta</reading>n (ぶた).

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>run</radical> and the kanji <kanji>run</kanji> are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>run</kanji> and run and run and suddenly you feel your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) leave your body. Still running, you turn around and see your soul running a few steps behind you.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone on a <radical>scooter</radical> has an <radical>axe</radical>, and they're getting <kanji>near</kanji> to you really fast! Oh no, they're so <kanji>close</kanji> now, you need to get out of here!
reading_mnemonic: As they draw <kanji>near</kanji>, you recognize who is riding the scooter: the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England! Behind him, a bunch of his guards also on scooters and wielding axes appear and move <kanji>close</kanji> to you.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>village</radical> you always think of first is your <kanji>hometown</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>hometown</kanji> is where you <reading>sat</reading> (さと), nostalgia tugging at your heartstrings amid the endless rice fields and dirt.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>gold</radical> radical and the <kanji>gold</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: The most <kanji>gold</kanji> in the land belongs to the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England. In fact, you've never actually met someone with gold, it all goes straight to the King whenever someone finds some. You just have a few pennies to work with.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>rain</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>rain</kanji> are the same thing.
reading_mnemonic: What if the <kanji>rain</kanji> actually tried to <reading>aim</reading> (あめ) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>blue</radical> radical and the <kanji>blue</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.

Additionally, this can also mean <kanji>young</kanji>. You can remember this because young people have potential as limitless as the blue sky!
reading_mnemonic: You've been feeling really <kanji>blue</kanji>. Mostly because your skin, hair, and eyes have all turned blue. It was an out-of-the-blue transformation! But now someone places his hand on your shoulder and points at your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). It's blue too! You aren't alone!

meaning_mnemonic: For some reason, you are <radical>stand</radical>ing on the <radical>sun</radical>. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the <kanji>sound</kanji> of you burning up.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>sound</kanji> isn't just loud, it's familiar. Finally you place it: <reading>on</reading>ions (おん)!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>life</radical> radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the <radical>winter</radical> radical, you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the <kanji>wheat</kanji> you store away.
reading_mnemonic: You found your <kanji>wheat</kanji>. Thank God. You'll survive. You have to take the wheat back to your house, though. On your way, you get <reading>mug</reading>ged (むぎ).

meaning_mnemonic: As you dig under the <radical>ground</radical> you discover a <radical>head</radical> resting near a <radical>mountain</radical>, which are <kanji>both</kanji> strange things to find beneath the earth.
