reading_mnemonic: But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat floating off in the distance.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>death</radical> and the kanji <kanji>death</kanji> are the same.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>death</kanji> will be because of a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) accident. Oh, you didn't know? You're going to be hit by a giant bowling ball and crushed flat.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hat</radical> crowns the <radical>king</radical>, because <kanji>all</kanji> kings must have one.
reading_mnemonic: But, as you're going through <kanji>all</kanji> the kings, it turns out not all of them have hats after all. The last one you come to is hatless. He's the king of <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん). He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby.

meaning_mnemonic:
There are some <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>knife</radical> in <kanji>front</kanji> of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.

This kanji means <kanji>before</kanji> too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all.
reading_mnemonic: You're going crazy with these things in <kanji>front</kanji> of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical> is a powerful thing. Even something as ordinary as a spoon can create great <kanji>change</kanji> in the world when given to the right person.
reading_mnemonic: Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, <kanji>changing</kanji> it into a <reading>car</reading> (か).

meaning_mnemonic: There's an <radical>ear</radical> just sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>. Nobody's watching, so, you <kanji>take</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: You're the kind of person who likes <vocabulary>to take</vocabulary> things. "What things?" you ask. Little <reading>toe</reading>s (と). Because that isn't creepy.

visually_similar_kanji: 同, 可, 何, 司, 伺, 洞, 阿, 河, 荷, 胴, 句, 旬, 詞, 飼, 銅
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> hits your <radical>mustache</radical>. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from <kanji>yonder</kanji>," you say, <kanji>facing</kanji> that way.
reading_mnemonic: Who shot this drop at you from <kanji>yonder</kanji>? You look over yonder, and see a figure. It is <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>king</radical> extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his <kanji>country</kanji>, give or take a few <radical>drop</radical>s.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out the king of this <kanji>country</kanji> loves drinking <reading>Coke</reading> (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast.

other_meanings: Ground, Land, Place, Area, Soil, Earth's Surface
meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>alligator</radical> lives in the <kanji>earth</kanji>, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary.

You can think of this word as <kanji>ground</kanji> too, because that's kind of what earth is made of.
reading_mnemonic: The only way to keep this dirt alligator from dragging you under the <kanji>earth</kanji> and eating you is to feed it <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). That way it won't lead you to a horrific death under the earth by dragging you under and spinning you around until you eat dirt (literally).

meaning_mnemonic: Who's that <radical>woman</radical> pretending to be a <radical>jet</radical>? That's my <kanji>younger sister</kanji>. *Sigh*
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>younger sister</kanji> is giving some <reading>mi</reading>ce (まい) a ride on her back like a jet.

meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>woman</radical> in this <radical>city</radical> is your <kanji>older sister</kanji>. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>older sister</kanji> may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet <reading>shee</reading>p (し) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet.

meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>roof</radical> over her head, a <radical>woman</radical> can <kanji>relax</kanji>. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super <kanji>cheap</kanji>, so she can even relax about her finances.
reading_mnemonic: As she <kanji>relax</kanji>es, she pulls out the <kanji>cheap</kanji>est, most relaxing food in the world: <reading>an</reading>chovies (あん).

meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>roof</radical> over the <radical>ground</radical> to make your own <radical>private</radical> patch of <radical>dirt</radical>. This is your <kanji>room</kanji>! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.
reading_mnemonic: The only problem with your <kanji>room</kanji> is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>house</radical> radical makes up the <kanji>house</kanji> kanji! Pretty easy. This kanji is also used to mean <kanji>home</kanji>, so try to remember that too.
reading_mnemonic: What do you do in your <kanji>house</kanji>? You <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>e</reading>ggs (いえ), that's what. You eat eggs three times a day, every day. You really love eating eggs in your <kanji>home</kanji>!

meaning_mnemonic: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s in the large <radical>river</radical> that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's <kanji>states</kanji> or <kanji>province</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: Each <kanji>state</kanji> has its own <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう) to represent it. The bottom of each shoe is the shape of the state, so when you step it leaves a state-shaped imprint in the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: A long time ago, someone put up a <radical>canopy</radical> over their <radical>fortune</radical> telling booth and created the first <kanji>shop</kanji>. This <kanji>store</kanji> was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>shop</kanji> quickly turned into <reading>ten</reading> (てん) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more.

kunyomi: うし, あと, のち
meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around to <radical>poop</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> you never know what could be happening <kanji>behind</kanji> you. <kanji>After</kanji> you're done you could turn <kanji>back</kanji> to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.
reading_mnemonic: You finally look <kanji>behind</kanji> you and see <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) and a giant <reading>こう</reading>いち having a violent battle <kanji>back</kanji> there!

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>rice paddy</radical> you find a <radical>heart</radical> and it makes you <kanji>think</kanji>. You think a lot of <kanji>thought</kanji>s like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"
reading_mnemonic: As you are <kanji>think</kanji>ing these <kanji>thought</kanji>s, you spot someone on the edge of the rice field. He really reminds you of someone. But who? That's it! He reminds you of that bartender on The Simpsons. What's his name? You think some more. What is it? <reading>Oh! Moe</reading> (おも) is his name!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> that gives <radical>life</radical> is our very own <kanji>star</kanji> (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.
reading_mnemonic: "All these life-giving <kanji>star</kanji>s need a protector," you say, pulling out your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). It's a big responsibility, but with your trusty saber in hand, you're sure you can defend our star system.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>mouth</radical>s, <radical>twenty</radical> of them, singing beautiful <kanji>music</kanji> together. The music seems to <kanji>bend</kanji> toward you through the air.
reading_mnemonic: The twenty mouths make so much <kanji>music</kanji> that they literally <reading>cloak you</reading> (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> and a <radical>moon</radical> is all you <kanji>have</kanji>. Imagine one of each under your arms.
reading_mnemonic: Everything you <kanji>have</kanji> (except the narwhal and the moon) were taken from you by a roving gang of <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう).

visually_similar_kanji: 車, 京, 乗, 束, 恵
meaning_mnemonic: This is the same as the radical for <radical>east</radical>, so it means <kanji>east</kanji> too.
reading_mnemonic: You see a man walk straight toward the sun rising in the <kanji>east</kanji>. It's so bright he can't see anything, so he trips and <reading>he gash</reading>es (ひがし) his knee on a rock. Yikes… But he gets back up, determined to head east, and, oh no, he gashes his other knee! OK, he should probably give up on going east.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stop</radical> at a <radical>small</radical> <radical>slide</radical>. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were <kanji>walk</kanji>ing.
reading_mnemonic: So, you're <kanji>walk</kanji>ing around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>yakuza</radical> hands you a <radical>spoon</radical>, <kanji>death</kanji> is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Death</kanji> comes in the form of a <reading>shee</reading>p (し). The death sheep works for the yakuza, and kills anyone who has their spoon.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> of <radical>tongue</radical>s is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... <kanji>lively</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>lively</kanji> feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the <reading>cats</reading> (かつ) in your neighborhood too!

visually_similar_kanji: 悔, 敏, 毎, 梅
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, so you point your <radical>gun</radical> out the <radical>window</radical> at it. "You better turn back, <kanji>sea</kanji>, or I'll shoot!"
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sea</kanji> decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fortune</radical> <radical>boil</radical>s down to a single <kanji>point</kanji> in time. One point in time determines how the rest of your future will go.
reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the <kanji>point</kanji>, you watch in awe as it moves to the <reading>ten</reading> (てん) spot in a long series of numbers.

meaning_mnemonic: You take an <radical>arrow</radical> to the <radical>mouth</radical> because you <kanji>know</kanji> too much. You know some very sensitive information, and someone's sent a bow-slinging enforcer to pin your big blabbermouth shut with arrows.
reading_mnemonic: One of the things you <kanji>know</kanji> too much about is the <reading>shee</reading>p (し) plan for world domination! Yes, you know that sheep are in fact plotting to overthrow humanity and take over the world.

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <radical>private</radical> <radical>grain</radical>s are meant to stay <kanji>private</kanji>! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you.

This kanji also means <kanji>I</kanji>. Why? Because what's more private than you? I mean, I! Basically, some things are only the business of you (I) and those things should be private.
reading_mnemonic: You're getting into the zone, thinking about yourself (<kanji>I</kanji>) and how much you love having things that are <kanji>private</kanji> and just yours, when you realize there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in this grain bag. And it's eating all of your (I's) private grains. No!

meaning_mnemonic: You scoop some <radical>grain</radical>s into a <radical>ladle</radical> to do <kanji>science</kanji>. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science <kanji>course</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Using your <kanji>science</kanji> skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). This is the science <kanji>department</kanji>'s special car now!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sheep</radical> radical and the <kanji>sheep</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning.
reading_mnemonic: To remember よう, we use the word "Yogurt." The <kanji>sheep</kanji> are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... because you stole their sheep's milk <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). Now you're running and crying and trying to eat the yogurt before the sheep catch up and stomp you down with their hooves.

meaning_mnemonic: If you can steal the <radical>flowers</radical> that adorn a <radical>hat</radical> worn by an <radical>angel</radical>, you can use them to make delicious <kanji>tea</kanji>. Naturally, angels decorate their hats with only the most aromatic and delicious flowers fit for brewing.
reading_mnemonic: After brewing the <kanji>tea</kanji>, you look at the hat again and find a nametag inside that says <reading>Cha</reading>d (ちゃ). You decide that from now on this tea variety will be known as Chad tea, in honor of Chad.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>blood</radical> radical and <kanji>blood</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup!

The radical is technically <radical>blood</radical>, but you know that radical is just a drop (of blood) on a plate. So, you ask yourself... Is that really blood on the plate? Could it be? You decide to take a gamble and lick it off. When you taste it, it's definitely not blood. No, it's <reading>ketsup</reading> (けつ).

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>long</radical> radical and the <kanji>long</kanji> kanji are the same! 

This kanji also means <kanji>leader</kanji>, because the longer a person is, the better a leader they'll be. Or maybe it was... the longer they've been somewhere? Whatever, longness = leaderness, you know?
reading_mnemonic: You see a very <kanji>long</kanji> person. It's Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the <kanji>leader</kanji> of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>eat</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>eat</kanji> are the same! Lucky you.
reading_mnemonic: Thank goodness, you finally get to <kanji>eat</kanji> your <kanji>meal</kanji>. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a <reading>shock</reading> (しょく) from somewhere.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>neck</radical> and the kanji <kanji>neck</kanji> are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: The only thing you do with your <kanji>neck</kanji> is use it to swallow lots of <reading>coo</reading>l <reading>bea</reading>ns (くび). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there.

meaning_mnemonic: When you take your <radical>leader</radical>'s <radical>measurement</radical>s, you realize they're too short, so you <kanji>attach</kanji> things to them to make the measurements more impressive. Attach some heels to the shoes, then attach another head on top of theirs. There — perfect measurements thanks to these attachments.
reading_mnemonic: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of how you would <kanji>attach</kanji> something to something else. What would you need? You'd need <reading>two</reading> (つ) things to put together!

other_meanings: Since, Compared With, With, By Means Of
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>lion</radical> drops a <radical>drop</radical> of saliva onto this <radical>person</radical> <kanji>from</kanji> above. The person is in a much worse place <kanji>compared with</kanji> where they were before, <kanji>since</kanji> they only just recently fell into this pit.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>From</kanji> above there is a loud caw, and a giant <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, <kanji>compared with</kanji> where he was before, is this really better?!

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen this as a radical before, and the kanji means the same thing — <kanji>south</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Think about the <kanji>south</kanji>. What's down there? <reading>Mean Amy</reading> (みなみ) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leaf</radical> shaped like an <radical>eye</radical> only grows in <radical>winter</radical>. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the <kanji>summer</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Now it's summertime! What do you do during the <kanji>summer</kanji>? You just sit around with your favorite string tying <reading>knots</reading> (なつ) in it over and over again.

visually_similar_kanji: 午, 牛, 矢, 去, 先, 生, 夫, 株, 朱
meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>slide</radical> is your <radical>husband</radical>'s only <kanji>fault</kanji>. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.
reading_mnemonic: You try to come up with another <kanji>fault</kanji> of his so you can complain, when you see a tiny <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing.

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>canopy</radical>, you use a <radical>tree</radical> for your <kanji>floor</kanji>. It also becomes your <kanji>bed</kanji>, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?
reading_mnemonic: It's great having a <kanji>floor</kanji> or <kanji>bed</kanji>, but whenever you use it you say <reading>yucka</reading> (ゆか) because it just gets so dirty. That's the one flaw of using a floor as a bed. In fact, it's the dirtiest floor you've ever seen, because it's covered in <reading>yucca</reading> (ゆか) leaves. You're sleeping on a yucca floor. Ew!

meaning_mnemonic: You have two <radical>bow</radical>s but they're both covered in <radical>ice</radical>. This has made them very <kanji>weak</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You give up on your trip and bring the <kanji>weak</kanji> bows back to your car, but it's stuck in the ice and snow. You decide to use the bows as a <reading>jack</reading> (じゃく) to try to get your car unstuck. Unfortunately, they're just too weak and they break in half.

meaning_mnemonic: You keep your <radical>bow</radical> <radical>private</radical> because it's made of <radical>insect</radical>s, meaning it's extremely <kanji>strong</kanji>. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for super strong bows. That's why you have to keep this one private — it's simply too strong to let others get ahold of.
reading_mnemonic: You had this <kanji>strong</kanji> bow made especially for you in <reading>きょう</reading>と. きょうと is famous for their strong bows, so if you ever want another, you know where to go.

meaning_mnemonic: Through the patient's <radical>heart</radical> runs a <radical>slide</radical>. It's a mad scientist's experiment to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive for now… but he's definitely slated for <kanji>certain</kanji> death.
reading_mnemonic: As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the scientist puts his hands together and <reading>hits</reading> (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>teacher</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> is happiest because they get to <kanji>teach</kanji>! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
reading_mnemonic: Teachers can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to <reading>きょう</reading>と. きょうと is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> in the <radical>center</radical> of the sky gives off its light, which <kanji>reflect</kanji>s off of everything around it.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>reflect</kanji>ed light is important for <reading>a</reading>corns (えい), in particular. Without light reflecting off everything, the sun's light would never make it down to the ground where they've fallen. They would never grow into trees. And we'd all suffocate.

visually_similar_kanji: 待, 持, 侍, 特, 詩, 寺
meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>sun</radical> is used in a <radical>temple</radical> to tell <kanji>time</kanji>. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."

This also can mean <kanji>o' clock</kanji>, as in "five o'clock" It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Time</kanji> in a temple makes you think of <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). Specifically, Jesus being able to perform time travel magic. He winks at you, goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth.

kunyomi: ま, いま, ひつじ
meaning_mnemonic: You're flying in a <radical>jet</radical>. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "<kanji>Not yet</kanji>! Not yet! NOT YET!"
reading_mnemonic: What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is "<reading>Me</reading> (み) me me me me me me me me me me." Hate kids like that.

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji uses a modified <radical>jet</radical> radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the <kanji>end</kanji> of the earth.
reading_mnemonic: When you get to the <kanji>end</kanji> of the world, you land your jet and put out a few <reading>mats</reading> (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>umbrella</radical>, which it's holding over its head. Strange, because trees normally like water… Turns out, this tree wasn't getting showered in water, but in dollar <kanji>bill</kanji>s instead.
reading_mnemonic: And the person who gave the tree an umbrella to protect it from all those <kanji>bills</kanji>? <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ), a little girl famous for… handing out umbrellas, I guess. Makes sense that Satsuki would take care of these bills then.

visually_similar_kanji: 交, 枚, 効, 絞, 較, 郊
meaning_mnemonic: Next to the <radical>tree</radical>, a <radical>lid</radical> is put on your <radical>father</radical>. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new <kanji>school</kanji>."
reading_mnemonic: Your new <kanji>school</kanji> has other students too. They are all <reading>こう</reading>いちs, though.

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. <radical>Lack</radical> becomes <kanji>Lack</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic:
To remember けつ, we use the word "ketsup." It's the perfect blend of ketchup and catsup!

You're <kanji>lack</kanji>ing something in your fridge. You look around, trying to find the <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ) you lack. You can't find it, because you lack it.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <kanji>family name</kanji>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <kanji>surname</kanji>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
reading_mnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your <kanji>family name</kanji> came from. Your family used to herd <reading>shee</reading>p (し). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>clan</radical> are a group of <kanji>people</kanji>. They are the <kanji>people</kanji> of a <kanji>nation</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The mouth clan <kanji>peoples</kanji> are a <kanji>nation</kanji> of <kanji>people</kanji> who use their mouths to say <reading>mean</reading> (みん) things to other peoples.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical>'s <radical>village</radical> is the <kanji>reason</kanji> he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.
reading_mnemonic: You can't have <kanji>reason</kanji> without <reading>re</reading> (り).

meaning_mnemonic: A giant <radical>cross</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> stands above you. "I am <kanji>reason</kanji>!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>reason</kanji> that this Cross of Reason exists is to combat the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) of the world, who just bring chaos into everything.

other_meanings: Drawing, Painting, Illustration, Sketch, Draw, Paint, Illustrate, Sketching, Illustrating, Picture
meaning_mnemonic: You go down a <radical>street</radical> that cuts through a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and leads to a <radical>box</radical>. When you open the box at the end of the street, you see it's full of <kanji>image</kanji>s. Image after image. <kanji>Drawing</kanji>, <kanji>painting</kanji>, you name it. Someone must have left this box of images here.
reading_mnemonic: Okay, I didn't want to tell you this, but the <kanji>image</kanji>s are all <kanji>drawing</kanji>s and <kanji>painting</kanji>s of <reading>ga</reading>rgoyles (が) and <reading>cock</reading>s (かく). Male chickens, that is. Turns out that's what you wanted to see most. Don't worry, no one is judging you.

visually_similar_kanji: 低, 底, 抵, 邸, 舐
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> that ties you to your <radical>clan</radical> is <kanji>paper</kanji>. Your papers, that is.
reading_mnemonic: You need this specific <kanji>paper</kanji> to prove that you aren't a <reading>Commi</reading> (かみ), aka a Communist. Or that you are. It really depends on where you want to go and what decade this is.

visually_similar_kanji: 相, 阻, 租, 粗, 祖, 狙
meaning_mnemonic: Sew <radical>thread</radical> through your <radical>top hat</radical> and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a <kanji>group</kanji> of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone in this <kanji>group</kanji> loves <reading>cumi</reading>n (くみ). You know, the spice or seed. The group take off their top hats and fill them with cumin. You're officially a group for lovers of cumin.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>boat</radical> has <radical>fins</radical> and a <radical>mouth</radical>! It's still a <kanji>boat</kanji> though.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>boat</kanji> belongs to the <reading>cen</reading>taurs (せん). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> to <radical>oneself</radical> (yourself), you decide to <kanji>write down</kanji>. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to <kanji>record</kanji> these important thoughts in some way.
reading_mnemonic: You need to protect what you <kanji>write down</kanji> and <kanji>record</kanji> for yourself with a <reading>key</reading> (き). These are your special thoughts and feelings, you don't want anyone else to see! Lock them away with a key!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>elephant</radical> radical and the <kanji>elephant</kanji> kanji are the same. But! This kanji has another meaning: <kanji>phenomenon</kanji>. If you were the first person to see an elephant, you'd call it that too.
reading_mnemonic:
<kanji>Elephant</kanji>s are great and all, except that when they die they turn into elephant <reading>zo</reading>mbies (ぞう). But you never see these zombies because the <reading>shou</reading>gun (しょう) has a special project in place that destroys all elephant bodies when they die.

Hint: The readings and meanings for this kanji match up really nicely. ぞう is always for elephant and しょう is always for phenomenon. Remember it like this, the elephant is the zombie and the shougun keeps everyone from finding out about this phenomenon.

meaning_mnemonic: While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you take your <radical>sword</radical> and cut out an <kanji>area</kanji> on the ground.  You carefully cut all the <kanji>side</kanji>s as you go. This area's all yours now!
reading_mnemonic: As you look down at your <kanji>area</kanji> with its sword-carved <kanji>side</kanji>s, you suddenly realize there is a <reading>hen</reading> (へん) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>scooter</radical> with your <radical>mama</radical> carrying a <radical>task</radical> she needs to get done. You see her <kanji>pass through</kanji>, hurrying by to get that task done.
reading_mnemonic: As you watch your mama <kanji>pass through</kanji> the house, she yells, "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS TASK <reading>TOO</reading> (つう)!" Too?! Oh no, now you have to do it too. Hurry up!

meaning_mnemonic: Use a <radical>scooter</radical> to travel the <radical>circumference</radical> of the world and it will take you a full <kanji>week</kanji>. Seven whole days!
reading_mnemonic: If you want to scoot for a <kanji>week</kanji>, you'll need <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). Good shoes too, not sandals or high heels or boots. Solid, high quality shoes, so you don't fall off the scooter and hurt yourself.

visually_similar_kanji: 雲, 電, 雰, 震, 露, 雷, 霧, 霜
meaning_mnemonic: When <radical>rain</radical> falls on <radical>Wolverine</radical>, it turns to <kanji>snow</kanji>. He's so emotionally distant and cold that the rain freezes into snow as soon as it gets near him.
reading_mnemonic: You're concerned for Wolverine's mental health. Him being so emotionally cold that he turns rain to <kanji>snow</kanji> means <reading>you kee</reading>p (ゆき) asking if he's okay. But that only makes him want to be more distant.

meaning_mnemonic:
You look at a <radical>table</radical> and notice it is being used as a <radical>slide</radical> by <radical>insect</radical>s to launch themselves into the <kanji>wind</kanji>.

This kanji can also mean <kanji>style</kanji>. To remember this, consider how styles can change quickly, just like the <kanji>wind</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: You wonder what's pushing these insects to jump into the <kanji>wind</kanji> in such a manner, and you realize that it's because they've had way too much <reading>foo</reading>d (ふう).

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and <radical>mustache</radical>, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how <kanji>tall</kanji> and <kanji>expensive</kanji> you are.
reading_mnemonic:
"I am <kanji>tall</kanji>er and more <kanji>expensive</kanji> than you." 

You're saying this because there are some <reading>こう</reading>いちs in the room, and you want to make them feel inferior (you're a こういち hater). You keep comparing your height to the こういちs in the room, and you keep checking price tags. Then you tell them you're taller and more expensive than they are.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>fish</radical> and the kanji <kanji>fish</kanji> are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: You catch a <kanji>fish</kanji>. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "<reading>GO</reading>!" (ぎょ). "GO GYO GYO GYO!" There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you.

visually_similar_kanji: 島, 烏, 篤, 馬
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bird</radical> radical and the <kanji>bird</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Think of a run-of-the-mill <kanji>bird</kanji>, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう).

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>yellow</radical> and the kanji <kanji>yellow</kanji> are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: You're in a room, surrounded completely by <kanji>yellow</kanji>. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow <reading>key</reading> (き) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>black</radical> and the kanji <kanji>black</kanji> are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: You're in a completely <kanji>black</kanji> room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's <reading>Coke</reading> (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke.

meaning_mnemonic: Just like the radical, the kanji means <kanji>capital</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading きょう we use the old <kanji>capital</kanji> of Japan, Kyoto, which is spelled <reading>きょう</reading>と. It was the capital of Japan before Tokyo!

visually_similar_kanji: 王, 主, 往, 注, 柱
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>master</radical>s gets to choose the place they <kanji>dwell</kanji>. So they <kanji>reside</kanji> in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings.
reading_mnemonic: She needs this big place to <kanji>dwell</kanji> so she has somewhere to store all of her <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう). Masters always have lots of fancy, expensive things, and she has jewels.

meaning_mnemonic: With <radical>top hat</radical> <radical>power</radical>, you're able to <kanji>help</kanji> anyone.
reading_mnemonic: The person you <kanji>help</kanji> with your top hat power? It's <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (じょ).

meaning_mnemonic: You're in a <radical>cage</radical> and you've been shot by an <radical>arrow</radical>. Obviously things are looking pretty bad. You need some <kanji>medicine</kanji> if you hope to live.
reading_mnemonic:
When we need to remember the sound い we use the word "Eagle."

You need your <kanji>medicine</kanji> really bad. Then, you look up. There's an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) flying overhead. He has a package. It's medicine! You're saved!

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>cliff</radical> there's a <radical>stool</radical>. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty <kanji>anti</kanji>-society, hiding away like that.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out, when you go to this guy and pull off his beard, its the <kanji>anti</kanji>-hero from Star Wars, <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo! What is Han doing here, so hidden away? He's obviously hiding from Jabba because he doesn't want to get frozen in carbonite again.

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Wolverine</radical> is going down a <radical>slide</radical> and from your <radical>mouth</radical> you scream, "Hey, <kanji>buddy</kanji>! Watch it with that slide, it's really fast and you might hurt yourself, buddy!" 

You're a really good buddy to Wolverine. He also happens to be the local ruler of these lands. You make it a habit to befriend the local strongmen, just in case… No wonder you're so buddy-buddy with all the rulers around here.
reading_mnemonic: As you're about to embrace your <kanji>buddy</kanji> Wolverine, a <reading>coon</reading>hound (くん) tackles him off the slide, and bites him in the process.

visually_similar_kanji: 陽, 湯, 揚, 腸
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dirt</radical> makes it <radical>easy</radical> to identify your <kanji>location</kanji>. Even if you add an extra line to mark the ground, it's still easy. Keep that in mind and you can go from <kanji>place</kanji> to place.
reading_mnemonic: Knowing your <kanji>location</kanji> from dirt is quite a feat! Who taught you that? It was <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the big local farmhand. Despite being a bit weird, he can identify any <kanji>place</kanji> just from its dirt!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Writing</radical> and <radical>measurement</radical> stand <kanji>versus</kanji> one another. Writing is all about feeling and expression. Measurement is about cold hard numbers. Yep, in this world writing people are basically the <kanji>opposite</kanji> of measurement people. Which side are you on?
reading_mnemonic: Whenever it's you <kanji>versus</kanji> someone else, you wear a <reading>tie</reading> (たい). Naturally, your tie is always the <kanji>opposite</kanji> color of your opponent's tie. Kinda like how political rivals wear different color ties when they debate. It's pretty silly, but at least your tie makes it clear that it's you versus them.

meaning_mnemonic: Your nation's <radical>flag</radical> sits on top of a <radical>cape</radical>d <radical>mouth</radical>. This is the symbol for the "<kanji>Bureau</kanji> of Secret Things." It's a special <kanji>department</kanji> of your government made to keep things hidden.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>bureau</kanji>'s best-kept secret is cloaking devices that <reading>cloak you</reading> (きょく) with the press of a button.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around with a <radical>weapon</radical> because you're currently doing your <kanji>service</kanji> and <kanji>duty</kanji> to your country. You're standing guard outside, waiting just in case something will happen.
reading_mnemonic: You're about halfway through your <kanji>service</kanji>, when a <reading>yak</reading> (やく) walks by. It stops directly in front of you and grunts. "Excuse me, Mr. Yak, but it's my <kanji>duty</kanji> to escort you away from my country."

meaning_mnemonic: You're tearing this <radical>door</radical> down with an <radical>axe</radical>. You're absolutely crazy. "I HATE THIS <kanji>PLACE</kanji>!!" you keep yelling as you smash in the door.
reading_mnemonic: You smash through the door and finally get inside the <kanji>place</kanji>, only to find some kind of <reading>sho</reading>w (しょ) going on. It's a circus show — elephants, tightrope walkers, bears on unicycles! The greatest show on earth, but why is it at this place?

visually_similar_kanji: 役, 技, 疫, 穀
meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>fingers</radical> is a <radical>weapon</radical>, so you <kanji>throw</kanji> it. Maybe you're angry and you threw the weapon at a person you don't like. Maybe you're a pacifist and you threw it away so no one else could use it. Either way, when you have a weapon in your fingers you have to throw it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>throw</kanji> your weapon away because you're about to enter <reading>とう</reading>きょう and there are no weapons allowed there. There is, however, a big pile of thrown away weapons by the border, which is where you're throwing yours right now.

visually_similar_kanji: 鼓, 伎, 枝, 技, 岐, 肢, 枚
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>branch</radical> radical and the <kanji>branch</kanji> kanji are the same! This kanji also means <kanji>support</kanji>. To remember it, think about a tree with lots of branches. The branches support each other and the trunk of the tree. If you were to climb the tree, the branches would be able to support your weight too!
reading_mnemonic: You're happily sitting on this <kanji>branch</kanji>, letting it <kanji>support</kanji> all this weight, when a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) starts to climb the tree. A very, very big sheep. Uh oh... no no, sheep. If you get on this branch it won't be able to support all this weight!!!

meaning_mnemonic: Give <radical>rice</radical> to a <radical>woman</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so she can <kanji>count</kanji> it. The woman will count each individual grain of rice, then tell you the <kanji>amount</kanji> or <kanji>number</kanji> of grains.
reading_mnemonic: Why do you have to <kanji>count</kanji> your rice out like this? It's because someone <reading>sue</reading>d (すう) your farm and took everything you owned. Since being sued, you only have a small <kanji>amount</kanji> of rice to last the winter.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the top of the <radical>sun</radical> and another <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the bottom. The <radical>moon</radical> is off to the right. That's because it's the <kanji>morning</kanji>, which is when the sun and moon switch over. Those crosses are making sure the sun stays high in the sky for the rest of the day.
reading_mnemonic: Every <kanji>morning</kanji> you have <reading>Asa</reading>hi (あさ) beer for breakfast.

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is just the <radical>tree</radical> radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means "<kanji>forest</kanji>."
reading_mnemonic: One tree? No. Two trees? Not enough. I want <reading>more</reading> (もり) trees, please!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>white</radical> <radical>ice</radical> <radical>tree</radical> is a magical tree that radiates an aura of <kanji>comfort</kanji>, <kanji>ease</kanji>, and <kanji>pleasure</kanji>, with its icy foliage tinkling like beautiful <kanji>music</kanji> whenever it sways in the breeze.
reading_mnemonic: You want more of this aura of <kanji>comfort</kanji>, so you chop down the magic tree and build a clothing <reading>rack</reading> (らく) out of it. Then, you put the rack in your house so you can enjoy that fuzzy feeling of comfort and ease every time you go to hang something up.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Ice</radical> is what you're <radical>lack</radical>ing, so the <kanji>next</kanji> thing you need to do is go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading じ, we used the word "Jesus" - Finally, when you're at the last store in existence, you decide it's time to pray to <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ), asking for a miracle. He comes down from the heavens with ice in his hands.

meaning_mnemonic: The poor <radical>alligator</radical> was taken far inland by a <radical>tsunami</radical>. Now his only source of water is a tiny <kanji>pond</kanji> that barely fits his body, and doesn't even provide much food.
reading_mnemonic: The worst part about this <kanji>pond</kanji> is that the only thing for the alligator to eat is <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). Cheese may be yummy for humans, but alligators hate it. They'd rather eat the cow the cheese came from. Sadly, this pond is full of cheese.

meaning_mnemonic: You have at your disposal a <radical>tsunami</radical> to assassinate this <radical>person</radical>, or a <radical>hook</radical>. Which method will you choose? <kanji>Decide</kanji> now!
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the けつ reading, we always use the word "ketsup." It's a special mix of ketchup and catsup (yum):

You finally <kanji>decide</kanji>. You're going to go with the tsunami... but not just any tsunami. You'll kill him with a tsunami of <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ).

other_meanings: Turn, Ordinal Number, Number In A Sequence
meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>sickle</radical> the <radical>rice paddy</radical> today because it's your <kanji>turn</kanji>. This kanji also means <kanji>number in a series</kanji>, which is a lot like a turn. For example, you're number 3, so your turn will be number 3.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>turn</kanji>-based rice sickle system is a contest as well! But, you are disappointed to find out that you have been <reading>ban</reading>ned (ばん) from the game because of the performance enhancing steroids you've been taking.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>stone</radical> <radical>lantern</radical> is an excellent way to <kanji>sharpen</kanji> anything, even in the dark. Your knives, your forks, your spoons, and even your sword.
reading_mnemonic: Why did you <kanji>sharpen</kanji> your blade? Because you are about to do battle with <reading>Ken</reading> (けん), the famous samurai warrior.

meaning_mnemonic: You dig a <radical>hole</radical> <radical>nine</radical> times for your <kanji>research</kanji>. You should always do research with nine variables so you can compare them, and so there's an uneven number.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>research</kanji> is on <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう)!

meaning_mnemonic: "Does the <radical>bamboo</radical> shirt <radical>suit</radical> me?" you ask... but nobody will <kanji>answer</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You pull out a <reading>quarter</reading> (こた) and offer it to whoever will give you an <kanji>answer</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: When a bunch of <radical>thread</radical>s are <radical>meet</radical>ing on paper (after you've dipped them in paint, say) they can create a masterpiece of a <kanji>picture</kanji> (or <kanji>painting</kanji>).
reading_mnemonic: You tell someone you painted this masterpiece of a <kanji>picture</kanji>. Their response? "<reading>EH</reading> (え)?!"

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>coffin</radical> has been left out in the <radical>sun</radical> for too long. When dead bodies are out in the sun like this, they really begin to decompose. You are wondering who this person is, though. You can't tell because it's fallen apart too much. You look on the coffin. There's a label, but it only says "<kanji>someone</kanji>."
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the sound しゃ we use "shaman."

It's time you open the coffin and check. Maybe there's more answers in there. There's no way this person could just be "<kanji>someone</kanji>." You lift the lid, and sure enough, you're able to figure out who it is. It's a <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ), dressed in full shaman garb.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Say</radical> it with your <radical>tongue</radical>. If you do, you'll be able to <kanji>talk</kanji>. You'll be able to <kanji>speak</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If something uses their tongue, it will be able to <kanji>talk</kanji> and <kanji>speak</kanji>. To prove this, you teach a <reading>wa</reading>lrus (わ) to use its tongue, and lo and behold, it speaks to you!

meaning_mnemonic: Here's a <radical>net</radical> full of of <radical>shellfish</radical> that you can <kanji>buy</kanji>. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>buy</kanji> as many shellfish as you can fit in your <reading>ca</reading>r (か). You keep buying until your car is completely full of shellfish before you stop. Cars are totally a realistic unit of measure.

meaning_mnemonic:
The self radical is a bit modified, with things sticking out, but that’s because it’s falling down a slide.

Sure, it’s your<radical>self</radical> who’s tumbling down the <radical>slide</radical>… at least that’s how it feels to you. Who are you? What are you? All you know is you’re <kanji>somebody</kanji>, but you don’t know who that somebody is.
reading_mnemonic: You’re falling down this metaphorical slide… And then you hit <kanji>somebody</kanji>… and you hit them really hard. On your metaphorical <reading>shin</reading> (しん). You split it in half and it’s at a right angle. The pain is incredible (shins have a lot of nerves!). It may have been broken, and you may not be able to walk correctly again… metaphorically speaking, that is.

meaning_mnemonic: Aim the <radical>scooter</radical>'s <radical>neck</radical> at the <kanji>road</kanji>! Scooters are only meant for driving on <kanji>street</kanji>s and <kanji>path</kanji>s, and if you go the wrong <kanji>way</kanji>, you'll probably break your own neck!
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading どう we use the word "doughnut."

You're traveling down this <kanji>road</kanji> so fast that you don't see the giant <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (どう) that's rolling toward you until the last minute. You crash into it, and both you and the doughnut go tumbling down. Ahg, your neck!

other_meanings: Interval of Time, Interval of Space, Time Interval, Space Interval, Space, Space Between
visually_similar_kanji: 閑, 閉, 閣, 聞, 問, 関, 開
meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>gate</radical> that the <radical>sun</radical> goes through at a regular <kanji>interval</kanji>. There is an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> in the sense that the sun goes through it at the same time every day. And there is an <kanji>interval of space</kanji> in the sense that it has to go through the space between the gate posts.
reading_mnemonic:
This method of keeping track of <kanji>interval</kanji>s of time was invented by the great Khans of Mongolia, specifically the most famous Khan of all: Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん).

Genghis Khan has had a huge impact on the world as we know it, especially the Eurasian continent of the past, so he's going to come up a lot from now on. Be prepared to get very familiar with him and his friends!

visually_similar_kanji: 雪, 電, 雰, 震, 露, 雷, 霧, 霜
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>rain</radical> <radical>cloud</radical> is still a <kanji>cloud</kanji>! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella.
reading_mnemonic: You lie down and try to figure out what the <kanji>cloud</kanji>s are shaped like. The first cloud is shaped... like a <reading>coo</reading>l <reading>mo</reading>m (くも). She's wearing high pants, and holding a kid on each hip, but she's also listening to the latest music and using slang. Huh. You look to the next cloud and see... wait, another cool mom?

visually_similar_kanji: 雪, 雲, 雰, 震, 露, 雷, 霧, 霜
meaning_mnemonic: You're in the <radical>rain</radical>, in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, holding an <radical>umbrella</radical>. You're here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by <kanji>electricity</kanji> (aka lightning), to prove that it exists.
reading_mnemonic: After the <kanji>electricity</kanji> hits you, you feel your face. In it is a huge <reading>den</reading>t (でん).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>horse</radical> radical and the <kanji>horse</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
reading_mnemonic: You are looking at a horse. It's looking at you. You try making horse noises at it, to get a reaction. Instead of reacting with a normal horse noise, it just makes sheep noises: "<reading>Baaa</reading>," (ば) it says. "Baaaaa."

meaning_mnemonic: You put a grain in your mouth and let it take a ride. This kanji has the same radicals as 和, but this time the grain is in your mouth, which is why there's little pieces of grain sticking out of the 口 part ;)
reading_mnemonic: You decide the grain is probably lonely on this <kanji>ride</kanji> alone, so you add some <reading>no</reading>ri (の) seaweed, so it has a friend.

meaning_mnemonic: What does your <radical>mama</radical> tell you to do in the <radical>street</radical>? Look before you cross! You gotta do it <kanji>beforehand</kanji>, or it could be too late.
reading_mnemonic: As you look <kanji>beforehand</kanji>, you see a <reading>yo-</reading>yo (よ) lying in the street.

other_meanings: Thing, Matter, Event, Incident, Circumstance, Situation
meaning_mnemonic: You find a <radical>cross</radical> in the <radical>mouth</radical> of <radical>Wolverine</radical>. What a strange <kanji>occurrence</kanji>. I guess he put it there, but why would he do such a <kanji>thing</kanji>? You ask him, but he says it's a personal <kanji>matter</kanji> of utmost secrecy.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>occurrence</kanji> doesn't impress <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ), who appears and gently removes the cross from Wolverine's mouth.

visually_similar_kanji: 反, 返, 坂, 飯, 阪, 販, 板, 版
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> is very <radical>anti</radical>-everything, making it all <kanji>temporary</kanji>. You get a new shirt, "I'm anti shirts!" she yells, and out it goes.
reading_mnemonic: The leader's most <kanji>temporary</kanji> possession is her <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Or... cars, because they're all very temporary. She buys one, drives it around, and then suddenly she's anti red car. She needs a blue one!

visually_similar_kanji: 史, 便, 更, 硬
meaning_mnemonic: A good <radical>leader</radical> can put the <radical>ground</radical>'s <radical>history</radical> to great <kanji>use</kanji>. You are a good leader. You have studied the ground and dirt of the earth your entire life. You know the history of the ground and you know how to use it to lead your people.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>use</kanji> the ground to raise <reading>shee</reading>p (し). When you were down there sniffing around you realized that your people will flourish best if you use this land for grazing and raising sheep.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>tree</radical> <radical>leader</radical> is all about trying to <kanji>preserve</kanji> the trees. In fact, she <kanji>guarantee</kanji>s that she will preserve the trees if it's the last thing she does.
reading_mnemonic: She chains herself to a tree to <kanji>preserve</kanji> them. But, unfortunately, the lumberjacks just take a giant back <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ) and tear this tree leader and the tree she's attached to in half.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>elephant</radical>s is so great, they put up an <kanji>image</kanji> or <kanji>statue</kanji> of him everywhere. Every house, every street corner — his image looks down on all the other elephants at all times.
reading_mnemonic: When they unveil the <kanji>image</kanji>s and <kanji>statue</kanji>s of the leader elephant, everyone gasps. They look like him, but he's a <reading>zo</reading>mbie (ぞう). Gasp!

visually_similar_kanji: 貝, 負, 真, 頁
meaning_mnemonic: There's an <radical>eye</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>, among some <radical>fins</radical>. What happened? You killed a fish, and now you you must hide the murder <kanji>tool</kanji>. Quick, hide the tool before someone finds out it was you.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>tool</kanji> is dripping with <reading>goo</reading> (ぐ). Goopy, incriminating goo. It's the guts of the fish you just killed and it's all over your hands too. Yuck.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> grants a <radical>gladiator</radical> its <radical>power</radical> so he will <kanji>win</kanji>! <kanji>Victory</kanji> will be his!
reading_mnemonic: He <kanji>win</kanji>s over and over again, and soon the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) is even rooting for him. In fact, the Shougun claims him as his personal gladiator of choice.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone throws a <radical>cleat</radical> at your <radical>forehead</radical> while you sit on a <radical>stool</radical>. You must <kanji>accept</kanji> this. Then another guy cleats you in the forehead, but you remain on the stool and <kanji>receive</kanji> it without complaint. This is some kind of acceptance ritual for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. If a cleat to the forehead doesn't knock you off the stool, you'll receive an offer to join.
reading_mnemonic: After they <kanji>accept</kanji> you, they give you a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (じゅ) box. It's to help you recover from the trauma of getting kicked. And you <kanji>receive</kanji> the juice with grace.

meaning_mnemonic: When everyone has <radical>grain</radical> in their <radical>mouth</radical>, you will have <kanji>peace</kanji>. That is the <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> of doing things.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Peace</kanji> is the <kanji>Japanese style</kanji>. The <reading>wa</reading>lruses (わ) living off of Japan see this, and start to emulate.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> has come bearing <radical>forehead</radical>s and <radical>legs</radical> that he's trying to <kanji>sell</kanji>. He thought it was a waste to leave all his slain enemies on the battlefield, so he gathered up their foreheads and legs to sell on the black market for some extra cash. Hey, no judging! A samurai's gotta sell what a samurai's gotta sell, okay?
reading_mnemonic: If you run into this samurai who <kanji>sell</kanji>s severed foreheads and legs, you should just say "<reading>bye</reading> (ばい)!" and get the heck out of there. Actually, if anyone tries to sell you severed body parts — samurai or not — you should probably say bye over and over until you can get away from them.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>roof</radical> is <radical>correct</radical> only if you <kanji>determine</kanji> that it is.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>determine</kanji>d it, but you still have to test this determination. You go to the top and roll a <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tot down the roof. Tater tots will only roll down a perfectly correct roof.

meaning_mnemonic: Climb onto the <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>spring</radical> to see the <kanji>truth</kanji>. The world is waking back up from winter and revealing the <kanji>reality</kanji> of what it is all around you.
reading_mnemonic: At the moment, you're trying to learn the <kanji>truth</kanji> about the deer that is coming out of the snowy woods when you see not one, but two baby deer appear with it! <reading>Gee! Two</reading> (じつ) babies! You keep looking around and realize that all of the animals seem to have two babies that they had hidden in the snow.

meaning_mnemonic: Under your <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> there are more <radical>mouth</radical>s to feed because you let <kanji>guest</kanji>s stay with you when it's cold. Some of them aren't family, so they have to pay to stay under your roof and get food. Those are <kanji>customer</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: One of your <kanji>guest</kanji>s is a regular named <reading>Kyaku</reading> (きゃく) the <kanji>customer</kanji>. Kyaku is always staying over at one place or another, so everyone knows their name.

meaning_mnemonic: You plant a <radical>flag</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical>, marking your <radical>private</radical> patch of <radical>dirt</radical>. In this spot you raise a <kanji>roof</kanji>, then fill the space beneath it with some <kanji>shop</kanji>s and <kanji>store</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>roof</kanji> covering the dirt is there so that the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や) can play baseball year round. The <kanji>store</kanji>s and <kanji>shop</kanji>s are there to sell hot dogs and Yankees memorabilia.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>yurt</radical>'s <radical>stool</radical> is always placed at certain <kanji>degree</kanji>s. The degrees change depending on specific <kanji>occurrence</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: Also angled at exact <kanji>degree</kanji>s is the <reading>do</reading>g (ど).

visually_similar_kanji: 待, 侍, 時, 特, 詩, 寺
meaning_mnemonic: You need to get your <radical>fingers</radical> around a <radical>temple</radical> if you want to <kanji>hold</kanji> it. Is the temple too big? Hold smaller temples you can buy in the temple's souvenir shop.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>hold</kanji> the temple you hear a voice. You look down through your fingers and see a tiny <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). He's smiling and gives you a thumbs up. Aww, thanks Jesus!

kunyomi: あたら, あら, にい
visually_similar_kanji: 規, 親, 視, 折, 祈, 析, 斬
meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>stand</radical>ing <radical>tree</radical> that you're taking an <radical>axe</radical> to. You're going to cut down this tree to let a <kanji>new</kanji> tree grow.
reading_mnemonic: You cut down the tree to make room for a <kanji>new</kanji> one, but it falls on your <reading>shin</reading> (しん).

meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>stamp</radical> on the <radical>stool</radical> in front of you and use it on all of your <kanji>clothes</kanji>. Now even if you sell or lose a piece of <kanji>clothing</kanji>, you'll be able to find it again by checking for your special moon stamp.
reading_mnemonic: A few days later you're with a friend when you recognize the <kanji>clothes</kanji> they're wearing. You grab it, rip it off, and scream, "<reading>F**k</reading> (ふく) you!" There is your moon stamp! These are your clothes!!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>compare</radical> radical and the <kanji>compare</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Compare</kanji> the <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) today with the heat yesterday. Is it hotter today? It's up to you to compare.

visually_similar_kanji: 水, 氷, 永, 詠
meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> is going to last an <radical>eternity</radical> you better learn how to <kanji>swim</kanji> now. We'll be under water for the rest of time and if you can't swim you're not gonna make it.
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Oy</reading> (およ)! Oy, stop daydreaming about <kanji>swim</kanji>ming and actually do it!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cow</radical> with <radical>wing</radical>s is flying in the air. What a strange <kanji>thing</kanji>! You've heard of flying pigs before, but cows? This is a new and strange thing indeed! Cows with wings! What a silly thing.
reading_mnemonic: You want a <kanji>thing</kanji> to help you fly with the cow so you put on your flying <reading>boots</reading> (ぶつ). Your flying boots are a pretty strange thing in themselves, but they're the only way you can keep up.

meaning_mnemonic: Every <radical>rice paddy</radical> sits <radical>jammed in</radical> to the <kanji>world</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: To get around this <kanji>world</kanji> of rice paddies, you need to use a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい).

meaning_mnemonic: Go to the <radical>tent</radical> and take the <radical>lantern</radical> from it, then we will be ready for <kanji>departure</kanji>. We can't leave the lantern inside of the tent; that's a fire hazard. We'd best take it with us before the departure. Don't you agree?
reading_mnemonic: Oh! Don't forget your <reading>hats</reading> (はつ) either. Wouldn’t want to start a <kanji>departure</kanji> without hats or a lantern. That'd be a short journey.

visually_similar_kanji: 阻, 租, 粗, 祖, 狙, 組
meaning_mnemonic: You need to look a <radical>tree</radical> in the <radical>eye</radical> to gain a <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.
reading_mnemonic: If your respect for the tree is <kanji>mutual</kanji> with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding."

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> of a <radical>lion</radical>, still <radical>small</radical> and curious, gazes upon the <kanji>prefecture</kanji> that will one day become his. He's a small lion, but once he grows up, everything reflected in his eye will be his prefecture to rule over.
reading_mnemonic: This small lion's <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is being protected by <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai, because the lion is too small to protect all of this land himself. Ken the samurai is used to wandering far and wide, so one prefecture is nothing to him.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> that's <radical>big</radical> is a true <kanji>beauty</kanji>. Big is <kanji>beautiful</kanji>, and that's all the more true for sheep.
reading_mnemonic: The big sheep's <kanji>beauty</kanji> has attracted a swarm of <reading>bee</reading>s (び). The sheep is so beautiful that the bees have mistaken it for a flower.

visually_similar_kanji: 古, 草, 岩, 若, 著
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> have grown <radical>old</radical>, so they're <kanji>suffering</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If a flower or a person is growing old and <kanji>suffering</kanji>, give them a <reading>coo</reading>kie (く).

visually_similar_kanji: 衣, 裏, 俵, 麦
meaning_mnemonic: Sometimes <radical>life</radical> gives you a <radical>kick</radical>, and you have to <kanji>express</kanji> yourself to deal with it! How do you express yourself? On the <kanji>surface</kanji> (of your face)!
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>express</kanji> yourself, so you call up a friend and say "<reading>Heyo</reading>!" (ひょう).

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>helicopter</radical> is piloted by a <radical>woman</radical>, it stirs an insatiable <kanji>need</kanji> in her. She doesn't know what it is. But she needs it. And that's why she's flying around looking for it!
reading_mnemonic: Finally she knows what she <kanji>need</kanji>s! It's <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう)! Delicious, creamy yogurt!

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> something at a <radical>ceremony</radical> for <radical>construction</radical> workers you're going to have to <kanji>try</kanji> really hard. Construction is loud, so if you want to be heard you have to <kanji>attempt</kanji> to be louder than the drilling and smashing and digging and handing out of awards.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>try</kanji> to get their attention the only way you know how, by lifting a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) above your head. The sheep baas and suddenly everything is silent, all eyes are on you. Well, they're on the sheep.

meaning_mnemonic: You  <radical>say</radical> things around a  <radical>fire</radical>. In fact there are two  <radical>fire</radical>s, and you're <kanji>talk</kanji>ing with a group of people, all sitting around two nice campfires.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>talk</kanji> in this intense, fiery way all the way until <reading>dawn</reading> (だん), but no longer! Once dawn comes the discussion needs to be concluded.

visually_similar_kanji: 貝, 魚, 具, 急, 頁
meaning_mnemonic: When you're in <radical>prison</radical>, whoever ends up with the <radical>shellfish</radical> will <kanji>lose</kanji>. It's the game all prisoners play. It's like keep away from the shellfish. And if you end up with the shellfish BZZZZTT that's it, you're the loser.
reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>lose</kanji>, you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). All you had to do was not hold the prison shellfish. It really shouldn't have been that hard to not lose, ya fool.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spicy</radical> radical and <kanji>spicy</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
reading_mnemonic: When you eat <kanji>spicy</kanji> food, it gives a <reading>から</reading>て chop to your mouth. That's where that spicy feeling comes from!

visually_similar_kanji: 版, 仮, 阪, 板, 坂, 飯, 販
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> is <radical>anti</radical> scoot. It doesn't want to run. So you have to <kanji>return</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>return</kanji> to the store and wait in line to return the scooter but the person working returns doesn't want you to return it. He stares you dead in the eyes, waves his hand, and turns you into a <reading>hen</reading> (へん)!

meaning_mnemonic: On its <radical>scooter</radical>, a creature with <radical>horns</radical> from <radical>heaven</radical> will take things you want to <kanji>send</kanji> there.
reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>send</kanji> your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) to heaven. I mean, you don't want it to go to some of those other places you've heard of, so why not send your soul?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>clown</radical> <radical>building</radical> is over in that <kanji>part</kanji> of town. We keep the clown part as separate as we can from the rest of the normal people. In fact, the entire clown education <kanji>department</kanji> and their clown <kanji>club</kanji>s have to stay in their part, they can't come in ours.
reading_mnemonic: You see, that <kanji>part</kanji> of town is full of <reading>boo</reading>ze (ぶ). Clowns need a lot of booze to keep their charade going, so we just let them have it. But they aren't allowed in our part anymore, because they all stink of nasty clown booze.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>heavy</radical> radical and the <kanji>heavy</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: In your hand is a very <kanji>heavy</kanji> <reading>jew</reading>el (じゅう). Real jewels are always heavier than they look.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> and a <radical>squid</radical> are going to <kanji>test</kanji> you.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>test</kanji> is being supervised by <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai.

meaning_mnemonic: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <radical>barb</radical>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <radical>barb</radical>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <kanji>finish</kanji>ed.
reading_mnemonic: How does the fish lure maker test his newly <kanji>finish</kanji>ed lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>fins</radical> in <radical>private</radical>. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them <kanji>public</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You head out into the <kanji>public</kanji> where everyone can see your fins, but... things have changed. All people are the same. There are thousands of <reading>こう</reading>いちs walking around, and they all stare at you (though they pretend like they aren't).

meaning_mnemonic: If you give a <radical>woman</radical> a <radical>machine</radical> she'll <kanji>begin</kanji> learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to <kanji>start</kanji> before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
reading_mnemonic: Actually, before she can <kanji>begin</kanji>, she has to shear the <reading>shee</reading>p (し) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe!

meaning_mnemonic: Let the <radical>sun</radical> shine into your <radical>ear</radical> while sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and make sure <kanji>most</kanji> of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone ever has.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Most</kanji> of this is for your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>spikes</radical> growing out of a <radical>sheep</radical> with <radical>fins</radical>. Turn this thing into a <kanji>business</kanji>! You could totally charge people money to look at it. Sure, you could also donate it to science, but a business-minded person like you knows a business opportunity when you see one. Step right up! Just five dollars for a glance at the rare spiky mer-sheep!
reading_mnemonic: As you evolve your <kanji>business</kanji>, you let customers feed the sheep <reading>gyo</reading>za (ぎょう) dumplings, its favorite snack. For a nominal fee, of course. People love it when the mutant sheep eats gyoza out of their hands. Wouldn't you?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> marked with a <radical>yellow</radical> X on the <kanji>side</kanji> of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm.
reading_mnemonic: Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is <reading>Yoko</reading> (よこ) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the <kanji>side</kanji> of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>lip ring</radical> (or two in this case) is what you <radical>lack</radical>, it's going to be way easier for you to <kanji>sing</kanji> a <kanji>song</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Where are you always singing <kanji>song</kanji>s, by the way? In your <reading>ca</reading>r (か). It's not just you, either. Pretty much everyone likes to sing in their car.

visually_similar_kanji: 球, 永, 氷, 水
meaning_mnemonic: Look at the <radical>ground</radical>! You spilled some <radical>water</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s, so I <kanji>request</kanji> that you wipe them up. I'd do it myself, but you're the one who spilled them, so I'm requesting that you do it. Pretty reasonable request, right?
reading_mnemonic: Oh, one more thing. I <kanji>request</kanji> that you wipe up the water with this <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう).

meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>tsunami</radical> hit ancient <radical>China</radical> and formed the <kanji>Chinese</kanji> country we know now as... <kanji>China</kanji>!

Sometimes this kanji also means <kanji>man</kanji>. In fact, it used to refer specifically to people of the Han dynasty, but over time evolved into a term for men in specific contexts.
reading_mnemonic: You peer closer at <kanji>China</kanji> and see one man, Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん), leading his troops into the vast country, ready to conquer all the Chinese people living in China!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sick</radical> stick of <radical>dynamite</radical> is going to be <kanji>sick</kanji> forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good.
reading_mnemonic: Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? <reading>B.O.</reading> (びょう). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being <kanji>sick</kanji> is no excuse.

visually_similar_kanji: 有, 県, 植, 置, 値, 殖
meaning_mnemonic:
This kanji is the same as the radical — <kanji>straight</kanji> as straight can be.

It can also mean <kanji>direct</kanji>, because when you go straight to a place, you're going there directly. Depending on the context it can even mean <kanji>fix</kanji>, since fixing something means straightening out all the messed up crooked bits.
reading_mnemonic: Put food <kanji>straight</kanji> into your esophagus without chewing and you will <reading>choke</reading> (ちょく). You want to get straight to the most important part of eating — the digesting part — but if you don't follow all the intermediate steps, you'll end up choking.

meaning_mnemonic: If someone sticks <radical>bamboo</radical> in your <radical>eye</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> times, the first thing your brain does is <kanji>calculate</kanji> how painful it is. Your brain's pain <kanji>calculation</kanji> will determine how you calculate your next move.
reading_mnemonic: Next you want to <kanji>calculate</kanji> how much punishment your bamboo attacker deserves, so you call on <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん). Santa-san is always calculating how many pieces of coal the naughty children deserve, so he's perfect for this <kanji>calculation</kanji> job.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and <radical>ice</radical> has brought this year to its <kanji>end</kanji>. Once you're in the long thread of winter and ice, you know the year will end soon.
reading_mnemonic: Whenever winter <kanji>end</kanji>s, you take the thread covered in ice, and lace it into your <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう).

visually_similar_kanji: 緑, 縁, 綿, 錦
meaning_mnemonic: You can use a long piece of <radical>thread</radical> during <radical>white</radical> <radical>water</radical> rafting as a safety <kanji>line</kanji>. Sure it's thin, but if someone goes overboard even a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard!
reading_mnemonic: The person who threw you that <kanji>line</kanji> of thread is actually a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off.

visually_similar_kanji: 翌, 陛, 階, 皆
meaning_mnemonic: You find some <radical>feathers</radical> that are so perfectly <radical>white</radical>, you want to <kanji>learn</kanji> more about where they came from and what they're made of.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>learn</kanji> that you should tie these white feathers to your <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building.

visually_similar_kanji: 閑, 閉, 閣, 間, 問, 関, 開
meaning_mnemonic: If you go up to a <radical>gate</radical> and press your <radical>ear</radical> to it, you'll <kanji>hear</kanji> what's going on on the other side. The people on the other side will have no idea you can hear their conversation.
reading_mnemonic: From the other side of the gate, you <kanji>hear</kanji> one of the people start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as "Hot Cross <reading>Bun</reading>s (ぶん)." You haven't heard this song since grade school. "Hot cross buns, hot cross buns~"

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> are knocked down by a violent <radical>tsunami</radical>, and swirl through the air to <radical>kiss</radical> your face gently as they <kanji>fall</kanji>. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew the flowers down. Amongst all the destruction, it's a pretty sight to watch them fall.
reading_mnemonic: You want to save these flowers that <kanji>fall</kanji> around you, so you take out a drying <reading>rack</reading> (らく) and place them carefully on it. Any flowers that fall will go on the rack like this, so can save them for later.
