meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> bring beauty to the <radical>world</radical> of <radical>trees</radical>, but the <kanji>leaf</kanji> is what matters the most. <kanji>Leaves</kanji> are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!
reading_mnemonic: Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The <kanji>leaf</kanji> pops out and it shouts, "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!"

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <radical>stand</radical>ing under a <radical>tree</radical> and you <radical>see</radical> your <kanji>parent</kanji>, it's a good chance for a moment of <kanji>intimacy</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Standing under the tree, you go to give your <kanji>parent</kanji> a big hug, but you manage to bang your <reading>shin</reading> (しん)  on a huge tree root. Your parent pulls you in for a warm hug and rubs your shin. Despite the pain, it becomes an unforgettable "shin-timate" moment.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Angle</radical> your <radical>sword</radical> correctly at this <radical>cow</radical> to <kanji>solve</kanji> its riddle. The key is to <kanji>untie</kanji> the cow with the sword without hurting it.
reading_mnemonic: Did I mention that you have to <kanji>solve</kanji> this whole riddle while on a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい)? No?! Whoops.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> between <radical>five</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s is a <kanji>language</kanji>. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language.
reading_mnemonic: Another mouth joins in speaking the <kanji>language</kanji>, but it's green and scaled and... it's <reading>Go</reading>dzilla's (ご) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too.

onyomi: とう, どく, とく
meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>say</radical> what you’re <radical>sell</radical>ing because people don’t like to <kanji>read</kanji>. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them.
reading_mnemonic: What are you forced to <kanji>read</kanji> aloud to sell? <reading>Yo-</reading>yo (よ) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something about the <radical>circumference</radical> of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to <kanji>investigate</kanji> something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet <kanji>tone</kanji> of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them.
reading_mnemonic: "I came here to <kanji>investigate</kanji> this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう)!"

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Run</radical> into <radical>oneself</radical> in a dream and you'll definitely <kanji>wake up</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If one runs into oneself and you don't <kanji>wake up</kanji>, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an <reading>o</reading>bi (お) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from.

meaning_mnemonic: If you've been walking all day, your <radical>foot</radical> is the last thing anyone would want to <radical>kiss</radical>, especially after wandering barefoot down a <kanji>road</kanji>. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet.
reading_mnemonic: What was this person walking down again? Oh, that's right – a <reading>ro</reading>ad (ろ). They were walking down a filthy road.

meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>car</radical> runs into a <radical>cloud</radical> you'll <kanji>revolve</kanji> around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway.
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>revolve</kanji> around the cloud <reading>ten</reading> (てん) times before it disappears and you're able to go through.

meaning_mnemonic: For a <radical>car</radical>, a <radical>tombstone</radical> is <kanji>lightweight</kanji>. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be <kanji>light</kanji> and easy to transport.
reading_mnemonic: What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right, a car. So you need some kind of <reading>car</reading> <reading>loo</reading>phole (かる). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but <kanji>lightweight</kanji> pebbles! But the rules say you can't use cars to carry tombstones, so you need to find a car loophole.

meaning_mnemonic: You blast your <radical>music</radical> loud so it causes a <radical>landslide</radical>, revealing the perfect soil for <kanji>farming</kanji>! Musically moved dirt is perfect for <kanji>agriculture</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The first person to come up with this <kanji>farming</kanji> method was <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth."

meaning_mnemonic: You jump on your <radical>scooter</radical> with a big <radical>bundle</radical> to go as <kanji>fast</kanji> as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there!
reading_mnemonic: You were going so <kanji>fast</kanji>, you only put on <reading>sock</reading>s (そく). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks.

visually_similar_kanji: 唯, 維, 離, 雑, 難, 稚, 雄, 誰, 推, 確, 権, 雅, 椎, 准
meaning_mnemonic: You give your <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>turkey</radical> so that it can <kanji>advance</kanji>. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance.
reading_mnemonic: You wave as the turkey <kanji>advance</kanji>s into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its <reading>shin</reading>s (しん) almost immediately. Ah!

meaning_mnemonic: While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you bang your <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>car</radical> in front. Your scooter's wrecked, so you have to <kanji>carry</kanji> it home. You'll need a lot of <kanji>luck</kanji> to get that scooter home safely.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>carry</kanji> the scooter, your <kanji>luck</kanji> turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your <reading>um</reading>brella (うん). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella.

visually_similar_kanji: 酌, 酸, 酔, 酎, 酢
meaning_mnemonic: You don't want to keep all the <radical>alcohol</radical> to yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), so you <kanji>distribute</kanji> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!
reading_mnemonic:
As you <kanji>distribute</kanji> the alcohol you say a <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい):

Here you go my friends
Alcohol for everyone
Never drink alone

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is an <radical>alcohol</radical>ic beverage containing a lot of <kanji>alcohol</kanji>. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it.
reading_mnemonic: As you lie on this beach, the <kanji>alcohol</kanji> keeps coming down a <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute.

meaning_mnemonic: You look at some <radical>gold</radical> and notice a <radical>fault</radical> in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless <kanji>iron</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Do you know that movie, <reading>Tetsu</reading>o (てつ) the <kanji>Iron</kanji> Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever.

visually_similar_kanji: 閑, 閉, 閣, 聞, 間, 問, 関
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>lantern</radical> is <kanji>open</kanji> for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>open</kanji> gate is in the water though, so you'll need a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> has a <radical>roof</radical> and will teach you about the <radical>origin</radical> of many things. It's an <kanji>institution</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: What does <kanji>institution</kanji> start with? In (いん)!

meaning_mnemonic: You chase a <radical>turkey</radical> up a <radical>tree</radical> to <kanji>collect</kanji> it. At least, you will once you've <kanji>gather</kanji>ed enough turkeys into this one tree.
reading_mnemonic: Once you've <kanji>collect</kanji>ed enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean <kanji>gather</kanji>ing even more turkeys!

kunyomi: ページ, ぺーじ, かしら
visually_similar_kanji: 百, 貝, 具, 負
meaning_mnemonic: Did you know that those strange <radical>geoduck</radical> creatures were once used to make <kanji>page</kanji>s? Okay maybe not, but it makes for a memorable image!
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>page</kanji> is a <reading>page</reading> (ページ).

visually_similar_kanji: 願, 頑, 頼, 預, 額, 領, 題, 顔
meaning_mnemonic: If you feed a lot of <radical>beans</radical> to a <radical>geoduck</radical>, its <kanji>head</kanji> will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, it can grow an incredibly large head. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads.
reading_mnemonic: As the geoduck eats more and more beans its <kanji>head</kanji> gets bigger and bigger, until finally the head explodes like an <reading>atomi</reading>c (あたま) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of its massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout.

visually_similar_kanji: 額, 頼, 題, 頭, 預, 領, 願, 頑
meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> on a <radical>cliff</radical>, a <radical>hair</radical>'s breadth away from the edge, when out of nowhere a <radical>geoduck</radical> slaps you in the <kanji>face</kanji>. The force makes you back away from the edge of the cliff, and your face is all slimy from the geoduck's residue.
reading_mnemonic: But where did that geoduck come from? As you turn from the cliff edge, you find yourself <kanji>face</kanji>-to-face with a <reading>cow</reading> (かお). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with a geoduck. You don't know why, but something about your face has upset the cow.

meaning_mnemonic: You can <radical>eat</radical> all you want, but you'll still <radical>lack</radical> something to <kanji>drink</kanji>. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too!
reading_mnemonic: You get desperate for a <kanji>drink</kanji> and put some <reading>no</reading>ri (の) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>bird</radical> opens, you're most likely to hear a <kanji>chirp</kanji>. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp!
reading_mnemonic: The best way to experience the <kanji>chirp</kanji>-chirping of birds is to offer them <reading>na</reading>chos (な). Birds love nachos so much, it's a guaranteed way to make them chirp with delight.

meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>prison</radical>, <radical>Wolverine</radical> gets picked on for the <radical>barb</radical>s coming out of his hands. This creates a lot of <kanji>conflict</kanji> between him and the other prisoners. They don't take kindly to mutants, and Wolverine doesn't take kindly to bigots — hence the conflict.
reading_mnemonic: This constant <kanji>conflict</kanji> between Wolverine and the other inmates is really affecting his <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Despite what people think, Wolverine really doesn't like to fight. He just hates injustice so much, he feels he has to do something about it.

meaning_mnemonic: If you know the radical meaning <radical>orders</radical> you know the kanji meaning <kanji>orders</kanji> as well!
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>orders</kanji> are to get a <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> who takes the <radical>middle</radical> of the road on every issue is likely to have an average <kanji>relationship</kanji> with everyone. He doesn't really take sides in matters, and just stays in the middle. This makes him seem like a wishy-washy people-pleaser, and as such he's only able to maintain average, mid-tier relationships.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine a flip-flopping politician you have an average <kanji>relationship</kanji> with. Now imagine that there's a <reading>knocker</reading> (なか) on their forehead and you get to knock that knocker as hard as you like. Maybe you can knock some integrity into them and form a better relationship.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>cloud</radical> that he uses to <kanji>transmit</kanji> all of the messages he needs to send to his people. The cloud floats above him and when he wants to tell people something he just whispers into the cloud and it transmits his message really, really loudly to all of them.
reading_mnemonic: As the leader <kanji>transmit</kanji>s his latest series of messages to you and the others, you notice a pretty large <reading>den</reading>t (でん) in it. That dent is probably a clue to what this cloud is really made of.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s at the highest <kanji>rank</kanji> in an organization. The leader is of the highest rank and stands above all others.
reading_mnemonic: This great leader is actually the leader of the boy scouts. And as we all know, the highest <kanji>rank</kanji> in boy scouts is the rank of <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) scout. This great leader has attained the rank of eagle scout and stands above all other scouts.

visually_similar_kanji: 邸, 抵, 底, 紙
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your <radical>clan</radical> wants to live close to the <radical>ground</radical> so he demands you get <kanji>low</kanji>. Low, low, with your belly to the ground. That way you're always below him, since he's the leader.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Low</kanji> people like you can only eat low food like potatoes. But that's boring, so you low people learned to make <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots. You roll them to each other and eat them without lifting your heads.

visually_similar_kanji: 史, 更, 硬, 使
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> stands upon the <radical>ground</radical> of the <radical>rice paddy</radical>. She is searching for <radical>treasure</radical>. It is said that this treasure here in this rice field will make things much easier for the leader (that's what leaders really want, after all). If she gets this treasure, it will be a great <kanji>convenience</kanji> for her, because convenience is everything when you're the leader.
reading_mnemonic: She finds a place to dig in the ground. It looks like there's some fresh dirt here. Finally, the treasure of <kanji>convenience</kanji> that will make this leader's life so much easier. She digs into the ground and pulls out a box. When she opens it, she finds out it's a <reading>ben</reading>to (べん). "My god," she thinks. "This really will make my life more convenient. My people can take their lunches with them now instead of coming back to base to eat, which will waste way less time!"

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> makes you lift <radical>heavy</radical> loads with all your <radical>power</radical>, since this is what you do for <kanji>work</kanji>. Why do you this kind of work? Well, you're good at it and the leader makes you do it, I guess.
reading_mnemonic: Where do you get the power to do all this <kanji>work</kanji>? From <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts (どう). You eat nothing but doughnuts. If you had no doughnuts, you couldn't work. In fact, your leader pays you for your work… in doughnuts.

meaning_mnemonic: The card game fish are best at is <radical>blackjack</radical> because they can easily hold the cards with their <radical>fins</radical> <kanji>together</kanji>. In blackjack you don't have to have a huge hand, full of cards. It's just a few, so fish fins can keep them together and just hit or stay.
reading_mnemonic: Once a year trillions of fish get <kanji>together</kanji> in <reading>きょう</reading>と to play blackjack. They have a huge tournament there once a year.

kunyomi: はじ, はつ, そ, ぞ
meaning_mnemonic: If you want a <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>sword</radical>, you have to be the <kanji>first</kanji> one to find it. Do you really think the first person to come across a spirit sword wouldn't want it?! No. So if you're any place but first, you're not getting anything.
reading_mnemonic: If you were lucky enough to be the <kanji>first</kanji> one to find the spirit sword, you should open up a small <reading>show</reading> (しょ) to show it off! And then you can make yourself the first in line every day to see the show.

meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>mouth</radical> you put a <radical>sword</radical> and a <radical>knife</radical>. Now that you have them in there, you have to make them <kanji>separate</kanji> from each other.
reading_mnemonic: Why are you trying to make a sword and knife <kanji>separate</kanji> in your mouth? Because someone <reading>bets</reading> (べつ) you can't do it.

meaning_mnemonic: Cut <radical>grain</radical>s with a <radical>knife</radical> to make them smaller and you'll make a great <kanji>profit</kanji>. By cutting them, now you can get three grains worth of money for what was once a single grain.
reading_mnemonic: To make an even better <kanji>profit</kanji>, you decide to cut up <reading>ree</reading>ds (り) too. You stuff the grains in the reeds and sell that as "self-cooking" sets.

meaning_mnemonic: Using your <radical>construction</radical> <radical>power</radical> you build something great. A true <kanji>achievement</kanji> built for the achievement of making kanji learning easier!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>achievement</kanji> was made possible by <reading>こう</reading>いち, so of course this construction project is a giant statue of the man himself. What an achievement of a statue. What an achievement of an achievement.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> sits on a <radical>stool</radical> to conserve her <radical>power</radical>, as her servants <kanji>toil</kanji> away in the kitchen. They toil away preparing a feast for this powerful woman while she kicks back on her cozy stool. She's a queen and deserves to be pampered.
reading_mnemonic: As a servant you <kanji>toil</kanji> not just for the woman, but also for her <reading>do</reading>g (ど). Anything she gets, the dog gets too. That means double the toil for you. But hey, at least the dog is cute.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> in a position of <radical>power</radical> does not need to <kanji>labor</kanji> in the fields. Labor is for the weak! A Viking of power takes what he wants, and need not labor for it. A powerful Viking plunders all and takes what he wants!
reading_mnemonic: It takes a lot of <kanji>labor</kanji> to harvest <reading>roe</reading> (ろう) so that’s what the Viking decides to take first! Roe is delicious, but it’s small and delicate. Vikings don’t labor for their own roe! They take it and eat it!

meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>mouth</radical> there is a <radical>jet</radical> dropping <kanji>flavor</kanji> bombs. Every time you <kanji>taste</kanji> something, it's actually because a tiny jet has flown into your mouth to bomb you with flavor.
reading_mnemonic: And what has more <kanji>flavor</kanji> than a big slab of <reading>me</reading>at (み)? You love meat and its flavor nearly as much as you love the <kanji>taste</kanji> of its juice. So many good things to put in your mouth!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Orders</radical> coming from your <radical>mouth</radical> will determine the <kanji>fate</kanji> of your soldiers. You are their commanding officer and your orders determine their <kanji>life</kanji> and death.
reading_mnemonic: You are the commanding officer on the <reading>May</reading>flower (めい). You give orders to colonize America. The orders spewing from your mouth hole determine the <kanji>fate</kanji> of the settlers and the fate of America and the fate of the world! You and the Mayflower have changed everything forever.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>woman</radical> and a <radical>child</radical> in front of you. You <kanji>like</kanji> them very much.
reading_mnemonic: "I <kanji>like</kanji> you two," you say to the woman and child. They both turn their heads 180 degrees back towards you. They both have faces that look just like <reading>こう</reading>いち's. "We like you too," they say in unison.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> on top of the <radical>cliff</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> from the <kanji>coast</kanji> below. Just from looking at the raging <kanji>shore</kanji> below, you'd think everything would be wet, it's splashing everywhere!
reading_mnemonic: Sitting up there, watching the <kanji>coast</kanji> with you, is <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (がん). The world famous Gandhi, is just hanging out up here with you, looking down at what you now realize must be a coast in India.

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>sound</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical> gives me an <kanji>idea</kanji>. The methodic thump thump thumping of a heart puts me in a trance that gives me great ideas. It’s a very inspirational sound, the sound of a heart is. It gives me an idea. 

Alternatively, you could look at this kanji and see a "stand" radical and something that kind of (almost) looks like the kanji for "think." When you stand up and think, you come up with your very own <kanji>idea</kanji>s!
reading_mnemonic: The heart of an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) is very strong. The person who knew this probably came up with the <kanji>idea</kanji> to make the bald eagle a symbol of the United States. Eagles are always flying around and doing things, so their hearts are very strong.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>drunkard</radical> holds a <radical>sword</radical> it <kanji>becomes</kanji> something else. The drunkard doesn't become a swordsman, they're still just a drunkard. But the sword in their hands does.
reading_mnemonic: The sword has <kanji>become</kanji> a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい)! It's just like the saber you have! Hey, wait.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>simple</radical> <radical>drunkard</radical> starting a <kanji>war</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The simple drunkard started a <kanji>war</kanji> with the <reading>cen</reading>taurs (せん)! This is especially unfortunate, because the centaurs are really good at <kanji>battle</kanji>s because they're all automatically cavalry troops.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> always seem to <radical>suit</radical> the random things you <kanji>pick up</kanji> off the ground. An old thimble. A discarded onion ring. A dead worm you tie in a knot. Your incredible fingers suit them beautifully, almost as if they were jewelry, so of course you pick up all of them.
reading_mnemonic: You're walking around looking for something to <kanji>pick up</kanji> when you see a sword in a rock. Yes, this will suit you. You pick up the sword and people jump out around you and tell you that you are the new <reading>hero</reading> (ひろ)! Uh oh. Maybe you shouldn't have picked this up.

meaning_mnemonic: Try to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to <radical>spoon</radical> out some of the <radical>sun</radical> and you'll come back with just one <kanji>finger</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Don't worry, you aren't the only one out there with just one <kanji>finger</kanji>, <reading>shee</reading>p (し) only have one finger too. I mean, they're hooves, which are really just a single animal finger. It's just big and kind of flat.

visually_similar_kanji: 改, 敗, 取, 族, 施, 妨, 訪, 坊, 旅, 旋, 紡, 防, 肪
meaning_mnemonic: As the year starts moving in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical>, the trees must <kanji>release</kanji> their leaves.
reading_mnemonic: The trees <kanji>release</kanji> all of their leaves onto your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). Slowly, you watch in horror as your home is consumed by the released leaves. They enter in through the windows, doors, and the chimney.

other_meanings: Long Time Ago, Old Time, Old Times
meaning_mnemonic: You've been playing <radical>blackjack</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical> since <kanji>long ago</kanji>. This is the longest game of blackjack you've ever played and it feels like ages since you started. You've been sitting out in the sun playing blackjack since long, long ago.
reading_mnemonic: Once you finally finish the game, you walk the long walk back home, in the sun, barefoot, on a dirt road that hasn't been maintained since <kanji>long ago</kanji>. Your feet are all sweaty from being out in the sun, and walking on this dirt road gives you <reading>muck ashi</reading> (むかし). Your ashi (feet) are all mucky and muddy from the combination of dirt and sweat. Your muck ashi are really gross, man.

visually_similar_kanji: 破, 彼, 被, 披, 疲, 皮
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>skin</radical> and creates smaller <kanji>wave</kanji>s. Those hit you too!
reading_mnemonic: When each <kanji>wave</kanji> hits your body, you shout, "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!" It's not like it's on purpose. When the wave crashes into you, the wind gets knocked right out of your mouth, making a HA sound.

visually_similar_kanji: 王, 主, 往, 住, 柱
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>master</radical> has the power to <kanji>pour</kanji> water wherever he pleases. Tsunami masters are masters over the most powerful water force in the universe, so it makes sense that they have the ability to pour water at will, wherever they please. Best not tick off the master, unless you want a tsunami poured on your head.
reading_mnemonic: If <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう) was trying to attack you, you’d be able to defend yourself easily. Simply <kanji>pour</kanji> a tsunami on him and Chewbacca would surrender in a heartbeat. Chewbacca doesn’t like having water poured on him, especially not all the water from a tsunami.

meaning_mnemonic:
This <radical>tsunami</radical> is ridden by a <radical>sheep</radical> in classic <kanji>Western style</kanji>. And by Western style I mean the sheep is dressed in a cowboy outfit and has put a saddle atop the tsunami wave to ride it. It's a tsunami rodeo and this crazy sheep is riding that tsunami wave in classic Western style.

This kanji also means <kanji>ocean</kanji>, because presumably the people from the West, with their Western style, came from across the ocean. You'll want to be familiar with both meanings for vocab later on.
reading_mnemonic: After a whole day of riding this tsunami, the sheep is hankerin' for some <kanji>Western-style</kanji> food, namely <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). Yogurt is Western-style food, right? If it helps you can imagine the yogurt is flavored like apple pie, to make it more American and Western.

visually_similar_kanji: 物, 待, 持, 詩, 時, 寺, 侍
meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>cow</radical> <radical>temple</radical> is <kanji>special</kanji>. This cow must have been very important to have an entire temple dedicated to it.
reading_mnemonic: This cow is <kanji>special</kanji> because it belonged to <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu, the first shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate and uniter of Japan! He's a super important figure in Japanese history. You should absolutely look him up and read a bit about him (when you're caught up on these lessons, that is).

visually_similar_kanji: 禅, 紳, 伸, 押, 袖
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>spirit</radical> should feel <radical>humble</radical> before a <kanji>god</kanji>'s <kanji>spirit</kanji>. You never really feel humble in front of anyone else, but if you meet a god's spirit… Well, you should probably lower yourself appropriately. Gods have powerful spirits.
reading_mnemonic: When you meet a <kanji>god</kanji>'s <kanji>spirit</kanji>, you need to get down on your <reading>shin</reading>s (しん). Get down on your ankles? No, not low enough. Knees? No, no, get your shins flat on the ground to show how humble you really are. Luckily, you're wearing <reading>jean</reading>s (じん), so at least that will stop your poor shins getting chafed!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Grain</radical>s are <radical>few</radical>. Imagine the last few grains trickling down the hourglass. You only have a <kanji>second</kanji> left.
reading_mnemonic: After the final <kanji>second</kanji>s go by, your awful <reading>B.O.</reading> (びょう) appears.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Stand</radical> on your <radical>older brother</radical>. Now <radical>stand</radical> on your <radical>older brother</radical> again. You wish to stand on, and above, your older brother. You <kanji>compete</kanji> over and over again, to stand atop your older brother.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>compete</kanji> with your older brother because only one of you may go to <reading>きょう</reading>と. Whoever stands on top the most gets to go to きょうと, so you must compete for a spot.

meaning_mnemonic: There are pieces of <radical>thread</radical> on each <radical>escalator</radical> showing you what <kanji>level</kanji> they go to in your school. Each escalator takes you to a different <kanji>grade</kanji>, so make sure you follow the right thread or you'll end up in a class that's either way above or way below your level.
reading_mnemonic: You want to see what the highest <kanji>level</kanji> is, so you go up the wrong escalator. At the top you find a giant <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう).

meaning_mnemonic: By the time you finish digging a <radical>coffin</radical> hole with nothing but a <radical>spoon</radical>, you’ll be an old <kanji>elderly</kanji> person. Digging with nothing but a spoon takes a long time, especially when the hole needs to be big enough for a coffin. You might as well be digging it for yourself at this rate. By the time you finish, you’ll be all wrinkled and elderly and just about ready to keel over.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you’re <kanji>elderly</kanji> (and probably about to die) you suddenly crave some delicious <reading>roe</reading> (ろう). Salmon roe, sea urchin roe, tofugu roe, doesn’t matter. Your old, tired bones need roe after all that hard work!

meaning_mnemonic: Give <radical>trash</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> and it will <kanji>nurture</kanji> and <kanji>raise</kanji> that trash like it's its own little moon baby.
reading_mnemonic: The moon <kanji>nurture</kanji>s the trash ball until one day, it speaks! "<reading>行く</reading> (いく), 行く！" it says. It wants to go live with mom moon!

visually_similar_kanji: 食, 根, 限, 退, 眠, 郎, 眼, 恨
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> of water to a <radical>root</radical> is <kanji>good</kanji>. It's good for the roots to grow and live and thrive. And what's good for roots is good for our plants and us humans too.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>good</kanji> way to get a lot of drops of water for your roots is to buy a <reading>row</reading> boat (りょう). Then just row out to the middle of the lake and plonk all the roots right into the source!

visually_similar_kanji: 唯, 維, 離, 雑, 難, 稚, 雄, 進, 推, 確, 権, 准, 椎, 雅
meaning_mnemonic: Who will <radical>say</radical> <radical>turkey</radical>? Who? <kanji>WHO</kanji>???
reading_mnemonic: Then, someone says turkey. "<kanji>Who</kanji> said turkey? You? How <reading>dare</reading> (だれ) you."

meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>scooter</radical> there is a <radical>bear</radical> with a <radical>drop</radical> on its head trying to <kanji>follow</kanji> and <kanji>chase</kanji> you! You accidentally splashed it with water and it's not happy about it. You're on your own scooter, luckily, but that doesn't make this any less terrifying.
reading_mnemonic: The bear is trying to <kanji>follow</kanji> you because it wants your <reading>o</reading>bi (お) as compensation for its injured pride. The obi is waving in the wind behind your scooter, and the bear is reaching out with its teeth to try and grab it.

meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>leader</radical> who hires his own personal <radical>clown</radical> will likely <kanji>double</kanji> his entertainment. Clowns are funny and make people laugh, so the leader decided to hire one. Since that time, the leader's amount of mirth has doubled. 

This also means <kanji>times</kanji>, which makes sense when you think about the kind of math you'll need to double something. What is A * 2? It's A doubled, first of all, but you're using multiplication. You're "timesing" something.
reading_mnemonic: When the clown stops being funny, it's time to say <reading>bye</reading> (ばい). At first, the clown <kanji>double</kanji>d the leader's entertainment, but now the clown is just annoying. It's time to say bye-bye.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>business</radical>? Ha! That's <kanji>me</kanji>! That's <kanji>I</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: You use the word <kanji>I</kanji> a lot. You say it so much, you just start referring to yourself with the french <reading>beaucoup</reading> (ぼく) for a lot. Because you love yourself a lot.

meaning_mnemonic: You'll have to <radical>excuse</radical> me, having all this <radical>power</radical> puts a lot of strain and <kanji>exertion</kanji> on my body. My power comes from exertion of muscle, so please excuse me if I start to perspire.
reading_mnemonic: Excuse me, I don’t think I’ve introduced myself yet. My name is <reading>Ben</reading> (べん) and I use powerful muscle <kanji>exertion</kanji> to accomplish every task. Ben knows what Ben wants and how to get it. Remember that, kids.

meaning_mnemonic: When something is <radical>heavy</radical>, you need a lot of <radical>power</radical> to <kanji>move</kanji> it. It’s not going to move unless you use a lot of power. That thing is heavy and unless you use all the power you got, it’s not moving.
reading_mnemonic: Remember that 1 ton weight? Well, actually it’s a <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (どう). A huge, massive, 1 ton doughnut. It’s super heavy and hard to move, but it’s delicious.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>suit</radical> and the kanji <kanji>suit</kanji> are exactly the same! This kanji can also mean <kanji>join</kanji> which makes sense. When something suits you well, like a hat or something, it joins together with you quite well too. Join me, my hat! You suit my head well. It just <kanji>fit</kanji>s, you know?
reading_mnemonic:
You need someone who will <kanji>suit</kanji> you. Someone who can <kanji>join</kanji> you on your life journey. So you call Grandpa <reading>ごう</reading>いち.

Note: For the ごう reading mnemonics, we use Grandpa ごういち because こういち is used for the こう reading. So just remember that ごう comes from Koichi's grandpa ごういち.

meaning_mnemonic: Even a <radical>mouth</radical>-bearing <radical>shellfish</radical> is a <kanji>member</kanji> of the invertebrate family. Yes, shellfish do have mouths, look it up!
reading_mnemonic: If you were a <kanji>member</kanji> of the same shellfish family, you'd be able to go to the special shellfish <reading>inn</reading> (いん). Every species has a members-only inn.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>stand</radical>ing <radical>mustache</radical> with <radical>legs</radical> is able to sell <kanji>merchandise</kanji>. Most mustaches can’t stand because they don’t have legs. This mustache, however, does. It also has a keen business sense, which is why it’s selling merchandise.
reading_mnemonic: The mustache is selling his <kanji>merchandise</kanji> so well that even the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) notices. He leans down really close to the standing mustache man's merchandise and stays very still. Then he snaps his fingers and his servants come rushing out to buy it all!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical>, even though it's almost <radical>spring</radical>, is still covered in <radical>ice</radical> so it's <kanji>cold</kanji>. Inside the house is cold, outside the house is cold. Everything is cold!
reading_mnemonic: You can't stand the <kanji>cold</kanji> anymore, so you hire a <reading>samu</reading>rai (さむ) to come try to hack the ice off of your roof with his sword. You stand outside shivering, and watching as the samurai tries to stab the ice off of your roof.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bird</radical> sits upon a <radical>mountain</radical>. If you look at the radicals, the bird is quite large and the mountain quite small. Think of this in the mnemonic as well. The reason the mountain is small is because you can only see the top of it, sticking out of the water. On it is the bird. This small mountain with the bird on it is an <kanji>island</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: But this <kanji>island</kanji> doesn't only belong to the bird. In fact, the bird shouldn't be on this island, because it belongs to the <reading>She</reading>ep <reading>Ma</reading>ma (しま), who is like Mother Nature but for sheep. The all-powerful Sheep Mama comes to kick the bird off the island, because this place is only for sheep! All hail the Sheep Mama.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>canopy</radical> and a man called the <radical>Yoga</radical> <radical>King</radical> standing in the middle of your <kanji>garden</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Not only is this Yoga King taking over your <kanji>garden</kanji>, but he's ordering you to serve food to his class. "You there, peasant, fetch these people your freshest <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots from this puny garden to give them strength."

visually_similar_kanji: 破, 被, 披, 疲, 波, 皮
meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around my <radical>skin</radical>, <kanji>he</kanji> will get angry at you. He's my very protective friend, and you don't wanna make him angry!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>He</kanji> may get grumpy if you loiter around my skin, but a well-made <reading>curry</reading> (かれ) always brightens his mood. So give him some curry.

visually_similar_kanji: 時, 持, 特, 詩, 寺, 得, 侍
meaning_mnemonic: People who <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>temple</radical> are probably just trying to <kanji>wait</kanji>. They don't mean to look like they're up to no good, but it's hard to wait without looking suspicious when you're waiting outside a temple.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>wait</kanji> outside the temple, you can't help but adjust your <reading>tie</reading> (たい). When you wait you get nervous, and when you get nervous you fidget. So now you're messing with your tie a whole bunch.

visually_similar_kanji: 思, 意, 億, 急
meaning_mnemonic: Imagining one’s <radical>self</radical> without a <radical>heart</radical> can make it hard to draw <kanji>breath</kanji>. Without a heart, you’d have no blood pumping and you would start to die. This would make it increasingly harder to draw breath and get oxygen to stay alive.
reading_mnemonic: You know how when people are unconscious and their <kanji>breath</kanji> slows or comes to a stop, they use smelling salts to revive them? Well a smelly <reading>sock</reading> (そく) can work just as well. Socks get really stinky and their stench is powerful enough to revive someone who isn’t drawing breath.

meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>Asia</radical> they assume everyone's <radical>heart</radical> is automatically <kanji>bad</kanji> and <kanji>evil</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Luckily, people in Asia know how to get the <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>bad</kanji>ness out of your heart with <reading>acu</reading>puncture (あく).

visually_similar_kanji: 族, 施, 妨, 訪, 坊, 旋, 紡, 放, 防, 肪
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>direction</radical> your <radical>gun</radical> is facing leads straight to a block of <radical>tofu</radical>. This might be a sign you need to take a <kanji>trip</kanji>. If you're out there pointing guns at tofu, you're probably a little… tired… and in need of a change of scenery. Take a trip!
reading_mnemonic: So, where do you go on your <kanji>trip</kanji>? To <reading>Rio</reading> (りょ). You had to go way down south to get as far away as possible from tofu. Ahh, nothing like a nice trip to Rio!

visually_similar_kanji: 施, 旅, 妨, 訪, 坊, 旋, 紡, 放, 防, 肪
meaning_mnemonic: If someone is headed in your <radical>direction</radical> with a <radical>gun</radical>, nock an <radical>arrow</radical> in your bow and gather your <kanji>tribe</kanji> behind you because it’s about to get real! This man with a gun is headed your direction and he doesn’t even know what you and your tribe are gonna do to him. If he gets any closer, you’re likely to shoot that arrow right at him.
reading_mnemonic: When he starts to get closer, you notice that this guy is a boso<reading>zoku</reading> (ぞく) bike gang member. Bosozoku means “running <kanji>tribe</kanji>” and this guy is running right at you. With a gun. So gather your own tribe behind you and prepare to defend yourself against this bosozoku member.

meaning_mnemonic:
If the <radical>sun</radical> is on <radical>someone</radical>, they will get <kanji>hot</kanji>. That's just how it is. Someone standing out in the sun for a long time will inevitably get hot. The sun is hot, and it makes you get hot too.

Note that this usually refers to hot weather or the heat of an area you're in and doesn't refer to a hot "thing."
reading_mnemonic: One sun was <kanji>hot</kanji> enough, but then a second one shows up. "<reading>Ah, two</reading> (あつ)!" you scream. If you were sweaty and sticky from the heat of just one sun, imagine what this second one is going to do to you. Ah, two hot suns!

meaning_mnemonic: A "<radical>crab</radical> <radical>moon</radical>" is a specific <kanji>period of time</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: When the crab moon <kanji>period of time</kanji> is upon us, we must take a special <reading>key</reading> (き) and lock everything in such a way that crabs cannot get in.

visually_similar_kanji: 良, 恨, 眼, 退, 郎, 限, 眠
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> <radical>root</radical> is still just a <kanji>root</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Tree <kanji>root</kanji>s are the perfect roosting place for <reading>con</reading>dors (こん). Unfortunately, living on roots is also why they're always endangered. Condors can be killed pretty easily living on the ground on roots like this.

visually_similar_kanji: 直, 置, 殖, 値
meaning_mnemonic: If you want a <radical>tree</radical> to grow <radical>straight</radical>, you have to <kanji>plant</kanji> it properly. Everyone knows that poorly planted trees grow all crooked and twisted. That's just how plants work. If your tree's not straight, start over and plant it again.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>plant</kanji> and re-plant your tree over and over, utterly <reading>shock</reading>ed (しょく) at how hard it is to plant it right. You thought planting trees was easy, so this is a real shock to you.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Stop</radical>! That <radical>box</radical> of <radical>rice</radical> is actually full of <kanji>teeth</kanji>! I know it says "rice" on the cover, but I promise you those are all teeth and if you bite into them you'll break a <kanji>tooth</kanji> of your own.
reading_mnemonic: Why do I have a rice box full of <kanji>teeth</kanji>? <reading>Ha</reading> (は)! Wouldn't you like to know. Ha! I definitely have an answer that isn't weird or creepy. Ha... ha ha...

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>White</radical> <radical>water</radical> shoots out from a <kanji>spring</kanji> in the ground. Due to the force the water shoots from the spring, the water looks white with all the air bubbles.
reading_mnemonic: From the <kanji>spring</kanji>, a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) emerges.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> lifts all the <radical>trash</radical> out of the <radical>river</radical> and it <kanji>stream</kanji>s out onto the shores.
reading_mnemonic: Next to the trash <kanji>stream</kanji> you suddenly see <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter and he looks pissed. He's furious that so many people throw their trash in the river and it causes streams like this.

meaning_mnemonic: A long time ago a huge <radical>tsunami</radical> swept a <radical>triceratops</radical> up into the <radical>moon</radical> and <kanji>extinguish</kanji>ed its life.
reading_mnemonic: This famous event where almost all life was <kanji>extinguish</kanji>ed is reenacted every year for the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). He's got a bit of an unhealthy obsession with extinguishing life...

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> is higher than your <radical>forehead</radical> you better move those <radical>legs</radical> and find a <radical>tree</radical> to climb, because that thing is <kanji>deep</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: You wait until the tsunami is only as <kanji>deep</kanji> as your <reading>shin</reading> (しん). Then you climb down the tree and wade home in the shin-deep water.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>tsunami</radical> which washes a <radical>plate</radical> out into the <radical>sun</radical>. Because it's in the sun, it becomes  <kanji>warm</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The plate starts to get so <kanji>warm</kanji> that you could fry an <reading>on</reading>ion (おん) on it. Who doesn’t love fried onions? That plate sure is warm enough, so start cookin’ ‘em!

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming and you want to be <radical>together</radical> with it by <radical>yourself</radical> (oneself) so you go to the <kanji>harbor</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As you look around at the <kanji>harbor</kanji> in your last moments you suddenly see someone in the water. It's <reading>こう</reading>いち! He's sitting in an inner tube in the harbor waiting for the tsunami too.

visually_similar_kanji: 場, 陽, 揚, 腸
meaning_mnemonic: If there's a <radical>tsunami</radical> it's <radical>easy</radical> to get <kanji>hot water</kanji>. Just stick your hand out the window as the tsunami goes by and poof! That water's HOT.
reading_mnemonic: As the <kanji>hot water</kanji> comes, you just lift up the bottom of the <reading>yu</reading>rt (ゆ) you live in, and it comes flowing in. All of the cups, pots, and barrels you laid on your floor are now full of hot water.

visually_similar_kanji: 永, 氷, 水, 求
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> <radical>request</radical>s a <kanji>sphere</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sphere</kanji> is a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう) sphere. A strange sphere shaped cucumber.

other_meanings: Exhausted, Fatigue, Exhaustion, Weariness, Weary, Fatigued
visually_similar_kanji: 皮, 病, 波, 被, 破, 彼, 披
meaning_mnemonic: I have <radical>sick</radical> in my <radical>skin</radical>. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably <kanji>tired</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>tent</radical> of <radical>beans</radical>. You try to <kanji>climb</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>climb</kanji> the bean tent, and from this vantage point you can see <reading>とう</reading>きょう in the distance.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>sheep</radical> right before your <radical>eye</radical>s, because they just love what you <kanji>wear</kanji>. It's a little known fact that sheep are fashionistas, and they <kanji>arrive</kanji> daily to admire your style. These sheep are so stylish they wear their tail to one side - in the latest fashion (check out the sheep radical - the tail is sweeping stylishly to the left!).
reading_mnemonic: More sheep <kanji>arrive</kanji> every day to admire the clothes you're <kanji>wear</kanji>ing. You use a <reading>chalk</reading> (ちゃく) board to keep count of how many sheep come by each day.

meaning_mnemonic: If you use an <radical>arrow</radical> to shoot a stalk of <radical>beans</radical>, the bean plant will end up <kanji>short</kanji>. When the beans are hit with that arrow, it severs the plant in two, and you are left with a stalk of beans that is much shorter than before.
reading_mnemonic: All this shooting of arrows to make the bean plants <kanji>short</kanji> is taking a long time. Since you're out in the sun, you're starting to get a <reading>tan</reading> (たん). After the day is finally over, your tan is really, really dark.

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>moon</radical>, there’s a <radical>stool</radical> with a <radical>jackhammer</radical> on it. It’s all there for the <kanji>festival</kanji>. Festivals need activities, and at this festival, you can stand on a stool in the moonlight and use a jackhammer to make a lot of noise. Perfect for a festival!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>festival</kanji> is for <reading>cy</reading>borgs (さい) only. Picture the cyborg you made getting excited that you're taking it to the festival. That's why all of the activities have to do with heavy machinery. The rides are mostly just cyborgs letting other people ride them, but it's still pretty fun.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> at a podium <radical>early</radical> in the morning to practice reading the <kanji>chapter</kanji> from your latest book.
reading_mnemonic: You're practicing this specific <kanji>chapter</kanji> because you've been asked to read it for the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). There will be a bunch of other authors reading chapters of their books to him too, and you want to make a good impression.

visually_similar_kanji: 重, 章, 瞳, 憧
meaning_mnemonic: Those who <radical>stand</radical> on top of a <radical>village</radical> are <kanji>juvenile</kanji>. Imagine a bunch of young people standing on the roofs of buildings in the village. That's a juvenile thing to do.
reading_mnemonic: Mostly, though, the  <kanji>juvenile</kanji>s are standing on top of village buildings, eating <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts (どう).

visually_similar_kanji: 弟, 沸, 弓, 弔
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Bamboo</radical>'s <radical>younger brother</radical> is counted with an <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji>. An ordinal number is one that represents a position or rank in sequential order (like first, second, third, etc.). We use this ordinal number prefix before counting these things in Japanese sometimes. Like with bamboo, going down in order toward the youngest.
reading_mnemonic: To remember you need to use the <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> before you count these bamboo, you <reading>dye</reading> (だい) them.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Someone</radical>s and <radical>building</radical>s, someones and buildings, someones and buildings. So many someones and buildings. With so many someones and buildings, we have ourselves a <kanji>metropolis</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: In this <kanji>metropolis</kanji> everything is a <reading>toe</reading> (と). The someones are toes, walking around. The buildings are toes, too.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>village</radical> <radical>beforehand</radical> (what the village was before it was a village) was a <kanji>field</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: On this <kanji>field</kanji>, the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や) used to play.

meaning_mnemonic: Look at a <radical>building</radical> and <radical>compare</radical> the <radical>white</radical> parts. Each of those white parts is a <kanji>floor</kanji>. Multi-<kanji>story</kanji> buildings have tons of different floors that you can see from the outside.
reading_mnemonic: One <kanji>floor</kanji> is just all <reading>kay</reading>aks (かい). You're looking at this building, and every other <kanji>story</kanji> is normal, but that one floor is kayak after kayak after kayak.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>big</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an <radical>umbrella</radical>. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is <kanji>I</kanji>. It is <kanji>me</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Why am <kanji>I</kanji> standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for <reading>ore</reading> (おれ).

other_meanings: 100 Million, 100000000, 100,000,000, 1 Hundred Million, A Hundred Million
meaning_mnemonic: A cult <radical>leader</radical> has a great <radical>idea</radical> to recruit a <kanji>hundred million</kanji> new members. Since he’s the guy with all the ideas, he is the leader of the cult. His idea is to give every new member a free puppy. He’ll have a hundred million new recruits in no time.
reading_mnemonic: The cult leader has his headquarters in <reading>Ok</reading>lahoma (おく). Are there a <kanji>hundred million</kanji> people in Oklahoma? No, probably not. But hey, this leader is shooting for the stars. First Oklahoma, then the universe!

visually_similar_kanji: 閑, 閉, 閣, 聞, 間, 関, 開

The problem you’re now in is one of getting to a hospital and having your mouth sewn back on. The <kanji>question</kanji> is, how are you going to get to the hospital?
reading_mnemonic: The reason you ran mouth first into this gate was because you were being chased by a <reading>mon</reading>ster (もん). A monster in and of itself is a big enough <kanji>problem</kanji> as is, let alone smashing your mouth into a gate. You poor, hapless soul.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Big</radical> <radical>products</radical> need to be put in a big <kanji>container</kanji>. A small container just won’t do. These products are big and they need a big container to be contained in.
reading_mnemonic: Once you get the big products into a <kanji>container</kanji>, you then lock it with a <reading>key</reading> (き). You wouldn’t want these products to bust out of their containers, so it’s best to lock them up with a key.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>samurai</radical> radical and the <kanji>samurai</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: The most famous <kanji>samurai</kanji> in Japanese history was the illustrious <reading>shee</reading>p (し) samurai. He wasn't JUST a sheep who learned the ways of the sword, he would use the wool from the sheep enemies he killed to create his armor!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> under which the <radical>leader</radical> can house one <radical>hundred</radical> of his people is at the local <kanji>lodge</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>lodge</kanji> <reading>shook</reading> (しゅく) as the hundred people came tumbling in through the door. It shook, but it didn't fall over. The roof stayed firmly in place, and everyone got to sleep under it okay.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> is <radical>blue</radical>. As in, it's sad and not feeling well. This is because your soul changes colors depending on your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s or what <kanji>emotion</kanji>s you're expressing.
reading_mnemonic: Why is your soul <kanji>feeling</kanji> blue? Because <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the big local farmhand, was extremely mean to you.

other_meanings: Contemplate, Imagining, Think, Thinking, Thought, Concept, Contemplation

reading_mnemonic: If a <radical>tree</radical> can <kanji>imagine</kanji>, it likely has a <reading>soul</reading> (そう). Its soul is what makes it possible for the tree to <kanji>contemplate</kanji> things, you see?

visually_similar_kanji: 成, 想, 減, 域, 惑
meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>canine</radical> puts its <radical>mouth</radical> on your <radical>heart</radical>, it's a pretty unforgettable <kanji>feeling</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Overall, though, it's a good <kanji>feeling</kanji> — so good that you feel like Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん)! With this canine lovingly slobbering on your heart, you feel like you could go out and conquer the world!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bundle</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> is the <radical>correct</radical> way to <kanji>arrange</kanji> things. Just make sure you <kanji>organize</kanji> it all before winter comes, or it'll be too late.
reading_mnemonic: But the most important things to <kanji>arrange</kanji> and <kanji>organize</kanji> are your <reading>sa</reading>bers (せい). You have an extensive saber collection that you simply must organize before winter arrives.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>rice</radical> <radical>ladle</radical> that's specifically for paying the rice <kanji>fee</kanji>. Each scoop of something has an extra fee tacked on, so when you use a <kanji>material</kanji>, there's a fee you have to pay in that material as well.
reading_mnemonic: One day, the <kanji>fee</kanji> ladle is suddenly the size of <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat oars! What! You're supposed to pay a row boat sized fee now?!

visually_similar_kanji: 情, 請, 清, 静, 精, 靖, 晴
meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>sun</radical> starts to make a <radical>sound</radical>, you know it's about to go <kanji>dark</kanji>. The sun isn't supposed to make a sound, so if you can hear it, it's probably about to fizzle out or something. After it's gone, obviously everything will be pitch black. Get ready to be in the dark!
reading_mnemonic: Now wandering around your house in the <kanji>dark</kanji> you start to feel hungry, so you reach blindly for some food and take a bite. Yuck! It's <reading>an</reading>chovies (あん). You don't even like anchovies, how did they get in your house? Hmm… Dark forces are at work here…

other_meanings: Manner, Formal Name Suffix, Formal Name Title, Formal Name Ending
meaning_mnemonic:
By a <radical>tree</radical>, there's a <radical>sheep</radical> in the <radical>water</radical> with a <kanji>formal name ender</kanji>. That means everyone calls him Sheep-sama. No one calls him just "Sheep," since he's kind of a big deal. He's actually like sheep royalty. When he's not in his castle, Sheep-sama enjoys playing in the water by the trees.

This can also mean <kanji>manner</kanji>, as in your manner of doing things. I guess someone with a formal name ender has a different manner of doing things.
reading_mnemonic: This sheep with the <kanji>formal name ender</kanji> only likes to play outside in the water during the <reading>summer</reading> (さま). Summer is the best season for this fancy sheep. The other seasons just can't compare.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>helicopter</radical> and a <radical>jackhammer</radical> tied to it. You look closer, because this is an odd sight, and realize that there is a sign here too. It's telling you to beware of helicopters and jackhammers in these woods. It's a poorly made <kanji>signpost</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: As you look at this weird <kanji>signpost</kanji> you notice a button. You press it because it will supposedly tell you more about these dangerous helicopters and jackhammers. Instead, it just yells out in a loud obnoxious voice: <reading>HEYO</reading> (ひょう)!!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> must've been sent from <radical>heaven</radical>, because it has a <radical>mouth</radical> and a <radical>mustache</radical>. Like some kind of special heaven tree that talks. And why was it sent? To be a <kanji>bridge</kanji>. To be the great heavenly bridge that we all, someday, must cross.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, to get across this <kanji>bridge</kanji> you have to give it some <reading>hash</reading> (はし) browns. That's what the bridge's mouth is for. Hash browns to get across the heaven bridge? Small price to pay, really.

meaning_mnemonic: There's <radical>treasure</radical> in this <radical>tree</radical> so you take out your <radical>weapon</radical> and <kanji>kill</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: But after the <kanji>kill</kanji>, <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) appears and yells at you. She likes trees — remember how she protected one in the 札 mnemonic? — so Satsuki's pretty upset you'd kill one like that.

meaning_mnemonic: Under a misshapen crescent <radical>moon</radical>, a <radical>dog</radical> <radical>boil</radical>s as much <kanji>nature</kanji> as it can find.
reading_mnemonic: Destroying <kanji>nature</kanji> like this is the dog's way of practicing <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん) Buddhism. As it breathes in the fumes from all of the different pieces of nature being boiled down, the dog gets really zen and chill.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>womb</radical> spins in a <radical>circle</radical> and starts to <radical>boil</radical> with <kanji>heat</kanji>. Uh oh, I think you have a <kanji>fever</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>heat</kanji> from your <kanji>fever</kanji> is making your insides and your head and your entire body spin and boil, until your doctor throws some <reading>nets</reading> (ねつ) around you. You were flailing around and they couldn't get you to stop, so they had to catch you in a series of nets.

meaning_mnemonic: You reach for a <radical>spoon</radical> to start eating, but your <radical>mama</radical> hands you an <radical>arrow</radical> instead and points towards the <radical>coat rack</radical>. Hm, that's not like her… Suddenly you're filled with <kanji>doubt</kanji>. Is this really your mama? You doubt it.
reading_mnemonic: Now full of <kanji>doubt</kanji>, you decide to test your mama by putting her in a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). It sounds harsh, but the guillotine is the only way to clear up your doubts.

visually_similar_kanji: 陛, 階, 習, 昆
meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>compare</radical> <radical>white</radical> light to the other colors you'll realize... white consists of <kanji>all</kanji> the colors in one. It contains all the colors in the spectrum in one color. It is the one color that is <kanji>everything</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You decide white light is the ultimate color. You decide you want to put it on <kanji>all</kanji> things to make everything white. "What a great idea," you think. You try to put it on everything and you nearly succeed... except, the <reading>miners</reading> (みな). They keep getting dirty doing all their mining things. NOOO, your plan is ruined!

visually_similar_kanji: 録, 縁, 線, 綿
meaning_mnemonic: If you tie a <radical>thread</radical> around <radical>Wolverine</radical> and dip him in <radical>water</radical>, he'll turn <kanji>green</kanji>, like the Hulk. Some kind of weird chemical reaction. But I… I wouldn't try it if I were you. You wouldn't like him when he's green.
reading_mnemonic: As the flailing Wolverine begins to turn even more <kanji>green</kanji>, he calls out, "HELP <reading>ME DORY</reading> (みどり)!" Me, Dory? No, not you. He's calling out to that fish from Finding Nemo, another Disney IP. "Help me Dory, I'm green!" Then Dory leaps out of the water to bite through the thread and save Wolverine… THE END. Fade to green.

visually_similar_kanji: 錬, 陳, 棟, 陣, 縛
meaning_mnemonic: Pointing a <radical>thread</radical> to the <radical>east</radical> is what you <kanji>practice</kanji> every day. You're incredibly passionate about eastward thread-pointing, so you make sure to practice every day.
reading_mnemonic: You do all of this <kanji>practice</kanji> to try and afford all of your <reading>ren</reading>tals (れん). One day, all of this practice will pay for all of your rentals.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>can</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>can</kanji>. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a <kanji>tin can</kanji>, though.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for a <kanji>can</kanji> is かん, which seems impossibly easy. If that isn't close enough for you, picture this:

Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) is drinking out of a tin can. He glug glug glugs, gasps, and wipes his face. He holds out the can, "Khan made cans," and winks.

visually_similar_kanji: 待, 持, 特, 時, 寺, 侍
meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> at a <radical>temple</radical> is a <kanji>poem</kanji>. It has to be a poem, because if you say anything else it's just plain disrespectful. All of the monks and priests at this temple have to read and recite poems all day, and if they can do it forever, you can while you're visiting.
reading_mnemonic: As you recite a long <kanji>poem</kanji> at the temple you see a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in the crowd. It's opening and closing its mouth like it wants to say the poem too.

meaning_mnemonic: I always <radical>say</radical> the <radical>fruit</radical> <kanji>section</kanji> at the grocery should be at the front of the store. It’s the perfect place for the fruit section, I say.
reading_mnemonic: To get to the fruit <kanji>section</kanji>, you have to go to the store. To get to the store you have to drive a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Driving a car is the fastest way to get to the fruit section at the store.

meaning_mnemonic: You thought it would be a good idea to <radical>say</radical> the <radical>body</radical> <radical>measurement</radical>s of everyone in your village and now you have to <kanji>apologize</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You were told you had to <kanji>apologize</kanji> by the village <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ). At first you didn't even know why everyone was glaring at you, but the shaman took you aside and explained. And now she's standing behind you with her arms crossed as you apologize to everybody.

visually_similar_kanji: 常, 堂, 党, 員
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Viking</radical> opens his <radical>mouth</radical>, and below it, a <radical>shellfish</radical> sits. Grab that shellfish and throw it into his mouth to win a <kanji>prize</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>prize</kanji> you're working so hard to win is lunch with the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). This is a pretty huge prize, considering all you're doing is knocking something over.

meaning_mnemonic: For your <radical>car</radical> you use a <radical>hat</radical>, some <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>bookshelf</radical> to build a new <kanji>wheel</kanji>. I mean, it's generally <kanji>ring</kanji> and <kanji>loop</kanji> shaped, it just needs to be a <kanji>circle</kanji>, so it should work, right?
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>wheel</kanji> is... generally <reading>rin</reading>g (りん) shaped, so that's good.

meaning_mnemonic: You want to get a <radical>scooter</radical>, so you have one self (<radical>oneself</radical>) and another self working <radical>together</radical> to <kanji>choose</kanji>. The two tiny yous sit on each of your shoulders, like angel and devil, and argue about which scooter you should choose.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly your selfs both gasp and <kanji>choose</kanji> a scooter in front of you that looks like a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). The scooter is designed like a human on the top, the bars are its arms, and the bottom with the seat and the wheels are all horse. This centaur scooter is what you choose to ride.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Gold</radical>, at its <radical>root</radical>, is made up of <kanji>silver</kanji>. Using silver as the root of a coin is a great way to save on gold! That's why, often, if you just scratch gold, you'll find there's silver hidden underneath, at its root.
reading_mnemonic: If you want to hunt for some <kanji>silver</kanji> for yourself, all you need is a <reading>gui</reading>nea (ぎん) pig. Guinea pigs can smell silver, so get a couple and set them loose in the woods and they'll lead you straight to it.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Gold</radical> reveals itself when you <radical>stand</radical> and <radical>see</radical> into this <kanji>mirror</kanji>. Yes, even you are made of gold. You're so great and valuable, standing in front of that mirror. It's not hard to see, especially in a mirror – you're golden.
reading_mnemonic: As you look into the <kanji>mirror</kanji> you think, "<reading>Kaga</reading>… <reading>me</reading> (かがみ)?" You always forget that you're Chairman Kaga from the Iron Chef TV show. That's why you say "Kaga… me?" every time you look in the mirror.

visually_similar_kanji: 預, 領, 額, 頭, 顔, 頼, 願, 頑
meaning_mnemonic: If you use the <radical>sun</radical>, you can find the <radical>correct</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical>. That's the <kanji>topic</kanji> of today's lecture.
reading_mnemonic: Our <kanji>topic</kanji> is actually mostly about using the sun to see different colored <reading>dye</reading>s (だい) in the water.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Sheep</radical> <radical>fins</radical> are <radical>good</radical> for <kanji>foster</kanji> children. The sheep have been genetically combined with fish, so the sheep have fins (and they've lost their tails — which is why the tail part of the sheep radical is missing in this kanji). These sheep fins are rich in nutrients, so they're good for fostering big, strong foster children.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to <kanji>foster</kanji> a better relationship with these foster kids would be to give them some <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). Maybe they can dip the sheep fins in the yogurt to help mask the strange taste. Yogurt is also very nutritious, so it's a good supplement to the foster kids' diet.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Eat</radical>ing the <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical>, because the roof is a <kanji>public building</kanji>. Because it is a public building bears are allowed to eat the roof.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Public building</kanji>s must make their roofs available for eating because of a law passed by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> and a <radical>shrimp</radical> are sitting next to each other. They are both at the train <kanji>station</kanji>, waiting for a train to come and take them home.
reading_mnemonic: The train pulls into the <kanji>station</kanji>. They walk up to the train doors, but they don't open. "Perhaps <reading>a key</reading> (えき) would help?" asks the station master, as he goes over to open the door to the train.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>well</radical> radical and the <kanji>well</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: Each time you go to the town <kanji>well</kanji>, there's a giant <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) hiding inside, just waiting for you to show up.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>yakuza</radical> shows you his <radical>knife</radical>. He says, "This is an <kanji>example</kanji> of a knife."
reading_mnemonic: "This is an <kanji>example</kanji>," the leader of the yakuza tells you. "Next time, I'll show you an example of a <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun."

meaning_mnemonic: You give a <radical>lid</radical> to a <radical>person</radical> (two of them, in fact), then they put it on a <radical>cross</radical> when you <kanji>graduate</kanji>. It's a symbolic ceremony, putting a lid over a cross, but it's just what you do when you graduate around these parts.
reading_mnemonic: Uh oh, looks like you forgot your lid. They decide not to let you <kanji>graduate</kanji>. <reading>So two</reading> (そつ) more years now until you can graduate, it seems. So two more years?! Just for forgetting a lid? Nonsense!

meaning_mnemonic: Next to the <radical>cross</radical> we combine our <radical>power</radical> <radical>power</radical> <radical>power</radical> so that we have <kanji>cooperation</kanji>. And with our powers combined, we become stronger than we ever could have been apart, lifting the cross above our heads!
reading_mnemonic: Nowhere is the power of cooperation more apparent than in <reading>きょう</reading>と. When invaders are attacking, when the townspeople want to rebel, when there is a kitty up a tree, the people combine their power from all reaches of Japan and cross into きょうと to put a stop to the madness through cooperation.

meaning_mnemonic: You try to be <radical>private</radical>, but because of your <radical>big</radical> <radical>hair</radical> you end up having to <kanji>participate</kanji> in everything. Can you imagine people asking for volunteers or something, and you trying to look inconspicuous with your big hair? Of course they're going to notice you and make you participate.
reading_mnemonic: You know who has big hair and loves to <kanji>participate</kanji> in everything? <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん)! Well, his hair is more big on the bottom (it's a beard) than whatever you have on your head, but hair is hair. And he participates in present-giving in every house in the world! See? Big hair = participation!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>circumference</radical> radical and the <kanji>circumference</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Practice how to measure the <kanji>circumference</kanji> of an item by using your <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう). Your shoe is kind of round, and it's free. I mean it's right there on your foot.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>well</radical> will <kanji>surround</kanji> you if you fall into it. The mouth of a well is the opening of the well, and if you fall into that well, the mouth as well as the rest of the well will surround you.
reading_mnemonic: The well walls <kanji>surround</kanji> you as you look up to the mouth once again. This time you see an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) flying overhead. You call out to the eagle to save you and the eagle comes swooping down into the well and flies you out to safety. What a nice eagle!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mouth</radical> that is <radical>old</radical> is going to be <kanji>hard</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You touch the old man's <kanji>hard</kanji> mouth and it crumbles away, revealing the face of a <reading>子</reading> (こ) inside.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Crab</radical>s in the <radical>dirt</radical> make a great <kanji>foundation</kanji> for a seaside hut. It's right on the seashore, where all the crabs dig their holes in the dirt. But as they get old and die, their bodies form a strong base. Perfect for the foundation of a building like this!
reading_mnemonic: Remember, a good <kanji>foundation</kanji> is the <reading>key</reading> (き) to a good house. No, literally. You have to use a piece of the foundation to make the key to your house.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cleat</radical>-wearing <radical>woman</radical> is walking on someone's back, but she doesn't want to hurt him, so she has to be very <kanji>gentle</kanji>. Cleats are sharp and pointy, and not designed for back-walking, so she's being extra gentle right now.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, the person she's being <kanji>gentle</kanji> with is her <reading>da</reading>d (だ). No one would ever want to hurt their dad, especially if he's asked you to walk gently on his back as a way of giving him a massage.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>grain</radical>'s <radical>child</radical> will grow with the <kanji>seasons</kanji>. In spring the grain is born, it grows in summer, is harvested in fall, and dies in winter.
reading_mnemonic: All of the <kanji>seasons</kanji> have their own special <reading>key</reading> (き). As they change, that season's key appears and unlocks the next step in the grain's life.

visually_similar_kanji: 売, 示, 宗, 奈
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> that became the <radical>origin</radical> of all roofs was <kanji>perfect</kanji>. It was tall and wide so it could fit and protect everyone. And the dimensions were perfect too.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>perfect</kanji> roof was commissioned by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). We got all of the carpenters and home makers and construction workers he'd conquered together and tasked them with making the first roof, but only if they made it absolutely perfect.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>treasure</radical> on top of a <radical>narwhal</radical> who wears a <radical>towel</radical> that will grant your greatest <kanji>wish</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: In order to open the treasure and get your <kanji>wish</kanji>, you need the <reading>key</reading> (き). The narwhal knows where it's hidden, so you'll have to convince it to tell you where the key is.

meaning_mnemonic: If you live in the <radical>now</radical>, there’s a good chance your <radical>heart</radical> controls your <kanji>thought</kanji> process. You don’t have time to think with your brain, you need an answer now so you use your heart to make decisions and thought process.
reading_mnemonic: You're living in the now and letting your heart control all your <kanji>thought</kanji>s. Why are you following your heart? You found you only have one <reading>年</reading> (ねん) to live, so you have to live for the now.

other_meanings: Nature, Sex, One's Nature, Characteristics, Trait, Sexuality
meaning_mnemonic: Everyone has a <radical>soul</radical> in their <radical>life</radical>, and that soul shapes their <kanji>gender</kanji>. It's not just about body parts — it's about what's inside. In the end, it's one's <kanji> nature</kanji> that truly matters.
reading_mnemonic: Once you've decided what your <kanji>gender</kanji> is, someone comes to your house and lays a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) on your shoulders. "This is now your <kanji>nature</kanji>," they say, lifting the saber. It's official! It's in all the newspapers, there's a parade, and everyone pats you on the back. Thanks, gender saber!

visually_similar_kanji: 祈, 析, 斬, 新
meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>fingers</radical> are strong enough, you can take an <radical>axe</radical> and <kanji>fold</kanji> it in half. But be careful not to <kanji>bend</kanji> it too far, or you might just <kanji>break</kanji> it!
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, as you <kanji>fold</kanji> these axes in half you realize they come in <reading>sets</reading> (せつ), so there are twice the axes you thought there would be. To compensate, you start folding them in sets too.

meaning_mnemonic: Causing <radical>death</radical> at every turn, the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>king</radical> sits inside his moon, getting ready to cause death on anything in his sights. Sounds a lot like the Death Star from a certain movie. One of which is "Star Wars: A New <kanji>Hope</kanji>."
reading_mnemonic: The name A New <kanji>Hope</kanji>, as we all know, comes from the ending where the moon king's son sends a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball into that little opening and knocks it out of the sky.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> with <radical>talent</radical> can become <kanji>lumber</kanji>. Not all trees can do this. Only the talented ones are able to turn themselves into lumber or <kanji>material</kanji>, to be used for a million different things.
reading_mnemonic: Trees can be turned into all kinds of things, but this one wants to use its <kanji>lumber</kanji> and <kanji>material</kanji> to build a <reading>xy</reading>lophone (ざい). It's the most difficult instrument to create, so it suits the talent level of this tree!

visually_similar_kanji: 京, 東, 恵, 車
