reading_mnemonic: You should always <kanji>bundle</kanji> your <reading>sock</reading>s (そく). If you don't, there is a 100% chance you'll lose all of the left ones.

meaning_mnemonic: When climbing a <radical>tree</radical> in <radical>public</radical>, it’s best to choose a <kanji>pine</kanji>. Pine trees offer the most coverage, so you’ll be able to hide, even out in public.
reading_mnemonic: In case you fall, someone has laid <reading>mats</reading> (まつ) out around the base of the <kanji>pine</kanji> tree. That way, you’ll land on the mats should something unfortunate happen.

visually_similar_kanji: 客, 枚, 絡, 各
meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tree</radical> wants to <radical>kiss</radical> you, it's a sign of your <kanji>status</kanji>. Only someone of high status would be worthy enough to receive the gnarly but gentle kiss of a tree. Trees don't kiss just anyone, you know.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to convince a tree of your <kanji>status</kanji> is to say "cock-a-doodle-doo" at it, like a <reading>cock</reading> (かく), i.e. a male chicken. Trees really place a lot of status on the ability to sound like a cock crowing.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Yakuza</radical> <radical>bars</radical> barely exist. The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of them aren't even in Japan.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of the yakuza bars aren't in Japan. Strangely, they are all in <reading>Zan</reading>zibar (ざん).

meaning_mnemonic: One <radical>animal</radical> that is particularly  <radical>good</radical> is the <kanji>wolf</kanji>. Wolves have a bad reputation, but actually they're very, very good animals.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>wolf</kanji> might be good, but if you run into one, all you can do is scream <reading>Oh 神</reading>!” (おおかみ).

meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>white</radical> guy jumps into a <radical>pool</radical> with a <kanji>target</kanji> painted on the bottom. He's aiming for the target, of course.

This kanji can also mean <kanji>-al</kanji>, as in the endings you get on some English adjectives. You know, like the pool is artifici-al. Or painting a target down there is not practic-al. That kind of -al.
reading_mnemonic: This white dude is a huge <reading>techie</reading> (てき) so he has electronic enhancements that make sure he hits the <kanji>target</kanji>. Being a techie has its advantages.

meaning_mnemonic: You tie a <radical>thread</radical> on your finger before jumping in the <radical>pool</radical> to remind yourself of the <kanji>promise</kanji> you made to your mother. The thread represents the promise you made to mow the lawn after you finished swimming in the pool.
reading_mnemonic: After you get out of the pool, you keep the <kanji>promise</kanji> you made to your mother. So you get on your <reading>yak</reading> (やく) powered mower and trim the grass. Yes, your mower is pulled by a yak. It’s very efficient.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>private</radical> place on the <radical>moon</radical>, you hide two <radical>spoon</radical>s that give you a special <kanji>ability</kanji>. It's the ability to predict the future! The private moon spoons reflect the knowledge of time and space into your brain. Now that's a cool ability!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>ability</kanji> to predict the future makes you famous and now everyone knows your name: <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう)! And now that people know about your name and special ability, everyone will love you!

meaning_mnemonic: You put <radical>flowers</radical> on a <radical>cloud</radical> and call it <kanji>art</kanji>. Not everyone agrees that your flower cloud art is actually art, but you know it is.
reading_mnemonic: Your beautiful <kanji>art</kanji> is going to be displayed at a <reading>gay</reading> (げい) club. Imagine the pride you feel about having your art on display.

meaning_mnemonic: The best kind of flowers to grow in your window? Strawberry, obviously. Yes, there are strawberry flowers — it's actually the flowers that turn into the strawberries, you know. And they're perfect as window flowers because they need a ton of light. That's why all your window flowers are strawberries.
reading_mnemonic: Believe it or not, your <kanji>strawberry</kanji> is the only cure for an <reading>itchy Go</reading>dzilla (いちご).

visually_similar_kanji: 閑, 閣, 聞, 間, 問, 関, 開
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>gate</radical> to <radical>talent</radical> is now <kanji>closed</kanji>. In fact, the gate to talent is always closed. It's not like anyone can just waltz in and get themselves some talent. You have to work for it! You have to work hard to get through that closed gate to talent!
reading_mnemonic: Outside the talent gate that's always <kanji>closed</kanji>, <reading>hay</reading> (へい) is piled up to make beds for the people who are still trying to get in. Who knows how long they'll be there outside the closed gate, sleeping in the hay, but they're all working hard to become talented.

visually_similar_kanji: 露, 霧, 雲, 雪, 震, 霜, 雷, 電
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> makes up one <radical>part</radical> of this, and the rest is air or something. I imagine this is what people thought the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> was made out of thousands of years ago.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out, studying the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> is <reading>fun</reading> (ふん)!

visually_similar_kanji: 頭, 額, 預, 頼, 願, 領, 顔, 題
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>origin</radical> of the <radical>geoduck</radical> is a pretty <kanji>stubborn</kanji> one. The geoduck race is so stubborn that it refused to evolve into an animal that made any sense. Hence, the origin of the geoduck is one of stubbornness.
reading_mnemonic: You know who else was <kanji>stubborn</kanji>? <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (がん). Gandhi believed in non-violent resistance and he was pretty stubborn about it.

visually_similar_kanji: 頭, 預, 頑, 領, 額, 頼, 顔, 題
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>original</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical> had a <kanji>request</kanji>. He wants there to be more geoducks in the world!
reading_mnemonic: The only person that would even hear the geoduck's <kanji>request</kanji> was <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (がん). Gandhi closed his eyes, sat down, and spread the geoduck's request to the rest of the world.

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <radical>mustache</radical> and you hit your <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>moon</radical>, you’re probably going to break a <kanji>bone</kanji>. Ok, so it doesn’t matter so much if you have a mustache, but if you’re travelling fast enough to make it to the moon, you’re definitely breaking a bone if you run into it.
reading_mnemonic: Outer space is cold, and if you're traveling to the moon, you're going to need a lot of <reading>coats</reading> (こつ). All of these coats will keep you warm, even if you do end up breaking your forehead <kanji>bone</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>height</radical> radical and the <kanji>height</kanji> kanji are the same!

That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of <kanji>ten feet</kanji>. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall.
reading_mnemonic: When you think of <kanji>height</kanji>, think of our huge farmhand friend, <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's <kanji>ten feet</kanji> tall.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> in <radical>private</radical> is <kanji>Buddha</kanji>. You don't feel the need to tell everyone. But when you're alone you give your time to Buddha and let him lead your life.
reading_mnemonic: Your private <kanji>Buddha</kanji> is a little different than other people's idea of him. Your Buddha is wearing <reading>boots</reading> (ぶつ). They're big and rubber, and they look fabulous on him.

meaning_mnemonic: To your <radical>leader</radical>, you <radical>say</radical>: "<kanji>Believe</kanji> and <kanji>trust</kanji> in me." The leader doesn't think you can handle your duties, so you have to say this to him. You want him to believe and trust that you're responsible. You can handle this task.
reading_mnemonic: As you face your leader and say "<kanji>Believe</kanji> and <kanji>trust</kanji> in me," you kneel down on each <reading>shin</reading> (しん). You have shin splints, so it hurts a bit, but you do it anyway to show how serious you are.

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>yakuza</radical> <radical>knife</radical> and put it in a <kanji>row</kanji> with the others.
reading_mnemonic: Should we put them in a <kanji>row</kanji>? <reading>Let's</reading> (れつ) put them in a row!

reading_mnemonic: A man needs <kanji>courage</kanji> to stand up to all the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) of the world. They are so numerous and difficult to understand, but the man can face them with courage thanks to his mama.

visually_similar_kanji: 旬, 句, 伺, 可, 詞, 飼, 同, 何, 洞, 阿, 荷, 河, 向, 苛

reading_mnemonic: After this creeper dons the cape, they decide to become <kanji>Director</kanji> of <reading>Shee</reading>p (し). From now on all sheep-related business, government policy, and law will be determined by this creeper in a cape, because they are the Director of Sheep.

visually_similar_kanji: 版, 仮, 阪, 板, 返, 飯, 販

Think about it — is there anything more annoying than having to walk up a steep slope? Why is the dirt here forming a slope?! Because the dirt is being anti-social, and a slope is how it tells you to stay away.
reading_mnemonic: You need to know these things about <kanji>slope</kanji>s if you want to play <reading>soccer</reading> (さか). Soccer is surprisingly slope-intensive, actually.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Again</radical> and again, <radical>winter</radical> <kanji>change</kanji>s you each year.
reading_mnemonic: You know what else <kanji>change</kanji>s each winter? <reading>Hen</reading>s (へん)! They're constantly laying eggs, which then (possibly) turn into new hens.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>knife</radical> got stuck in <radical>Wolverine</radical>'s <radical>forehead</radical>, and he has a <radical>towel</radical> wrapped around it to stop the bleeding, but he really needs to <kanji>return home</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic:
A good <radical>ceremony</radical> is under <radical>construction</radical> for a long time. You can't just make up a new ceremony on the spot. A ceremony is done a certain way because that's the way it's always been done. In short, to build a ceremony, you have to create a <kanji>ritual</kanji> first. Then, the ritual can be constructed into a bigger, more lavish <kanji>ceremony</kanji>.

This kanji also means <kanji>equation</kanji> for some reason. Just think of a ceremony that involves doing math and solving equations. How strange would that be? Pretend you're at this ceremony.
reading_mnemonic: So, you're at a <kanji>ritual</kanji>, but not just any old ritual. This is a full-blown <kanji>ceremony</kanji> and it's incredibly <reading>chic</reading> (しき). Imagine just how chic it is. Give it a shot — I'll let you come up with the chicness this time (it's good practice).

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> are <radical>private</radical>, no one can see them unless they <kanji>pay</kanji>! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek.
reading_mnemonic: If someone tries to look without paying, that's <reading>hara</reading>ssment (はら)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent!

visually_similar_kanji: 支, 投, 枚, 枝, 伎, 岐, 鼓, 肢
meaning_mnemonic: You can make your <radical>fingers</radical> <radical>branch</radical> out. It's your special <kanji>skill</kanji>, a very advanced <kanji>technique</kanji>. Your fingers branch out into smaller fingers and you can hold things really well. You can type super-duper fast. And you can win any tickle fight. These are skills you have thanks to your branching fingers.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, these <kanji>skill</kanji>s are too much for the normal skill-less people to handle, so they pull out the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). I guess they're going to chop off your skillful fingers because they're kinda scary.

meaning_mnemonic: When you see the <radical>spring</radical> <radical>sun</radical> you know it's finally the  <kanji>spring</kanji> season.
reading_mnemonic: When the <kanji>spring</kanji> season comes around, it makes you want to laugh: "<reading>HAR</reading> (はる) HAR HAR!" you yell.

meaning_mnemonic: Once the <radical>sun</radical> comes out, you can use this <radical>key</radical> to unlock it and take you to any <kanji>previous</kanji> day, even just <kanji>yesterday</kanji>! The sun is in charge of the day changes, so if you use a key to unlock it, you can control the flow of time and return to yesterday, or a previous day in the past. Behold the power of the sun.
reading_mnemonic: Time traveling to a <kanji>previous</kanji> time, like <kanji>yesterday</kanji>, can be rough on the body. As such, you wear a small <reading>sack</reading> (さく) to hold your valuables while you're ripped through the sands of time. The sack keeps your important stuff from getting lost. The sack holds your key to the sun as well.

meaning_mnemonic: A giant <radical>shrimp</radical> appears on top of the <radical>sun</radical> after it rises high above the <radical>ground</radical>, and this is how you know it's <kanji>noon</kanji>. The shrimp appears on the sun exactly at noon every day, to announce that it's noon.
reading_mnemonic: At <kanji>noon</kanji>, the shrimp also puts on its high <reading>heel</reading>s (ひる). It wants to look good for the other shrimp it's going to lunch with. High noon? More like high heels, am I right?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> has an <radical>excuse</radical> for disappearing at <kanji>night</kanji>. The sun gets really tired, same as anyone else – so when night rolls around the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep. It’s a valid excuse.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, you also have a history of overworking yourself, so you've been outright <reading>ban</reading>ned (ばん) from showing up at <kanji>night</kanji>.

visually_similar_kanji: 暗, 情, 請, 清, 静, 精, 靖
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is out, the sky is <radical>blue</radical>, things have begun to <kanji>clear up</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Now that it's starting to <kanji>clear up</kanji> you can't help but laugh. "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)! Ha ha ha!" you laugh up into the sky. The sun feels great on your face, making you feel lively! And that blue sky ain't too shabby either.

meaning_mnemonic: To throw <radical>life</radical> out the <radical>window</radical>, use <kanji>poison</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If anything's worse than <kanji>poison</kanji> it's doing Su<reading>doku</reading> (どく) puzzles.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical>s in the <radical>past</radical> changed the <kanji>method</kanji>s and <kanji>law</kanji>s of today.
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>method</kanji>s and <kanji>law</kanji>s affected your own <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう) the most.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> approaches, and anyone who dares to <radical>stand</radical> in front of it will surely <kanji>cry</kanji>. That tsunami is going to hit you hard, and rip you right off the ground you're standing on. Who wouldn't cry?
reading_mnemonic: Do you know the only way to stop yourself <kanji>cry</kanji>ing after a tsunami? That's right, <reading>na</reading>chos (な)! Nachos are the only proven way to cheer people up after being hit by a tsunami.

visually_similar_kanji: 銭, 桟, 践, 残
meaning_mnemonic: After a <radical>tsunami</radical>, if you go to a <radical>bar</radical>, you'll find yourself standing in <kanji>shallow</kanji> water. You're just trying to enjoy a drink, but with your feet constantly soaked, it's not exactly pleasant. Here's to hoping the conversations with your date won't be shallow too!
reading_mnemonic: What beer are you drinking at this bar while standing in <kanji>shallow</kanji> water? You’re drinking <reading>Asa</reading>hi (あさ), the beer of the salaryman. Asahi is super dry, so it takes your attention away from the shallow water a bit.

meaning_mnemonic: If you see an <radical>animal</radical> among the <radical>flowers</radical> in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, chances are it’s a <kanji>cat</kanji>. Cats love rice paddy flowers, almost as much as they love catnip.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> decides to live in your <radical>scarecrow</radical>, you'll be granted good <kanji>luck</kanji> and good <kanji>fortune</kanji>. Crows won't hang out in your farm. Everything you grow will become large and delicious. But not everyone is so lucky that a spirit will decide to live in their scarecrow. So maybe the luck was in you all along!
reading_mnemonic: You want to check the scarecrow to make sure your recent <kanji>luck</kanji> is coming from it, so you kick it. "<reading>F***</reading> (ふく) you!" it yells. Oh yeah, there's a spirit in there.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Grain</radical>s look like they're on <radical>fire</radical> in <kanji>autumn</kanji>. They all turn red and orange and brown, the colors of fire. It's also fun to set grains on fire in Autumn, since it's getting colder.
reading_mnemonic: As the grains burn, and the season changes to autumn, imagine them yelling out in pain: "<reading>ACK</reading> (あき)!"

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> you weave together to tell others about <radical>oneself</radical> is the <kanji>account</kanji> of your life. It's your very own <kanji>narrative</kanji>, tying everything you've been through together.
reading_mnemonic: You take this <kanji>account</kanji> and lock it with a special <reading>key</reading> (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you.

meaning_mnemonic: Members of the <radical>tongue</radical> <radical>clan</radical> like to do one thing: <kanji>lick</kanji>. They go around licking everything to mark their tongue clan territory, you know? They even lick each other on the cheek by way of greeting.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the tongue clan members also <kanji>lick</kanji> your <reading>na</reading>chos (な). You'd been saving those nachos! They were your travel rations. Now each and every nacho has been licked clean.

meaning_mnemonic:
There are many <radical>flowers</radical> in the <radical>center</radical> of <kanji>England</kanji>. It may seem rainy and gray at first, but if you walk right to the center you'll see all the flowers that grow there in the center of the country.

This kanji also means <kanji>English</kanji>, which is pretty similar to England. Just imagine all the people of England walking to the center, where the flowers are, and speaking English to them to help them grow.
reading_mnemonic: You keep walking to the very central center of <kanji>England</kanji> and see a giant <reading>a</reading>corn (えい) planted in the middle of the ground. This acorn is the source of all the flowers and life in England.

meaning_mnemonic: There <radical>go</radical> some <radical>angel</radical>s with <radical>drop</radical>s on their shoulders. Carrying drops like that requires <kanji>technique</kanji>. It’s a real <kanji>art</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Angels are so good at this because they are trained in nin<reading>jutsu</reading> (じゅつ), or the "ninja techniques." Everyone knows that ninjas are great at carrying drops on the go!

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> how big a <radical>cross</radical> is, you have to <kanji>measure</kanji> it. You can't say the size of something without measuring it first.
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>measure</kanji> this cross but all you have is a <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい). Good enough! I'm sure all cakes are exactly the same size, so they're a reliable unit of measure.

meaning_mnemonic: You run into someone's <radical>forehead</radical> with your <radical>car</radical>. The big forehead you hit is Kim Jong Un's. You know that now you're going to have the whole North Korean <kanji>army</kanji> coming after you.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>army</kanji> is after you. Each army soldier has a <reading>gun</reading> (ぐん) and they want to use these guns of theirs to shoot you dead! You killed their leader with a car and now they’re gonna get you back with a gun!

reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sunshine</kanji> gets into the building so easily, in fact, that it hits your <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). The sunshine makes the yogurt... gross.

visually_similar_kanji: 版, 仮, 阪, 板, 返, 坂, 販

reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the <kanji>meal</kanji>, <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo appears before you and takes a bite! This is what happens if you don't eat your food, someone else will eat it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hat</radical> comes to a <radical>stop</radical>, thinking of a <kanji>plan</kanji>. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>plan</kanji> that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the <reading>key</reading> (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple!

meaning_mnemonic: A psychic <radical>leader</radical> kneels to the <radical>ground</radical>, picks up a <radical>thread</radical>, and instantly makes a <kanji>connection</kanji> with the person that it came from. This leader is very powerful, so even a thread is enough for them to make a psychic connection with the person who was wearing it.
reading_mnemonic: As you develop this psychic <kanji>connection</kanji> with the owner of the thread, you can tell that they're currently eating a <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい).

meaning_mnemonic: If you play <radical>music</radical> with your <radical>fins</radical>, one <kanji>rule</kanji> is that you must be a fish. You can’t play music using fish fins that don’t belong to you. That’s the rule. And it’s also rude.
reading_mnemonic: There’s also a <kanji>rule</kanji> in place to limit the amount of fish fin musicians. No more than <reading>ten</reading> (てん) are allowed to gather and play their music together. That’s the rule. No more than ten.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets in your <radical>eye</radical>, I <kanji>dare</kanji> you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you.
reading_mnemonic: After you’ve blinded yourself from the <kanji>dare</kanji> of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>forehead</radical> <radical>table</radical> is completely <kanji>superfluous</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The only person you know with a <kanji>superfluous</kanji> forehead table is <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the ten foot tall, simple farmhand.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>prison</radical> on a <radical>cliff</radical> surrounded by <radical>snake</radical>s. Now that's a <kanji>dangerous</kanji> place. If you try to escape the prison you either fall to your death off the cliff or get bitten/squeezed to death by the snakes. Can you think of anything more dangerous than this? I can't.
reading_mnemonic: Lucky for you, even though you're stuck in this <kanji>dangerous</kanji> place, there is hope. There is a <reading>key</reading> (き). All dangerous prisons have a key. You just have to find and steal it so you can avoid the cliffs and snakes!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>products</radical> radical and the <kanji>product</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Productive!
reading_mnemonic: As you try to sell these <kanji>product</kanji>s, you finally get a buyer. It's a <reading>Hin</reading>du (ひん) person. She walks in and buys your products on the spot!

meaning_mnemonic: You examine the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>zombie</radical> and find a small <kanji>garden</kanji> in there. There are even benches... it looks like a <kanji>park</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You look closer at the <kanji>garden</kanji> and suddenly everything <reading>en</reading>ds (えん).

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>narwhal</radical> <radical>stick</radical>s a <radical>child</radical> with its horn then you have to admit that it <kanji>exist</kanji>s. We know some of you have been doubting narwhals and whether they're real. Well now your kid is a kabob, so do you believe they exist now? I <kanji>suppose</kanji> you do.
reading_mnemonic: Oh, and the child we had to narwhal stab to prove they <kanji>exist</kanji> - that's your <reading>son</reading> (そん). Maybe you should have listened and kept your son out of the Narwhal Danger <reading>Zone</reading> (ぞん) after we warned you about it.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>roof</radical> needs <radical>measurement</radical>s done every year to make sure it will <kanji>protect</kanji> you properly.
reading_mnemonic: If the measurements are off, and your roof doesn't <kanji>protect</kanji> you, then you get to <reading>sue</reading> (す)! If you're still alive, that is.

meaning_mnemonic: Sticking a <radical>cross</radical> into a <radical>rice paddy</radical> to get its <radical>measurement</radical>s is your <kanji>specialty</kanji>. Most people get really confused when they have to measure their rice paddies, but that's where you come in. You plant a cross right in the middle, look down it from one end to the other, and voila! You know the measurements immediately. That's why it's your specialty!
reading_mnemonic: Hearing of your amazing <kanji>specialty</kanji> and cross measurement abilities, a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) from a far off land recruits you for a job. The centaur’s father has just passed away and the centaur wants you to measure the rice paddies that have been left to him.

kunyomi: しあわ, さいわ, さち
meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>lid</radical> on something <radical>spicy</radical> and you'll cook up pure <kanji>happiness</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Out of spicy foods you made pure <kanji>happiness</kanji>. You give it to your sad friend <reading>こう</reading>いち, who waits at the table.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> <radical>attach</radical>ing your entire country is the <kanji>government</kanji>. They loom over you all and try to keep you all organized and together under their control.
reading_mnemonic: Try to get out from under this <kanji>government</kanji> canopy and you'll be labeled a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). Unless... you can fool them!

meaning_mnemonic: If you listened in to the <radical>private</radical> lives of <radical>twenty</radical> people, all of them would have different <kanji>dialect</kanji>s and ways of <kanji>speech</kanji>. Whether they actually use these dialects with you is another story. But when they're alone, or with other people who are from the same place, their speech will be different.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to learn someone's <kanji>dialect</kanji> is to buy them a <reading>ben</reading>to (べん) from where they're from. Not only do these bento have writing in their dialect on them, but their speech will immediately shift to match. Then you'll be able to hear how they sound in their head and in private!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>prison</radical> where you once kept <radical>Wolverine</radical>, you find a beating <radical>heart</radical>. You don't understand how it's still going, but you know you need to <kanji>hurry</kanji> up and do something, or it might stop all of a <kanji>sudden</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You start to overheat as you <kanji>hurry</kanji> around, so you grab a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう) to cool you down. The high water content re-hydrates you and lets you continue hurrying to help save this heart.

meaning_mnemonic: It's <radical>correct</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> to focus on <kanji>politics</kanji> and the <kanji>government</kanji>. Elections are happening, in the new year politicians are being sworn in. Winter is government time!
reading_mnemonic: Everyone involved in <kanji>politics</kanji> and <kanji>government</kanji> wields a special <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). If two political parties are arguing, they'll whip out their sabers and start slashing away!

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> is out, you can see two <radical>Wolverine</radical>s and a <radical>turkey</radical> playing together, but only on a certain <kanji>weekday</kanji>. Which <kanji>day of the week</kanji> is it? I'll never tell you. It could be Sunday. It could be Monday. It could be any day of the week.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you know how to figure out what <kanji>day of the week</kanji> it is, you can start making <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). It can take up to 24 hours to make yogurt. Knowing which weekday it is at any given moment means you can perfect your yogurt-making schedule.

meaning_mnemonic: Why would you try to take a <radical>brush</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical>? It's almost too obvious, because you want to <kanji>write</kanji> something down.
reading_mnemonic: What did you <kanji>write</kanji> about? You were writing about this amazing circus <reading>show</reading> (しょ) you just watched on the sun. You didn't expect there to be any shows here, but turns out you were wrong!

visually_similar_kanji: 台, 始, 浴, 沿, 胎
meaning_mnemonic:
After a <radical>tsunami</radical>, use this <radical>machine</radical> to <kanji>cure</kanji> the people and the country from the damage. <kanji>Heal</kanji>ing machines are all over Japan just in case a tsunami does way more damage than they can handle. 

Oh, and whoever cures and heals the most people will be able to <kanji>rule</kanji> over them once everything starts going back to normal. So keep that in mind, kay?
reading_mnemonic:
Alternative ways to <kanji>cure</kanji> yourself after a tsunami are either praying to <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) or eating your weight in <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). I'm not sure if I have enough cheese for all the people that got hit though... Hmm, do you have cheese?

Before you make your decision, remember that whoever cures you will be able to <kanji>reign</kanji> over you and your people. So do you want to be led by Jesus or by some cheese? The choice is yours.

meaning_mnemonic: A group of <radical>private</radical> <radical>sword</radical> guys are in your <radical>rice paddy</radical>. You must <kanji>detain</kanji> them at once! Private sword guys are people who work for private companies and use their swords on people. They're basically paid assassins. And you're going to detain them!
reading_mnemonic:
You're running out of steam and you're afraid you might not be able to <kanji>detain</kanji> all of these guys when <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter appears. He hates swords, and will only use fists because it's the honorable way to fight, so he starts helping you detain them!

He's also found a <reading>loo</reading>phole (る) in the system and you don't have to be super gentle with these guys either. So detain them as forcefully as you want. It is your rice paddy they're in, after all.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>pope</radical> stays fixated on the <radical>ground</radical>, staring at <radical>fins</radical>, he's going to lose touch with <kanji>reality</kanji>. He should be focusing on his popish duties, but instead he's looking at the fish fins he dropped, and now can't eat because they're dirty. Silly pope. You can't let this one thing get you down. You have other things to do.
reading_mnemonic: You're doing your best to bring the pope back to <kanji>reality</kanji> when he snaps and kicks you in the <reading>shin</reading> (しん). Oww! What the heck, pope! But he's already back staring at the fins and your shin is throbbing where he kicked it.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Bamboo</radical> <radical>heaven</radical> is a place for <kanji>laugh</kanji>ing. Bamboo is a very jolly plant, and they love to laugh. Even after death in bamboo heaven, the bamboo continue to laugh joyfully. Bamboo heaven is truly a place of laughter.
reading_mnemonic: There’s actually a war a goin’ on up in that there bamboo heaven, y’know? Ye might not have heard of it with all that there <kanji>laugh</kanji>in’ a goin’ on, but there definitely be a <reading>war a</reading> (わら) goin’ on up in bamboo heaven, y’hear? The bamboo are scared so that’s why they be laughin’ so much. They nervous.

meaning_mnemonic: With the <radical>bamboo</radical> from that <radical>tree</radical>, your trained <radical>eye</radical> can tell it'll make an excellent <kanji>box</kanji>. Boxes made from bamboo trees are very sturdy and fashionable. You have an eye for fashion as well, you see.
reading_mnemonic: Now you can use that <kanji>box</kanji> to store all your <reading>ha</reading>rd<reading>co</reading>re (はこ) punk vinyl records. You're a real connoisseur, so you know that hardcore music should only ever be kept in bamboo boxes.

reading_mnemonic: Unconvinced by your flattery, the leader refuses to carry your <kanji>luggage</kanji>, so you get on your <reading>knee</reading>s (に) and beg them to carry it.

meaning_mnemonic: What I <radical>say</radical> is <radical>correct</radical> 100%! You may use it as <kanji>evidence</kanji> in this murder case.
reading_mnemonic: The officials force you to present this <kanji>evidence</kanji> in front of the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう), himself. Your knees quake, you feel like you're gonna be sick, but you try to stand up tall and tell him everything. After all, you know your <kanji>proof</kanji> is correct, so you shouldn't be so scared.

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <radical>tongue</radical> becomes too <radical>spicy</radical> for you to bear, it’s time to <kanji>quit</kanji> the jalapeño eating contest. You’ve been eating them for three hours now and the spiciness from the peppers is really burning your tongue. Throw in the towel, it’s time to quit the contest.

This kanji has another meaning too:

Eating isn't the only thing that makes your <radical>tongue</radical> <radical>spicy</radical>, so do certain <kanji>word</kanji>s. Say your favorite words out loud right now. Feel them on your tongue. Words are the spicy food of language!
reading_mnemonic: Oh, you're probably wondering who won that spicy food contest after you <kanji>quit</kanji> and became obsessed with <kanji>word</kanji>s instead. It was <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). Who did you expect? He was great with words AND never quitting when things got spicy.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>scooter</radical> with a <radical>zombie</radical> on it, going really <kanji>far</kanji> away. Someone tied that zombie to the scooter and now it's far off in the distance, groaning and growling.
reading_mnemonic: The zombie goes so <kanji>far</kanji>, that its life <reading>en</reading>ds (えん). Zombies need to eat to live (it's really all they need), but they go so far on their scooter trip, that they just give up and end it all.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>gate</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>gates</kanji> are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You want to pass through this <kanji>gate</kanji> but it’s guarded by… a <reading>mon</reading>ster (もん)!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>gate</radical> of <radical>horns</radical> will take you to <radical>heaven</radical>. These horns are <kanji>related</kanji> and <kanji>connected</kanji> to heaven in some way.
reading_mnemonic: They are <kanji>related</kanji> and <kanji>connected</kanji> to heaven because these are the horns that Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) made from his enemies. God said he could come into heaven if he made a gate of horns, so that's what he did.

visually_similar_kanji: 版, 仮, 板, 返, 坂, 飯, 販
meaning_mnemonic: If there's something about a <radical>building</radical> that people are <radical>anti</radical> towards, it's usually the <kanji>heights</kanji> aspect. Another thing would be if it's on a big <kanji>slope</kanji>. No one likes that kind of building.
reading_mnemonic: Another person you know who's afraid of <kanji>heights</kanji> is <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. Now wait, you protest, he flies a space ship! You're right, but only because he doesn't like to walk all the way up high buildings, it freaks him out. He flies up instead so he doesn't have to think about heights.

meaning_mnemonic: Going into a <radical>building</radical> made by a <radical>squid</radical> is <kanji>risky</kanji>. First of all, squids only have tentacles, no bones, and they make all of their buildings out of risky materials like kelp and sharp coral.
reading_mnemonic: "It's too <kanji>risky</kanji>, leave me!" the squid cries. "I'll save you, underwater citizen! Nothing is too risky for <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai!" The building is collapsing on the squid, the risk is so great, but Ken the samurai dives in and saves him!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>face</radical> radical and the <kanji>face</kanji> kanji are the same! But this isn't just a face like the one you're looking at your computer/phone with. It's the <kanji>surface</kanji> kind of face too!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>face</kanji> you're looking at, that has a lot of <kanji>surface</kanji> area, belongs to <reading>men</reading> (めん). Not a single man, but all men put together. It's hundreds of thousands of men's faces in a row.

meaning_mnemonic: When you swing your <radical>axe</radical>, the <radical>ground</radical> ends up covered in <radical>fins</radical>, because you're a <kanji>soldier</kanji>. Only a skilled axe soldier could make such precise cuts as to de-fin a bunch of fish like that.

The only thing nearby to light on fire is a bale of <reading>hay</reading> (へい). Well, it's not the best thing, but at least it will get these fish cooked.

The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger, but now they're bitter enemies and the tiger just stabbed the pig right in the chest with a knife.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>drama</kanji> is being put on by <reading>Gecki</reading> (げき), your childhood pet gecko. Gecki is playing all the parts, because as true drama fans know, one-gecko-shows are the highest form of art.

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>original</radical> radical and the <kanji>original</kanji> kanji are the same!

This kanji can also mean <kanji>field</kanji>, probably because that's what everything originally looked like before humans: just a bunch of fields.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> Japanese hero was <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji."

meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <radical>drum</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> it's time to <kanji>rejoice</kanji>! And because of your mouth drum your rejoicing will be loud and booming!
reading_mnemonic: You loudly <kanji>rejoice</kanji> for a while when suddenly someone runs over and shoves a <reading>key</reading> (き) in your mouth, locking it shut. You can't rejoice anymore! You need that key to unlock your mouth!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is so <radical>big</radical> that it's the <kanji>cause</kanji> of all your problems.
reading_mnemonic: Your big mouth is the <kanji>cause</kanji> behind all your friends and family moving to an <reading>inn</reading> (いん). They move to the inn so they don't have to live with you and hear you talk anymore.

visually_similar_kanji: 常, 賞, 党, 覚
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> will empty his <radical>mouth</radical> of all its <radical>dirt</radical> in the great <kanji>hall</kanji>. They all get together in some kind of <kanji>public chamber</kanji> and dish all the dirt (literal and figurative) that they've got.
reading_mnemonic: While the Vikings gather to spill the dirt in their <kanji>hall</kanji>, they also stuff their faces with <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts (どう). Ah yes, Vikings love to eat doughnuts when they talk trash.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical>, there's a <radical>gun</radical>. Its <radical>mouth</radical> points toward a <radical>plate</radical>. What's on the plate? Why, it's <kanji>salt</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>salt</kanji>, you think to yourself, "<reading>She owe</reading>s (しお) me big time, so I'm going to go ahead and snatch her salt!" Who is she, you ask? She's the lady who owns the salt. And the gun in the dirt, of course.

meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical> who works for the <kanji>government</kanji>. If you saw a bear out in the wild you might be afraid and try to run, but if you see a bear inside a building under a roof, don't be scared! It's just a government bear.
reading_mnemonic: The first <kanji>government</kanji> that allowed bears was set up by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He was all about conquering people and then using them as efficiently as possible. He discovered that bears are incredibly useful in government buildings as government workers.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're on the <radical>roof</radical> of the <radical>festival</radical> you'll have to <kanji>guess</kanji> what's actually going on below you. You can kind of see that there are rides and maybe food? It smells like food. But you have to guess on the specifics because you're above it and not in it.
reading_mnemonic: To get a better <kanji>guess</kanji>, you ask <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) for help. She's that little girl you know from some earlier mnemonics, and she happens to be up on the roof with you. Picture her as you ask, "What's your guess, Satsuki?"

visually_similar_kanji: 庶, 度, 革, 座
meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>yurt</radical> you use a <radical>towel</radical> as a <kanji>seat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Something about using a towel for a <kanji>seat</kanji> is very <reading>sexy</reading> (せき) to you. Probably because you associate it with sexy people using towel seats on the beach.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>viking</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>towel</radical> is a totally <kanji>normal</kanji> thing. It's <kanji>ordinary</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: It's <kanji>normal</kanji> for a viking to have a mouth towel, but your sloppy farmhand friend <reading>Joe</reading>(じょう) has a mouth towel too. That's a habit that's only <kanji>normal</kanji> for vikings, so why does he have one?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dry</radical> radical and the <kanji>dry</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>dry</kanji> Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He hates being wet, all of the Mongols do, so your job is to dry his entire body. And his clothes, and his horse. In fact, when it rains, you have to ride next to him keeping him dry by holding an umbrella above his head.

meaning_mnemonic: You hide <radical>poop</radical> in a <radical>cape</radical> as part of the <kanji>illusion</kanji> in your magic show. Your acts are kind of gross and this one involves creating the illusion of disappearing poop by hiding it within the folds of your cape.
reading_mnemonic: Somehow the poop cape <kanji>illusion</kanji> goes over really well. The crowd is giving you a standing ovation and right in the center is <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). He marches up to you, wipes a tear from his eye, and says, "Your illusion cape is wonderful. I must have it!"

visually_similar_kanji: 邸, 抵, 低, 紙
meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>canopy</radical> your <radical>clan</radical> digs in the <radical>ground</radical>, trying to get to the <kanji>bottom</kanji>. They want to build a nice home your entire clan can live in, but they need to get to the bottom before they'll start building.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly someone down in the hole shouts that they've reached the <kanji>bottom</kanji>, but it's full of water and they're all <reading>soak</reading>ed (そこ)!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Again</radical> and again, your <radical>heart</radical> comes back to the same person. Is this <kanji>romance</kanji>? Are you in <kanji>love</kanji>?
reading_mnemonic: But, remember that your <kanji>romance</kanji> isn’t a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん). You really wanna reserve it for the right person!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>criminal</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> will always be <kanji>sad</kanji>. No one chooses a life of crime if they're happy. And even if they seem like they're doing fine on the outside, deep down they're really sad.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sad</kanji> feelings fill the criminal's body with <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). This heat spreads and radiates out. If you walk next to them on the street, you'll feel the sad heat floating by you.

meaning_mnemonic: Put on <radical>cleat</radical>s so you can plant a kiss on your sweetheart's <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> — that's <kanji>love</kanji>. You'll be braving the harsh winter elements for love, so you put on your cleats to get a better grip on the snow. Sure, you could just wait for better weather to go see them, but then it wouldn't be true love, would it?
reading_mnemonic: Walking through the winter snow with your cleats on, you've gotta keep your <reading>eye</reading> (あい) on the prize. It's a really hard journey, but you keep your eye on the prize, which is your <kanji>love</kanji> and the time you'll get to spend with them.

visually_similar_kanji: 放, 取, 枚, 改, 賄

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, and you want to <radical>walk</radical> over it, so you have to <kanji>ford</kanji> it. You don’t walk across a tsunami, you <kanji>wade</kanji> across it.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>net</radical> is for <radical>someone</radical> who works in a <kanji>government office</kanji>. You'll also take someone from a <kanji>political office</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> can be used for <radical>comfort</radical>, but also for <kanji>medicine</kanji>. Sure, it’s a comfort to smell flowers because they smell nice, but one can also use them as medicine to heal people.

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Viking</radical> <radical>see</radical>, Viking <kanji>memorize</kanji>. That’s how Vikings learn things. They see something, and then they memorize it. Quite simple, really.

It can also mean <kanji>awake</kanji>. Just remember that Vikings can't see if they aren't awake. There won't be anything to memorize if their eyes are still closed, after all!
reading_mnemonic: Every morning, a <reading>cock</reading> (かく) crows and rouses the Vikings. Seeing this, one of the Vikings <kanji>memorize</kanji>s the cock crow so that he can mimic it and play pranks on his fellow Vikings.

meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>say</radical> what <radical>sound</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> makes, you must be very <kanji>discerning</kanji>. meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>poem</radical> about <radical>winter</radical> that you <radical>say</radical> to <kanji>warn</kanji> people against going outside. meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>criminal</radical> has done an <kanji>injustice</kanji> on the world or other people. Being a criminal is a <kanji>negative</kanji> thing, and even if it was just a <kanji>mistake</kanji>, it was still a crime.

Luckily, you have a very astute <kanji>nose</kanji>, allowing you to quickly assess the state of your twenty rice paddies all by yourself.

So you found him, grabbed him, and threw him into a <reading>shack</reading> (しゃく) — where you "borrow" a few parts of the leader himself, and do other terrible things to him.

reading_mnemonic: Now that you're about to <kanji>announce</kanji> something important, you should maybe get it nice and smooth in your mouth so the dirt can slide out easier. So take a big gulp of <reading>Coke</reading> (こく). Coke is just like, the dirt of soda anyway, you know?

reading_mnemonic: Who decided people have to <kanji>sit</kanji> like this? The C<reading>za</reading>r (ざ). The Czar wants to be above everyone, so he makes them sit on the dirt under canopies while he goes around on horseback or something, towering over them as they sit.

People think memories are kept in your brain, but that's not true. Your heart is where all of your most precious memories are kept, and when it dies, you forget them all.
reading_mnemonic: When someone <kanji>forget</kanji>s everything they're left with only one thing to do: go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). Bowling is easy, and there's nothing to forget. You pick up a ball. You drop it. Everything else is automatically taken care of.

reading_mnemonic: As you count each <kanji>counter for flat objects</kanji>, a bunch of <reading>mi</reading>ce (まい) show up and start climbing all over you. This won't do, so you take two slats and start smashing and flattening all the mice. Now that the mice are flat too, you can also use them as a counter for flat objects. Good job, mice.

meaning_mnemonic: The water from a <radical>tsunami</radical> can create a lot of <radical>energy</radical> when made into <kanji>steam</kanji>. Steam power used to be all the rage back in the day. Steam comes from water, water comes from tsunamis, so logically, tsunamis are a great source of energy.
reading_mnemonic: In order to contain this <kanji>steam</kanji> energy and store it for later, you lock it up in a box with a <reading>key</reading> (き). That way the energy can be used at a later time. Provided you don’t lose the key, that is.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>previous</radical>ly gave everything in this town a good <kanji>wash</kanji>. There are many laundromats in this town, so when the previous tsunami hit, all of the detergent mixed with the water and gave everything a good wash.
reading_mnemonic: It wasn't just the town that got a <kanji>wash</kanji>, it was the <reading>cen</reading>taurs (せん) too. (Centaurs happen to live in this town.) And being half horse, centaurs have a lot of hair that needs washing. Luckily, the soap tsunami gave them a good wash too.

meaning_mnemonic:
In a dangerous <radical>fire</radical>, a <radical>gambler</radical> will always try to <kanji>bake</kanji> something before fleeing to safety. It could be his own house on fire, and the gambler would still use the free heat source to get some baking done. Maybe he's gambling that those baked goods will offset the cost of a new home…

This kanji also means <kanji>burn</kanji>, because that's what happens when you expose something to a lot of heat.
reading_mnemonic: He used to <kanji>bake</kanji> for the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や). Baseball cakes, bat baguettes, that kind of thing. A career-ending kitchen injury forced him to retire. That's when he developed a gambling problem. But he still likes to bake whenever the Yankees are on TV.

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <radical>fire</radical> and a <radical>helicopter</radical> hovering beside it, there's going to be a lot of <radical>dirt</radical> and <kanji>smoke</kanji> billowing around. Mostly smoke, on account of the fire. Now it's in your eyes and mouth. It gets in your lungs and you can't breathe. Why, helicopter, why!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>smoke</kanji> is too much and you realize this is the <reading>en</reading>d (えん) for you. You're gonna die here!

meaning_mnemonic: Killing two <radical>tree</radical>s with a <radical>jackhammer</radical> is expressly <kanji>prohibit</kanji>ed. Don't get me wrong, you can rip up one tree with your jackhammer, but not two.
reading_mnemonic: The person who decided to <kanji>prohibit</kanji> jackhammering two trees is the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England. He's the only person who's able to prohibit certain things, so it had to be him.

meaning_mnemonic: You want your <radical>spirit</radical> to be <radical>simple</radical> so you practice <kanji>Zen Buddhism</kanji>. Zen is all about meditating and letting earthly things go. There's nothing more simple for your spirit than being <kanji>Zen</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this kanji is <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん), just like the <kanji>Zen</kanji> in <kanji>Zen Buddhism</kanji>. Pretty easy to remember, no? Just remember that the reading is the same as the meaning. It’s easy!

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>grain</radical> seems extra <radical>heavy</radical>, you know it's a different <kanji>kind</kanji>. Not all <kanji>type</kanji>s of grains are the same. So when you feel the heavy type, you know it isn't the same as the light kind.
reading_mnemonic: You sort all of the different <kanji>kind</kanji>s and <kanji>type</kanji>s by putting them in the right <reading>chu</reading>tes (しゅ). They slide away, probably to some big type-based piles you can't see.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>temple</radical> is <kanji>equal</kanji> to all of the other non-bamboo temples. Just because it's made of bamboo doesn't make it any less special and spiritual.
reading_mnemonic: The bamboo temple is also an <kanji>equal</kanji> distance away from the other temples in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. When you look at a map of とうきょう temples, you can measure them out and they'll all be perfectly equal.

other_meanings: Tie, Link Together, Connect Together, Tether, Fasten
visually_similar_kanji: 撃, 緊, 紫, 潔, 繁
meaning_mnemonic: You've got a <radical>car</radical>, a <radical>weapon</radical>, and some <radical>thread</radical> lying around. So of course you decide to <kanji>connect</kanji> them all together.
reading_mnemonic: There's only one reason you've <kanji>connected</kanji> all this together: <reading>Tuna</reading> (つな) fishing. Obviously!

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>prison</radical>, there lies a <radical>treasure chest</radical> containing a golden <kanji>chest</kanji> piece. This mighty chest armor will grant you protection from nearly any attack, because it is imbued with moon magic.
reading_mnemonic: Where is this <kanji>chest</kanji> armor from? It's from the moon. Now how would you say that if you were Canadian? It's from the <reading>moon, eh</reading> (むね). Right, this here chest armor is from the moon, eh.

meaning_mnemonic: Nestled in the light of the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>grass</radical> is a <radical>treasure chest</radical> that you can see with your <kanji>brain</kanji>. You close your eyes, and you can see the spot, but it's kept deep in your brain, and you have to use its power to find it.
reading_mnemonic: If you can unlock the secrets of your <kanji>brain</kanji> you'll have powers like <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう). Nostradamus was able to look inward at his own hidden brain treasure chest and see the future, so maybe you can be like him too.

kunyomi: いじ, いら, さいな
visually_similar_kanji: 荷, 可, 何, 同, 司, 伺, 阿, 河, 句, 旬, 詞, 飼
meaning_mnemonic: Using <radical>flowers</radical> to make a <radical>lip ring</radical> is always going to end in <kanji>frustration</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: After some <kanji>frustration</kanji>, you made your flower lip ring. Now you look like an <reading>Egy</reading>ptian  (いじ) pharaoh. Because all ancient Egyptian monarchs wore flower lip rings (historical fact)!

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> stuff to a <radical>river</radical>, giving it <kanji>instruction</kanji>. This river is a new river so it needs you to say things, giving it instruction on what to do. Otherwise the river wouldn’t know how to behave.
reading_mnemonic: While giving <kanji>instruction</kanji> to the river, you see a small boat coming down it. Inside the miniature boat is a rac<reading>coon</reading> (くん) captain and his raccoon crew. The raccoon captain is instructing them, “Stroke! Stroke!”

visually_similar_kanji: 計, 評, 討, 詳
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Say</radical> it at <radical>noon</radical>. That's the only time I will <kanji>allow</kanji> you to say it. That's the only time I will <kanji>permit</kanji> you to say it. Other than that, no saying anything. Noon is your window.
reading_mnemonic: Where do these archaic horrible rules exist? The smaller version of Kyoto, Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ). Normal Kyoto is just fine. This smaller one is where a group of people went to create their own little town with their own dumb rules.

meaning_mnemonic: You ride your scooter through the dirt while carrying a sheep because you're determined to attain something. Greatness? Glory? Everlasting fame? Maybe you'll attain a plural combination of all those things. After all, you are the best sheep-carrying off-road scooterist the world has ever seen.
reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>attain</kanji> that <kanji>plural</kanji> combination of glory, greatness, and fame, you get a <reading>tattoo</reading> (たつ) to celebrate: "world's greatest," in gothic lettering, above a picture of you and your sheep on your scooter.

visually_similar_kanji: 暗, 情, 請, 清, 精, 靖, 晴
meaning_mnemonic: Within the <radical>blue</radical> water, a <radical>conflict</radical> stirs, but is made <kanji>quiet</kanji> by the muffling power of liquid. Under this blue water is a great conflict between two sea monsters, but on the surface it appears peaceful and quiet as the water prevents sound from rising above the surface.
reading_mnemonic: As you watch below the <kanji>quiet</kanji> water, every once in a while a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) breaches the surface and quietly slices back down.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice</radical> you feed to a <radical>big</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical> can be of any <kanji>type</kanji>, <kanji>kind</kanji>, or <kanji>category</kanji>. It doesn't matter what kind of rice it is, the big geoduck will eat it.
reading_mnemonic: While eating every <kanji>type</kanji> and <kanji>kind</kanji> of rice from every <kanji>category</kanji>, the big geoduck has become even bigger. Its body is <reading>rui</reading>ned (るい). It's painfully obese. This geoduck has eaten itself to ruin.

meaning_mnemonic: What do you <radical>eat</radical> like a <radical>machine</radical>? <kanji>Candy</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>candy</kanji> in particular is just drops of hardened, clear sugar that looks like <reading>雨</reading> (あめ) drops.

meaning_mnemonic: If you stab somebody in the <radical>tongue</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical>, it’s sure to start a <kanji>riot</kanji> and cause <kanji>disorder</kanji>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done.
reading_mnemonic: Just now you realize that the man you stabbed in the tongue with your umbrella was none other than Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy Savage (らん). Being a professional wrestler, Macho Man Randy Savage is ready to throw down at a moment’s notice. A <kanji>riot</kanji> immediately erupts. It’s a battle royal with you and Randy at the epicenter.

other_meanings: Counter For Books, Counter For Volumes, Volume Counter, Number Of Books, Number Of Volumes, Books
meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>bookshelf</radical> as a <kanji>book counter</kanji>. Duh. What, are you gonna count them one by one? Okay, well maybe, but you should count them while they're nice and organized on the shelves. Otherwise counting is going to be a huge pain.
reading_mnemonic: You use this <kanji>book counter</kanji> method to count all the books <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) has in her house. Remember her? She's got, like, a ton of books, but she's just a little girl so she needs some help. That's where your book counter know-how comes in handy.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>power</radical> of your <radical>mouth</radical> lets you <kanji>add</kanji> words together to form a sentence. Marvel at the mighty additive power your mouth holds! You add words together in an amazing fashion!
reading_mnemonic: Your parents are so proud of you being able to <kanji>add</kanji> words together that they surprise you with a new <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Wow! You add some stickers to your bumper and add your favorite playlist to the car radio. Let's drive.

visually_similar_kanji: 便, 更, 硬, 使
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>history</radical> radical and the <kanji>history</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>History</kanji> was full of famous <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Sure there are people and stuff, but historical sheep are where it's at. There's the famous sheep samurai, the death sheep who works for the yakuza, just tons!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> loses its <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> so it picks them up in its <radical>mouth</radical> to take them to someone who's <kanji>morally good</kanji> enough to attach them back onto its head. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. Someone evil would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find someone <kanji>good</kanji> to reaffix them.
reading_mnemonic: Since you are <kanji>morally good</kanji>, you decide not to murder the sheep and harvest its organs. Instead, as a practitioner of the <kanji>good</kanji> teachings of <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん) Buddhism, you decided to help the sheep out. Your Zen teachings have increased the power of your healing abilities, so you fix the sheep up in no time.

meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>mouth</radical> to take a <radical>measurement</radical> of this <kanji>group</kanji>. Just stretch your mouth out and around every single person. Get 'em all in there.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>group</kanji> is so big it takes you till <reading>dawn</reading> (だん) to get your measurement: they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (とん) too!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> next to your <radical>village</radical> is where you <kanji>bury</kanji> the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.
reading_mnemonic: You don't just <kanji>bury</kanji> dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet <reading>u</reading>ni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive.

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>roof</radical> to keep yourself <radical>dry</radical> and safe from <kanji>outer space</kanji>. Look outside, above your roof, and you'll see outer space stretching above you.
reading_mnemonic: Why isn't it dry in <kanji>outer space</kanji>, you ask? Because of all the <reading>u</reading>ni (う) swimming around up there. They have nasty, wet, pointy spikes and they're all over the place.

meaning_mnemonic: You jumped off your <radical>roof</radical> for some <radical>reason</radical> and now you're floating in <kanji>midair</kanji>! You kick your legs a bit and move your arms like you're in water, but you're still just stuck there in midair.
reading_mnemonic: As you spin a bit in <kanji>midair</kanji> you look up and see <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう) looking down at you from a spaceship. He's laughing his Chewbacca laugh and you realize he has you trapped in his tractor beam.

visually_similar_kanji: 浴, 溶, 俗, 沿, 裕, 鉛, 谷
meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>roof</radical> over a <radical>valley</radical> it will change its <kanji>form</kanji>. Its <kanji>appearance</kanji> will alter completely!
reading_mnemonic: Its new <kanji>appearance</kanji> looks familiar to you, like it's a big <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう) cup! A valley with a roof on it looks exactly like a yogurt cup. Huh!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flag</radical> <radical>loiter</radical>s in a <radical>black hole</radical>. This flag marks (in the black hole) where you left your <kanji>footwear</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You grab your <kanji>footwear</kanji> from the black hole. In your footwear (thanks to the shelter they provided), some <reading>ree</reading>ds (り) have grown in!

meaning_mnemonic: To a <radical>narwhal</radical>, a <radical>towel</radical> is just normal <kanji>cloth</kanji>. They're always wet so towel cloth is all they know.
reading_mnemonic: If you use this type of <kanji>cloth</kanji> for your clothes and blankets people will call you a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). They think you're a fool who can't tell the difference between human cloth and towel cloth.

meaning_mnemonic: “Don’t <radical>loiter</radical> – <radical>run</radical>, <kanji>Junior</kanji>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run!
reading_mnemonic: Deciding not to loiter any longer, Indiana Jones <kanji>Junior</kanji> takes his dad’s advice and starts to run. Unfortunately he wasn’t paying attention to where his feet were and he stubbed his <reading>to</reading>e (と) on a jagged rock. His toe is in so much pain that he can’t bear to run any longer.

visually_similar_kanji: 待, 是, 提, 堤
meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>sun</radical> <radical>temple</radical>, it's likely you'll <kanji>acquire</kanji> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that.
reading_mnemonic: You managed to <kanji>acquire</kanji> some tobacco, but just as you're about to leave <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu comes marching up to you!! Or at least, his ghost does. He stares you dead in the eyes and says, "I didn't found the shogunate for you to acquire illegal goods and kill your body toking on my soil."

meaning_mnemonic: You'll work your <radical>soul</radical> to <radical>death</radical> if you're too <kanji>busy</kanji>. Being busy just isn't good for your soul. Take breaks. Go on vacation. Don't be so busy that you destroy yourself.
reading_mnemonic: Take time out of your <kanji>busy</kanji> life and go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) once in a while. In fact, you should probably go bowling once a week at least. Nothing brings energy back to your life like some relaxing bowling.

visually_similar_kanji: 放, 取, 敗, 妃
meaning_mnemonic: It's important to focus <radical>oneself</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so that one can emerge <kanji>renew</kanji>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU.
reading_mnemonic: Winter ends and, <kanji>renew</kanji>ed, you come out ready to start a new hobby: <reading>kay</reading>aking (かい)! Nothing says renewal like a brand new kayak and sense of purpose in life.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>sun</radical> is <radical>compare</radical>d to an <kanji>insect</kanji>, you’ll see that they're both shiny, but that the sun is much shinier than the insect.
reading_mnemonic: While you’re holding up an <kanji>insect</kanji> to the sun for comparison, a flock of <reading>con</reading>dors (こん) flies by, blocking out the sun. There are so many condors that they manage to totally block out the sun.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>easy</radical> radical and the <kanji>easy</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: What would be an <kanji>easy</kanji> reading for this kanji? <reading>い</reading>! The sound easy starts with!

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets <radical>together</radical> with <radical>water</radical>, only <kanji>violence</kanji> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence.
reading_mnemonic: But after a while, the sun and the water have had enough of <kanji>violence</kanji>. They decide to settle their differences with a friendly game of <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). Bowling is a great way to relieve stress and in the end, they bond over it.

meaning_mnemonic: At the edge of the <radical>cliff</radical>, two <radical>tree</radical>s mark the spot where you must <radical>stop</radical>, since any <kanji>continuation</kanji> requires a way across. The trees seem long enough to reach to the other side, but how are you going to chop them down?
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Continuation</kanji> is impossible unless you chop these trees down to make a bridge to the other side. You decide to use a <reading>wrecki</reading>ng (れき) ball. Luckily, there's one right by you. So you take the wrecking ball and knock the trees over, making a bridge with them.

meaning_mnemonic: A raging <radical>tsunami</radical> rises next to the calm <radical>sun</radical>. When you try to <radical>compare</radical> these two things, it's clear that they cannot <kanji>mix</kanji>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun.
reading_mnemonic: Just before the tsunami crashes over you, a <reading>con</reading>dor (こん) swoops out of the sky and grabs you up. This condor must be a <kanji>mix</kanji> — a normal condor is not strong enough to pick up a human. The condor must be mixed with something else. Like a pterodactyl.

meaning_mnemonic: Direct a <radical>tsunami</radical> into a <radical>canine</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical> to <kanji>decrease</kanji> the amount of water that strikes the surrounding area.
reading_mnemonic: After you and your canine <kanji>decrease</kanji> the tsunami's power, <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん) comes out to thank you. That tsunami was on track to wash away Genji's house, which would have forced him to majorly decrease his frivolous playboy activities.

meaning_mnemonic: Within the <radical>bamboo</radical> grove, someone asks your <radical>reason</radical> for being there, and you explain it's to harvest bamboo to craft a <kanji>flute</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You cut down the bamboo and whittle a <kanji>flute</kanji>. You start playing a song. You know the reason why. An alien spacecraft comes flying down and drops a box full of alien <reading>tech</reading> (てき) in front of you.

meaning_mnemonic:
On the bottom of <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>root</radical>s, there’s a <radical>stamp</radical> that tells you the <kanji>season</kanji> in which it was cut.

Additionally, the stamp also has information on the condition of the bamboo’s <kanji>joint</kanji>s, because no one wants to buy bamboo with damaged joints!
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>season</kanji> stamps are marked on bamboo <reading>sets</reading> (せつ). You can't buy a single banana or a single grape, and just like that, if you want some nice seasonal bamboo, you have to buy them in sets.

visually_similar_kanji: 格, 結, 続, 経
meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>thread</radical> in the middle of a <radical>kiss</radical>, you’re going to <kanji>entangle</kanji> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it.
reading_mnemonic: This isn't going well, so you pull out the weird kiss thread and <kanji>entangle</kanji> it around a <reading>rack</reading> (らく). Good thing that rack was there! Much better to have it entangled around a rack when you're trying to kiss someone.

visually_similar_kanji: 読, 結, 絡, 統, 銃
meaning_mnemonic: You have to gather <radical>thread</radical> to <radical>sell</radical> if you want to <kanji>continue</kanji> living. You want to make a living, don't you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day!
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>continue</kanji> to sell that thread because a Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (ぞく) bike gang is forcing you to do it. You see? If you want to continue to live, you have to appease this Bosozoku gang. You better keep selling!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tongue</radical> radical and the <kanji>tongue</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Yee-haw!
reading_mnemonic: You’re sound asleep in bed when your <kanji>tongue</kanji> drops out of your mouth and you start to drool, getting saliva all over the bed <reading>sheet</reading> (した). You wake up with a soggy patch of sheet near your mouth and wipe the drool off your face. Your significant other sees the whole thing.

meaning_mnemonic: If you see some <radical>flowers</radical> that are <radical>dry</radical>, pull them up and you'll find a <kanji>potato</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Potato</kanji>es are totally <reading>emo</reading> (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>right</radical> to show that you're still <kanji>young</kanji>. Your body still works, you're happy, you have your entire life ahead of you! And everything smells like flowers.
reading_mnemonic: When <kanji>young</kanji> people look to the right, they'll see their future: a <reading>walke</reading>r (わか). You know, those metal contraptions with tennis balls on the bottoms to make sure they don't scrape the floor. Everything may be flowers and happiness now, but your future is in a walker.

other_meanings: Speech Particle, Particle Of Speech, Grammar Particle
visually_similar_kanji: 調, 旬, 句, 伺, 可, 司, 飼, 同, 何, 洞, 阿, 荷, 河, 向, 銅, 胴, 苛
meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> to the <radical>director</radical> is judged immediately. You're having trouble understanding this <kanji>part of speech</kanji>, so he's trying to help you. But you say it over and over and he keeps saying you're wrong.
reading_mnemonic: The director asks you again, "What is the part of speech for the word <reading>shee</reading>p (し)?"

meaning_mnemonic: Give some <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>talent</radical>ed person and they'll have no problem accumulating <kanji>wealth</kanji>. People with talent can make money out of pretty much anything, so shellfish are like easy-mode.
reading_mnemonic: This talented person really starts accumulating <kanji>wealth</kanji> when their <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい) is unveiled. It's a half-man, half-shellfish cyborg that plays the <reading>xy</reading>lophone  (ざい), and everyone wants to buy it.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical> is what you always <kanji>take along</kanji> with you. Make sure they're <kanji>connect</kanji>ed well so you don't lose them!
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>take along</kanji> your scooter and your car. Anything else, you can do a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん) for!

meaning_mnemonic: Passed out in front of your <radical>gate</radical> lies a former <radical>leader</radical>. He's now a <radical>drunkard</radical>, but once ran a popular <kanji>clique</kanji> called the Cool Kids <kanji>Clan</kanji>. The clan has fallen apart, and he no longer has a clique to call his own.
reading_mnemonic: Eventually you get sick and tired of this washed up <kanji>clan</kanji> leader and you gather your own <kanji>clique</kanji> to chase this guy away from your gate and your property. You and your friends grab some <reading>bats</reading> (ばつ) and use these bats to beat the drunkard leader. Being beaten with bats frightens him, and he scurries away.

meaning_mnemonic: When they migrate to a <radical>river</radical>, a group of <radical>geoducks</radical> must do so in a certain <kanji>order</kanji> and <kanji>sequence</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, they go in birth-month <kanji>order</kanji>, starting from <reading>June</reading> (じゅん). No one knows why they follow this June-based <kanji>sequence</kanji>. But the geoducks born in June always go first in the migration order.

meaning_mnemonic: Regardless of whether or not you wear a <radical>hat</radical> while you <radical>jackhammer</radical>, you’re going to have a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.
reading_mnemonic: One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ) stand. Having a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical> has grown <radical>old</radical> from saying so many things. This is what makes them different from everyone else, they speak truly like an <kanji>individual</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As an <kanji>individual</kanji>, they must teach all the <reading>子</reading>s (こ) their way. Their individual way.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone stabbed the <radical>leader</radical> <radical>mole</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>overthrow</kanji> it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole.
reading_mnemonic: Where do leaders get <kanji>overthrow</kanji>n the most? In <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Just think back in Japanese history, back when everyone was at war with one another. People were taking over and getting overthrown and then that guy gets overthrown and then THAT guy gets overthrown. Basically, it used to be hard to stay a leader in とうきょう.

meaning_mnemonic: You walk into this <radical>tree</radical> and hit your <radical>head</radical> on it, then a <radical>knife</radical> falls out of it to <kanji>stab</kanji> you. Ow! What the heck?! What was a knife doing in that tree?
reading_mnemonic: There's nothing more dangerous than a tree that likes to <kanji>stab</kanji>, so you get your <reading>saw</reading> (さ) and start to saw it down. Trees that stab get sawed.

meaning_mnemonic: Hanging off the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> is a <radical>sun</radical>-worshipping <radical>child</radical> with a <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries out to the sun to save them from this cruel fate. Even the thickness of their unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to climb back up on their own.
reading_mnemonic: The child glances up at their <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow and yells, "<reading>ah, two</reading> (あつ)!" Yup, it turns out the sun misunderstood the child's pleas for help. Instead of pulling them up from the cliff, it gave them a second thick unibrow on top of the first one.

meaning_mnemonic: If you put your <radical>mouth</radical> on a <radical>tree</radical> and try to eat it, you’re probably a <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> individual (unless you’re a woodchuck). You don’t need to eat this tree, you have plenty of food at home. Get your mouth off that tree you distressed child.
reading_mnemonic: You thought you were the most <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> person in this situation, but then you look up and see a very equally distressed and troubled <reading>con</reading>dor (こん). The tree you've been mouthing is its home. And now you've slobbered all over it, ruining this condor's day.

meaning_mnemonic: Under any <radical>cliff</radical>, there's some <radical>dirt</radical> that's under a lot of <kanji>pressure</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You want to increase the <kanji>pressure</kanji>, so you stack on a second cliff. "<reading>Ah, two</reading> (あつ)?!" the dirt cries out in dismay. This dirt is tough, but it's really starting to feel the pressure now.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> sticks a <radical>stick</radical> into the <radical>dirt</radical> to see what might <kanji>exist</kanji> underneath it. Narwhals live in the sea, you see. So they're convinced nothing can exist anywhere else.
