meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> stuck in the ground with a little bit of <radical>fur</radical> coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a <kanji>tail</kanji>. meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>tree</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> sits with <radical>twenty</radical> little <kanji>contraptions</kanji>. There's little electronic ones, little bopping ones, little walking ones... twenty of them.

meaning_mnemonic: Next to a <radical>tree</radical>, you spot <radical>poop</radical>, not once but twice. Only a <radical>drunkard</radical> would be the type of <radical>person</radical> to not use the nearby <kanji>machine</kanji> toilet. There's a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.
reading_mnemonic: Oh, I see — the door to the outhouse with the <kanji>machine</kanji> toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn't have the <reading>key</reading> (き). If he had a machine like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he's reduced to pooping under the tree instead.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flood</radical> and a <radical>fire</radical>! At the same time? This is a <kanji>disaster</kanji>!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>animal</radical> kingdom, a <radical>snake</radical> is the most likely to commit a <kanji>crime</kanji>. Remember the Garden of Eden? The snake was the bad guy. Ever since then, snakes are the animal most known for committing crimes.

meaning_mnemonic: Sitting on the <radical>lid</radical> of a toilet, you're praying your <radical>poop</radical> <radical>explosion</radical> will be flushed away, beseeching the <radical>cross</radical> decorating the bathroom wall. The poop needs to be one hundred <kanji>percent</kanji> flushed away because you're on a date, and you don't want even one percent of your explosion left for them to see.
reading_mnemonic: It was extra important that there was zero <kanji>percent</kanji> poop left, because you're not on a date just anywhere, you're at the <reading>Ritz</reading> (りつ)!

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> on the <radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Life</radical> and <kanji>give birth</kanji> to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it! In your despair, you throw all your <kanji>property</kanji> off the cliff too.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>give birth</kanji>, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん)! He caught your baby! And all your <kanji>property</kanji>.

Sometimes Wario cuts himself by accident and just becomes <reading>わ</reading> (which is all he says too).

meaning_mnemonic: Wrap <radical>vines</radical> around a <radical>stool</radical> to <kanji>obtain</kanji> it. Don't worry about paying for it, sneak into the stool store and tie some vines around the legs. Then when you leave, pull the vines and the stool will come out after. That's how you obtain a stool!
reading_mnemonic: Today you want to <kanji>obtain</kanji> a new pair of <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). You tie your vines around the stool they're on, and slowly inch them toward the door.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mouth</radical> that wants <radical>peace</radical> can <kanji>call</kanji> for it. If you don’t have a mouth, you can’t call for peace. So use your mouth and call for peace when you can. Peace is great.
reading_mnemonic: But before you <kanji>call</kanji> for peace, you must first placate the masses. To do so, you astound them with your <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ) skills. Once they are so entranced by how talented you are with a yo-yo, you easily convince them to make peace.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dirt</radical> can <radical>become</radical> a <kanji>castle</kanji> at any time. You just have to have the right conditions. The right time, the right people, and any patch of dirt can grow into a huge castle.
reading_mnemonic: Once you turn dirt into a <kanji>castle</kanji>, that's all <reading>she wro</reading>te (しろ). That's it. It's done. The story is over.

meaning_mnemonic: You need to go up on the <radical>roof</radical> and <radical>slide</radical> down <radical>seven</radical> times to make this your <kanji>house</kanji>. A house isn't a <kanji>home</kanji> until you've slid down it exactly seven times, you know.
reading_mnemonic: If you try to slide down your new <kanji>house</kanji> and you land on a <reading>tack</reading> (たく), that means the house has rejected you. It isn't your home now. You need to leave and find a new home.

meaning_mnemonic: Take this <radical>road</radical>'s <radical>measurement</radical>. Hmm. It seems a bit too long. As you measure it, you continue down this road, wondering where it will <kanji>lead</kanji> you.
reading_mnemonic: Where does the road that you're measuring <kanji>lead</kanji> to? To a <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (どう) shop!

meaning_mnemonic: From the top of a <radical>mountain</radical> you see something that looks like a <radical>big</radical> <radical>lip ring</radical> jutting out into the ocean: it's a <kanji>cape</kanji>! You know, the geological formation where a big piece of land sticks out into the ocean? That kind of cape.
reading_mnemonic: Looking down at the <kanji>cape</kanji>, you realize capes always make the coastline look jagged, like a <reading>saw</reading> or <reading>key</reading> (さき). Thanks for keeping the coastline interesting, you saw-key capes!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> of water falls from a <radical>bear</radical> onto the <radical>ground</radical> and needs to be wiped up with a <radical>towel</radical>. Only a <kanji>teacher</kanji> or an <kanji>expert</kanji> could get away with getting close to this wet bear to wipe up after it.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>teacher</kanji> tells you to start with something smaller, after all, you're not an <kanji>expert</kanji> yet. You have to practice on a wet <reading>shee</reading>p (し). "I became a wet, dangerous animal expert by starting with sheep, you will too!" your teacher says.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>morning</radical>, if you want your <radical>hat</radical> to <radical>dry</radical>, you need to hang it on a <kanji>tree trunk</kanji>. In the morning, everything is covered in dew. The grass is wet, the leaves are wet, but the tree trunk isn't wet! It was protected by the rest of the tree, so you can hang your hat there to dry.
reading_mnemonic: You lean against the <kanji>tree trunk</kanji>, waiting for your hat to dry, and suddenly you realize Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) is on the other side of it. You look around and see that all of the tree trunks around you have Mongols drying their hats under them.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>bow</radical> and you want to make it <radical>long</radical>. To do that, you'd naturally just <kanji>stretch</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>stretch</kanji> the bow, you hear someone running at you. "That's my bow you're stretching!" yells Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう). She is not happy that you're stretching her things. You should probably try to un-stretch it, put it down, and run before she beats you.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Loiter</radical>ing around with a <radical>brush</radical>? Sorry, but you're breaking the <kanji>law</kanji>. If you have a brush, that's okay. If you're loitering, that's okay. If you combine the two? Well... watch your back.
reading_mnemonic: Where were you loitering with your brush, breaking the <kanji>law</kanji>? Right outside the <reading>Ritz</reading> (りつ) Hotel. You'd think that it would be okay since you were staying there, but the law is the law.

visually_similar_kanji: 族, 旅, 旗, 妨, 訪, 坊, 旋, 紡, 放, 防, 肪
meaning_mnemonic: Moving in the <radical>direction</radical> of a <radical>gun</radical>, an <radical>alligator</radical> can <kanji>carry out</kanji> a murder once it reaches it. This alligator wants to kill someone. The alligator wants to carry out their execution.
reading_mnemonic: In order to <kanji>carry out</kanji> this murder, the alligator has to sneak up on its prey, so it can shoot it. You look across the water and see a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) grazing by the shore. The alligator is going to carry out a murder on that sheep!

meaning_mnemonic: Take a <radical>tree</radical> and make two <radical>moon</radical>-shaped <kanji>shelf</kanji> units with it. Moon radical-shaped, that is. Those moon radicals standing side by side kinda look like a shelf, don't you think? The tree on the left is just there to remind you it's made of wood, I guess. A lovely wooden shelf.
reading_mnemonic: To match the moon radical shape, this would have to be a pretty tall <kanji>shelf</kanji>, meaning you can store a <reading>ton-a</reading>-stuff (たな) on it.

visually_similar_kanji: 駅, 訳, 択, 況
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> of <radical>shrimp</radical> crashes into a <kanji>swamp</kanji>. Now the swamp is filled with shrimp. They used to live in the ocean, but the tsunami has carried them to their new home in the swamp.
reading_mnemonic: Your house was right next to the <kanji>swamp</kanji> and on this side of your house you had many a <reading>tack</reading> (たく) there to hang things on. Now, on every tack there is skewered a shrimp. The force of the tsunami drove them into the tacks on the side of your house.

meaning_mnemonic: Riding a <radical>tsunami</radical> you see a <radical>turkey</radical> carrying a <radical>cross</radical>, but that’s pretty <kanji>standard</kanji> here. This is your dreamland. You always dream about tsunamis and the turkeys carrying crosses that ride them. This might be strange for other people, but for you it’s pretty normal.
reading_mnemonic: These wacky dreams are only <kanji>standard</kanji> fare in <reading>June</reading> (じゅん) though. You don’t have them any other time of the year, just in June. You don’t know why June is the only time you have dreams about tsunami riding turkeys, but that’s just the way it is.

meaning_mnemonic: There's going to be a <radical>tsunami</radical>. So you get up on your <radical>roof</radical>. You see people across the <radical>street</radical>, in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>. They watch as you put on a pair of <radical>fins</radical>. And you begin <kanji>acting</kanji>. This is your last chance to <kanji>perform</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: As the <kanji>acting</kanji> <reading>en</reading>ds (えん), so do you all.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> can <radical>see</radical> the <kanji>present time</kanji> for what it really is. The future isn't important. The past isn't important. The present is when everything <kanji>appear</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: At the <kanji>present time</kanji> the king is <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). The time has finally come for him to get serious, and as they say, there's no time like the present.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sick</radical> <radical>sheep</radical> is <kanji>itchy</kanji> and it can barely sit still. Help the poor sheep!
reading_mnemonic: Even though the sheep is <kanji>itchy</kanji>, look how <reading>kah-yu</reading>te (かゆ) it is! It’s not just cute. It’s kah-yute!

meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>hand</radical> over your <radical>eye</radical> to <kanji>watch over</kanji> others.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>watch over</kanji> your friends and neighbors you see movement in the distance. Oh no, it's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) and his army!

meaning_mnemonic: If you can eat <radical>grain</radical>s while running up <radical>stairs</radical>, you'll <kanji>excel</kanji> at everything.
reading_mnemonic: In order to <kanji>excel</kanji> at this, though, you need a good pair of <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう).

meaning_mnemonic: How do you make a <radical>hole</radical> nice and <radical>big</radical>? You gotta <kanji>stab</kanji> something in it. Just <kanji>thrust</kanji> it right in there. And make sure your movements are really <kanji>sudden</kanji>. Stabs and thrusts are more effective when they're sudden.
reading_mnemonic: Give that hole one last big <kanji>stab</kanji>, now you've <reading>totes</reading> (とつ) showed that hole who's boss. What did I tell you about the <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>thrust</kanji> technique? It's totes super effective. Like, totes.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stop</radical> a <radical>spoon</radical> from moving by tying it with <radical>thread</radical> that's <kanji>purple</kanji>. The spoon wouldn't stop moving around, so you had to use your favorite purple thread to make it stop. It's the strongest thread you have.
reading_mnemonic: To remember this reading, think about how the village you previously went to was all <kanji>purple</kanji>. It was the "<reading>村先</reading>" (むらさき) that you went to.

meaning_mnemonic: Reaching your <radical>ear</radical> is the <radical>sound</radical> of a <radical>drunkard</radical> who can’t find <kanji>employment</kanji>. You hear him before you see him because he’s behind some trash cans. Being a drunkard, he’s like, super wasted and just kind of rambling to himself, making strange sounds. No wonder he can’t find employment.
reading_mnemonic: Since this guy is such a pathetic drunkard, it comes as no <reading>shock</reading> (しょく) that he can’t find <kanji>employment</kanji>. If he did find employment, I would be filled with both shock and awe.

visually_similar_kanji: 製, 載, 我, 装, 栽
meaning_mnemonic: You place a <radical>cross</radical> on this <radical>drunkard</radical>'s <radical>clothes</radical> to show him you <kanji>judge</kanji> him. In fact, you yell, "I JUDGE YOU FOR BEING DRUNK AND WEARING THESE CLOTHES, TAKE THIS!"
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>judge</kanji> each other, your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい) comes stomping over and slams the drunkard against the wall. With your trusty cyborg coming to your rescue, you can continue to judge this guy all you want.

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> that <radical>flowers</radical> held by a <radical>turkey</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> are good to <kanji>defend</kanji> yourself with. Even better than a guard dog they say. People are so confused by the turkey sitting on a stool holding flowers that they just lose their will to fight. This turkey is great to defend yourself and your home.
reading_mnemonic: The only thing this flower-bearing turkey can't <kanji>defend</kanji> against is <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご). Godzilla is pretty much undefeatable, especially for a turkey. The turkey is totally unable to defend anything from the mighty Godzilla.

visually_similar_kanji: 貨, 賀, 貸, 貿, 資
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dirt</radical> shifts <radical>direction</radical> in <radical>winter</radical>, and instead of the usual stuff it starts to grow <radical>shellfish</radical> that are very <kanji>extravagant</kanji>. These shellfish are so extravagant because they can only be grown in the dirt in winter (after the dirt has shifted "direction" and started sustaining shellfish instead of plants, that is).
reading_mnemonic: To make this experience even more <kanji>extravagant</kanji>, you eat them with a <reading>zei</reading>ber (ぜい), a German saber. A fork is just too plain for these extravagant shellfish — you gotta use a zeiber for maximum extravagance.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leather</radical> radical and the <kanji>leather</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Cool!
reading_mnemonic: One way to get <kanji>leather</kanji> is to skin a male chicken, a <reading>cock</reading> (かく). Not a very efficient way to get leather, but one way nonetheless.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>demon</radical> radical and the <kanji>demon</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Wicked!
reading_mnemonic: How do you keep a <kanji>demon</kanji> locked up? Use a <reading>key</reading> (き). Use a lock and key and keep that demon locked up safely behind bars so he can’t get out and do bad demon stuff.

visually_similar_kanji: 洪, 併, 共, 借
meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>leader</radical> wants to work <radical>together</radical>, it means they want what you have to <kanji>offer</kanji>. Congrats! Now you can <kanji>accompany</kanji> them everywhere and offer them hot towels and bottled water, or whatever it is you do…
reading_mnemonic: Once a year, the leader will <kanji>offer</kanji> you a vacation in <reading>きょう</reading>と. It's an all-expenses-paid trip! The catch is that you have to <kanji>accompany</kanji> your leader to きょうと…

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>lantern</radical> on top of a <radical>knife</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical>. You walk up to take the knife and lantern when you realize it's just a <kanji>model</kanji>. It all looked real from far away, but now that you're up close you can see none of it is real.
reading_mnemonic: You touch the <kanji>model</kanji> and see that it's made of <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)! Someone really into lanterns and knives must have been given this model cake as a birthday present! Though they left it out here so they probably didn't like it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> where you just <radical>stand</radical> and <radical>see</radical> is a <kanji>boundary</kanji>. You don't want to cross the boundary, you just stand there and see over it. As a general rule, you can stand in the dirt and see beyond boundaries, but you don't usually cross them.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>boundary</kanji> you're looking at now is the <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょう) boundary. Kyoto is one of the most famous places in Japan, so you can imagine its boundary is really clear and marked by all kinds of boundary signs that say KYOTO.

meaning_mnemonic: You're about to enter a <radical>roof</radical> that has your <radical>number</radical> on it so you can face the <kanji>judge</kanji>. You've been sitting here for what feels like hours, waiting for your number to come up. Finally the time has come—the judge will see you now.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>judge</kanji> is not happy with you. He tells you to come closer and when you do, he takes his gavel and hits you in the <reading>shin</reading>s (しん). Ouch!

visually_similar_kanji: 屈, 居, 涙, 房, 戻, 泥, 堀, 掘, 握, 漏, 塀, 据, 遅
meaning_mnemonic: The American <radical>flag</radical> is the <radical>reason</radical> you need to <kanji>deliver</kanji> this package. The flag is inside the package, and you need to deliver it to the president. He lost his old flag, so now it’s up to you to deliver this new one to him. What more of a reason do you need?
reading_mnemonic: To <kanji>deliver</kanji> this flag is something you just have <reading>to do</reading> (とど). Need to do. Want to do. There is no one else to do it. This is something only you are equipped to do.

meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>flag</radical> under the <radical>blackjack</radical> table that you can <radical>kick</radical> in order to <kanji>expand</kanji> the table. Sometimes you only have a few people playing blackjack so you don’t need to kick the flag at all, and sometimes  there are many people playing blackjack so you need to kick the flag many times in order to expand it to a proper size.
reading_mnemonic: The blackjack table does have a limit though of how many times it will <kanji>expand</kanji>, and that limit is <reading>ten</reading> (てん). You can only kick the flag to get the table to expand ten times.

meaning_mnemonic: Behind the <radical>flag</radical> lies a <radical>mask</radical>—yet another <kanji>layer</kanji> of secrecy. You’re standing in front of a crowd, giving a rousing speech. Hiding your face is the flag of your country, and behind that flag you’re also wearing a mask, just in case the flag falls down. The extra layer of secrecy is just to be safe.
reading_mnemonic: Someone jumps up on stage and starts peeling off your <kanji>layer</kanji>s! You stand there, first goes the flag, then the mask, then ... your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) is laid bare. No, literally. You don't have a body, your soul was under that mask. And now it's floating there for all to see.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>sheep</radical> tries its hoof at <radical>construction</radical>, it gains <kanji>distinction</kanji>. Now that is something that really sets a sheep apart! After all, have you ever seen a sheep working in construction?
reading_mnemonic: The extra <kanji>distinction</kanji> of this sheep is that its really skilled with a <reading>saw</reading> (さ). That's why it's so good at construction.

meaning_mnemonic: There are people under a <radical>canopy</radical> on the <radical>street</radical> forming their own <kanji>agency</kanji>. They're banding together right here in the street, making a new <kanji>government office</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic:
This new <kanji>agency</kanji> is just starting to make progress when you hear a low rumble... then a screech.

"THIS IS MY STREET. NO NEW AGENCIES ON MY STREET!" Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) cries as she barrels into everyone.

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> at <radical>dawn</radical> to <kanji>carry</kanji> many things. You have to carry yourself out of bed. You have to carry your backpack or purse or laptop bag to school or work. Your fingers have to carry a lot of weight around at dawn.
reading_mnemonic: Once you're <kanji>carry</kanji>ing everything, and the dawn sun is shining bright, you start getting <reading>tan</reading> (たん). Especially those fingers you're using to carry things.

meaning_mnemonic: What might cause a <radical>tree</radical> to <radical>slide</radical> down a <radical>jet</radical> would be if its <kanji>stock</kanji>s and <kanji>share</kanji>s took a dive in the market. This tree was on a jet for an important investor meeting when it got the news that its stocks and shares had just plummeted. Being very upset, the tree got up and got on the emergency slide out of the jet and plummeted into the ground just like his stocks and shares.
reading_mnemonic: Once the tree hits the ground with his <kanji>stock</kanji>s and his <kanji>share</kanji>s, the impact creates a large <reading>KABOO</reading>M (かぶ)! Stocks hit the ground - KABOOM! Shares! KABOOM! Tree! KABOOOOOOM~!

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical> there's a <radical>ceremony</radical> where everyone keeps <radical>stop</radical>ping. This stopping ceremony is being performed by the <kanji>military</kanji>. They'll march one direction, then stop and turn, then march another direction, then stop again.
reading_mnemonic: You look closer at the people in the <kanji>military</kanji> and realize that every time they stop they take a drink of <reading>boo</reading>ze (ぶ)!

reading_mnemonic: What is the worst thing that could <kanji>burn</kanji> in this fire? Your <reading>nen</reading>doroid (ねん) collection. You've spent a lot of time and money collecting all these cool and rare and unique nendoroids and now they've all burned in the fire.

meaning_mnemonic: You have an <radical>animal</radical> for a <radical>husband</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> that are <kanji>narrow</kanji>. This animal husband of yours is a goat. A goat with narrow horns. Why is this animal your husband? You’re weird, that’s why.
reading_mnemonic: I’m not even going to get into the <reading>sema</reading>ntics (せま) of how this weird relationship of yours works. Nope, this reading explanation is on the straight and <kanji>narrow</kanji>. Need to know basis. Classified. All that junk. There will be no discussion of the semantics between you and your goat lover.

reading_mnemonic: The king also explains that this <kanji>loop</kanji> technique was used by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) when he was conquering cities. He'd loop around the entire place with a net and trap them.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>spirit</radical> blesses your <radical>older brother</radical> it's time to <kanji>celebrate</kanji>! This isn't something that happens every day to everyone's older brother. Yours is very good and very lucky. So celebrate with him!
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the two of you <kanji>celebrate</kanji>d too much, and you went a little crazy. The spirit grabbed your brother and <reading>shook</reading> (しゅく) him. Shook him so hard his head popped off.

meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical>. It is pulling the bamboo off, because it wants to use it to make a long <kanji>pipe</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>pipe</kanji> will be for Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん), who would like some pipes for his house.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>door</radical> leading to the <radical>moon</radical> can be broken down with one’s <kanji>shoulder</kanji>. It’s not a very sturdy door to the moon, so it’s quite easy to drop your shoulder and ram it open.
reading_mnemonic: "Wow, your <kanji>shoulder</kanji> is just like my <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた)!" you hear someone shout. As you turn you're just in time to see a man catapulting through his own moon door!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> shines on your <radical>roof</radical> in the <radical>evening</radical> and a <radical>snake</radical> suddenly appears! Wait, that's not a snake, it's your <kanji>arm</kanji>, sticking out from under the roof.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>arm</kanji> is exposed to the moon and the outside and you feel a chill. Where are your clothes? Ah, you're n<reading>ude, eh</reading> (うで)?! I guess it is pretty common to sleep in the nude, eh?

meaning_mnemonic: You approach the <radical>Moon</radical> in a <radical>helicopter</radical> and see a <radical>woman</radical> there on the surface, touching her <kanji>waist</kanji>. She's posing with one hand on her waist, like she's Sailor Moon or something. I guess that would explain what she's doing here on the Moon!
reading_mnemonic: Once you get close, you see that her <kanji>waist</kanji> looks weird and… puffy? You realize she's stuffed some <reading>子 shee</reading>p (こし) under her skirt's waistband to line her waist with them. Guess it's cold up here on the moon, so the 子 sheep keep her waist warm. And they had to be 子 sheep, otherwise they wouldn't be small enough to fit under her clothes.

visually_similar_kanji: 裂, 栽, 載, 装, 裁, 袋
meaning_mnemonic: In an attempt to <radical>control</radical> your <radical>clothes</radical>, you <kanji>manufacture</kanji> a mind control device. This mind control device will allow you to control the mind of your clothes and all that they do. You just need to manufacture it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>manufacture</kanji> these clothes to control your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). It's hard to manufacture, you have to do a lot of work, but you manage to make your clothes control your saber. Now you don't need to rely on your hands!

meaning_mnemonic: A man who is <radical>husband</radical> material can <radical>see</radical> a <kanji>standard</kanji> woman and think she’s the greatest thing ever. This man will make a great husband. Even though the lady is pretty standard, the husband treats her like she’s anything but.

visually_similar_kanji: 祝, 新, 規, 親

Hmm.

meaning_mnemonic:
The  <radical>fortune</radical> radical and the <kanji>fortune</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! This can also mean <kanji>occupy</kanji>, maybe because learning your fortune shows you how you're going to occupy your life. Or how it will occupy you…

You haven't seen the radical in a while, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kanji: Put your toe in your mouth to learn your <kanji>fortune</kanji>. The taste will tell you everything you need to know about your fortune. But your toe has to <kanji>occupy</kanji> your mouth first for it to work.

Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>soul</radical> floating around a <radical>tombstone</radical> acting <kanji>suspicious</kanji>. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird.

Even more suspicious, the soul seems to be holding a <reading>ke</reading>ttle (け). Considering the soul is already dead, this doesn't seem like something it will need.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>ego</radical>... it's totally out of control. <kanji>I</kanji> mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's <kanji>me</kanji>. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.

other_meanings: Mop, Mopping, Wiping, Wipe Up, Wiping Up, Wipe Off, Wiping Off
meaning_mnemonic: You're using your <radical>fingers</radical> to do something important for this <radical>ceremony</radical>'s <radical>construction</radical>. What's really important for this ceremony's construction, using your fingers? Well… you <kanji>wipe</kanji> the floors.
reading_mnemonic: Now <kanji>wipe</kanji> these floors, you <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ)!

meaning_mnemonic: When you hold out your <radical>fingers</radical>, a <radical>person</radical> — and then a second <radical>person</radical> — stomps them into the <radical>dirt</radical>, leaving you with a serious finger <kanji>sprain</kanji>. meaning_mnemonic: You're trying to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cause a <radical>landslide</radical> so you have to <kanji>shake</kanji> the earth. meaning_mnemonic: "Take your <radical>fingers</radical>. <radical>Now</radical>, put them on your foe's <radical>heart</radical> and <kanji>twist</kanji>." These are the words of your martial arts master as he teaches you his final, ultimate technique: the "finger-heart twister."

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>fingers</radical> reaching towards you asking you to <radical>accept</radical> to <kanji>instruct</kanji> them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them!
reading_mnemonic: "Yes! I will <kanji>instruct</kanji> you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (じゅ) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>old</radical> <radical>winter</radical> is to blame for today's <kanji>circumstance</kanji>. It is the <kanji>reason</kanji> things are bad now.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> going down your <radical>dry</radical> face is just <kanji>sweat</kanji>.

visually_similar_kanji: 阿, 何, 荷, 可, 同, 司, 伺, 洞, 向, 句, 旬, 詞, 飼, 銅, 胴, 苛
meaning_mnemonic: During a <radical>tsunami</radical>, your <radical>lip ring</radical> is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a <kanji>river</kanji>. meaning_mnemonic: There once was an <radical>animal</radical> with an <radical>insect</radical> friend who felt very <kanji>alone</kanji> unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>grass</radical> near a <radical>rice paddy</radical> sits a <radical>creeper</radical> that is some sort of a <radical>dog</radical> <kanji>beast</kanji>, a vicious <kanji>animal</kanji>. meaning_mnemonic: Out of <radical>bamboo</radical>, you make a <radical>brush</radical> – a <kanji>writing brush</kanji>. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in the <radical>village</radical> you <kanji>long for</kanji>. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you <kanji>yearn</kanji> for it.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>sun</radical> while holding a <radical>comb</radical> in a <radical>cage</radical> and sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>, you comb your hair in your <kanji>spare time</kanji>. reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>extreme</kanji> challenge could only be solved by one person: <reading>Goku</reading> (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z! He has a special cloak that'll allow you to plant trees in record time, so he quickly <reading>cloaks you</reading> (きょく) to help with your extreme task.

meaning_mnemonic: Cut this <radical>comb</radical> up with your <radical>weapon</radical> and turn it into the <kanji>steps</kanji> for some <kanji>stairs</kanji>.

other_meanings: Thick, Concentrated, Condensed, Strong, Dark, Deep, Substantial
meaning_mnemonic: After a <radical>tsunami</radical> hit your <radical>farming</radical> land, you're gonna see a lot of <kanji>dense</kanji> silt left behind. This <kanji>thick</kanji> layer really enriches the soil, and your crops will come out tasting extra thick and dense in flavor.
reading_mnemonic: Know who’s likely responsible for this <kanji>dense</kanji>, <kanji>thick</kanji> layer of silt? <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう). He’s the one who urged you to buy this farmland in the first place, likely because he predicted the tsunami would bring this thick layer of silt.

meaning_mnemonic: When someone is <radical>sick</radical> in order to diagnose the <radical>correct</radical> cause and treatment, you need to check their <kanji>symptom</kanji>s. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them!
reading_mnemonic: You need to figure out the <kanji>symptom</kanji>s the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head.

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>sick</radical> <radical>mama</radical> tries to do a <radical>task</radical> she's filled with <kanji>pain</kanji>!

meaning_mnemonic: Closing each <radical>eye</radical> is something that the <radical>peoples</radical> do before they <kanji>sleep</kanji>. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.

meaning_mnemonic: Setting up a <radical>stand</radical> on the top of a <radical>mountain</radical>, you <radical>rake</radical> all the rocks to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.
reading_mnemonic: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a <reading>tan</reading> (たん). You lie next to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.

meaning_mnemonic: You pull on a <radical>thread</radical> as you <radical>stand</radical> with a <radical>towel</radical> wrapped around you. This allows you to <kanji>tighten</kanji> the towel.
reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>tighten</kanji>ing your towel because you've been eating a lot of <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots lately. You want to keep a slim figure, and rather than give up your beloved tater tots, you've just opted to constrict yourself with this towel, corset-style.

meaning_mnemonic: Taking a <radical>thread</radical> and moving to the <radical>sound</radical> of the music, a <radical>drunkard</radical> makes a <kanji>weave</kanji> through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.
reading_mnemonic: This drunkard is really <reading>chic</reading> (しき), but he's just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he's using the thread to weave back together is one of his fancy chic outfits.

meaning_mnemonic: If you eat a <radical>rice paddy</radical> the size of the <radical>moon</radical>, your <kanji>stomach</kanji> is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.
reading_mnemonic: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended <kanji>stomach</kanji>. Bam! The <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.

meaning_mnemonic: Inside this <radical>moon</radical> is a <radical>black hole</radical>... haha just kidding, it's your <kanji>belly</kanji>! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good <kanji>stomach</kanji> you have!
reading_mnemonic: If you don't treat your <kanji>belly</kanji> with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "<reading>F**k</reading> (ふく) you!" Be nice to your stomach!

visually_similar_kanji: 族, 施, 妨, 坊, 旅, 旋, 紡, 放, 防, 肪
meaning_mnemonic: Someone just asked you to <radical>say</radical> which <radical>direction</radical> they should <kanji>visit</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You end up saying, "You should <kanji>visit</kanji> my <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう)." How kind of you!

other_meanings: Lure, Induce, Invitation, Entice, Tempt, Temptation
meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> you've left some <radical>grain</radical> on the <radical>stairs</radical>. This is how you <kanji>invite</kanji> people into your place.
reading_mnemonic: You've <kanji>invite</kanji>d people in by leaving grain on the stairs but some <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) have ended up eating all the grain.

visually_similar_kanji: 贅, 賀, 貿, 資, 貨, 賃
meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>substitute</radical> some <radical>shellfish</radical> for collateral so your friend will <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.
reading_mnemonic: You want your friend to <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money so you can buy yourself a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan.

visually_similar_kanji: 追, 担, 泊, 伯, 拍, 舶
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>scooter</radical> is <radical>white</radical>. This color will <kanji>urge</kanji> and <kanji>compel</kanji> you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to <kanji>coerce</kanji> you, even.
reading_mnemonic: When they <kanji>urge</kanji>, <kanji>compel</kanji> and <kanji>coerce</kanji> you like this, they are <reading>hack</reading>ing (はく) your brain.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're riding your <radical>scooter</radical> through some <radical>rice</radical>, it's likely you've gone <kanji>astray</kanji>. Also you might be <kanji>lost</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You got so <kanji>lost</kanji> and went so <kanji>astray</kanji> you ended up on the <reading>May</reading>flower  (めい), a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray.

kunyomi: しりぞ, ひ, ど, の
visually_similar_kanji: 恨, 眼, 根, 良, 限, 郎, 眠
meaning_mnemonic: If you're on your <radical>scooter</radical> and you run over a <radical>root</radical>, you'll need to <kanji>retreat</kanji>. The roots have obviously <kanji>reject</kanji>ed you, they want you to leave, so you should.
reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>retreat</kanji> by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your <reading>tie</reading> (たい). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck.

meaning_mnemonic: When you ride a <radical>scooter</radical> you'll have a <radical>surplus</radical> of possible <kanji>route</kanji>s. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too!
reading_mnemonic: You decide to take the fastest <kanji>route</kanji>, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single <reading>toe</reading> (と) on every single person trying to walk there.

visually_similar_kanji: 眠, 眼, 根, 恨, 限, 退
meaning_mnemonic: Inside the "<radical>Good</radical> <radical>Building</radical>" there's a single <kanji>guy</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You talk to that <kanji>guy</kanji>. The only thing he does is offer you <reading>roe</reading> (ろう).

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>leather</radical> and <radical>change</radical> it into <kanji>shoes</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Some <kanji>shoes</kanji> aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old <reading>coots</reading> (くつ). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.

meaning_mnemonic: You stick <radical>horns</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical> using them as <radical>spikes</radical> and you <kanji>line up</kanji> the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>line up</kanji> these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on <reading>hay</reading> (へい) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty.

other_meanings: Repair, Discipline, Master, Repairing, Fix, Fixing, Correct, Correcting, Acquire, Acquiring, Learn, Learning, Complete, Completing, Decorate, Decorating, Decoration, Adorn
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> is using a <radical>stick</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> made of <radical>hair</radical>. This is the stick of <kanji>mastering</kanji> and <kanji>repair</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: What's the key to <kanji>mastering</kanji> any skill? A stick and a <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう)!

meaning_mnemonic: Using a <radical>hat</radical>, four <radical>person</radical>s with a <radical>cross</radical> make an <kanji>umbrella</kanji>. The hat is big enough to be an umbrella for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that's why they're holding the cross under the "umbrella."
reading_mnemonic: You know the Spanish phrase "Mi <reading>casa</reading> (かさ) es su casa"? Well, this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is also an <kanji>umbrella</kanji>. Mi casa es yours too, because it's an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me.

meaning_mnemonic: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing <radical>stick</radical> at the <radical>sun</radical>, you attain the <radical>legs</radical> of a <kanji>child</kanji>. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child.
reading_mnemonic: As you delight in your new legs, <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) descends from the sky. “My <kanji>child</kanji>,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.”

meaning_mnemonic: You got your <radical>ice</radical> <radical>orders</radical>. Of course, your ice orders are to make things <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>cold</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: How will you make things <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>cold</kanji>? You'll use a special <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun that shoots a cold ray.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Ice</radical> from the <radical>east</radical> is <kanji>frozen</kanji>. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen.
reading_mnemonic: Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was <kanji>frozen</kanji> in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. とうきょう is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>winter</radical> <radical>table</radical> would be an odd thing to <kanji>deal with</kanji>. Winter can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst!
reading_mnemonic: This winter table is something you have to <kanji>deal with</kanji>, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus <reading>show</reading> (しょ)? They like weird stuff like this.

visually_similar_kanji: 拳, 巻, 挙, 港
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>gladiator</radical> in front of you draws his <radical>sword</radical>. He points the sword at your chest and right when you think everything is about to end, you realize he's pointing the sword at the <kanji>ticket</kanji> in your hand.
reading_mnemonic: The gladiator happily marks your <kanji>ticket</kanji> with his blade, when <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai pushes past you. He holds up his own sword, challenging the gladiator, who just shakes his head and points at your ticket again.

meaning_mnemonic: You wear a great big <radical>cross</radical> with a <radical>drop</radical> on it, and head to a <radical>specialty</radical> <kanji>exhibition</kanji> for <kanji>gambling</kanji>. The big cross and drop on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross and drop, and everyone is gambling.
reading_mnemonic: You’re not very good at <kanji>gambling</kanji>, but you are pretty good at cheating. You <reading>hack</reading> (はく) the specialty <kanji>exhibition</kanji> gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>odd</radical> radical and the <kanji>odd</kanji> kanji are the same. They're both... really <kanji>strange</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>odd</kanji> too, just like this kanji. But you don't want anyone to know, so you lock away your <kanji>strange</kanji> habits with a <reading>key</reading> (き).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> is one of the <radical>few</radical> <kanji>peculiar</kanji> things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few truly peculiar things in this world, with woman being one of them.
reading_mnemonic: But when you think about it, we're all a little peculiar. Me, you, <reading>myou</reading> (みょう) everybody!

meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>woman</radical> dressed as <radical>Wolverine</radical> with her <radical>forehead</radical> wrapped in a <radical>towel</radical> is your <kanji>wife</kanji>. You're cosplaying together!
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>wife</kanji> suddenly looks at you and calls you a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). Wuh! Then you look down and see that you're also dressed as Wolverine.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>giant</radical> radical and the <kanji>giant</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
reading_mnemonic: Just recently, a <kanji>giant</kanji> rampaged through Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto.

meaning_mnemonic: Super <radical>poop</radical> is a super <radical>power</radical> you have in <kanji>infancy</kanji>. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power!
reading_mnemonic: In <kanji>infancy</kanji>, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> is over your <radical>car</radical> because your car is in <kanji>storage</kanji> in a large <kanji>storehouse</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your car is in this <kanji>storage</kanji> <kanji>warehouse</kanji>, just sitting there. A <reading>子</reading> (こ) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it.

other_meanings: Tiny, Slight, Faint, Very Small, Small
meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> on the <radical>mountain</radical>, reading off the digits of <radical>pi</radical> on this <radical>winter</radical> morning. The cold mountain air is so <kanji>delicate</kanji>, and changes only in very <kanji>tiny</kanji> ways — just like pi when you add another digit to it.
reading_mnemonic: Ah! Of course! The <kanji>delicate</kanji> bumble <reading>be</reading>e (び). Slightly out of place in winter, but this tiny creature is your idea of delicate. It lands on your finger, and you look at every tiny fiber of its being.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> protecting your <radical>life</radical> and the <radical>net</radical> protecting your <radical>heart</radical> are both protected by the <kanji>constitution</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your country's <kanji>constitution</kanji> is being protected by none other than <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai, hero for hire.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> <radical>before</radical> were <kanji>complete</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: To have your <kanji>complete</kanji> fingers back, you gotta run to the hospital <reading>solo</reading> (そろ).

meaning_mnemonic: If someone is coming toward you in a <radical>car</radical>, holding a <radical>weapon</radical> in their <radical>hand</radical>, they're going to <kanji>attack</kanji> you!
reading_mnemonic: Right before the <kanji>attack</kanji> begins, you recognize the hand holding this weapon and driving this car. It's <reading>Gecki</reading> (げき), your long-lost gecko who you may or may not have let fly off into a really fierce tsunami. Oops. I think he may be here attacking you out of revenge.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Construction</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> leads to <kanji>aggression</kanji>. Just think about it. It's cold, it's unpleasant, and you don't want to be there. So, you start to develop an aggression towards other people working with you on this winter project.
reading_mnemonic: You're taking your <kanji>aggression</kanji> out on everyone. Then, the sexy construction worker from WaniKani Level 1, <reading>こう</reading>いち, walks by without a shirt on. You take out all your aggression on him.

visually_similar_kanji: 招, 昭, 紹, 照
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> can't resist the <radical>call</radical> of a <kanji>bog</kanji>. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~"
reading_mnemonic: As you listen to the <kanji>bog</kanji>'s call you realize it looks just like the <reading>Numa</reading> (ぬま) Numa guy in your mind. You open your eyes and it's just a bog. You close your eyes, and there he is. The Numa Numa guy.

meaning_mnemonic: After a <radical>tsunami</radical>, you find an <radical>axe</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to some <radical>fins</radical> on the <kanji>beach</kanji>. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach.
reading_mnemonic: Walking down the <kanji>beach</kanji> a bit more, you also find a <reading>hammer</reading> (はま). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer.

onyomi: せい, しょう, しん
visually_similar_kanji: 暗, 情, 晴, 静, 精, 請, 積, 靖, 漬
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> that's <radical>blue</radical> is <kanji>pure</kanji>. Some tsunami are other colors, like brown or red because they aren't pure, they'll full of trash and poop and other horrible things. But a blue tsunami is completely pure!
reading_mnemonic: Seeing this <kanji>pure</kanji> blue tsunami inspires you to pull out your glowing blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい)! As the pure water comes toward you, you take one, long slash!

visually_similar_kanji: 喫, 緊, 繁, 紫, 繋
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> takes <radical>life</radical>, cuts it like a <radical>sword</radical> through <radical>thread</radical>, and leaves everything behind completely <kanji>pure</kanji> and <kanji>clean</kanji>. Everything is dead and gone, wiped clean off the face of the earth, thanks to the tsunami. It's back to the way it was before humans were here, completely undefiled.
reading_mnemonic: After the tsunami pulls away, everything left is <kanji>pure</kanji> white. You hate this, so you run over and squirt <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ) all over the place to make it not so pure.

meaning_mnemonic: There are some <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to <radical>fins</radical> on a <radical>plate</radical> that are meant to <kanji>benefit</kanji> everyone. If you're a member of this town, one of your benefits is this little set up.
reading_mnemonic: Another <kanji>benefit</kanji> is free <reading>駅</reading> (えき) usage! Whenever you come back home from places on the train, this 駅 is completely free.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>grain</radical>, from one <radical>evening</radical> to the next <radical>evening</radical>, experiences a <kanji>shift</kanji>. After two evenings, the grain has shifted from one location to another.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>shift</kanji> is caused by the <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) that wants to eat the grains. Every other evening, the eagle swoops down, shifts the grains (eating a few) and then flies off.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Grain</radical> <radical>Mouth</radical> <radical>King</radical> pours grain from his mouth for you and his other subjects. You go to him and pull his finger. When you do this, grain pours from his mouth. But we were greedy. We didn't understand the <kanji>extent</kanji> to which we were harvesting his mouth wheat.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>extent</kanji> to which we were harvesting grain from his mouth was too great. The Grain Mouth King has run out of grain. He worries he will lose power if he has no grain to offer, so he switches to barfing out <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots instead.

visually_similar_kanji: 唯, 維, 離, 雑, 難, 雄, 誰, 進, 推, 椎, 確, 権, 准, 雅
meaning_mnemonic: Only give <radical>grain</radical>s to a <radical>turkey</radical> if it's <kanji>immature</kanji>. Adult turkeys should be eating healthier things, like insects and grass. But immature turkeys don't care if they get fat, so they whine and whine and whine until you give them grains.
reading_mnemonic: Another thing <kanji>immature</kanji> turkeys (and people) love is <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). Most of us non-immature people and birds still like cheese, but if you didn't have an immature cheese phase as a kid or teen, you won't be able to like cheese as a mature old person.

visually_similar_kanji: 暗, 情, 請, 清, 静, 靖, 晴
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rice</radical> that is <radical>blue</radical> has a strong <kanji>spirit</kanji>. Our spirits are blue, so if you ever see rice (or other food, or even people) that's blue, you know that's their spirit radiating out!
reading_mnemonic:
You want to see the <kanji>spirit</kanji> up close, so you take your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい), throw the blue rice in the air, and slice it in half! The rice explodes and blue light fills everything!

Then it's gone.

visually_similar_kanji: 崎, 奇, 埼, 椅
meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>thread</radical> is <radical>odd</radical>, but that's what makes it <kanji>beautiful</kanji>. It's a little frayed, it's a little miscolored, but that's what makes it appealing to you.
reading_mnemonic: You take this <kanji>beautiful</kanji> thread and lock it up with a <reading>key</reading> (き). You want to keep it all to yourself, you want its beauty to be for your eyes only!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Blood</radical> and <radical>hair</radical> and <radical>tofu</radical> make up the <kanji>populace</kanji>. Those are the three categories the entire populace fits into, anyway.
reading_mnemonic: The entire <kanji>populace</kanji> deserves <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). It's a basic thing all humans should have like flowing blood, hair (somewhere), and tofu to eat.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> takes you to the <radical>barracks</radical>, <radical>drop</radical>s you off, and then goes in <kanji>reverse</kanji> all the way back home in the <kanji>opposite</kanji> direction.
reading_mnemonic: Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial.

visually_similar_kanji: 緑, 銀, 縁, 錦
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>Wolverine</radical> swam in the <radical>water</radical> while his father made a <kanji>record</kanji> of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine.
reading_mnemonic: Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a <kanji>record</kanji> of this also. One angry fan threw a <reading>rock</reading> (ろく) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> features <radical>horns</radical> on a <radical>pig</radical> to represent our <kanji>squad</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Our <kanji>squad</kanji> also wears special <reading>tie</reading>s (たい) with our horned pig on it. And we don't care if you think that's lame, because we're A SQUAD.

meaning_mnemonic: If you know the radical meaning <radical>lovely</radical>, you know the kanji meaning <kanji>lovely</kanji> as well!
reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Lovely</kanji>" is the name of my <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun. It's more lovely than any other thing.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>morning</radical>, you use a <radical>gun</radical> on your <radical>nose</radical> to make it <kanji>dry</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This technique for a nice <kanji>dry</kanji> nose was invented by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん)! Well, not him, but someone who worked under him. You see, he had a bit of a damp nose problem.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> sees your bare <radical>foot</radical> and <kanji>urge</kanji>s you to put a sock on it.
reading_mnemonic: As <kanji>urge</kanji>d, you put a <reading>sock</reading> (そく) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>turkey</radical>s is our <kanji>sponsor</kanji>. He's paying us to say and type everything you're reading.
reading_mnemonic: This same <kanji>sponsor</kanji> is also how you made your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). You didn't think you were able to get all those body parts yourself, did you? No no, the leader of the mountain turkeys sponsored you so you could do your experiments.

meaning_mnemonic: A good <radical>leader</radical> will use <radical>charcoal</radical> to mark her <kanji>colleague</kanji>s. Sometimes if leaders aren't around all the time, people will get rebellious and act badly toward people who can get them in trouble. So when you mark them with charcoal you know that someone close with your leader is around and you should probably stop being a butt.
reading_mnemonic: You have to be good around her <kanji>colleague</kanji>s, because if you aren't your <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat permit will be taken away. Row boating is the only fun you ever get to have, besides learning kanji. So act as best you can around the leader's colleagues so you don't lose your row boat rights.

meaning_mnemonic: There’s an <radical>arrow</radical> in that <radical>turkey</radical> and you do everything in your <radical>power</radical> to <kanji>recommend</kanji> that we don’t eat the turkey. meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>lineage</radical> radical and the <kanji>lineage</kanji> kanji are the same. Sometimes this kanji can also mean <kanji>system</kanji>. I guess a lineage is a kind of system, if you think about it.

meaning_mnemonic: Whenever all the <radical>feathers</radical> start <radical>stand</radical>ing, you know it's time for <kanji>the next</kanji> day. Once the day comes to its end, all feathers start standing up like clockwork.

meaning_mnemonic: You fly <radical>north</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> and break your <kanji>back</kanji> when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact.

Your <kanji>back</kanji> hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい) form. 

I flew to the moon.
It is there I broke my back.
My back hurts real bad.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>servant</radical> holding a <radical>gun</radical> sits on the <radical>ground</radical> to <radical>see</radical> if he can find something to <kanji>look at</kanji>. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers.
reading_mnemonic: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, <kanji>look at</kanji> this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him.

meaning_mnemonic: Those that can only eat a <radical>part</radical> of a <radical>shellfish</radical> are probably a bit <kanji>poor</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: And since they are <kanji>poor</kanji>, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash <reading>bin</reading> (びん). It's quite unfortunate.

meaning_mnemonic: You give a <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>lifeguard</radical> to <kanji>purchase</kanji> their services. You think lifeguards are interested in normal money? Come on, they're obviously out there using shellfish for their purchases. It's only natural, given their seaside habitat.
reading_mnemonic: This time you <kanji>purchase</kanji> some <reading>こう</reading>いち goods. You know, since you're such a fan. How else can you show love in this world, if not through purchases? The lifeguard hands over a little haul of こういち plushies and figurines. Nice.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>run</radical> every day and soon you <radical>become</radical> a human that can <kanji>go beyond</kanji> the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast.
reading_mnemonic: To solidify your ability to <kanji>go beyond</kanji> the abilities of other humans, you <reading>etch</reading> (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate.

meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>scooter</radical> running in one <radical>direction</radical> is a <radical>gun</radical>-toting <radical>child</radical>. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just <kanji>play</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Everything is <kanji>play</kanji> for <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>scooter</radical> with a <radical>mohawk</radical>, now that's the most <kanji>suitable</kanji> hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter!
reading_mnemonic: You want this <kanji>suitable</kanji> hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a <reading>techie</reading> (てき), so it's easy for you to install one.

visually_similar_kanji: 頭, 題, 願, 領, 頑, 額, 頼, 顔
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Beforehand</radical>, to buy a <radical>geoduck</radical>, you have to go to the bank to <kanji>deposit</kanji> enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy one! They're expensive, after all.
reading_mnemonic: You go to the bank to make the <kanji>deposit</kanji>, and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo. Now you can't even see, let alone make the deposit.

meaning_mnemonic: When you <radical>eat</radical> you want to see the shape of your <radical>gun</radical> from under a <radical>towel</radical>, so you <kanji>decorate</kanji> your house with them.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> gets trapped in a small room with a <radical>stool</radical> and an <radical>insect</radical>, and together they create a very <kanji>boisterous</kanji> situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place.
reading_mnemonic: At the height of their <kanji>boisterous</kanji> sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>demon</radical> on a <radical>jet</radical> is pretty <kanji>alluring</kanji>. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>alluring</kanji> demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. <reading>Me</reading>at (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> of (odd-looking) <radical>lion</radical>s puts a <radical>drop</radical> of magic liquid on his face to look like a <radical>person</radical> who <kanji>resemble</kanji>s someone else. The leader of lions is going incognito, so he needs to resemble a person who is not himself. He takes this drop of powerful face paint and transforms.
reading_mnemonic:
Now he <kanji>resemble</kanji>s an even greater leader, and all the lions get down on one <reading>knee</reading> (に) to pay their respects.

(Note that we recently changed this kanji's main reading from ね to に, because ね is an irregular reading.)

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>warehouse</radical> radical and the <kanji>warehouse</kanji> kanji are the same! You can call it a <kanji>storehouse</kanji> too.
reading_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>warehouse</kanji> to store all of your <reading>sou</reading>ls (そう). When people or animals you know pass away, you take their souls and store them in your dry warehouse for safekeeping. It's a public service, really.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> sticks his <radical>toe</radical> into a <radical>shellfish</radical>. You ask him why and he says he wants to <kanji>spy</kanji> on it.
reading_mnemonic: You and the leader review the <kanji>spy</kanji> footage and find a single <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tot hidden within the shellfish. Together you uncover a huge smuggling ring. Clams, oysters, mussels, you name it! Shellfish of all kinds are using their bodies to sneak tater tots to the undersea world.

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>mouth</radical> when you see a <radical>Chinese</radical> person and you <kanji>sigh</kanji>. You sigh so loud that it’s practically a roar coming out of your mouth. Chinese people and Chinese things make you sigh because it reminds you of when you stayed in China and it brings up memories. The sigh is a sigh of nostalgia.
reading_mnemonic: Your favorite Chinese thing to do is <reading>tan</reading> (たん). You can wander around without your shirt on and tan all day. No one will <kanji>sigh</kanji> or scoff at you, it’s perfectly acceptable. The Chinese just love to get their tan on.

meaning_mnemonic: You have some <radical>dirt</radical> next to a <radical>pool</radical> that has an extra <radical>drop</radical> of water in it because you need them to be <kanji>equal</kanji>. If there's too much dirt outside the pool and not enough water inside, it's gonna look weird. We can't have that.
reading_mnemonic: You spend a few hours making sure the water-to-dirt ratio is perfectly <kanji>equal</kanji>, not for yourself, but because the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England told you to. You may agree that equality is important, but it's the King's responsibility to keep things that way. Which is why he ordered you, small peon, to do the equalizing work for him.

visually_similar_kanji: 慕, 募, 幕, 暮, 基
meaning_mnemonic: Inside your <radical>greenhouse</radical> there's a mound of <radical>dirt</radical> which appears to be someone's <kanji>grave</kanji>. When you dig into it, you discover that it's an entire <kanji>tomb</kanji>, with doors and passages and everything!

visually_similar_kanji: 後, 係, 系, 遜
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>child</radical> shares his <radical>lineage</radical> with a <kanji>grandchild</kanji>. The child passes his lineage down to his child and then that child’s child is the grandchild and between them all a lineage is shared.

meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>scarecrow</radical> because you're <kanji>rich</kanji>. You want to scare away all the poor, non-rich people so you put a scarecrow on your roof.

"You basically put an advertisement on your roof telling everyone you're rich. Of course you got robbed, you fool."

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Wolverine</radical> is doing a <radical>construction</radical> job and using his <radical>mouth</radical> to take <radical>measurement</radical>s, so he knows how many folks he needs to <kanji>inquire</kanji> with about helping him. Using the mouth is a strange way to take measurements, but that's just how Wolverine does things. Once he measures it all out, he'll know how many construction workers he needs to inquire with about working for him.
reading_mnemonic: Another thing Wolverine has to <kanji>inquire</kanji> about is <reading>jean</reading>s (じん). He wants to make sure everyone on the construction site has good-fitting jeans to work in, so he inquires with them about their jean measurements.

visually_similar_kanji: 果, 呆, 単, 菓
meaning_mnemonic: Birds use <radical>grass</radical> and <radical>fruit</radical> to make their <kanji>nest</kanji>s.
