meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>mountain</radical> coming out of the <radical>ground</radical> that you want to climb, but your <radical>forehead</radical> needs a <radical>towel</radical> for all your sweat. You don't have a towel, so you take off your <kanji>belt</kanji> and tie it around your forehead.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>belt</kanji> isn't absorbent enough, so you wrap it in your <reading>tie</reading> (たい) and then tie the whole thing around your forehead again.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>poop</radical> twice on a sleeping <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>person</radical> and you find yourself wondering <kanji>how many</kanji> more times you can poop on them and wonder <kanji>how much</kanji> they can take before they realize what’s going on.
reading_mnemonic: As you continue thinking about <kanji>how much</kanji> poop this drunkard can take and <kanji>how many</kanji> more poops you can drop on him, he begins to wake up. Quickly, you <reading>eke</reading> (いく) out one last poop before you scurry away. You eke that poop out just in time to make your escape.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>canopy</radical> <radical>guy</radical> is a guy who stands in the <kanji>corridor</kanji> trying to sell people canopies.
reading_mnemonic: You take the <kanji>corridor</kanji>, but this time the canopy guy is gone. In his place is a new salesman. This one is trying to sell you <reading>roe</reading> (ろう).

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around a <radical>tombstone</radical> to measure its <kanji>diameter</kanji>. You’re doing this to each tombstone, and if you loiter around long enough, you’ll soon know the diameter of every tombstone.
reading_mnemonic: You need to know the <kanji>diameter</kanji> of each tombstone so you can make <reading>ca</reading>kes (けい) for each one. But the cakes can't be wider than the tombstones, or they'll flop off onto the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: You're <radical>loiter</radical>ing, staring down at the <radical>cross</radical> that got caught in the <radical>net</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical>, because it's trying to teach you to act with <kanji>virtue</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As you try to decide if you want to live a life of <kanji>virtue</kanji> the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own.

meaning_mnemonic: Using his <radical>fingers</radical>, <radical>Wolverine</radical> wraps his <radical>forehead</radical> in a <radical>towel</radical> to get ready to <kanji>sweep</kanji>. Sweeping floors is hard work! That's why he always puts a towel around his forehead when he sweeps up the mess he made during yet another X-Men fight.
reading_mnemonic: Wolverine knows that <kanji>sweep</kanji>ing is good for the <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Plus, if you don't help clean up after you defeat bad guys, you're just as bad as them. Sweeping up the mess cleans your soul of any guilt too!

meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> to your <radical>forehead</radical> and stand your <radical>legs</radical> high up in a <radical>tree</radical> if you want to <kanji>look for</kanji> something. After all, shielding your eyes and getting up high is the best way to look for something, isn’t it?
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>look for</kanji> it for so long that you can't help getting a <reading>tan</reading> (たん). I mean, you're up some tree, shielding your eyes from the sun as you look for that thing, and it's been hours, days? Of course you're going to get a tan.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>request</radical> that <radical>winter</radical> <kanji>rescue</kanji> you from the warmth of the other seasons.
reading_mnemonic: You get a note in the mail from winter! This is it, you're going to be rescued! You open the note and it says, "I have <kanji>rescue</kanji>d you with this <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう)." A cucumber falls out of the note.

meaning_mnemonic: If you play <radical>blackjack</radical> on the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical>, your cards will <kanji>scatter</kanji> everywhere. The cards scatter because the gravity is so weak on the moon, so the blackjack game is prone to disaster.
reading_mnemonic: You are playing blackjack with <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん). Santa-san is doing his best to use his Christmas magic to prevent the <kanji>scatter</kanji> of cards, but it’s not working out so well. Good effort, Santa-san.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>root</radical> where your <radical>fang</radical> <kanji>previously</kanji> was. Your fang isn't there anymore, you ripped it out.
reading_mnemonic: To remember the beautiful fangs you <kanji>previously</kanji> had, you keep all of the ones you pull out in a box you lock with a <reading>key</reading> (き).

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>line up</radical> your body with the <radical>sun</radical> and everything looks <kanji>normal</kanji>.  The sun is lined up behind you, and you’re looking at all the things the sun has lit up. Everything looks normal.
reading_mnemonic: Soon you see something that doesn’t look so <kanji>normal</kanji>. It’s a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ), a jester. Dressed all in fool’s garb, this fool is dancing up towards you with a ridiculously unsettling grin on his face.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> in <radical>spring</radical> that's nice and <radical>dry</radical> will make a good <kanji>pole</kanji> or <kanji>rod</kanji>. Break it out of the ground and give it a swing to see what a nice, sturdy <kanji>stick</kanji> it is!
reading_mnemonic: After much deliberation, you decide to use this <kanji>pole</kanji> to go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). It's a pretty long pole, so you can just stand at the top of the lane and directly poke the bowling pins with it.

visually_similar_kanji: 屈, 届, 居, 涙, 房, 戻, 堀, 掘, 握, 漏, 塀, 据, 遅
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> came in and buried your <radical>flag</radical> so now you have to use a <radical>spoon</radical> and dig it out of the <kanji>mud</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You may know of Dora the Explorer. But have you heard about her dirty, <kanji>mud</kanji>dy brother, <reading>Doro</reading> (どろ)? They're like a team. And because of all the exploring he does, Doro is always covered in mud.

meaning_mnemonic: If you grind <radical>rice</radical>, every <radical>part</radical> of it, eventually it will become a fine <kanji>powder</kanji>. You can then use this rice powder as a part to create some other dish. Some kind of cake, perhaps.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, grinding the rice down to a <kanji>powder</kanji> is super <reading>fun</reading> (ふん). It’s so fun you don’t want to stop! AH HAHAHAHA! RICE POWDER! SO FUN!

meaning_mnemonic: Bring <radical>thread</radical> to the <radical>library</radical> to <kanji>knit</kanji>. Libraries are quiet and generally pretty empty nowadays, so it's the perfect place to relax and do some knitting. Of course, if you find thread lying around in a library you know what to do now.
reading_mnemonic: You need to come to the library to <kanji>knit</kanji> because if you try to do it at home all your <reading>hen</reading>s (へん) will try to eat the thread. Hens love eating things that look like worms, like hay, string, and thread. So it's important to get far away from them before you start to knit.

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>moon</radical> while you sit on a <radical>cliff</radical>, you inject a syringe of <radical>tofu</radical> right into your <kanji>vein</kanji>. Ahh, tofu. You're addicted to it. You sneak out to the cliff at night to get your tofu fix, injecting it straight into your vein.
reading_mnemonic: Eventually, your friends and family find you at the cliff, tripping on tofu. Each and every <kanji>vein</kanji> on your body is engorged, pulsating with the effects of tofu. Your friends try and take you home. "You cyan't <reading>myake</reading> (みゃく) me!" you slur, suffering from the effects of the tofu. "None of you cyan myake me go home! You cyan’t myake me! Nyah!"

meaning_mnemonic: You want some <radical>flowers</radical> so you take your <radical>cleat</radical> to the side of a <radical>tree</radical> hoping they'll fall down, but you get a <kanji>vegetable</kanji> instead. What? You kick the tree again and another, different vegetable falls out.
reading_mnemonic: You feed these <kanji>vegetable</kanji>s (that you didn't even want) to your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). It only needs a little though, since its stomach is so thin, so you just make it hold the rest.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> growing out of a <radical>rice paddy</radical> into the shape of a <radical>cross</radical> are really <kanji>showy</kanji> <kanji>flower</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>flower</kanji>s are too <kanji>showy</kanji>. You hate them. You hate these showy flowers so much you run them over with your <reading>ca</reading>r (か)!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>bully</radical> take an <radical>insect</radical> and <kanji>dissolve</kanji> it in some acid. Bullies are messed up, mean people. They do awful things that normal kids and people wouldn't do... like dissolve a living creature.
reading_mnemonic: The only bullies heartless enough to <kanji>dissolve</kanji> insects like this are <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう). Do you really think an adult would melt a harmless critter? No. Only inexperienced youths could be so cruel.

meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>lid</radical> on a dish you're cooking, made up of the <radical>mouth</radical>s and <radical>forehead</radical>s of a <radical>pig</radical>. This is truly an <kanji>exceptional</kanji> dish you are cooking up.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Exceptional</kanji> pig mouth forehead soup is a favorite of Grandpa <reading>ごう</reading>いち. You see him sniffing around your window, then he knocks and waves.

meaning_mnemonic: You want to <radical>change</radical> your <radical>shellfish</radical> into <kanji>freight</kanji> so you can transport it. That means packing them up into giant freight containers.

meaning_mnemonic: See that <radical>gold</radical> man <radical>oversee</radical>ing everyone? He's a <kanji>model</kanji> human. His goldenness is a sign of how exemplary he is, and he's overseeing all of us flawed, regular folks to try to help us get on his level.
reading_mnemonic: As you look closer at the golden <kanji>model</kanji> human, you realize he's actually Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん)! No wonder he's covered in gold and overseeing everyone — he's the greatest conqueror in history!

meaning_mnemonic: If you can write an interesting <radical>poem</radical> about <radical>winter</radical> while riding on a <radical>horse</radical>, I’ll be pretty <kanji>surprised</kanji>. meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>gun</radical> it's <radical>easy</radical> to <kanji>wound</kanji> people. reading_mnemonic: Which leader wounded the Japanese people? The <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). The Shougun is a military leader. The Shougun even has gun in the name. And they wounded hundreds of thousands of samurai and soldiers.

visually_similar_kanji: 常, 賞, 堂, 覚
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> and his <radical>older brother</radical> join a <kanji>party</kanji>. They can raid and pillage better in a <kanji>group</kanji> like this, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>party</kanji> has decided to raid <reading>とう</reading>きょう. It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. とうきょう doesn’t stand a chance.

meaning_mnemonic: Two <radical>pool</radical>s, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an <kanji>egg</kanji>. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar.
reading_mnemonic: You remember <reading>Tamago</reading>tchi (たまご), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an <kanji>egg</kanji>, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg.

meaning_mnemonic: If you see a <radical>grass</radical>y <radical>cliff</radical> with an <radical>elf</radical> under it in <radical>winter</radical>, it's because their parents are so <kanji>strict</kanji>. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand under grassy cliffs to think about what they've done.
reading_mnemonic: One of the <kanji>strict</kanji> parents of this elf kid is... <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん)?! Looks like he had another illegitimate kid... this time with an elf.

meaning_mnemonic: Standing on your <radical>roof</radical>, you're <radical>certain</radical> that the nearby <radical>mountain</radical> is shrouded in <kanji>secrecy</kanji>. But you can't do much about it, stuck on your roof as you are. So much secrecy, but so far away.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>secrecy</kanji> is so secret that the people who know about it wear magical <reading>mitts</reading> (みつ) of secrecy that make it so we can't tell anyone, no matter what.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>canopy</radical> comes <radical>beforehand</radical>, it's a <kanji>preface</kanji> for the rest of the canopy.
reading_mnemonic: You read the <kanji>preface</kanji>. It just goes on and on and on about <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (じょ), a short lady the author loves very much.

meaning_mnemonic: If you look inside a <radical>samurai</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>, you'll discover their true <kanji>intention</kanji>s and <kanji>ambition</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: You try to read the <kanji>intention</kanji>s of the samurai in front of you and they're dark, evil, scary. Oh no! These are the intentions of the <reading>shee</reading>p (し) samurai!

meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>mouth</radical> is <radical>big</radical> but your <radical>heart</radical> is in the right place, people will recognize your <kanji>kindness</kanji>. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you.
reading_mnemonic: To further show your <kanji>kindness</kanji>, you chop up some <reading>on</reading>ions (おん) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it's a nice act of kindness that you're toughing it out for your pal.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> have nothing to do when you're at your <radical>cottage</radical> except <kanji>throw away</kanji> things. Your cottage is for vacation. And vacation means being as lazy as possible. But you certainly don't want to live in filth, so you have to throw away your trash at least.
reading_mnemonic: The number one thing you <kanji>throw away</kanji> while in your cottage is your <reading>su</reading>it (す). Suits just don't fit the cottage vibe, man.

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical> to this <radical>cleat</radical> to dig out bits of <radical>tree</radical> and <kanji>gather</kanji> them. Taking your fingers to this cleat is the only way to gather the tree bits stuck in it. Gather them in a big pile… as evidence to examine later.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>gather</kanji> them all together and realize there are <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい) parts mixed in with the tree bits. Uh oh, it's as you feared. Your cyborg definitely got into trouble somewhere around here and you walked all over it with your cleats.

meaning_mnemonic: You're in the <radical>sun</radical> playing <radical>football</radical> and you get very <kanji>warm</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: It's <kanji>warm</kanji> like this because it's <reading>dawn</reading> (だん). That's when the sun comes up.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> combines with a <radical>table</radical> to make a <kanji>desk</kanji>. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk.
reading_mnemonic:
When you finish the <kanji>desk</kanji> you turn to your friend and say, “<reading>It’s cool, eh</reading> (つくえ)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.”

Another way to remember this reading is to think about where you find lots of desks. That's right, in a <reading>school</reading> (つくえ).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> runs into <radical>nine</radical> <radical>tree</radical>s and produces a <kanji>dye</kanji> the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>dye</kanji> continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of <reading>cen</reading>taurs (せん). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy.

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>tree</radical> sitting on the <radical>grass</radical> is a <radical>woman</radical> who loves <kanji>sakura</kanji>, or <kanji>cherry tree</kanji>, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty.
reading_mnemonic: How do you say <kanji>cherry tree</kanji> in Japanese? <reading>Sakura</reading> (さくら). <kanji>Sakura</kanji> is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>valley</radical> you feel a <radical>lack</radical> of <kanji>want</kanji>. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty.
reading_mnemonic: Once you get to the valley, you <kanji>want</kanji> some protein. Egg <reading>yolk</reading> (よく) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth.

visually_similar_kanji: 詠, 泳, 球, 氷, 水, 求
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eternity</radical> radical and the <kanji>eternity</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: How long is an <kanji>eternity</kanji>? Just look at this little <reading>a</reading>corn (えい) and ask. The acorn starts small but it grows into a huge tree and can live for all eternity by dropping more acorns to create more trees. Its acorn line will live on forever!

kunyomi: よご, きたな, けが
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hit not one, but <radical>TWO</radical> <radical>prison</radical>s, making them extremely <kanji>dirty</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: What's the most <kanji>dirty</kanji> are the prisons' <reading>o</reading>bi (お) collections. You can hear the prisoners crying, "Oh, not the obi. Our obi are all dirty, oh no!"

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> that hits at <radical>night</radical> leaves even more <kanji>fluid</kanji> than normal. It's dark at night, so the sun isn't there to help evaporate all that tsunami <kanji>liquid</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>fluid</kanji> stays in the <reading>駅</reading> (えき) longer than anywhere else. All of those tsunami liquids pour deep inside the 駅 late at night and the sun still can't reach them to help evaporate them during the day. It's a real *night*mare.

visually_similar_kanji: 限, 郎, 恨, 根, 退, 良, 眠
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical>'s <radical>root</radical> is the <kanji>eyeball</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You know who has some pretty good <kanji>eyeball</kanji>s? <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (がん). Gandhi used his eyes to see the oppression around him and decided to do something about it. But it's all thanks to his eyeballs.

visually_similar_kanji: 相, 阻, 租, 粗, 狙, 組
meaning_mnemonic: You come across a <radical>spirit</radical> wearing a <radical>top hat</radical> and it claims to be your <kanji>ancestor</kanji>. Well of course, if you remember correctly, all of your ancestors wore top hats when they were alive. This spirit must be your long lost, great great... uh... somebody.
reading_mnemonic: You ask your <kanji>ancestor</kanji> what it wants and it points to the <reading>so</reading>ap (そ) by the sink. Soap? It nods at you. I guess your ancestor is here to see the wonders of soap.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>grain</radical> is <radical>certain</radical> to keep a <kanji>secret</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If someone finds out your <kanji>secret</kanji> (not from the grain though, it will certainly keep it) then your entire face will fill with <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ).

other_meanings: Achievements, Results, Result, Accomplishment, Performance, Exploits
meaning_mnemonic: Tie a <radical>thread</radical> to yourself whenever you take the <radical>blame</radical> for someone. This marks your <kanji>achievement</kanji>. Your achievement in blame-taking, I guess. Isn't it a great achievement to selflessly shield others from blame? Of course it is! So these little blame-threads are symbols of your achievement.
reading_mnemonic: But your latest <kanji>achievement</kanji> is covering yourself in these threads and everyone thinking it's <reading>sexy</reading> (せき). The newspapers and fashion mags can't get enough of your sexy style. See? If you're a good person, people will think your achievements are sexy.

meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>comb</radical> and what looks like the <radical>same</radical> <radical>comb</radical>, and you found them on the <radical>ground</radical> next to some <radical>fins</radical> you showed <kanji>interest</kanji> in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that are interesting too.
reading_mnemonic: Since the combs <kanji>interest</kanji> you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in <reading>きょう</reading>と. Dang, きょうと sure does make some nice combs.

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>go</radical> to <radical>Korea</radical> you'll need a good <kanji>defense</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You need a good <kanji>defense</kanji> to go to Korea, so you fill your pockets with <reading>a</reading>corns (えい). When you get to Korea you plant them all around yourself. In no time you'll have a strong tree defense, keeping you safe.

meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>spirit</radical> in a <radical>black hole</radical> and a <kanji>duplicate</kanji> comes out. The duplicate looks exactly like the original spirit that went in. How strange.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly the <kanji>duplicate</kanji> spirit starts yelling, "Why did you throw me into that black hole?! <reading>F***</reading> (ふく) you!"

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> a <radical>shrimp</radical> who is bad with <kanji>translation</kanji> has no <kanji>reason</kanji> to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>translation</kanji> this shrimp failed to make was for the word “<reading>yak</reading>” (やく). The shrimp found no <kanji>reason</kanji> to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>husband</radical> and his <radical>husband</radical> find a <radical>shellfish</radical> and <kanji>agree</kanji> to share it.
reading_mnemonic: Since the husbands were able to <kanji>agree</kanji>, <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん) believes they’re both good husbands and belong on the good list. Therefore, Santa-san gives them each lots and lots of shellfish for Christmas.

meaning_mnemonic: If you get on your <radical>scooter</radical> and <radical>enter</radical> somewhere, you’re going <kanji>into</kanji> that place.
reading_mnemonic: Once you’ve gone <kanji>into</kanji> this place, what do you see? Your <reading>子</reading> (こ)!

meaning_mnemonic: In its <radical>scooter</radical>, a <radical>cat pirate</radical> scoots up to <kanji>welcome</kanji> you!
reading_mnemonic: The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they <kanji>welcome</kanji> all kinds of people. Especially <reading>gay</reading> (げい) people. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate either thinks you're gay or wants you to be.

visually_similar_kanji: 酌, 酔, 酎, 酢, 配
meaning_mnemonic: Take some <radical>alcohol</radical> and put a <radical>spider</radical> in it to make <kanji>acid</kanji>. Spiders have a little acid in them already, but if you want something really potent, smash one up in some whiskey to make a deadly acid that'll rip through anything.
reading_mnemonic: You're trying to find a container for this <kanji>acid</kanji> when <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん) bursts through your wall. He frowns down at you. You're on the naughty list now. You killed spiders AND made dangerous acid? Ooooh you're in trouble.

meaning_mnemonic: To use your <radical>gold</radical> at the <radical>bar</radical> you need to turn it into a <kanji>coin</kanji>. Well, more than one coin, probably. But you know for sure that you can make at least one coin out of the gold you have.
reading_mnemonic: You use the <kanji>coin</kanji> to pay a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) at the bar. The centaur is the bartender and he makes special drinks for those who pay in gold coins. Good for you!

visually_similar_kanji: 唯, 維, 離, 難, 稚, 雄, 誰, 進, 推, 確, 権, 椎, 雅, 准
meaning_mnemonic: You count <radical>nine</radical> of them in the <radical>tree</radical>, each <radical>turkey</radical> holding something <kanji>random</kanji> or <kanji>miscellaneous</kanji>. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd.
reading_mnemonic: As if things couldn’t get any more <kanji>random</kanji>, <reading>Zazu</reading> (ざつ) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys <kanji>miscellaneous</kanji> trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange.

visually_similar_kanji: 旬, 句, 伺, 可, 司, 詞, 同, 何, 洞, 阿, 荷, 河, 向, 銅, 胴, 苛
meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>eat</radical> part of a <radical>director</radical> to <kanji>domesticate</kanji> him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down.
reading_mnemonic: While you did succeed in your attempt to <kanji>domesticate</kanji> the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Not</radical> <radical>Mouth</radical> says “<kanji>no</kanji>”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question.
reading_mnemonic: You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). The Not Mouth says, “<kanji>no</kanji>”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat.

meaning_mnemonic: Next to your <radical>mouth</radical> there are <radical>fins</radical> which react to <radical>alcohol</radical>. If you exceed a certain alcohol <radical>measurement</radical>, they start flapping about, which makes you spread <kanji>rumors</kanji> and <kanji>gossip</kanji> uncontrollably.
reading_mnemonic: The flapping fins are making you slur your words, but that doesn't stop you from spreading <kanji>rumors</kanji> and <kanji>gossip</kanji>: "<reading>Ooo</reading> <reading>whassa</reading>t (うわさ) I hear about so and so having an affair?!"

visually_similar_kanji: 乗, 車, 華, 睡
meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>car</radical> is all weird because it looks like the side is going to <kanji>dangle</kanji> and <kanji>drip</kanji> off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment.
reading_mnemonic: You see the parts as they <kanji>dangle</kanji> off the car and you get an idea. You could probably <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they <kanji>drip</kanji> off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone climbs onto the <radical>roof</radical> from the <radical>ground</radical> when <radical>dawn</radical> comes to <kanji>proclaim</kanji> that a new day has begun! They proclaim this at the top of their lungs!
reading_mnemonic: The thing that climbs up on the roof to <kanji>proclaim</kanji> that the new day is here is a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). Ohoho, did you think I was going to say it was a rooster? Wrong! Centaurs are taller than humans and roosters, so when they climb onto the roof with their horse legs they can see dawn starting before anyone else.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>horns</radical> of the creatures who drink <radical>alcohol</radical> have a <radical>measurement</radical> so large that they are <kanji>revered</kanji> the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns.
reading_mnemonic: The reason you are interested in these <kanji>revered</kanji> horns so much is that your <reading>son</reading> (そん) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life.

meaning_mnemonic: Use a <radical>flag</radical> to <radical>compare</radical> your <kanji>flatulence</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic:
How do you read <kanji>flatulence</kanji>? <reading>Heh</reading>(へ)...heh..heh..heheheh. You can't NOT laugh at the word flatulence.

Note that some dictionaries incorrectly list おなら as a reading for this kanji. While おなら also means "flatulence" (as in "fart"), you’ll only ever encounter this reading in hiragana, as the kanji can only be read as へ.

meaning_mnemonic: Those that are in the <radical>middle</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical> are the ones you have the most <kanji>loyalty</kanji> towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to.
reading_mnemonic: You pictured <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s <kanji>loyalty</kanji>. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so he deserves your loyalty back.

meaning_mnemonic: To make your <radical>fingers</radical> <radical>wide</radical> you <kanji>extend</kanji> them.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>extend</kanji> your fingers a <reading>cock</reading> (かく) comes running by and runs straight into them. Bu-COCK!

meaning_mnemonic:
If someone has their <radical>fingers</radical> in your <radical>syrup</radical>, it's just another way of saying they <kanji>manipulate</kanji>d you. Cause only slimy people manipulate other people, so their fingers are slimy and sticky because they're covered in your syrup from mucking up your life.

This also has another meaning: <kanji>chastity</kanji>. Just imagine if someone wanted you to keep your chastity and they called s.e.x. when someone "puts their fingers in your syrup." That would be pretty effective, right? Cause it's like, super gross.
reading_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>manipulate</kanji> someone else it's going to have a permanent effect on your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Being manipulative isn't cool. And your soul will suffer forever for it.

meaning_mnemonic: Writing a <radical>poem</radical> about <radical>winter</radical> is the only way to get <kanji>respect</kanji> from other poets.
reading_mnemonic: Once you have their <kanji>respect</kanji> you get <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)!

visually_similar_kanji: 慕, 募, 幕, 墓, 暑
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>greenhouse</radical> is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the <radical>sun</radical> into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their <kanji>livelihood</kanji> will be awesome, now!
reading_mnemonic: From out of nowhere, <reading>Bo</reading>bo (ぼ) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their <kanji>livelihood</kanji>. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood.

meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>cliff</radical>, a <radical>fire</radical> burns to <kanji>ashes</kanji>. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>ashes</kanji> inspire you to write a <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>receive</radical> something edible, arrange it in a <radical>circle</radical> and <radical>boil</radical> it. That way, it’ll <kanji>ripen</kanji> more quickly.
reading_mnemonic: Once everything you received has <kanji>ripen</kanji>ed, you kick back near your <reading>juke</reading>box (じゅく) and eat it. The jukebox sets the mood, making the ripened treat feels twice as sweet.

meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>rice paddy</radical> <radical>together</radical> with other paddies and you'll see how much they <kanji>differ</kanji>. When you're driving or taking a train through the countryside it may seem like all of those rice paddies blurring together are all the same, but they can differ quite a bit!
reading_mnemonic: To see how rice paddies <kanji>differ</kanji>, you need an <reading>ea</reading>gle's (い) eye view. It can be hard to see from the ground, so soar up into the sky like an eagle and look down at the rice paddies together.

meaning_mnemonic: Social commentary aside, the <radical>white</radical> <radical>king</radical> is the king that wears all white. Traditionally, this is someone better than a king. The <kanji>emperor</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Who is the <kanji>emperor</kanji>? It is <reading>こう</reading>いち. こういち the emperor stands over his subjects.

other_meanings: Prosperous, Heap, Pile Up, Head Up
meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>become</radical> a <radical>plate</radical>, I will <kanji>pile</kanji> food up upon you. With such a huge pile, everyone will think you're <kanji>prosperous</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You're so <kanji>prosperous</kanji> you use your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) to cut the food pile and shove the bits into your plate mouth. In fact, your entire family is using your special saber to cut and eat off of you. A normal knife wouldn't be able to get through all this food!

meaning_mnemonic: If you grind a <radical>stone</radical> down to more than just a <radical>few</radical> pieces, it will become <kanji>sand</kanji>. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand.
reading_mnemonic: After breaking up your stone into <kanji>sand</kanji>, you fetch your special sand <reading>sa</reading>w (さ). A few bits are still too chunky, so you'll have to use a sand saw now.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hole</radical> leading to the <radical>private</radical> <radical>heart</radical> of your house is the <kanji>window</kanji>. Or maybe it's just the window to your soul, and not your house. Like the poetry people say.
reading_mnemonic: You realize that a ton of people are looking into your <kanji>window</kanji> and seeing all your private things. This makes you <reading>mad</reading> (まど)! What right do they have to know your private thoughts and desires?!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>bamboo</radical> absorbed the <radical>moon</radical>'s <radical>power</radical>, and you want that power in your body, so you surgically insert them into your body to replace your <kanji>muscle</kanji>s and <kanji>tendon</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: Your special <kanji>muscle</kanji>s and <kanji>tendon</kanji>s have become famous and the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England has requested that you appear in his court! It looks like he wants you to teach his barber surgeons how you got your new muscles.

meaning_mnemonic: You line up stalks of <radical>bamboo</radical> with an equal <radical>interval</radical> between each one. This pattern creates a sense of <kanji>simplicity</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: That kind of <kanji>simplicity</kanji> is what Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) always demanded. Everything he decided was based on simplicity.

meaning_mnemonic: Bring some <radical>rice</radical> under a <radical>canopy</radical> and stuff it in <radical>Wolverine</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical>. Make him chew it a bit, scrape it out, and voila — you've made <kanji>sugar</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: You learned how to make this kind of <kanji>sugar</kanji> in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. You found a special とうきょう sugar sensei and they introduced you to all the secret methods you know now.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>village</radical>, so you <radical>kick</radical> it over on its <kanji>backside</kanji> to see what's on its <kanji>underside</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>child</radical> will ask if they want <radical>two</radical> <radical>water</radical>s because they need a grown-up's <kanji>consent</kanji>. Children aren't allowed to have whatever they want, they need to make sure it's okay and get consent first.

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical> and <radical>dry</radical> them. Then <radical>dry</radical> them again. This is what you do when you are in  <kanji>worship</kanji>. How did I infer that, dear Watson? Why, isn't it obvious! There are vines here. Turkeys can't fly. So I shall swing my way to freedom!

meaning_mnemonic: There's some <radical>rice</radical> in the shape of a <radical>nine</radical> on a <radical>cross</radical> and this is <kanji>stylish</kanji>. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it's stylish to carry it around and be seen with it.
reading_mnemonic: It's also <kanji>stylish</kanji> to <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい) the cross around while you wait for things. You're waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ear</radical> and the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>king</radical> are <kanji>holy</kanji>. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine.

meaning_mnemonic: Set up your <radical>canopy</radical>, <radical>attach</radical> some <radical>meat</radical> to it, and the meat will eventually <kanji>rot</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>moon</radical> <radical>storehouse</radical> is another storehouse you own. Remember how your regular storehouse holds zombies (from the kanji 蔵?). Your moon storehouse is on the moon, and it is filled with <kanji>internal organs</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Where did you get all these <kanji>internal organ</kanji>s from? You actually harvested them from the <reading>zo</reading>mbies (ぞう) from your other storehouse.

meaning_mnemonic: You want some <radical>flowers</radical> to put on the <radical>canopy</radical> above your <radical>helicopter</radical> to keep the <radical>bird</radical>s away, so you ask people what they would <kanji>recommend</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>beans</radical> radical and the <kanji>beans</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>beans</kanji> are from <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Everybody knows とうきょう has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>middle</radical> of the <radical>ground</radical> is a <radical>shellfish</radical> that is very <kanji>valuable</kanji>. Inside of this valuable shellfish is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground.
reading_mnemonic: You want to get the <kanji>valuable</kanji> thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the <reading>key</reading> (き). Search for the key!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> handling a <radical>jackhammer</radical>, cleaning <radical>brush</radical>es (in their 肀 form), and carrying <radical>water</radical> for someone?! All that should tell you that he's not just working, he's been made into a <kanji>slave</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You don't like seeing <kanji>slave</kanji>s. As you walk by, you hand this slave a <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun so he can free himself.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>shuriken</radical> have <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here.
reading_mnemonic: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect is out of balance. This summons <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>jammed in</radical> radical and the <kanji>jammed in</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Look down! You're <kanji>jammed in</kanji>to something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい).

meaning_mnemonic: Tie a <radical>squid</radical> to a <radical>knife</radical> and you get a <kanji>sword</kanji>! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife.
reading_mnemonic: You learned how to make <kanji>sword</kanji>s this way from <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword!

meaning_mnemonic: If you're on the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> with a <radical>snake</radical>, that's a <kanji>misfortune</kanji>. A whole stampeding herd of yak is passing just as you fall. Oops! You've accidentally committed yourself to the ultimate misfortune, death by yak trampling.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>World</radical> <radical>Tree</radical>, all it does is <kanji>chat</kanji> and <kanji>talk</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: To <kanji>chat</kanji> or <kanji>talk</kanji> with the World Tree, just head over to <reading>Sha</reading>man <reading>Bay</reading> (しゃべ).

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is wearing a <radical>mask</radical> so people won't realize you're the one being so <kanji>boisterous</kanji> as you eat your <kanji>miso</kanji>. If you cover your mouth with this mask, no one will know you're such a boisterous eater of miso.
reading_mnemonic: You're being <kanji>boisterous</kanji> and having your <kanji>miso</kanji> outside when suddenly someone shoves <reading>so</reading>ap (そ) in your mouth. "Even your mask can't hide that boisterous miso-eating. Quiet down and wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell.

other_meanings: Longevity, Lifetime, Celebration, Festivities, Congratulations, Long Life
meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>spring</radical>, your <radical>measurement</radical>s will reveal your <kanji>lifespan</kanji>. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight.
reading_mnemonic: If your <kanji>lifespan</kanji> measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small <reading>ju</reading>ice (じゅ) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all!

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>oneself</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>oneself</kanji> as well.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Oneself</kanji>. Who only thinks of oneself? Every <reading>子</reading> (こ) in the world.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>circumference</radical> around someone's <radical>hair</radical>, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has <kanji>carve</kanji>d the hair off someone's head!
reading_mnemonic: When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have <kanji>carve</kanji>d out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>ear</radical> listens to your <radical>heart</radical> and feels <kanji>shame</kanji>. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.

(Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “<reading>HA</reading>HAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>slide</radical> with a <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>above</radical> it, and they're making you feel <radical>small</radical>. And the worst part is that the drunkard is one of your <kanji>relatives</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As if things couldn't get worse, your relative seems to think they're <reading>sexy</reading> (せき) when they're on the slide drunk. Sexy? More like irresponsible!

meaning_mnemonic:
There’s a <radical>tree</radical> in your <radical>hair</radical>, I think it’s a <kanji>cedar</kanji>. How did that cedar tree get in your hair?

(Certain types of cedar trees have bark that comes off in fine threads, making them very hairy trees. So this kanji makes perfect sense!)
reading_mnemonic: Once the <kanji>cedar</kanji> is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A <reading>Sue gui</reading>tar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> carries a <radical>cross</radical> into your <kanji>soup</kanji>. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup!
reading_mnemonic: You pull the cross out of your <kanji>soup</kanji> and see that the cross' <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tsunami</radical> is the <radical>reason</radical> we have so much <kanji>oil</kanji> now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami!
reading_mnemonic: Now that <kanji>oil</kanji> is so abundant, everyone lives in <reading>yu</reading>rts (ゆ). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil.

reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>teardrop</kanji>s are like little waves. What are they? They're <reading>波だ</reading> (なみだ).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical>s during the <radical>old</radical> <radical>moon</radical>s (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's <kanji>lake</kanji>s.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits the <radical>greenhouse</radical>, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a <kanji>desert</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Fire</radical>, <radical>fire</radical>, <kanji>flame</kanji>! There’s flames everywhere!

A <kanji>bear</kanji> boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magna <reading>cum</reading> (くま) laude.

Get it? A little hot bear humor for you.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something and the <radical>flowers</radical> are <radical>right</radical> in <kanji>agreement</kanji>. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement.

You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face.

Shellfish were used as currency back in the olden days. And you aren't going to go out trading and dirty your own hands, no no. Trading your shellfish is the job for the private sword you hired!
reading_mnemonic: While he's out making the <kanji>trade</kanji> for you, you decide to relax and do some <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). In fact, you can't wait for the trade to be done because you're hoping he's going to come back with a new bowling ball for you.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>run</radical> and <radical>call</radical> out to people at the same time because you're <kanji>super</kanji> <kanji>ultra</kanji> excited right now. You have a super crazy amount of energy you need to get out with your running and calling.

Unfortunately, the sun keeps getting hotter, meaning you have to take breaks between steps more often, to get your feet wet with even more water. But you're determined to reach とうきょう, no matter how many steps it takes.

meaning_mnemonic: When you go on a <radical>scooter</radical>, anything <radical>valuable</radical>, you need to <kanji>leave behind</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: What kind of <radical>fish</radical> jumps from <radical>dirt</radical> to <radical>dirt</radical>? A <kanji>salmon</kanji>!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> and a <radical>helicopter</radical> are being <radical>compare</radical>d by a <kanji>deer</kanji>. The deer is standing very still (as deer do) and looking very slowly between the empty canopy and the helicopter sitting next to it.

meaning_mnemonic: Destroy a <radical>lantern</radical> with your <radical>knife</radical> and you'll be <kanji>punish</kanji>ed.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>triceratops</radical> with a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>knife</radical> can <kanji>whittle down</kanji> anything.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Happiness</radical> is a <radical>circle</radical> that's <kanji>tenacious</kanji>. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can.

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>rice paddy</radical>, an <radical>explosion</radical> shakes the <radical>dirt</radical>, exposing a hidden <kanji>base</kanji>. A <kanji>baseball base</kanji>! I guess this rice paddy was built on top of an old baseball field…
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, thanks to the explosion, the <kanji>base</kanji> is in <reading>rui</reading>ns (るい). It's dark and smokey and kinda half burned. You probably can't get this in a regulation game.

meaning_mnemonic: The weight of <radical>life</radical> on your <radical>sword</radical> is <radical>big</radical> when you <kanji>pledge</kanji> to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword.

meaning_mnemonic: Below this <radical>mountain</radical>, a <radical>moon</radical> and another <radical>moon</radical> crash into each other and the entire thing <kanji>crumble</kanji>s to pieces.
reading_mnemonic: As the mountain <kanji>crumble</kanji>s you see your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう), which is at the very top of the mountain, come crumbling down too.

meaning_mnemonic: What's like a <radical>bow</radical>, but even more <radical>simple</radical>? A <kanji>bullet</kanji>. With a bow, you have to load an arrow and pull back the string and aim, yuck. Bullets can be shot with just a simple squeeze of a trigger.

The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it.
reading_mnemonic: You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the <kanji>favor</kanji> you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “<reading>Eh</reading> (え)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>skewer</radical> to the <radical>heart</radical> has <kanji>afflicted</kanji> your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying.

meaning_mnemonic: You take your <radical>fingers</radical> and slam a <radical>lid</radical> on the <radical>table</radical>. You make this big noise to <kanji>confront</kanji> the person in front of you.

I know you said I'd learn like 2000 kanji in no time, but this is way too efficient! What will the people do when they're done? Do you think they will sit idly by?"

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>scooter</radical> is an <radical>insect</radical> and a <radical>bear</radical>. The bear immediately stomps the insect, squishing it flat. "My god, the insect is smashed. Someone call <kanji>dispatch</kanji>!"
reading_mnemonic: Out of the <kanji>dispatch</kanji>ed ambulance jumps <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai. "Dispatch sent me! I'm here to fix that insect."

meaning_mnemonic: At this <radical>gate</radical> you're trying to get some <radical>beans</radical> through, but your <radical>measurements</radical> were off, leading to a big <kanji>fight</kanji>. The bean authorities at the gate always want to fight about bean sizes, and now you have to fight to get those beans through.
reading_mnemonic: The gate you put up a <kanji>fight</kanji> at leads to <reading>とう</reading>きょう. The people of とうきょう need those beans for sustenance, and that's why you fight — for them!

other_meanings: Army Base, Encampment, Base, Army Encampment, Warrior Camp, Warrior Encampment, Military Camp, Military Encampment, Military Base

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> is full of <radical>car</radical>s because it's an <kanji>army camp</kanji>. The cars (and tanks and planes) need to be ready to go at any moment just like the soldiers.
reading_mnemonic: All of the people in the <kanji>army camp</kanji> are wearing <reading>jean</reading>s (じん). You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms, but it looks like when they're in the camp they have to wear jeans.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Grain</radical> left in the <radical>sun</radical> blossom and give off a wonderful <kanji>fragrance</kanji>. They smell fresh and delicious. There's nothing better than the fragrance of fresh, sun-kissed grain.

With... his... arm... up. "Do you like my fragrance? I was genetically modified to have a unique fragrance compared to the other こういちs."

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> asks <radical>half</radical> of his men to <kanji>accompany</kanji> him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him.
reading_mnemonic: The leader you decided to <kanji>accompany</kanji> is none other than <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> takes a <radical>lantern</radical> and searches for people to <kanji>join</kanji> him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern.
reading_mnemonic: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to <kanji>join</kanji> him. You look around and spot a large <reading>hay</reading>stack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>change</radical> this <radical>geoduck</radical> because you want it to <kanji>lean</kanji>. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead.

meaning_mnemonic: You got your copy of "The <radical>Dry</radical> <radical>Knife</radical>." It's the newest <kanji>edition</kanji> of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry.
reading_mnemonic: In this <kanji>edition</kanji> of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning.

other_meanings: On The Contrary, Instead, Retreat, Return

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Past</radical> <radical>stamp</radical>s usually depict images <kanji>contrary</kanji> to current views.
reading_mnemonic: Don't be the type of person who acts <kanji>contrary</kanji> to how they should and instead be like <reading>Kyaku</reading> (きゃく) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> has a <radical>tooth</radical> that you use to <kanji>bite</kanji> and <kanji>chew</kanji> with.
reading_mnemonic: Your one tooth is so strong that you can even use it to <kanji>bite</kanji> and <kanji>chew</kanji> up a whole  <reading>ca</reading>r (か).

meaning_mnemonic: When it's <radical>spring</radical> in <radical>heaven</radical> they <kanji>play music</kanji>. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up.
reading_mnemonic: In heaven, the ones that <kanji>play music</kanji> are the <reading>sou</reading>ls (そう) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band!

meaning_mnemonic: If there’s a <radical>drop</radical> on your <radical>head</radical> and the <radical>rice</radical> is <radical>big</radical>, you know you’re in the <kanji>interior</kanji>. reading_mnemonic: While you’re in the <kanji>interior</kanji> of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “<reading>Ok</reading>lahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!”

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> sleeps with the <radical>king</radical> and becomes <kanji>pregnant</kanji>. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby!
reading_mnemonic: Being <kanji>pregnant</kanji> with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who has a <radical>landslide</radical> getting ready inside her is <kanji>pregnant</kanji>. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide.
reading_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>pregnant</kanji> the baby is constantly kicking you with their <reading>shin</reading>s (しん). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you.

meaning_mnemonic: By showing the <radical>roof</radical> of your <radical>top hat</radical> you send your <kanji>best regards</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: When you give your <kanji>best regards</kanji> you always yell <reading>YOLO</reading> (よろ) to the other person.

kunyomi: おもんぱく, おもんぱか
visually_similar_kanji: 嘘, 膚, 墟, 虜
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> needs to <radical>think</radical> and <kanji>consider</kanji> its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation.
reading_mnemonic: Finally, the tiger speaks: "I'm <kanji>consider</kanji>ing going to <reading>Rio</reading> (りょ). Have you ever been?"

meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>prefecture</radical>, you come from a long <radical>lineage</radical> of people who share one <radical>heart</radical>. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and <kanji>suspend</kanji>s itself in the sky, for you to take.
reading_mnemonic: You arrive at the <kanji>suspend</kanji>ed heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai.

visually_similar_kanji: 戻, 涙, 屈, 届, 居, 泥, 堀, 掘, 握, 漏, 塀, 据, 遅
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>door</radical> in that <radical>direction</radical> is among a <kanji>cluster</kanji> of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it.
reading_mnemonic: After you make it through the door, you come across another <kanji>cluster</kanji> of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) alley and people bowling, loudly!

meaning_mnemonic: Where do you put your <radical>fingers</radical> when you're on an <radical>escalator</radical>? On the <kanji>handle</kanji>! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead.
reading_mnemonic: You put your hand on the <kanji>handle</kanji> and an old person leans in close to you and says, "<reading>暑か</reading>?" (あつか). He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him.

meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>fingers</radical> on the <radical>cat pirate</radical> to <kanji>suppress</kanji> him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you.
reading_mnemonic: He forgot, but you know you had to <kanji>suppress</kanji> the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg <reading>yolk</reading> (よく). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force.

meaning_mnemonic: Shove your <radical>fingers</radical> into a bowl of <radical>shrimp</radical> to <kanji>select</kanji> the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most.
reading_mnemonic: You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp <kanji>select</kanji>ion methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a <reading>tack</reading> (たく)!

meaning_mnemonic: With your <radical>fingers</radical> you pluck some <radical>flowers</radical> in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, in order to <kanji>draw</kanji> them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them, you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone.
reading_mnemonic: Even though you tried to <kanji>draw</kanji> the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell <reading>B.O.</reading> (びょう). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O.

meaning_mnemonic:
You offer a <radical>hot pepper</radical> to the <radical>king</radical>, and he gives you a <radical>drop</radical> of something. You look down at the drop to see it transforming into a <kanji>disc</kanji>. And not just any old disc at that. It's a <kanji>jade disc</kanji>.

Have you ever seen ancient Chinese jade discs with holes in the middle? That's what this kanji is referring to.
reading_mnemonic: Wait, did a drop really just change into a <kanji>disc</kanji>? What the <reading>heck i</reading>s (へき) going on?

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>boat</radical> holds your <radical>weapon</radical> like a <radical>plate</radical>. So in a way, it's just a <kanji>tray</kanji> for your weapon.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, this boat <kanji>tray</kanji> is so huge, it's gotten you <reading>ban</reading>ned (ばん) from the Small Boat Tray Association. Those pesky small boat tray enthusiasts...

kunyomi: とな, たた, ほめ
meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>grain</radical> and fashion it into a <radical>gun</radical> that is <radical>small</radical>, earning you the <kanji>title</kanji> of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations!
reading_mnemonic: Word of your SAD <kanji>title</kanji> makes it all the way to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it.

other_meanings: Connection, Mood, Thread, Strap, String, Continuity, Feeling
meaning_mnemonic:
The kind of <radical>thread</radical> you'd wrap around <radical>someone</radical> would have to be a <kanji>cord</kanji>. A regular thread wouldn't be strong enough, so you'd definitely use a cord. 

This can also mean <kanji>connection</kanji>, since cords create connections (by tying things together).
reading_mnemonic: Actually, you're tying this <kanji>cord</kanji> around someone as part of a <reading>show</reading> (しょ). What kind of a show? I really shouldn't say. This cord show isn't free, I'll tell you that much.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> on this <radical>football</radical> is <kanji>loose</kanji>. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing.
reading_mnemonic: You finally tighten the <kanji>loose</kanji> thread and all of your friends cheer, “<reading>You ru</reading>le!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man!

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>thread</radical> and some <radical>syrup</radical> and you need to <kanji>spin</kanji> them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>spin</kanji> the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a <reading>coo</reading>kie (く)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air.

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>moon</radical> beneath a <radical>tree</radical> there is a <radical>hat</radical> filled with <radical>water</radical>. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your <kanji>knee</kanji> in it.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, in your <kanji>knee</kanji>, you feel <reading>he</reading>at and a <reading>za</reading>p (ひざ)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hot water!!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mole</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> will <kanji>do</kanji> whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it.
reading_mnemonic: To get the mole to <kanji>do</kanji> what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of <reading>chee</reading>se (ち).

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> if you put things on a <radical>slide</radical>, <radical>seven</radical> things to be exact, that’s the best way to <kanji>consign</kanji> goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em.
reading_mnemonic: One of the seven things you <kanji>consign</kanji> over to this guy is a <reading>tack</reading> (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone is offering you a <radical>shellfish</radical> in exchange for a <radical>kiss</radical>. This is a <kanji>bribe</kanji>! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty.
reading_mnemonic: You go through with the <kanji>bribe</kanji> and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the <reading>ro</reading>ad (ろ). No!!

meaning_mnemonic: The more <radical>shellfish</radical> you <radical>have</radical>, the more you can <kanji>bribe</kanji> people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood.
reading_mnemonic: Welp, the cops found out about your <kanji>bribe</kanji>, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "<reading>WHY</reading> (わい)?!

meaning_mnemonic: You put on the <radical>shellfish</radical> <radical>mask</radical> once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind <kanji>presents</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The "<kanji>presents</kanji>" you leave? They are actually just <reading>zo</reading>mbies (ぞう). You leave zombies in people's houses.

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>scooter</radical> when the <radical>omen</radical> comes so that you can <kanji>escape</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>escape</kanji> this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of <reading>とう</reading>きょう. By now, you know とうきょう like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way.

meaning_mnemonic: You're on a <radical>scooter</radical> and suddenly someone throws a <radical>hot pepper</radical> at you and you have to <kanji>dodge</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>dodge</kanji> the hot peppers, you feel a strong <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>scooter</radical> coming toward you with a <radical>net</radical> trapping a weird <radical>zombie</radical> on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to <kanji>send back</kanji> the zombie. (It's a weird zombie because it has the ground on top of its head instead of dirt!)
reading_mnemonic: As you prepare to <kanji>send back</kanji> the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>rain</radical> I take my <radical>rake</radical> and shake it, making a <kanji>demand</kanji> that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it!
reading_mnemonic: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's <reading>ju</reading>ice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and <kanji>demand</kanji> that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box.

meaning_mnemonic: You get <radical>tooth</radical> <radical>orders</radical>. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your <kanji>age</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on <kanji>age</kanji>. There is also an age in which you get your first <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> who lives in a <radical>mountain</radical> is a <kanji>hermit</kanji>. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now.
reading_mnemonic: One day the <kanji>hermit</kanji> was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>allocate</radical> radical and the <kanji>allocate</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>allocate</kanji> your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>excuse</radical> radical and the <kanji>excuse</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Dandy!
reading_mnemonic: Who always makes <kanji>excuse</kanji> after excuse? <reading>Men</reading> (めん)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway.

meaning_mnemonic: Inside this giant <radical>mouth</radical> is a <radical>person</radical>, trapped, because they're a <kanji>criminal</kanji>. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>criminal</kanji> is only wearing <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> contains a <radical>scroll</radical>, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the <kanji>range</kanji> of the <kanji>sphere</kanji> of your mouth.
reading_mnemonic: Looking at the <kanji>range</kanji> of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai.

meaning_mnemonic: This hunk of <radical>dirt</radical> sticks out in a very <radical>odd</radical> way. Oh, wait, it's just the <kanji>cape</kanji> jutting out into the water below. Phew.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>cape</kanji> below looks just like your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>hot peppers</radical> hiding in this <radical>dirt</radical>, so you build a <kanji>wall</kanji> to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up.
reading_mnemonic: On the other side of this <kanji>wall</kanji> there are much less threatening <reading>cob</reading>s (かべ) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>big</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> takes the <radical>measurement</radical>s of a safe before he can <kanji>rob</kanji> it. If the safe is too big it won't fit in his getaway car and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs a place he needs to get those measurements.
reading_mnemonic: Once he's able to <kanji>rob</kanji> the place, he gets away in an <reading>Uber</reading> (うば). He just called the Uber in advance and had it wait outside. Hey, if you're gonna rob a place, make sure you have an Uber.

meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>roof</radical> every <radical>evening</radical> you meet with <radical>snake</radical>s. All snakes know your <kanji>address</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The snakes come to your <kanji>address</kanji> every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: <reading>a 手</reading> (あて).

visually_similar_kanji: 肢, 枚, 鼓, 支, 伎, 枝, 技
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>branch</radical> will <kanji>branch off</kanji> from the rest.
reading_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>branch off</kanji> from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special <reading>key</reading> (き). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ).

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> at <radical>noon</radical> near a <radical>stop</radical> sign to get a <radical>stamp</radical> of approval from someone <kanji>honorable</kanji>. This honorable personage drives by at noon every day, and because they have to stop at the stop sign, people loiter here for a chance to get their honorable stamp of approval.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>honorable</kanji> personage is <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご). Actually, you're requesting Godzilla's stamp of approval for a new demolition job in downtown Tokyo. Godzilla is the god of urban demolition, what with all those cities it's destroyed, and you need its honorable approval to continue.

meaning_mnemonic: When someone wants to view your <radical>soul</radical>'s <radical>reality</radical>, show it with <kanji>humility</kanji>. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility.
reading_mnemonic: As <kanji>humility</kanji> washes over you, you feel a shaking in your <reading>shin</reading>s (しん). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: Show your <radical>fingers</radical> to a <radical>giant</radical> to show you <kanji>refuse</kanji> him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean.
reading_mnemonic: What do you <kanji>refuse</kanji>? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops.

meaning_mnemonic: Raise your <radical>fingers</radical> to the <radical>sky</radical> to symbolize that you <kanji>abstain</kanji> from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain.
reading_mnemonic: This symbol to <kanji>abstain</kanji> comes from the <reading>hica</reading>tee (ひか) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee are endangered. So people started to rally around them, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming these hicatee!"

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Criminal</radical> <radical>writing</radical> is always <kanji>patterned</kanji>. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters.
reading_mnemonic: As you look closer at the <kanji>patterned</kanji> writing you realize that it forms the shape of an <reading>eagle</reading> (い). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all!

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>tree</radical> on <radical>nine</radical> branches are some <radical>cross</radical> <kanji>frame</kanji>s. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one.
reading_mnemonic: You realize that the <kanji>frame</kanji> isn't half as nice as you thought it was, in fact it's totally <reading>wack</reading> (わく). How disappointing.
