meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> <radical>crab</radical> breaks into your games cabinet and steals a <kanji>chess piece</kanji>. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set.
reading_mnemonic: Before the tree crab can make it out with the <kanji>chess piece</kanji>, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a <reading>key</reading> (き), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what?

meaning_mnemonic:
There's a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming and you can't <radical>stop</radical> the <radical>explosion</radical> of <kanji>bitter</kanji>ness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and <kanji>astringent</kanji>.

This word also means <kanji>reluctant</kanji>, because wouldn't you be reluctant to let a tsunami come wash you away with that bitter explosion of flavor in your mouth?
reading_mnemonic: With the <kanji>bitter</kanji> taste in your mouth, you <kanji>reluctant</kanji>ly gather up all of your <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>one sided</radical> radical and the <kanji>one sided</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Think of anything that is <kanji>one sided</kanji>. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>turtle shell</radical> radical and the <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Oddly, this can also be used to talk about the first item in a list, so to mean <kanji>A</kanji> out of A through D, for example.
reading_mnemonic: With a <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> on his back, imagine <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>stop</radical>s protecting you, you'll have to go on <kanji>welfare</kanji>. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else.
reading_mnemonic: While on <kanji>welfare</kanji>, you have to do the only job available to you: herding <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical> stuck in your <radical>cleat</radical> had a <radical>former</radical> life. In that life it was a <kanji>rice plant</kanji>. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up, cleaned, and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now all that's left is this sad loose grain in the bottom of your shoe.
reading_mnemonic: The grain of rice thinks about its former life as a <kanji>rice plant</kanji> and, like you, mutters "<reading>いね</reading>." What's that, little rice grain? Are you trying to say life was good?

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>buddy</radical> the <radical>sheep</radical> is part of a <kanji>flock</kanji>. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock.
reading_mnemonic: Now take out your <reading>gun</reading> (ぐん) and murder every sheep in the <kanji>flock</kanji>. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical>, clad in <radical>spikes</radical>, exists in the <kanji>void</kanji>. This tiger is from another dimension where tigers rule the earth, clad in armor with spikes. The void has allowed this tiger to cross dimensional planes.
reading_mnemonic: The aforementioned <kanji>void</kanji> has opened up in Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ). The spiked void tigers chose to come here in order to face off against the Hanshin Tigers baseball team in battle. It will be a vicious match here in Little Kyoto. Since this is taking place in Little Kyoto and not Japan itself, the Hanshin Tigers won't have the home field advantage. Who will win?

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>Mona Lisa</radical> had more <kanji>modesty</kanji> than any other woman at the time.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>modesty</kanji> of Mona Lisa inspired <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai to become more modest.

visually_similar_kanji: 嫌, 謙, 嬢, 壌
meaning_mnemonic: When you <radical>say</radical> "<radical>Nurse</radical>!" you're probably asking to <kanji>defer</kanji> to them in some way, shape, or form.
reading_mnemonic: The reason you’re trying to <kanji>defer</kanji> to a nurse is because you’re trying to save the local farmhand, <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう). He’s seriously injured, and you don’t know how to help him, so you’ll have to defer to the knowledge of a nurse.

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>foot</radical> to kick <radical>Wolverine</radical> in the face so a <radical>turkey</radical> can <kanji>leap</kanji> to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety.
reading_mnemonic: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you <kanji>leap</kanji> onto a <reading>yak</reading> (やく) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>three</radical> <radical>slide</radical>s sticking out of this <radical>building</radical> that lead to your <kanji>home country</kanji>. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>home country</kanji> is your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう)!

visually_similar_kanji: 齢, 冷, 錦, 銀
meaning_mnemonic: You take <radical>gold</radical> in exchange for executing <radical>orders</radical> to construct a <kanji>buzzer</kanji>. You are a <kanji>small bell</kanji> maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer in exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living.
reading_mnemonic: Finally the <kanji>buzzer</kanji> is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes <reading>rin</reading>g (りん)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do.

meaning_mnemonic: Take some <radical>gold</radical> and <radical>allocate</radical> it to buy a <kanji>gun</kanji>. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins or bricks.
reading_mnemonic: You need this <kanji>gun</kanji> so you can steal some <reading>jew</reading>els (じゅう)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store!

meaning_mnemonic: You come across a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>hill</radical>. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of <kanji>steel</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You report your findings about the <kanji>steel</kanji> you found to Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> of rain falls on a <radical>bear</radical> leaning up against a <radical>cross</radical> stuck into a <kanji>mound</kanji>. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over.
reading_mnemonic: Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the <kanji>mound</kanji> on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>building</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> will allow <radical>life</radical> to have <kanji>prosperity</kanji>. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>prosperity</kanji> isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed.

meaning_mnemonic: In through your <radical>door</radical> walks a <radical>turkey</radical>, so you <kanji>employ</kanji> it. You've always employed any turkey that comes through that door.
reading_mnemonic: Although you <kanji>employ</kanji> turkeys, when a <reading>子</reading> (こ) walks through your door, you send them away.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Construction</radical> for <radical>geoduck</radical>s doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a <kanji>paragraph</kanji> to explain what you're doing.
reading_mnemonic: You turn in your <kanji>paragraph</kanji>, and it is given to Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of all the <radical>spider</radical>s is a <kanji>genius</kanji>! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything!
reading_mnemonic: As you watch the spider <kanji>genius</kanji> you realize that <reading>soon</reading> (しゅん) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Mona Lisa</radical> is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa <kanji>concurrently</kanji>," says your art class teacher.
reading_mnemonic: Your entire class finishes <kanji>concurrently</kanji>. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Simultaneous</radical>ly, you throw your <radical>knife</radical> at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a <kanji>dose</kanji> of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed.
reading_mnemonic: "I need a <kanji>dose</kanji> of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny <reading>xy</reading>lophone (ざい) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?"

meaning_mnemonic: You attempt to expel wind out of your <radical>mouth</radical> but <radical>lack</radical> the breath to <kanji>blow</kanji> out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so.
reading_mnemonic: You silly <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ), the reason you couldn’t <kanji>blow</kanji> any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you.

meaning_mnemonic: It's time to do the <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>sun</radical> <radical>sun</radical> <kanji>chant</kanji>. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears.
reading_mnemonic: You're doing this <kanji>chant</kanji> because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him.

visually_similar_kanji: 据, 塀, 掘, 握, 屈, 届, 居, 涙, 房, 戻, 泥, 漏, 遅
meaning_mnemonic: Imagine you're driving and there's some <radical>dirt</radical> with a <radical>flag</radical> in it near the <radical>exit</radical> ramp. That flag marks a <kanji>ditch</kanji> running alongside the road. Don't try to exit the road here, or you'll end up stuck in that ditch.
reading_mnemonic: If you do end up veering into a <kanji>ditch</kanji> you'll find yourself yelling, "<reading>Holy</reading> (ほり) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch.

meaning_mnemonic: What kind of <radical>woman</radical> comes down from <radical>heaven</radical>? A <kanji>supernatural</kanji> one. She is so <kanji>enchanting</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>supernatural</kanji> woman comes down in front of you and she's so <kanji>enchanting</kanji> that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> is <radical>rejoic</radical>ing. She must be <kanji>glad</kanji> and <kanji>happy</kanji> to rejoice out loud in front of you like this.
reading_mnemonic: "I'm so <kanji>glad</kanji>!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the <reading>key</reading> (き)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Teacher</radical>s are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of <kanji>filial piety</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: With <kanji>filial piety</kanji> in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: You're using your <radical>scooter</radical> to navigate the <radical>flood</radical> because you're on <kanji>patrol</kanji>. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help.
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>patrol</kanji> all of the floods in <reading>June</reading> (じゅん). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>drunkard</radical> issued <radical>twenty</radical> <kanji>commandment</kanji>s to his people.
reading_mnemonic: The drunkard is yelling out his twenty <kanji>commandment</kanji>s to the others at the bar, but they're all about <reading>kay</reading>aks (かい).

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> have to <radical>stand</radical> up straight, to protect you from being <kanji>abduct</kanji>ed, or <kanji>pull</kanji>ed away against your will.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, someone really is trying to <kanji>abduct</kanji> you. They're <kanji>pull</kanji>ling you away. It's the ancient Egyptian god <reading>Ra</reading> (ら). Help!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fingers</radical> are where <radical>criminal</radical>s <kanji>emit</kanji> or <kanji>expel</kanji> all of their bad energy from.
reading_mnemonic: Then you realize what the fingers are actually <kanji>emit</kanji>ting: terrible, awful <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい).

meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>fingers</radical> to shoo a <radical>turkey</radical> down the <radical>stairs</radical> and into a <kanji>portable</kanji> carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers.
reading_mnemonic: You needed the turkey to be more <kanji>portable</kanji> because you're going to be bringing it to a <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference.

visually_similar_kanji: 悔, 毎, 梅, 海
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>winter</radical> you are <kanji>alert</kanji> for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive.
reading_mnemonic: Being the <kanji>alert</kanji> fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash <reading>bin</reading> (びん) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe.

meaning_mnemonic: Taking a <radical>cross</radical> with a <radical>drop</radical> on it, you walk through the <radical>rice paddy</radical> in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and <kanji>spread</kanji> your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion, and the drop in case any of that rice is thirsty.
reading_mnemonic:
With your arms <kanji>spread</kanji> like that, you look extremely <reading>chic</reading> (しき). Spread arms are obviously a chic posture, and the fact that you're holding a cross makes it even more chic. 

Side note: The official kun'yomi reading is just し, but since far more words use しき, we're focusing on that here. Even though the き part is technically okurigana, it's actually used in the readings for most of the compounds that use this kanji!

visually_similar_kanji: 王, 主, 往, 注, 住
meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> is the <radical>master</radical> of a <kanji>pillar</kanji>. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master.
reading_mnemonic: While bowing, the <kanji>pillar</kanji> accidentally smashes <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished.

visually_similar_kanji: 直, 置, 植, 値
meaning_mnemonic: When you go to the <radical>yakuza</radical> to make things <radical>straight</radical>, your problems just <kanji>multiply</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your problems <kanji>multiply</kanji> and give you quite a <reading>shock</reading> (しょく) as yakuza thugs commit crime after shocking crime on your behalf. You really shouldn't be shocked though — of course crimes are going to multiply when you ask the yakuza to "straighten things out."

meaning_mnemonic: Under the same <radical>flag</radical>, all the people get <radical>together</radical> to present a new <radical>weapon</radical> to your <kanji>lord</kanji>. You all bow and say, "<kanji>Milord</kanji>, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord.
reading_mnemonic: As you give the <kanji>lord</kanji> his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, <kanji>Milord</kanji>?" you ask. "THERE'S A <reading>DEN</reading>T (でん)!" he bellows.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cow</radical> of <radical>righteousness</radical> is always there for us. He is the cow that must <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> himself for us to survive.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> must be done via <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing.

meaning_mnemonic: You see an <radical>animal</radical> with some <radical>flowers</radical> and a <radical>turkey</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> trying to <kanji>seize</kanji> them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers.
reading_mnemonic: The animal the turkey is trying to <kanji>seize</kanji> the flowers from is a <reading>cock</reading> (かく). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers.

visually_similar_kanji: 紫, 緊, 潔, 繋
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>winter</radical> the <radical>thread</radical> fields become <kanji>overgrown</kanji>. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete.
reading_mnemonic: The reason this field of thread got so <kanji>overgrown</kanji> is because you’re <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete.

meaning_mnemonic: You take <radical>flowers</radical> down a <radical>slide</radical> to a <radical>drunkard</radical> that you picked from your <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.
reading_mnemonic: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> garden that he begins to <reading>mo</reading>an (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> are being worked upon by a <radical>tsunami</radical> with a <radical>drop</radical> <radical>specialty</radical>: this tsunami can <kanji>dilute</kanji> flowers with just one tsunami-powered drop of itself. That’s its specialty.
reading_mnemonic: You watch the flowers become <kanji>dilute</kanji>d with just one drop, and realize that this is a nature <reading>hack</reading> (はく). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature.

meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <radical>go</radical> somewhere but you're too <radical>heavy</radical> you'll <kanji>collide</kanji> with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all.
reading_mnemonic: You're going around the town, you <kanji>collide</kanji> with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad.

meaning_mnemonic: Lift the <radical>lid</radical> off your <radical>preserve</radical>s, <radical>kick</radical> it, and <kanji>praise</kanji> the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be!
reading_mnemonic: You do this <kanji>prais</kanji>ing in your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects.

meaning_mnemonic: There’s <radical>grass</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and the <radical>fins</radical> there <radical>say</radical> you have no <kanji>honor</kanji>. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor.
reading_mnemonic: Being one of little <kanji>honor</kanji>, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>scooter</radical> you made out of <radical>grain</radical>s, and are about to ride down the <radical>stairs</radical> with, is completely <kanji>transparent</kanji>. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter.
reading_mnemonic: You slip, the <kanji>transparent</kanji> scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back!

visually_similar_kanji: 税, 説, 脱, 悦
meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>gold</radical> you also need a <radical>guard</radical> with a very <kanji>sharp</kanji> sword to protect it.
reading_mnemonic: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a <kanji>sharp</kanji> <reading>a</reading>corn (えい) that's just lying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea!

meaning_mnemonic: Inside that <radical>building</radical> someone is doing a <radical>rice</radical> <radical>dance</radical>. That someone is your <kanji>neighbor</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>neighbor</kanji> has an incredible <reading>rin</reading>g (りん) that they use for their rice dance.

visually_similar_kanji: 邪, 確, 進, 難, 権, 雄, 離, 維, 稚, 雑, 推, 誰, 唯, 准, 椎
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fang</radical> on a <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>elegant</kanji>. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>elegant</kanji> fang makes the turkey look more like a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (が) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle!

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>walk</radical> by a <radical>geoduck</radical> a <kanji>frequent</kanji> amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around.
reading_mnemonic: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because <reading>Hin</reading>du (ひん) people <kanji>frequent</kanji> this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>employ</radical> a <radical>geoduck</radical> to <kanji>review</kanji> all your work.
reading_mnemonic: As the geoduck <kanji>review</kanji>s your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a <reading>子</reading> (こ)!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> goes to his favorite <radical>district</radical> to <kanji>gallop</kanji> around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there.
reading_mnemonic: Then the horse <kanji>gallop</kanji>s into the road and gets hit by a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> is your <radical>master</radical> and you are merely a <kanji>resident</kanji> in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident!
reading_mnemonic: To prove yourself a worthy <kanji>resident</kanji> of the horse master’s house, you must capture <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca.

meaning_mnemonic: One way to put <radical>wheat</radical> in your <radical>face</radical> is with <kanji>noodles</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Once you're done stuffing noodles in your face, you can use your leftover noodles to make <kanji>noodle</kanji><reading>men</reading> (めん).

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>leader</radical> has <radical>two</radical> things that remind him of his <kanji>humanity</kanji>: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats.
reading_mnemonic: Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your <kanji>humanity</kanji> is wearing <reading>jean</reading>s (じん). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity.

other_meanings: Pay Respects, Pay A Visit, Visit
visually_similar_kanji: 旬, 句, 可, 司, 詞, 飼, 同, 何, 洞, 阿, 荷, 河, 向, 苛
meaning_mnemonic: Being a <radical>leader</radical> or <radical>director</radical> in a company means you have to <kanji>inquire</kanji> about lots of things. Have you started this yet? Have you finished that yet? Did you get that thing I sent you? Where's my coffee? Basically if you're a leader or director, your main job is to inquire about these very important things.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out the leader and director of your company is Chairman Kaga from the TV show Iron Chef. Every time he tries to <kanji>inquire</kanji> about weird stuff, you have to say <reading>Ooh, Kaga</reading> (うかが) disapprovingly. "What are you doing for dinner tonight?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga! "What's the best way to soften an eggplant?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga!

meaning_mnemonic: There is a tiny <radical>leader</radical> on <radical>Wolverine</radical>'s <radical>forehead</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and commanding his troops to <kanji>invade</kanji> Wolverine's brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine's body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn't going to invade Wolverine's brain, he's just going to sit on the stool and supervise.
reading_mnemonic: Soon they realize that they cannot <kanji>invade</kanji> Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his <reading>shin</reading> (しん). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> gets a nice uniform for the <radical>sake</radical> of not wanting to look like a <kanji>fake</kanji>. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake.
reading_mnemonic: Well, everyone found out he was a <kanji>fake</kanji> anyway, and now you're all going to use a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ) to cut off his fake head.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>righteousness</radical> is the only one who can run this <kanji>ceremony</kanji>. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it.
reading_mnemonic: Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this <kanji>ceremony</kanji> is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ).

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>ice</radical> <radical>wife</radical> is <kanji>amazing</kanji>. She's also <kanji>terrible</kanji>, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing!
reading_mnemonic: She turns her <kanji>amazing</kanji> gaze onto your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too!

visually_similar_kanji: 飽, 胞, 抱, 泡, 砲
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>wrap</radical> radical and the <kanji>wrap</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Think about being <kanji>wrap</kanji>ped up, nice and warm and safe in your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love.

other_meanings: Boisterous, Too Noisy, Loud, Too Loud
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>proclaim</radical>s "I am <kanji>noisy</kanji> and I am loud!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by.
reading_mnemonic: You are so <kanji>noisy</kanji> and loud that the townsfolk hired <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the Samurai to shut you up.

meaning_mnemonic: Open your <radical>mouth</radical>. A <radical>tiger</radical> fell in there on some <radical>spikes</radical>! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big <kanji>lie</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Lie</kanji> about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using <reading>u</reading>ni <reading>so</reading>ap (うそ).

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is <radical>showy</radical> so it makes everybody around you <kanji>rowdy</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone is getting <kanji>rowdy</kanji> so you get in your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) to escape.

meaning_mnemonic: You're digging in the <radical>dirt</radical> when you find a <radical>tiger</radical> and a <radical>cactus</radical>. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big <kanji>ruins</kanji>. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins.
reading_mnemonic: Well, as it turns out, these are the <kanji>ruins</kanji> of Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago.

meaning_mnemonic: You decide to <radical>loiter</radical> next to the <radical>trash</radical> under the <radical>moon</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so the moon's light will <kanji>penetrate</kanji> you. The sky is <kanji>clear</kanji>est in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it.
reading_mnemonic: You want the light to <kanji>penetrate</kanji> you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots <kanji>clear</kanji> through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of <reading>鉄</reading> (てつ).

meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>fingers</radical> to wipe this <radical>winter</radical> <radical>table</radical> and see what it was <kanji>based on</kanji>. The cold winter weather covers the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them.
reading_mnemonic: This particular table was <kanji>based on</kanji> Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ). Little buildings and temples, that sort of look like Little Kyoto. Problem is, it was made by a <reading>子</reading> (こ), so it's not very good.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gladiator</radical> turns his <radical>hand</radical> into a <kanji>fist</kanji>. A fist for punching other gladiators.
reading_mnemonic: The gladiator's <kanji>fist</kanji> is now aimed at <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists.

meaning_mnemonic: You find some <radical>fingers</radical> from <radical>long ago</radical>. They must have been <kanji>set aside</kanji> by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside.
reading_mnemonic: I know why they <kanji>set aside</kanji> their fingers long ago, it's because there was no <reading>so</reading>ap (そ). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long...

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> to dig through the <radical>trash</radical> in the light of the <radical>moon</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> because somewhere in there is your <kanji>withdrawal</kanji> letter. What did you withdraw? Your resignation? Your troops? Whatever it was, you need to find the proof, and fast.
reading_mnemonic: While looking for the <kanji>withdrawal</kanji> letter, your fingers hit a piece of <reading>鉄</reading> (てつ). Ouch!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>trash</radical> is a weird looking <radical>fruit</radical>. Someone decided to <kanji>abandon</kanji> it here.
reading_mnemonic: You reach into the trash, take out the <kanji>abandon</kanji>ed fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a <reading>key</reading> (き) inside, and you just bit into it.

meaning_mnemonic: Each <radical>tree</radical> needs its <radical>drum</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> done before you can say it's really made of <kanji>wood</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of <kanji>wood</kanji>, just take out a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (じゅ) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all.

kunyomi: くぐ, ひそ, もぐ
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> carries two <radical>husband</radical>s up into the <radical>sun</radical>, where they're going to <kanji>conceal</kanji> something.
reading_mnemonic: The husbands are going to <kanji>conceal</kanji> their pet <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) in the sun. The local government isn't too pleased that they have a pet centaur, so they have to conceal it in the sun so it doesn't get confiscated.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>bundle</radical> of <radical>geoduck</radical>s, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating <kanji>rapids</kanji>! The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the <kanji>shallows</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: While those geoducks are getting tossed about in the <kanji>rapids</kanji>, you're sitting in the <kanji>shallows</kanji> chomping down on some <reading>ce</reading>lery (せ).

meaning_mnemonic: You climb up a <radical>mountain</radical> and a <radical>cliff</radical> in search of <radical>fire</radical>, but all you find is <kanji>charcoal</kanji>. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing.
reading_mnemonic: After crushing the <kanji>charcoal</kanji>, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lie out in the sun for a while to get a <reading>tan</reading> (たん). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fire</radical> in the <radical>rice paddy</radical> burns down the <kanji>field</kanji>. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm!
reading_mnemonic: Your rice paddy farm and <kanji>field</kanji> are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a <reading>hot-a cay</reading>! (はたけ) Mama mia!

meaning_mnemonic: Dig up a <radical>mole</radical> and you <kanji>attain</kanji> a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level!
reading_mnemonic: Mole isn't enough, you want to <kanji>attain</kanji> <reading>shee</reading>p (し) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>boat</radical> that <radical>oversee</radical>s other boats, land, and people is usually a <kanji>warship</kanji>. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it.
reading_mnemonic: This huge <kanji>warship</kanji> is run by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him?

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> has <radical>legs</radical> that belong to a <kanji>tiger</kanji>. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>tiger</kanji> is using his legs to run away from the <reading>Torah</reading> (とら). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> <radical>insect</radical> is a <kanji>firefly</kanji>. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly.
reading_mnemonic: The Viking <kanji>firefly</kanji> is attacking <reading>Hotaru</reading> (ほたる) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>insect</radical> <radical>signpost</radical> there is a single sign that says <kanji>bee</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Thanks to the insect signpost you find the <kanji>bee</kanji>. You make it just in time to see the bee <reading>hatch</reading> (はち) from its egg.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> (hive) on a <radical>certain</radical> <radical>insect</radical> (a bee) is what protects all of the <kanji>honey</kanji> or <kanji>nectar</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: To get the <kanji>honey</kanji> out, you need to put on special <reading>mitts</reading> (みつ) so your hands don't get stung.

meaning_mnemonic: Something you <radical>say</radical> to someone you <radical>become</radical> attached to should be said with <kanji>sincerity</kanji>. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example.
reading_mnemonic: When you say something with complete, unabashed <kanji>sincerity</kanji> your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere!

meaning_mnemonic: On this <radical>scooter</radical> is a <radical>child</radical> who's trying to show that his <radical>lineage</radical> is <kanji>humble</kanji>. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>humble</kanji> child is your <reading>son</reading> (そん). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble.

meaning_mnemonic: Everyone has a <radical>poop</radical> <radical>guy</radical> from their <kanji>hometown</kanji>. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>hometown</kanji> is in <reading>きょう</reading>と which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in きょうと too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up.

visually_similar_kanji: 酌, 酸, 酔, 酢, 配
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>alcohol</radical> that needs <radical>measurement</radical> is <kanji>hard liquor</kanji>. Drinking too much hard liquor isn't good for you, so you must make sure to measure it out in precise quantities.
reading_mnemonic: You know who enjoyed <kanji>hard liquor</kanji> a lot? <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did.

meaning_mnemonic: Aside from <radical>gold</radical> there are a <radical>wide</radical> variety of other <kanji>mineral</kanji>s as well.
reading_mnemonic: One person is trying to control all the <kanji>minerals</kanji> of the world. That person is Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: Even though you’ve <radical>old</radical> <radical>legs</radical>, you <kanji>overcome</kanji> your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!
reading_mnemonic: When you pass the finish line and finally <kanji>overcome</kanji> the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold <reading>Coke</reading> (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mole</radical> has a <radical>knife</radical> ready for your <kanji>arrival</kanji>. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>arrival</kanji> to <reading>とう</reading>きょう is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a とうきょう hospital to get this mole knife out.

visually_similar_kanji: 対, 奴, 叙, 淑, 叔
meaning_mnemonic: If you have one <radical>stool</radical> and another <radical>stool</radical>, you have a <kanji>pair</kanji> of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>pair</kanji> of stools shares a <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together.

meaning_mnemonic: Wrap your <radical>fingers</radical> around this <radical>axe</radical> and put it in your <radical>mouth</radical> to express your <kanji>philosophy</kanji>. Your philosophy of… putting axes in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, but by doing this you're showing them that it's not!
reading_mnemonic: Your axe-in-mouth <kanji>philosophy</kanji> means you're always tasting <reading>鉄</reading> (てつ). They say blood tastes like copper. Well, weapons (and your philosophy) taste like iron.

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>cross</radical> is a <radical>mouth</radical> and another <radical>mouth</radical> wearing special <radical>clothes</radical> because they're in <kanji>mourning</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As the <kanji>mourning</kanji> continues, the <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>servant</radical> secures a <radical>stool</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> so that it is a <kanji>solid</kanji> sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting!
reading_mnemonic: You need this stool to be extra <kanji>solid</kanji> because you're using it to test your new <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you?

visually_similar_kanji: 爪, 狐, 瓜, 孤
meaning_mnemonic: Using a <radical>bow</radical>, shoot a <radical>melon</radical> and it will fly in a steep <kanji>arc</kanji>. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all.
reading_mnemonic: Shooting melons in an <kanji>arc</kanji> is something little <reading>子</reading>'s (こ) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place.

meaning_mnemonic: Someone's <radical>fingers</radical> touch your <radical>tongue</radical> and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this.
reading_mnemonic: Only one creature could use its fingers to <kanji>fasten</kanji> your tongue like this: <reading>cats</reading> (かつ). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?"

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>fingers</radical> move like that, you know it's an <radical>omen</radical> of a <kanji>challenge</kanji> that will face you soon in the future.
reading_mnemonic: In your finger, you see a <kanji>challenge</kanji>. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading>'s (ちょう) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou!

visually_similar_kanji: 据, 堀, 塀, 握, 屈, 届, 居, 涙, 房, 戻, 泥, 漏, 遅
meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>fingers</radical> on a <radical>flag</radical> by the <radical>exit</radical>, indicating that you should <kanji>dig</kanji>. The fingers on the flag point downward, just by the exit, as if to say "dig here!" There must be something under here. That's what you think to yourself as you start to dig with your fingers.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dig</kanji> until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old <reading>coots</reading> (くつ). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!"

visually_similar_kanji: 掲, 渇, 腸, 湯, 場, 陽
meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>fingers</radical> it's <radical>easy</radical> to <kanji>hoist</kanji> things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy.
reading_mnemonic: Today, you have to <kanji>hoist</kanji> so much stuff. "<reading>Ah</reading> (あ)!" you say, "So much hoisting to do." Better get to it!

visually_similar_kanji: 据, 堀, 塀, 掘, 遅, 屈, 届, 居, 涙, 房, 戻, 泥, 漏
meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> in a <radical>shop</radical> to <kanji>grip</kanji> what you want to buy.
reading_mnemonic: You have a really strong <kanji>grip</kanji> thanks to <reading>acu</reading>puncture (あく)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles.

meaning_mnemonic: With your <radical>fingers</radical>, you grab a <radical>satellite</radical> and <kanji>shake</kanji> it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong enough for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker.
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>shake</kanji> it because this satellite is full of <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). You only like yogurt that's been well shaken. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone?

meaning_mnemonic: Use <radical>simultaneous</radical> <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to perform the <kanji>purification</kanji> ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.)
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>purification</kanji> ritual is supposed to help you forget your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it out of your head.

meaning_mnemonic: To your <radical>car</radical> you take an <radical>axe</radical>. The <radical>sun</radical> has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that <kanji>temporarily</kanji>. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.
reading_mnemonic: You were driving around in <reading>Zan</reading>zibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next.

visually_similar_kanji: 祈, 折, 斬, 新
meaning_mnemonic: You hit a <radical>tree</radical> with an <radical>axe</radical> so you can do some <kanji>analysis</kanji> on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe.
reading_mnemonic: The person who is doing this <kanji>analysis</kanji> is very <reading>sexy</reading> (せき). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>tree</radical> <radical>district</radical> of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need <kanji>hinge</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: You buy an awesome <kanji>hinge</kanji> and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO <reading>SUUUUEEE</reading> (すう) YOU!"

meaning_mnemonic: You walk up to a <radical>tree</radical> and put <radical>dynamite</radical> on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful <kanji>pattern</kanji> into the side of it as well as the ground around it.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>pattern</kanji> is so beautiful that you want to put it on your <reading>gara</reading>ge (がら). So, you do.

visually_similar_kanji: 伯, 迫, 舶, 拍
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>white</radical> is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place <kanji>overnight</kanji>, without even asking!
reading_mnemonic: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying <kanji>overnight</kanji> and decides it doesn't like it, so it <reading>hack</reading>s (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> breaks your <radical>bone</radical>s, not from hitting you, but from making you <kanji>slide</kanji> and <kanji>slip</kanji> into stuff. Hard to keep your footing in a tsunami, you know? You're slipping and sliding all over the place.
reading_mnemonic: As you continue to <kanji>slide</kanji> around you see a bunch of stray <reading>cats</reading> (かつ) slipping and sliding too. They're yowling and sliding right toward you. Uh oh…

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> crashes into the <radical>sun</radical> (breaking it in half) and creating a different <radical>wing</radical> of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a <kanji>lagoon</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>lagoon</kanji> was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun!

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>turkey</radical> and try to <radical>boil</radical> it but you <kanji>char</kanji> it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there.
reading_mnemonic: You're staring sadly at the <kanji>char</kanji>red turkey when you suddenly sense the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>bamboo</radical> can be whittled into an <kanji>example</kanji> of anything. See, here's a <radical>car</radical>. Here's a <radical>snake</radical>. I can make so many examples just with bamboo.
reading_mnemonic: One last <kanji>example</kanji> for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Thread</radical> and <radical>vines</radical> alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to <kanji>twist</kanji> them together to make them strong.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>twist</kanji> the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう) twisted into it.

meaning_mnemonic: Take this <radical>thread</radical> and look at this <radical>part</radical>. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have <kanji>distract</kanji>ed you!
reading_mnemonic: Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of <reading>fun</reading> (ふん).

meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <radical>thread</radical> and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a <radical>hill</radical> of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a <kanji>rope</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Congratulations, now you have a perfect rope for <reading>tuna</reading> (つな) fishing. Tunas are massive, so you need a strong rope to reel one in.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>thread</radical>-covered <radical>hill</radical>, but it's all lumpy and weird. You approach it to take a closer look, and you see it's actually a huge <kanji>net</kanji> with a bunch of stuff caught in it: fish, cats, tree branches. All this random stuff is what's making the net look so lumpy!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>net</kanji> is creating a serious obstacle to you <reading>mow</reading>ing (もう) your lawn. The net has way too much stuff in it for you to be able to drag it away, so for now you're just going to have to mow around it.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>moon</radical> is <radical>dry</radical>, it's good for your <kanji>liver</kanji>! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
reading_mnemonic: As you pat your <kanji>liver</kanji> suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) comes out! Right out of your liver.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>hills</radical> in your front <kanji>lawn</kanji>. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.
reading_mnemonic: You are the proud owner of a <reading>Shiba</reading> (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your <kanji>lawn</kanji> and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> find their <radical>death</radical> in a <radical>river</radical> out in the <kanji>wild</kanji>. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Ah</reading> (あ), the flowers in the <kanji>wild</kanji> have been claimed <reading>à la</reading> (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do.

meaning_mnemonic: You keep your <radical>substitute</radical> <radical>clothes</radical> in a <kanji>sack</kanji>. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.
reading_mnemonic: You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes <kanji>sack</kanji>. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: <reading>F**K ROE</reading> (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Shellfish</radical> cause <radical>landslide</radical>s because of all their <kanji>bustling</kanji> and <kanji>lively</kanji> underwater activity.
reading_mnemonic: You can't stand <kanji>bustling</kanji> and <kanji>lively</kanji> situations, so you get out your <reading>knee gui</reading>llotine (にぎ). What's a knee guillotine? It's exactly what it sounds like, and you're about to use it on these shellfish to prevent some landslides.

other_meanings: Pivotal Part, Shaft, Central Rod, Core, Central Point, Central Part, Pivot
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>car</radical> works for one <radical>reason</radical>: its wheels can spin on an <kanji>axis</kanji>. Yep, that lateral axis is definitely a car's most <kanji>pivotal part</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your friend is always bragging about his car's <kanji>axis</kanji>. He's all like, "My car's wheels move on more than one axis!" And you sarcastically reply: "<reading>Gee, coo</reading>l" (じく).

meaning_mnemonic: What do you <radical>eat</radical> if you’re wearing <radical>horns</radical> and surrounded by <radical>lantern</radical>s? <kanji>Mochi</kanji> (or <kanji>sticky rice cake</kanji>s) of course!
reading_mnemonic: The reading of <kanji>mochi</kanji> is <reading>mochi</reading> (もち). Yay!

meaning_mnemonic: You take out a <radical>flag</radical>, lay a <radical>towel</radical> below it, and use your <radical>knife</radical> to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old <kanji>printing</kanji> presses used to work.
reading_mnemonic: As you get your flag ready for <kanji>printing</kanji> you look over and see <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ), who's already finished a nice pattern on her towel. She's a little young to be using a knife, but her print came out nice.

visually_similar_kanji: 却, 印, 卸, 叩
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>root</radical> of a <radical>stamp</radical> is to get an <kanji>instant</kanji> picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant.
reading_mnemonic: Think about the thing you want to make <kanji>instant</kanji>. I'd want instant <reading>sock</reading>s (そく)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant!

meaning_mnemonic:
Look at the <radical>dirt</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> at <radical>dawn</radical> and you'll be able to see all the <kanji>hedge</kanji>s growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out.

This hedge also works as a <kanji>fence</kanji>. It borders an area and you can't walk through it. A natural fence!
reading_mnemonic: You're looking intently at one particular <kanji>hedge</kanji> because yesterday you dropped your <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>key</reading>s (かき) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys.

other_meanings: Might, Majesty, Intimidate, Threaten, Majestic, Majestical, Power, Force, Dignified
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canine</radical> and a <radical>woman</radical> stand before you, radiating <kanji>dignity</kanji> and <kanji>might</kanji>. Who is this majestic pair?
reading_mnemonic: Just when you thought this woman couldn't emit any more <kanji>dignity</kanji>, an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) swoops down and perches on her shoulder. The huge canine behind her already gave her a dignified aura, but this eagle has made her look positively awe-inspiring.

meaning_mnemonic: You take two clumps of <radical>dirt</radical> to make a <radical>measurement</radical>, using them to <kanji>seal</kanji> each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to <kanji>seal in</kanji> things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue.
reading_mnemonic:
You can also <kanji>seal</kanji> <reading>foo</reading>d (ふう) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew.

By the way, this has another reading you should probably know. It's ほう. Most sealing is done in the <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう), you know? So just think about eating food in your own home!

other_meanings: Console, Consoling, Comfort, Comforting, Sooth, Soothing
meaning_mnemonic: We put up a <radical>flag</radical> to remember where we tried to use a <radical>jackhammer</radical> to take a <radical>measurement</radical> of your friend's <radical>heart</radical>. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of <kanji>consolation</kanji>?
reading_mnemonic: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>badger</radical>, at the <radical>root</radical> of its <radical>heart</radical>, is a <kanji>courteous</kanji> creature.
reading_mnemonic: Badgers are especially <kanji>courteous</kanji> to <reading>con</reading>dors (こん). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>loiter</radical>ing <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>king</radical> who hangs around during <radical>winter</radical> to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your <radical>heart</radical>, and only sees bad things. So, he <kanji>chastise</kanji>s you about it.
reading_mnemonic: Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is <kanji>chastis</kanji>ing you for saving Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう).

meaning_mnemonic: Below the <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>hand</radical>. The hand is just there to <kanji>chafe</kanji> against the trees.
reading_mnemonic: As the hand <kanji>chafe</kanji>s on the trees, it says <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま), mama.

meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> in somebody's <radical>business</radical> by <kanji>slap</kanji>ping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers.
reading_mnemonic: ぼく is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you <kanji>slap</kanji> this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? <reading>ぼく</reading>.

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> to hold the <radical>roof</radical> of the <radical>festival</radical> up, but it <kanji>rub</kanji>s against them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is rubbing against them really, really badly.
reading_mnemonic: Just when you thought the <kanji>rub</kanji>bing couldn't get any worse, <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) appears and hops up onto the roof. AAGH! It hurts!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>simultaneous</radical> radical and the <kanji>simultaneous</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: What <kanji>simultaneously</kanji> protects and kills? Your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい).

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>spoon</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical> to be able to take a bite. It's <kanji>delicious</kanji>, you hear. That's the <kanji>point</kanji> of the spoon.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>delicious</kanji> taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like <reading>shee</reading>p (し)!

meaning_mnemonic: The sun hits this and breaks into three <radical>sun</radical>s. What can split the sun in three directions? A <kanji>crystal</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these <kanji>crystal</kanji>s? That would be the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>good</radical> <radical>moon</radical> is a <kanji>bright</kanji> moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon.
reading_mnemonic: It's so <kanji>bright</kanji> that you can see all the <reading>roe</reading> (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon!

meaning_mnemonic: You've been ordered to <radical>spear</radical> this <radical>tree</radical> but you decide to be really <kanji>gentle</kanji> instead.
reading_mnemonic: You're being really <kanji>gentle</kanji> to the tree when a <reading>jewel</reading> (じゅう) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>pirate</radical> they are going to <kanji>sink</kanji> no matter how good of a pirate captain they are.
reading_mnemonic: As the tsunami comes to <kanji>sink</kanji> the pirate, the pirate holds his <reading>chin</reading> (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity.

meaning_mnemonic: The sound of <radical>spring</radical> <radical>water</radical> always puts you at <kanji>peace</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You want to feel this <kanji>peace</kanji> all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your <reading>tie</reading> (たい) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love.

meaning_mnemonic: You're struck by a <radical>tsunami</radical>, mauled by a <radical>canine</radical>, and then set on <radical>fire</radical>. It seems the universe is trying to <kanji>destroy</kanji> you.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, the universe wants to <kanji>destroy</kanji> you because you're a <reading>Mets</reading> (めつ) fan. The universe despises the Mets — why do you think they haven't won a World Series since 1986?

meaning_mnemonic: A (fresh water) <radical>tsunami</radical>. Some <radical>horns</radical>. The <radical>ground</radical>. A bunch of <radical>poop</radical>. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very <kanji>nourishing</kanji> soil.
reading_mnemonic: This is the kind of <kanji>nourishing</kanji> soil that <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably.

meaning_mnemonic: A small <radical>tsunami</radical> comes in the <radical>morning</radical> with the <radical>moon</radical>. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the <kanji>tide</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You go check out the <kanji>tide</kanji>. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう)!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fire</radical> <radical>door</radical> is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a <kanji>furnace</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You're using the <kanji>furnace</kanji> to melt tar to put on the <reading>ro</reading>ad (ろ).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cow</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the <kanji>pasture</kanji>. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat.
reading_mnemonic: ぼく is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "<reading>ぼく</reading>will take these cows out to pasture!"

visually_similar_kanji: 修, 診, 参, 惨
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical>'s <radical>hat</radical>, not to mention the <radical>hair</radical> stuck to said hat, is incredibly <kanji>rare</kanji>. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck.
reading_mnemonic: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even <kanji>rare</kanji>r. Attached to the hair is the king's <reading>chin</reading> (ちん).

meaning_mnemonic: Two <radical>king</radical>s are here right <radical>now</radical>! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the <kanji>harp</kanji>, or the <kanji>zither</kanji>, or something.
reading_mnemonic:
You may already know that a Japanese <kanji>harp</kanji> is called a こと, but here's a mnemonic to help you if you don't:

When playing your <kanji>harp</kanji>, you always wear your <reading>coat</reading> (こと).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> stalk looks the <radical>same</radical> as a big ol' <kanji>cylinder</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Picture a <kanji>cylinder</kanji> shaped <reading>とう</reading>きょう. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of とうきょう!

meaning_mnemonic: People had to use their <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>plow</radical>s <radical>long ago</radical> to put their name in a <kanji>register</kanji>. This is because there was no paper yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their names into the dirt to create all kinds of registers.
reading_mnemonic: If your name is in a <kanji>register</kanji>, people will find you very <reading>sexy</reading> (せき). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than someone whose existence is accounted for in official documentation.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>yakuza</radical> takes a <radical>knife</radical> to <radical>clothes</radical>, it will of course cause a <kanji>split</kanji> or <kanji>tear</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "I want to <kanji>split</kanji> and <kanji>tear</kanji> that." You agree, so you say <reading>Let's</reading> (れつ) do it.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Imperial</radical> <radical>clothes</radical> allow you to perform an ancient <kanji>attack</kanji> that cannot be repelled.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>attack</kanji>'s power is concentrated in the <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>construction</radical> project made from <radical>shellfish</radical> will act as a <kanji>tribute</kanji> to the Crabigator.
reading_mnemonic: This great <kanji>tribute</kanji> is being commissioned by Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>run</radical>, put your <radical>ear</radical> on the <radical>stool</radical>, then run back. That's the <kanji>charm</kanji> of this game.
reading_mnemonic: The added <kanji>charm</kanji> of this game is that there's this big <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ) at the end. It's so charming because you love chutes.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>foot</radical> on a <radical>giant</radical> is a pretty long <kanji>distance</kanji> for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large <kanji>distance</kanji>s very quickly.
reading_mnemonic: Going to Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ) is a short <kanji>distance</kanji> for a giant but a long <kanji>distance</kanji> for you.

visually_similar_kanji: 霧, 雪, 霜, 雲, 電, 雰, 震, 雷
meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>rain</radical> touches your <radical>foot</radical> and gives it a little rain <radical>kiss</radical>, you know that part of your foot is <kanji>expose</kanji>d to the elements. You can also see some <kanji>dew</kanji> forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are!
reading_mnemonic: You run along the <reading>ro</reading>ad (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is stuck into the <radical>ground</radical> on a <kanji>hill</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You reach the top of the <kanji>hill</kanji> and realize the entire hill is covered in <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use."

visually_similar_kanji: 待, 持, 時, 寺, 詩, 特
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>temple</radical> isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a <kanji>samurai</kanji>, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is <reading>samurai</reading>, which should be easy enough to remember.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>blade</radical> and the kanji <kanji>blade</kanji> are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: When you stab your <kanji>blade</kanji> into an enemy you shout "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>vines</radical>, so you <kanji>shout</kanji>! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout.
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>shout</kanji> so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "<reading>きょう</reading>と!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition.

meaning_mnemonic: From my <radical>mouth</radical> I have told you <radical>seven</radical> times not to do that. Now I have to <kanji>scold</kanji> you.
reading_mnemonic: What were you doing wrong that caused me to <kanji>scold</kanji> you? You were feeding the <reading>鹿</reading> (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>good luck</radical> radical and the <kanji>good luck</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: For <kanji>good luck</kanji>, you keep special <reading>kits</reading> (きつ) in your <reading>kitch</reading>en (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms.

meaning_mnemonic: When <radical>dirt</radical> and <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>suit</radical> one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a <kanji>tower</kanji>! A flower tower made of flower power!
reading_mnemonic: The only place flowers grow into <kanji>tower</kanji>s like this is in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> <radical>servant</radical> is the lower ranking <kanji>princess</kanji>. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>princess</kanji> goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. <reading>He may</reading> (ひめ) not like it."

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> loves her <radical>catapult</radical> for some good ol' fashioned <kanji>recreation</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for <kanji>recreation</kanji> is <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>measurement</radical> radical and the <kanji>measurement</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: "Calculate your enemy's position with accurate <kanji>measurement</kanji>," is more or less what <reading>Sun</reading> (すん) Tzu said, I think. The guy wrote The Art of War, you know. When Sun says measurements are important, you don't question him.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>wind</radical> coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a <kanji>storm</kanji>. Well, it is a storm, really.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>storm</kanji> is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get <reading>a rash</reading> (あらし).

meaning_mnemonic: If someone puts a <radical>blade</radical> to your <radical>heart</radical>, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to <kanji>endure</kanji> the pain and <kanji>conceal</kanji> your discomfort with the situation.
reading_mnemonic: Learning to <kanji>endure</kanji> and <kanji>conceal</kanji> is all part of your <reading>nin</reading>ja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing — you have to be able to endure this if you want to conceal yourself.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> told you that a <radical>flood</radical> last <radical>evening</radical> would <kanji>draw close</kanji>. There was nothing you could do to stop it, it seemed to be <kanji>be imminent</kanji>, coming in the darkness of the evening.
reading_mnemonic: Luckily whenever you sense a flood starting to <kanji>draw close</kanji>, <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) prepares a raft. Remember Satsuki? Such a talented little girl. I guess floods are common enough that she's learned to make rafts?

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> when you're in <radical>private</radical> to use an <radical>arrow</radical> to <kanji>push open</kanji> things.
reading_mnemonic: Your favorite thing to <kanji>push open</kanji> is your own <reading>eye</reading> (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ladle</radical> radical and the <kanji>ladle</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You use a <kanji>ladle</kanji> to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a <reading>toe</reading> (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground.

visually_similar_kanji: 午, 牛, 矢, 先, 失, 生, 株
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> to get off this <radical>jet</radical> is a beautiful, brilliant <kanji>vermilion</kanji> color.
reading_mnemonic: You jump onto the <kanji>vermilion</kanji> slide. It's actually more of a steep <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>omen</radical> growing from it, one single <kanji>peach</kanji> that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.
