reading_mnemonic: If <reading>momo</reading>taro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the <kanji>peach</kanji> growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "<reading>MO</reading>RE! <reading>MO</reading>RE!" (もも).

other_meanings: Sand Pear, Japanese Pear, Korean Pear, Asian Pear
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical> you cut off a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> is a <kanji>pear</kanji>. You've found some particularly big, sturdy ones, which is why you need the help of your knife. These pears are sure to be super juicy and delicious, but you need some extra tools to get them off the tree.
reading_mnemonic: As you cut the <kanji>pear</kanji>s down, you can't help but <reading>gnash</reading> (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast.

visually_similar_kanji: 爪, 瓜, 弧, 孤
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>animal</radical> that hangs out in <radical>melon</radical> patches is the elusive <kanji>fox</kanji>! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that.
reading_mnemonic: If you want to stop <kanji>fox</kanji>es from stealing your melons you can get one of those <reading>kits</reading> that <reading>neigh</reading> (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back!

visually_similar_kanji: 飽, 胞, 抱, 泡, 包
meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>stone</radical> into a <radical>wrap</radical> of some kind. This wrap happens to be a <kanji>cannon</kanji>, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.
reading_mnemonic: You aim the <kanji>cannon</kanji> at your own <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dragon</radical> radical is the same as this kanji, which is <kanji>dragon</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine a <kanji>dragon</kanji>. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> thing you put on your head to <radical>stand</radical> taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a <kanji>conical hat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>conical hat</kanji> is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's <reading>kasa</reading> (かさ)!

meaning_mnemonic: The part of <radical>rice</radical> that <radical>stand</radical>s up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the <kanji>grains</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You have a box of <kanji>grains</kanji>. <reading>Ryuu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers.

visually_similar_kanji: 録, 緑, 線, 綿
meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>thread</radical> tying <radical>Wolverine</radical> to a <radical>pig</radical>, balancing them over the <kanji>edge</kanji> of a cliff together.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the <kanji>edge</kanji>. Straight to their <reading>en</reading>d (えん).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>feather</radical> is on a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and they are attached <radical>together</radical>. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one <kanji>wing</kanji> of your amazing aircraft.
reading_mnemonic: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the <reading>yolk</reading> (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.

other_meanings: Arms And Legs, Legs And Arms, Limbs
visually_similar_kanji: 岐, 技, 支, 枝, 伎, 鼓, 枚
meaning_mnemonic: Looking at the <radical>moon</radical>, you notice it's grown a bunch of <radical>branch</radical>es. Wait, are those all… <kanji>limbs</kanji>?!
reading_mnemonic: After some consideration, you know who put all those <vocabulary>limb</vocabulary>s on the moon. It must've been none other than the moon <reading>shee</reading>p (し)!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>fang</radical> is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little <kanji>sprout</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: When the <kanji>sprout</kanji> gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking <reading>目</reading> (め), looking right at you.

meaning_mnemonic: No one can <radical>say</radical> what a <radical>scooter</radical> weighs in grains of <radical>rice</radical> — it's a <kanji>mystery</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: To get to the bottom of this mystery, you use a nozzle (なぞ). You pass rice through the nozzle one grain at a time, so you can figure out precisely how many grains of rice are equal to the weight of a scooter.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>pool</radical> is where you're going to go <kanji>fishing</kanji>. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.
reading_mnemonic: You caught a couple of gold fish. <reading>Two</reading> (つ) gold fish, actually!

visually_similar_kanji: 露, 霧, 雲, 雪, 震, 霜, 雰, 電
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> on a <radical>rice paddy</radical> means only one thing... <kanji>thunder</kanji>! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!
reading_mnemonic: You can’t run fast enough to escape the <kanji>thunder</kanji>, so you decide to hide under a pile of… <reading>rye</reading> (らい)?!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>long</radical> <radical>hair</radical> is your <radical>friend</radical>. It's your <kanji>hair</kanji> and you're so proud of it.
reading_mnemonic: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great <reading>神</reading> (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>alligator</radical> is <kanji>considerably</kanji> dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].
reading_mnemonic: Speaking of <kanji>considerably</kanji> terrifying, that place known as <reading>Nar</reading>nia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there.

meaning_mnemonic: If there's a <radical>treasure chest</radical>, there's always a <kanji>villain</kanji> too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>villain</kanji> beat you all the way to <reading>きょう</reading>と to get this particular treasure chest.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>toe</radical> is <radical>early</radical>. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the <kanji>table</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: What do all the early toes on the <kanji>table</kanji> do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, <reading>talk</reading>ing (たく).

meaning_mnemonic: From the <radical>mouth</radical> of your <radical>older brother</radical> comes... a <kanji>curse</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Turns out, he put the <reading>no ro</reading>ad (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>demon</radical> is just a <kanji>lump</kanji>. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>lump</kanji> of something is just a <reading>固まり</reading> (かたまり) — the hardened thing itself.

visually_similar_kanji: 熱, 勢, 熟, 壁
meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>receive</radical> instruction in a <radical>circle</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical>. Where are you? <kanji>Cram school</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Not only does your <kanji>cram school</kanji> teach kids in a circle in the dirt, it also plays music on a <reading>juke</reading>box (じゅく). Yes, a jukebox. They believe a jukebox's tunes help with cramming.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> who makes your <radical>house</radical> a home is your <kanji>bride</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you have a <kanji>bride</kanji> in your house, you can get rid of <reading>yo</reading>ur <reading>mai</reading>d (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning.

visually_similar_kanji: 嫌, 譲, 謙, 壌
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who is a <radical>nurse</radical> should be called <kanji>miss</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "Call me <kanji>Miss</kanji> <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう)," Joe says to you.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is sticking in the <radical>ground</radical> on top of a <radical>mountain</radical>. It's sticking into the very <kanji>peak</kanji>. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?
reading_mnemonic: You can't help but <reading>gawk</reading> (がく) at the <kanji>peak</kanji>. Somehow it looks even higher now.

meaning_mnemonic: Looking up to the <radical>cliff</radical>, you see the <radical>tree</radical>s, and the <radical>sun</radical> shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole <kanji>calendar</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a <kanji>calendar</kanji>, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is being blocked by a <radical>rain</radical> <radical>cloud</radical>, making it <kanji>cloudy</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both <reading>くも</reading>.

meaning_mnemonic: After the <radical>tsunami</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> comes out again and shines on these <radical>spikes</radical>. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still <kanji>damp</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As you're looking at the <kanji>damp</kanji> spikes, a <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo!

other_meanings: Ditch, Drain, Drainage, Drainage Ditch, Trench, Small Trench, Groove, Gap
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical> vs <radical>lifeguard</radical>. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the <kanji>gutter</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: In the <kanji>gutter</kanji> is a lifeguard, so Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち decides to survey the damage.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> in the shape of a <radical>dragon</radical> flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a <kanji>waterfall</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Despite how cool a dragon <kanji>waterfall</kanji> is, to be honest it's also pretty <reading>tacky</reading> (たき).

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>tsunami</radical> struck, it hit your <radical>tent</radical> full of <radical>beans</radical>. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of <kanji>lucidity</kanji>. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it!
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>lucidity</kanji> is clear to everyone because you wear a <reading>su</reading>it (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>animal</radical> <radical>king</radical>? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a <kanji>lunatic</kanji>, though.
reading_mnemonic: You might see that <kanji>crazy</kanji> <kanji>lunatic</kanji> hanging around the outskirts of <reading>きょう</reading>と. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels.

meaning_mnemonic: I <radical>protect</radical> my own <radical>animal</radical>s by going to <kanji>hunt</kanji> other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.
reading_mnemonic: I also do all my <kanji>hunt</kanji>s using a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways.

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>eye</radical> catches an <radical>omen</radical>, it's only natural that you will <kanji>stare</kanji> at it.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>stare</kanji> at the omen, you see Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spear</radical> radical and the <kanji>spear</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You take this <kanji>spear</kanji> and stab it into a cow. "<reading>MOO</reading> (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream.

visually_similar_kanji: 史, 便, 更, 使
meaning_mnemonic: You feel like a <radical>stone</radical> that’s been <radical>renew</radical>ed. How do renewed stones feel? <kanji>Stiff</kanji>. Very stiff.
reading_mnemonic: You remember how you used to cure these <kanji>stiff</kanji> body times: your old friend <reading>こう</reading>いち would just massage them out for you.

meaning_mnemonic: Below this <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>stone</radical>. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to <kanji>polish</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>polish</kanji> the stone due to your <reading>meager</reading> (みが) lifestyle.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical>s you have stored in your <radical>house</radical> reflect on your <kanji>earnings</kanji>. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains.
reading_mnemonic: Another way to check someone's <kanji>earnings</kanji> is to see if they have a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> with <radical>feathers</radical> (and presumably wings, too) is able to <kanji>fly</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Watching that sheep with feathers and wings flying around made you thirsty. You remember that you have a <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>ke</reading>ttle (かけ), so you reach into your car and grab your car kettle to make a special car-kettle brew.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> <radical>table</radical> is a table that's made entirely of <kanji>skin</kanji>. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin.
reading_mnemonic: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of <kanji>skin</kanji>, you realize that it's <reading>harder</reading> (はだ) than you expected.

meaning_mnemonic: If you've been to the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>past</radical>, you had to get the special <radical>stamp</radical> on your <kanji>leg</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their <kanji>leg</kanji> and it was <reading>Kyaku</reading> (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>boat</radical> radical and the <kanji>boat</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same reading that you learned with the vocabulary 船.

meaning_mnemonic: When you leave <radical>grain</radical>s in your <radical>mouth</radical> for long enough, they'll turn into <radical>flowers</radical> of <kanji>bacteria</kanji>. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time.
reading_mnemonic: There is a lot of this <kanji>bacteria</kanji> in the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're showing me your "<radical>spirit</radical> <radical>fruit</radical>" then you are just <kanji>naked</kanji>. You're <kanji>nude</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Known for being <kanji>naked</kanji> (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god <reading>Ra</reading> (ら).

meaning_mnemonic: I'm putting all my <radical>shellfish</radical> on <radical>someone</radical>, hoping they'll win the race! This is a <kanji>gamble</kanji> and you're gambling.
reading_mnemonic: If you win this <kanji>gamble</kanji> you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new <reading>ca</reading>r (か)!

meaning_mnemonic: Something made of <radical>gold</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in a <radical>village</radical>. It's a <kanji>bell</kanji>!  The village bell.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>bell</kanji> rings whenever the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> <radical>now</radical> has a <radical>cloud</radical> over it, creating <kanji>shade</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The building that's getting this nice <kanji>shade</kanji> is the <reading>inn</reading> (いん) you're staying at.

meaning_mnemonic: Coming down with the <radical>rain</radical> is <radical>two</radical> <radical>spikes</radical>. They go right through two <kanji>ghost</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: You come across the <kanji>ghost</kanji>s, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun that's in that <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and end our suffering."

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spoon</radical> to measure a <radical>geoduck</radical> is a very <kanji>approximate</kanji> measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?
reading_mnemonic: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an <kanji>approximate</kanji>. So, you take the <reading>core</reading> (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cloud</radical> floating above a <radical>demon</radical> has its <kanji>soul</kanji> in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the <kanji>spirit</kanji> it once was.
reading_mnemonic: You shout out and beg its <kanji>soul</kanji> for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a <reading>con</reading>dor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!"

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your sad <radical>life</radical> aims a <radical>kick</radical> at the <kanji>straw sack</kanji> you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your straw sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it's not something you want to have kicked.
reading_mnemonic: You manage to get your <kanji>straw sack</kanji> out of the way as you shout "<reading>Heyo</reading> (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!" Unfortunately your leader's friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. "Heyo!" he shouts, mockingly.

meaning_mnemonic: I have <radical>five</radical> things in my <radical>mouth</radical> and <kanji>I</kanji> need them all for <kanji>me</kanji>. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Me</kanji>, personally, <kanji>I</kanji> am quite thirsty so I ask for some “<reading>waga</reading>” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!”

meaning_mnemonic: You use <radical>black</radical> <radical>dirt</radical> to make <kanji>black ink</kanji>. That's what you use to write in black!
reading_mnemonic: Be careful that you don't spill <kanji>black ink</kanji> on anyone or anything. If you do, you have to own it. Imagine spilling black ink on someone, and when they confront you, you yell, "Yeah I got black ink on you, so <reading>sue me</reading> (すみ)!"

visually_similar_kanji: 礼, 札, 乱, 乳
meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>child</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical> in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a <kanji>cavity</kanji> in the road. It's a big <kanji>hole</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: "Into my <kanji>cavity</kanji> you go!" yells a voice. It is <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>roof</radical> is your <radical>heart</radical>. OR! In a <radical>net</radical> in the <radical>street</radical>. Which would you <kanji>rather</kanji>?
reading_mnemonic: As you try to decide which you'd <kanji>rather</kanji> have, your <reading>neigh</reading>bors (ねい) come out and grab the heart out of your hands.

meaning_mnemonic: You need to bring <radical>charcoal</radical> under this <radical>roof</radical> to heat the <kanji>dormitory</kanji>. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>dormitory</kanji> is on an island, so when you go out to get the charcoal you have to take a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat. You row and row and row until you reach the shed with all the charcoal. Then you row and row and row it back to the dormitory.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> on a <radical>towel</radical> because you're the <kanji>sovereign</kanji>. As a sovereign, you're too important to be getting your shoes dirty. Everywhere you go, you're standing on a towel — that's how people know you're the sovereign.
reading_mnemonic: And it's not just any towel you stand on. To show that you're the <kanji>sovereign</kanji>, it has the symbol of a <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tot on it. The mighty, sovereign tater tot! That's how everyone knows it belongs to the sovereign.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Poop</radical> <radical>Poop</radical> <radical>Mountain</radical> is covered in poop because it is such a <kanji>secluded</kanji> place.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>secluded</kanji> Poop Poop Mountain is a favorite of <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう). They go there to get away from their phones to get in touch with nature again.

meaning_mnemonic: You're standing under a <radical>canopy</radical> when you see something strange sticking out of the <radical>dirt</radical>. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant <kanji>manor</kanji> starts rising out of the ground with you on top!
reading_mnemonic: The beautiful <kanji>manor</kanji> begins to shake and the <reading>shou</reading>gun (しょう) bursts out of the front door. "WHO HAS UNEARTHED MY SECRET MANOR?!" he screams.

visually_similar_kanji: 暫, 析, 折, 祈, 新
meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>car</radical> and an <radical>axe</radical> to <kanji>slice</kanji> down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood.
reading_mnemonic: You were driving around in <reading>Zan</reading>zibar (ざん) when you <kanji>slice</kanji>d down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe.

meaning_mnemonic: With the <radical>power</radical> of your <radical>mouth</radical> you command a <radical>tree</radical> to become a <kanji>shelf</kanji>. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth.
reading_mnemonic: Once you turn the tree into a <kanji>shelf</kanji> you put the shelf in your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money.

visually_similar_kanji: 練, 陣, 錬, 陳
meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>tree</radical> in the <radical>east</radical> that looks like a <kanji>building</kanji>. The tree is tall and straight and doesn't have any leaves or branches. It's basically a big wooden building.
reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>building</kanji> happens to be in the center of <reading>とう</reading>きょう. If you need to find east (which is where とうきょう is), you just look for the building.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> is very <radical>odd</radical>, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a <kanji>chair</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: But, this odd tree <kanji>chair</kanji> is also home to an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>stop</radical> keeping <radical>canine</radical>s which are <radical>small</radical> once you reach a certain number of <kanji>years old</kanji>. You'll be hitting that age limit this <kanji>year</kanji>, which means your <kanji>time</kanji> with your small canine will end and you'll have to grow up and get a bigger one.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the vocab word 〜才 which also meant "<kanji>years old</kanji>"? Well, this has the same reading: さい.

visually_similar_kanji: 飽, 胞, 抱, 包, 砲
meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>wrap</radical>s around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of <kanji>bubbles</kanji>. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created.
reading_mnemonic: One of the biggest <kanji>bubbles</kanji> heads straight for your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう), engulfs it, and picks it up into the air!

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>animal</radical> that <radical>kick</radical>s <radical>dirt</radical> into people's <radical>mouth</radical>s is a <kanji>monkey</kanji>. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse.
reading_mnemonic: You spit the dirt out of your mouth and look back at the <kanji>monkey</kanji> to see that it's <reading>salu</reading>ting (さる) you. Is... is it mocking you?

meaning_mnemonic: When you get <radical>sick</radical> you always eat a <radical>hot pepper</radical>. It's a <kanji>habit</kanji> you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone you know has a different <kanji>habit</kanji> when they get sick. Instead, they eat <reading>cous</reading>cous (くせ). But you think couscous is gross. It's bland and does nothing for your stuffy noses and scratchy throats. I wonder how you can convince them to replace their habit with your own.

other_meanings: Ancestral Festival, Bon, Obon, Festival Of The Dead, Obon Festival, Lantern Festival, Ancestry Festival, Bon Festival
meaning_mnemonic: You put <radical>part</radical> of your food on a <radical>plate</radical>, then put that on a <kanji>tray</kanji> to keep it safe. This tray is an offering for the <kanji>ancestral festival</kanji>, where your ancestors' spirits visit you to check in and share some of that food you're offering on a tray.
reading_mnemonic: The plate you put on the <kanji>tray</kanji> for the <kanji>ancestral festival</kanji> is made of <reading>bone</reading> (ぼん). Bone china, that is. How fancy… And appropriate, considering bone china is made from actual bone.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>eye</radical> gets kicked with a <radical>cleat</radical> that came careening toward your <radical>forehead</radical> when it popped off someone doing a <radical>dance</radical>, and you <kanji>blink</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>blink</kanji> and blink and <reading>soon</reading> (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more.

meaning_mnemonic: Inside your <radical>eye</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s a tiny <radical>village</radical> that makes up your <kanji>pupil</kanji>. That's the black part of your eye!
reading_mnemonic: All of the people in your <kanji>pupil</kanji> eat <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts (どう) all day long. That's why your eye is shaped like a doughnut, with the "hole" (village) as their home.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>crab</radical> moves a <radical>stone</radical> because he is playing the game <kanji>Go</kanji>. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Go</kanji> is pronounced <reading>Go</reading> (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember!

visually_similar_kanji: 相, 阻, 粗, 祖, 狙, 組
meaning_mnemonic: Someone with a <radical>top hat</radical> comes and tells you that your <radical>grain</radical>s are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a <kanji>tariff</kanji> that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple.
reading_mnemonic: You're listening to all the things in this <kanji>tariff</kanji> and you finally get fed up and ask what isn't being taxed now. The top hat man looks at you and smiles, holding out his hand. In his hand is some <reading>soa</reading>p (そ).

meaning_mnemonic: The part of the <radical>grain</radical> people <radical>favor</radical> the most is the <kanji>head of the plant</kanji>. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are.
reading_mnemonic: When you want to harvest the <kanji>head of the plant</kanji> you'd like to eat, you need to use a <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head.

meaning_mnemonic: Some <radical>grains</radical> get stuck in his <radical>cleat</radical>, and <radical>Wolverine</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> grows <kanji>calm</kanji>. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down.
reading_mnemonic: Now that Wolverine is <kanji>calm</kanji>, tears come to his eyes. Being calm has given him perspective on what his anger has done. Oh, wait no. There are just some <reading>on</reading>ions (おん) in his cleats too, and they're making calm tears trickle down his eyes.

visually_similar_kanji: 緑, 線, 錦, 縁
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>white</radical> <radical>thread</radical> in your <radical>towel</radical> comes from <kanji>cotton</kanji>. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>cotton</kanji> is made by <reading>men</reading> (めん).

meaning_mnemonic: If you pick the wrong kind of <radical>flowers</radical>, you'll be put into <radical>prison</radical> with nothing but <radical>rice</radical> to eat. You'll especially want to avoid picking <kanji>chrysanthemums</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If you go to prison for <kanji>chrysanthemum</kanji> picking, everyone in the prison is going to <reading>kick</reading> (きく) you nonstop. You broke the chrysanthemum picking law, so kicking is your punishment. And believe me, you don't want these kicks.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Say</radical> "<radical>two</radical> <radical>big</radical> <radical>prison</radical>s" with <kanji>pride</kanji>! Nobody said you can't have pride after serving time in two big prisons. So say it with your chest!
reading_mnemonic: After mustering all your <kanji>pride</kanji>, you feel like a new person, reborn almost. "I feel like a <reading>子</reading> (こ) again!", you proclaim to the world.

meaning_mnemonic: Make <radical>barracks</radical> out of <radical>gold</radical> and they will get <kanji>dull</kanji> quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days.
reading_mnemonic: As you stare sadly at the <kanji>dull</kanji> barracks, the <reading>don</reading> (どん) shows up out of nowhere, and he's pissed. He turns his angry gaze toward you and says, "How did my barracks get so dull? Are you at fault? This is bad, this is very bad. Someone will pay for this."

visually_similar_kanji: 縛, 鐘, 鏡, 練, 陳, 棟, 陣, 穂
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>gold</radical> from the <radical>east</radical> needs <kanji>tempering</kanji> before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it's entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you'd do in a forge.
reading_mnemonic: The smithy where you're doing the <kanji>tempering</kanji> is just a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん). You need a rental for your tempering because you haven't sold enough gold to own your own smithy yet. It's seen its fair share of tempering, so it's a pretty shabby rental…

meaning_mnemonic: You want to turn your <radical>gold</radical> <radical>comb</radical> into a <radical>weapon</radical>, so you throw it into the <kanji>forge</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You're trying to work the <kanji>forge</kanji>, but it's harder than you thought. You end up forging outside all day and get a wicked <reading>tan</reading> (たん).

meaning_mnemonic: You take some <radical>gold</radical> and cover your <radical>yoga</radical> <radical>brush</radical> in it, turning it into a <kanji>key</kanji>. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>key</kanji> has to be perfect, because if it isn't the <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>gui</reading>llotine (かぎ) will come down and chop off your hand!

visually_similar_kanji: 相, 租, 粗, 祖, 狙, 組
meaning_mnemonic: If you see a <radical>building</radical> wearing a giant <radical>top hat</radical>, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to <kanji>thwart</kanji> all of the plans the people in other buildings have.
reading_mnemonic: The building next door is being painted, and the top hat building is jealous. It <kanji>thwart</kanji>s the painting plans by dumping <reading>so</reading>ap (そ) out of its windows and onto the painters and the building!

meaning_mnemonic: You get <radical>rain</radical> <radical>orders</radical>. Your orders are to make sure there is <kanji>zero</kanji> <kanji>spill</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to make sure there is <kanji>zero</kanji> <kanji>spill</kanji> when it rains is to get rid of the rain. You use a special <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun and zap the rain right out of the sky. There will be zero spills because there will be zero rain.

meaning_mnemonic: Below the <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>demon</radical>. This demon is a <kanji>devil</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Why is the <kanji>devil</kanji> under a canopy of trees? Because he's looking for his <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま).

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>nine</radical> <radical>bird</radical>s and one of them is a <kanji>dove</kanji> and another is a <kanji>pigeon</kanji>. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders.
reading_mnemonic: Take a look at the <kanji>pigeon</kanji> in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the <reading>heart</reading> (はと) from its little body.

meaning_mnemonic: Your village wants to take the <radical>village</radical> <radical>dog</radical> and <radical>boil</radical> it, and you can think of no other response than <kanji>SHUT UP</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: The villagers are mad that you told them to <kanji>shut up</kanji>, and they start to <reading>mock</reading> (もく) you. They put their hands on their hips, lean forward, cross their eyes, and yell "SHUT UP!" back.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> and <radical>Wolverine</radical> take a <radical>slide</radical> to <kanji>Italy</kanji>. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun!
reading_mnemonic: Before Professor X can get off the slide into <kanji>Italy</kanji>, a large <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>narwhal</radical> <radical>construction</radical> crew needs all the <kanji>help</kanji> he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city.
reading_mnemonic: Then you discover a <reading>saw</reading> (さ) who would be a great big <kanji>help</kanji>. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away.

meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>lid</radical>, you hit yourself in the <radical>mouth</radical> and then <radical>kick</radical> it like a <kanji>pathetic</kanji> loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic.
reading_mnemonic: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the <reading>eye</reading> (あい). How <kanji>pathetic</kanji>. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>landslide</radical> came out of your <radical>mouth</radical> and created your <kanji>lips</kanji>. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole.
reading_mnemonic: Now you can use your new <kanji>lips</kanji> to enjoy a nice, cold <reading>Kuchi beer</reading> (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there.

visually_similar_kanji: 据, 堀, 掘, 握, 屈, 届, 居, 涙, 房, 戻, 泥, 遅, 漏
meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical> there are <radical>flag</radical>s and <radical>horns</radical> lined up with a <radical>lantern</radical> attached to them, making a <kanji>fence</kanji>. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in.
reading_mnemonic: You want to know what this <kanji>fence</kanji> is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of <reading>hay</reading> (へい).

other_meanings: Fall, Fall Down, Falling, Falling Down
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>building</radical> falls into the <radical>dirt</radical> when a <radical>pig</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> <kanji>crash</kanji>es into it. The building literally crashes to the ground when the horned pig attacks it.
reading_mnemonic: You pull the poor pig out of the rubble of the <kanji>crash</kanji>. It's not dead, but it had a nasty bump to the head and now thinks it's a bird. "<reading>TWEE</reading>T (つい)!" says the pig. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" Poor confused pig.

meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>woman</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical>, you have a <kanji>likeness</kanji> to me.
reading_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>likeness</kanji> to <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (じょ) when you wear that mouth.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>wave</radical> crashes into a <radical>woman</radical>, transforming her into an <kanji>old woman</kanji>! The wave washes away all of the woman's makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is.
reading_mnemonic: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an <kanji>old woman</kanji>, the old woman starts to <reading>baa</reading> (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes "Baa! Baa!" and hops around on all fours like a sheep.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>shrimp</radical> is the exact length of a <kanji>shaku</kanji>, or <kanji>Japanese foot</kanji>. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot.
reading_mnemonic: How is <kanji>shaku</kanji>, the <kanji>Japanese foot</kanji>, pronounced by <reading>Shaq</reading> (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>mountain</radical> on top of a bunch of <radical>dirt</radical> with a steep <radical>cliff</radical>. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the <kanji>cliff</kanji> even bigger and steeper and scarier.
reading_mnemonic: You can't believe how big the <kanji>cliff</kanji> is now with the mountain and the dirt. You look at it for so long, you just become another <reading>gawker</reading> (がけ) who can't stop staring at the huge cliff. It really is huge.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>towel</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>towel</kanji> as well.
reading_mnemonic: You know who loves <kanji>towel</kanji>s? The <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put きん on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one.

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>towel</radical> and wrap it around your head to keep the <radical>sun</radical> out of your <radical>eye</radical>s. You've invented... the <kanji>hat</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: After inventing the <kanji>hat</kanji>, you wanted to show it off to everyone, so you went to the <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) alley. You really stood out bowling strike after strike in your fancy new hat, and before you knew it, people had coined a term for your funky headpiece. That's right — you became the namesake of the iconic bowler hat!

meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>penguin</radical> over there seems to have a <radical>towel</radical> stuffed with <kanji>cash</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your eyes follow the <kanji>cash</kanji>, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a <reading>hay</reading> (へい) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles.

visually_similar_kanji: 眼, 根, 退, 良, 郎, 限, 眠
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>soul</radical> will only inhabit a <radical>root</radical> if it's holding a <kanji>grudge</kanji>. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something.
reading_mnemonic: If you see one of these <kanji>grudge</kanji> trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a <reading>con</reading>dor (こん). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>soul</radical> <radical>mask</radical> helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see <kanji>hate</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much <kanji>hate</kanji> because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of <reading>zo</reading>mbies (ぞう).

meaning_mnemonic: You keep your <radical>tongue</radical> to your <radical>self</radical> to give your <radical>heart</radical> a <kanji>rest</kanji>. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time.
reading_mnemonic: What better way to <kanji>rest</kanji> than to eat some <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief.

meaning_mnemonic: After passing through a <radical>door</radical>, you use a <radical>feather</radical> to put the finishing touches on a <kanji>folding fan</kanji>. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is.
reading_mnemonic: Your biggest <kanji>folding fan</kanji> customer is a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur.

meaning_mnemonic: What would a <radical>door</radical> <radical>criminal</radical> steal? A <kanji>door</kanji>, of course, but specifically a <kanji>hinged door</kanji>. You know, the kind that swings open and shut? That's the kind of door 扉 means.
reading_mnemonic: To protect your <kanji>door</kanji>, you get help from <reading>飛び Ra</reading> (とびら). 飛び Ra is the flying (飛び) version of Ra, the Egyptian sun god. Whenever a criminal tries to steal your door, 飛び Ra flies out from behind it and blinds them with his sun-god brightness.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>fingers</radical> in the <radical>thousand</radical>s and while looking up at the <radical>sun</radical> you decide you want to <kanji>insert</kanji> them in there.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>insert</kanji> one finger, it burns up immediately, and its <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone.

other_meanings: Palm Of The Hand, Palm Of Hand, Palm Of One's Hand
meaning_mnemonic: If you want to cover a <radical>Viking</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical> with your <radical>hand</radical>, you have to use your <kanji>palm</kanji>. Why the palm? Well, if you do it knuckles-to-mouth, you're sort of just punching the Viking… and you don't want a punch a Viking. That's why you use the palm.
reading_mnemonic: This Viking-touching technique of using the <kanji>palm</kanji> was developed by the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). The Shogun has to deal with a lot of loudmouthed Vikings, so he's learned to use his palm to cover their mouths.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> that is <radical>stamp</radical>ed with one pattern, then <radical>stamp</radical>ed with another pattern, over and over, is the <kanji>willow</kanji> tree.
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves <kanji>willow</kanji> trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>crab</radical> will try to hide what it <radical>lack</radical>s with <kanji>deceit</kanji>. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Deceit</kanji> can only take you so far, and soon the crab is caught, tried for its crimes and coverups, and sentenced to death via <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>mohawk</radical> and it begins to <kanji>drip</kanji>. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while.
reading_mnemonic: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed <reading>techie</reading> (てき), so you develop a device to stop the <kanji>drip</kanji> drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits.

meaning_mnemonic: Without a <radical>fire</radical>, you will <radical>lack</radical> the ability to <kanji>cook</kanji> anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>cook</kanji> your meal evenly by <reading>swi</reading>nging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Before</radical> you <radical>boil</radical> something, make sure that you <kanji>roast</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: Now you <kanji>roast</kanji> yourself some <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). Roasted centaur goes well with tea.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>big</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> <radical>treasure</radical> is <kanji>refreshing</kanji>! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing.
reading_mnemonic: You’d had a <reading>sour</reading> (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo <kanji>refreshing</kanji>!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>rice paddy</radical> there is a <radical>forehead</radical> with a <radical>top hat</radical>. It sits atop an area of <kanji>tatami mat</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: Who made this creepy <kanji>tatami mat</kanji> altar? It was <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village.

meaning_mnemonic: Rub <radical>charcoal</radical> under your <radical>eye</radical>s if you want to see <kanji>clear</kanji>ly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun.
reading_mnemonic: You have to have <kanji>clear</kanji> vision because you're about to go out in your <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death.

meaning_mnemonic: Take this <radical>stone</radical> and throw it at <radical>nine</radical> <radical>cross</radical>es to <kanji>smash</kanji> them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits!
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>smash</kanji> these crosses, you think of your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい) and how much you want to smash the people who took it away from you. Your cyborg was so good at smashing things too. You could be smashing together, if you didn't have to sell it.

meaning_mnemonic: You give <radical>bamboo</radical> to <radical>someone</radical> and they make them into <kanji>chopsticks</kanji>. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession.
reading_mnemonic: Now use those <kanji>chopsticks</kanji> to eat some delicious <reading>hash</reading> (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>rice</radical> <radical>fortune</radical> is <kanji>sticky</kanji>. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice.
reading_mnemonic: This rice is so <kanji>sticky</kanji> that you are able to sculpt <reading>nen</reading>doroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it.

meaning_mnemonic: Sitting safely under your <radical>canopy</radical> you take <radical>rice</radical> and <radical>dirt</radical>, mix it up, and create unique <kanji>cosmetics</kanji> for your face.
reading_mnemonic: You need these <kanji>cosmetics</kanji> because you have a meeting with the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) coming up. You want to impress him, and you don't want anyone to copy your look.

visually_similar_kanji: 銅, 洞, 同, 阿, 河, 向, 詞, 飼
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> is the <radical>same</radical> as your <kanji>torso</kanji>. You must have a really huge torso for it to be the same as the moon.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>torso</kanji> got so big because of all the <reading>dough</reading>nuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> growing around a <radical>heart</radical> with a <kanji>wick</kanji> sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow.
reading_mnemonic: Sometimes the <kanji>wick</kanji> burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your <reading>shin</reading> (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>insect</radical> specializing in <radical>construction</radical> builds a <kanji>rainbow</kanji>. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>rainbow</kanji> building insect is so <reading>needy</reading> (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!”

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> the <radical>key</radical> to telling a <kanji>lie</kanji> is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>lie</kanji> you told was about not stealing your buddy’s <reading>saw</reading> (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well.

visually_similar_kanji: 雪, 雲, 電, 雰, 震, 露, 雷, 霜
meaning_mnemonic: It's <radical>rain</radical>ing on your <radical>spear</radical> that has <radical>winter</radical> <radical>power</radical>. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates <kanji>fog</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Through the <kanji>fog</kanji> you see the shape of a mythical <reading>kiri</reading>n (きり). You can only see the outline through the fog, but you know it's there.

meaning_mnemonic: When a flower looks like a <radical>mouth</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> that reach up to <radical>heaven</radical>, you know it's in <kanji>blossom</kanji>. It's all opened up like a mouth, and the pistil and stamen are like horns reaching up to heaven for its sunlight and rain.
reading_mnemonic: If it's shaped like a mouth with horns poking out of it, you know it's going to be a tough little <kanji>blossom</kanji>. That's why you'll need a <reading>saw</reading> (さ) if you've got any hope of cutting it down for your blossom collection.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>dirt</radical> needs a  <radical>clown</radical> in it if you want to <kanji>cultivate</kanji> good crops. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing?
reading_mnemonic: Before you can start this whole <kanji>cultivation</kanji> process however, you have to say <reading>bye</reading> (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>surplus</radical> will cover all the <radical>dirt</radical> with <kanji>paint</kanji>. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors.
reading_mnemonic: You touch the <kanji>paint</kanji> in the dirt with your <reading>toe</reading> (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow.

meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>shrimp</radical> on <radical>ice</radical> at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been <kanji>exhaust</kanji>ed. It's all gone! You never thought they'd <kanji>use up</kanji> their shrimp supply so quickly.
reading_mnemonic: How could the store <kanji>use up</kanji> its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their <reading>jean</reading>s (じん) . Aha! The culprit!

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>towel</radical> and make it <radical>long</radical>. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your <kanji>notebook</kanji>, which you will write all your notes in.
reading_mnemonic: Inside your long towel <kanji>notebook</kanji> you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading>" (ちょう).

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>cleat</radical> to climb a <radical>tree</radical> and your <radical>hair</radical> gets the same <kanji>coloring</kanji> as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red!
reading_mnemonic: This cool <kanji>coloring</kanji> can only happen because you turned yourself into a <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones.

meaning_mnemonic: If you try to put your <radical>soul</radical> into <radical>every</radical>thing, you'll <kanji>regret</kanji> it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>regret</kanji> is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but <reading>kay</reading>aking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club.

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>soul</radical> has an <radical>idea</radical> it's just a <kanji>recollection</kanji> of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>surplus</radical> of <radical>ladle</radical>s laid out <kanji>diagonally</kanji> in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there.
reading_mnemonic: In front of this <kanji>diagonal</kanji> pattern is a <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>district</radical> is full of <radical>weapons</radical>, but everyone prefers to <kanji>punch</kanji> each other. When everyone's armed, things can escalate quickly, so it's better to stick to fists to be safe.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Fire</radical> you use to light up the <radical>street</radical> needs to go in a <kanji>lamp</kanji>. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>king</radical> gives you a <radical>knife</radical> you become part of his <kanji>squad</kanji>. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>mysterious</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> there is some <kanji>livestock</kanji>. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed.
reading_mnemonic: Your favorite member of the mysterious <kanji>livestock</kanji> crew is a little <reading>chick</reading> (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings.

meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>cliff</radical>, the <radical>pope</radical> is holding a <kanji>shield</kanji>. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off.
reading_mnemonic: The light of the pope's <kanji>shield</kanji> begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's <reading>June</reading> (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell!

meaning_mnemonic: You need to feed this <radical>grain</radical> to a <radical>flower</radical> wearing <radical>turkey</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> so you start the <kanji>harvest</kanji>. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them.

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>rake</radical> in for a <radical>measurement</radical> but it is <kanji>resistant</kanji>. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others.
reading_mnemonic: Because the rake is persistently <kanji>resistant</kanji>, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck <reading>tie</reading> (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly.

meaning_mnemonic: There's <radical>power</radical>, <radical>power</radical>, and <radical>power</radical> stacked on top of the <radical>moon</radical>, <kanji>threaten</kanji>ing to bring it down!
reading_mnemonic: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to <kanji>threaten</kanji> the safety of <reading>きょう</reading>と. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> has a lot of <radical>power</radical> that is <radical>power</radical> it gets from the <radical>power</radical> of every <kanji>armpit</kanji> of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices.
reading_mnemonic: This is a pretty <reading>wacky</reading> (わき) <kanji>armpit</kanji> image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life?

other_meanings: Accumulate, Save Up, Store, Store Up, Build Up
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> are <radical>mysterious</radical>ly appearing in the <radical>rice paddy</radical>. No matter what you do to them, they continue to <kanji>amass</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: The type of <radical>insect</radical> that ruins your <radical>writing</radical> is the <kanji>mosquito</kanji>. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing.
reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>mosquito</kanji> noise sounds like it's driving a tiny <reading>ca</reading>r (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car?

meaning_mnemonic: There is an <radical>insect</radical> on the <radical>roof</radical> in a <radical>spoon</radical>. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a <kanji>snake</kanji> to your roof.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>shellfish</radical> are worth a <radical>fortune</radical> because you decided to <kanji>paste</kanji> your fortune to the shellfish.
reading_mnemonic: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use <kanji>paste</kanji> to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!" Paste.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>servant</radical> uses a <radical>stool</radical> to break open <radical>shellfish</radical>. This is really <kanji>clever</kanji>, because shucking shellfish is a lot of work. It's also a <kanji>wise</kanji> move, because it'll save him time that he can spend on all his other servant chores.
reading_mnemonic: "Yes, more <kanji>clever</kanji> than you!" he yells, tearing off his servant's disguise. "It is I, <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai. I won't let you eat these shellfish. I'm taking them back to the sea, where they belong!"

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>foot</radical>, as your <radical>mama</radical> says, was given the <radical>task</radical> to <kanji>dance</kanji>. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance!
reading_mnemonic: You both <kanji>dance</kanji> so much that you develop an <reading>odo</reading>r (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>light</radical> shines on your <radical>forehead</radical> in your <radical>car</radical> with a great <kanji>radiance</kanji>. The car you are in is a convertible, so the light shines right onto your big bald forehead. The light has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from this light hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>radiance</kanji> is the <reading>key</reading> (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>landslide</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> <kanji>humiliate</kanji>s you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet.

meaning_mnemonic: You drive your <radical>scooter</radical> off this <radical>cliff</radical>, holding your <radical>cross</radical> tight to your chest, at a <kanji>swift</kanji> speed.
reading_mnemonic: Because you had such a <kanji>swift</kanji> take off, you didn't notice that your <reading>jean</reading>s (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>scooter</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> with a <radical>pig</radical> riding on it will be able to <kanji>accomplish</kanji> anything.

reading_mnemonic: The gold <kanji>flower pot</kanji> has a <reading>hatch</reading> (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the flower pot!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>gate</radical> makes the <radical>sound</radical> of <kanji>darkness</kanji>. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to taste the <kanji>darkness</kanji> and discover that it is so <reading>yummy</reading> (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy!

meaning_mnemonic: In this <radical>building</radical> there's a <radical>small</radical> <radical>sun</radical> that's <radical>small</radical>. They keep this small, small sun inside of a <kanji>crevice</kanji>.

reading_mnemonic: Before <kanji>horse riding</kanji>, you’ll need the <reading>key</reading> (き) to access the stable and let out the odd horse you'll be riding.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>crab trap</radical> has the <radical>power</radical> of <kanji>intuition</kanji>. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them.

visually_similar_kanji: 維, 離, 雑, 難, 稚, 雄, 誰, 進, 推, 確, 権, 雅, 准, 椎

reading_mnemonic: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is <kanji>solely</kanji> his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a <reading>U-ey</reading> (ゆい). You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>dirt</radical> there is a <radical>lid</radical> trying to cover the number of <radical>times</radical> the <radical>dawn</radical> has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a <kanji>podium</kanji>. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!)
reading_mnemonic: You listen to what the <kanji>podium</kanji> has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the <reading>dawn</reading> (だん), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>commander</radical> who's <radical>big</radical> will use his size to <kanji>encourage</kanji> his troops.
reading_mnemonic: He <kanji>encourage</kanji>s the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike.
