reading_mnemonic: You can tell someone's a <kanji>royal consort</kanji> by the <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ) she radiates. Royal consorts are all smoking hot… literally, because they have to wear bulky, elaborate dresses that were designed several centuries ago. Those things trap heat like nobody's business.

meaning_mnemonic: You give a <radical>flag</radical> and a <radical>spoon</radical> to a <kanji>nun</kanji> as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds.
reading_mnemonic: You’re getting down on one <reading>knee</reading> (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the <kanji>nun</kanji>. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved!

meaning_mnemonic: If someone <radical>loiter</radical>s it's <radical>correct</radical> to <kanji>subjugate</kanji> them.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>subjugate</kanji> these loiterers with your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing.

other_meanings: Comprehension, Realization, Perception, Perceive, Awaken, Awakening, Realise, Realisation
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> connects to <radical>five</radical> different <radical>mouths</radical>, allowing you to <kanji>realize</kanji> something. You can realize profound truths about the world with these five mouths speaking to your soul.
reading_mnemonic: Right now those five mouths are helping you to <kanji>realize</kanji> something about <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご). First you hear Godzilla, then you see him, then you smell him, then you touch him. Finally you taste Godzilla. Now you've realized exactly what kind of thing he is. You truly know Godzilla.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> is going <radical>wild</radical> because you're <kanji>confused</kanji>. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild!
reading_mnemonic: Whenever you're <kanji>confused</kanji>, <reading>こう</reading>いち appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by こういち is the best medicine for confusion.

visually_similar_kanji: 押, 軸, 油, 袖
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> give you a good <radical>reason</radical> to <kanji>extract</kanji> things. You extract juice from fruits, oil from seeds, and coffee from beans. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason.
reading_mnemonic: Your magic fingers can even extract the essence out of living things, so you decide to <kanji>extract</kanji> some from <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう). You always thought a nice Chewbacca extract could take your cookies to the next level. It'll help offset the sweetness and make them extra chewy (or chewbacca-y!).

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> and a <radical>stone</radical> to begin <kanji>cultivation</kanji> of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Cultivation</kanji> is suddenly halted because a <reading>tack</reading> (たく) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks!

meaning_mnemonic: You run your <radical>fingers</radical> along the words of a  <radical>paragraph</radical>. You are learning about the law because you plan to <kanji>arrest</kanji> somebody.
reading_mnemonic: Who do you want to <kanji>arrest</kanji>? You want to arrest <reading>こう</reading>いち. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now.

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>stool</radical>, another <radical>stool</radical>, and yet another <radical>stool</radical> and stack them on top of a <radical>tree</radical> to make a <kanji>mulberry</kanji> bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>mulberry</kanji> tree then produces a <reading>qua</reading>ntity (くわ) of mulberries. Yum.

meaning_mnemonic: Bite a <radical>tree</radical>'s <radical>root</radical> with your <radical>fang</radical> to get an <kanji>approximation</kanji> on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close.
reading_mnemonic: As you're recording your <kanji>approximation</kanji> down,  somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey <reading>guy</reading> (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway.

meaning_mnemonic: In the event of a <radical>tsunami</radical>, <radical>Wolverine</radical>, your <radical>forehead</radical>, and a <radical>stool</radical> will all be <kanji>immersed</kanji> in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool.
reading_mnemonic: Still <kanji>immersed</kanji>, the stool floats over and hits you in the <reading>shin</reading> (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> and a couple <radical>fire</radical>s run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a <kanji>faint</kanji> remnant of what was once there.
reading_mnemonic: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a <kanji>faint</kanji> remainder of what was, your <reading>tan</reading> (たん) is extremely faint as well.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> at the <radical>gate</radical> of the <radical>king</radical> makes sure all of his plants get <kanji>watered</kanji>. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami.
reading_mnemonic: These plants are getting <kanji>watered</kanji> in <reading>June</reading> (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did.

meaning_mnemonic: If <radical>someone</radical> wants to <radical>boil</radical>, you let them <kanji>boil</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Welp, the pot is at a rolling <kanji>boil</kanji> and your <reading>knee</reading> (に) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> takes his <radical>slide</radical> into his private <radical>jet</radical> and is given a <kanji>pearl</kanji> as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards.
reading_mnemonic: The king takes the <kanji>pearl</kanji> and tosses it into a <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls.

meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>stone</radical>, a <radical>tree</radical>, another <radical>tree</radical>, and a <radical>coat rack</radical>. That stone and two trees will make the perfect <kanji>foundation</kanji>, or <kanji>cornerstone</kanji>, for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable.
reading_mnemonic: After you finish the <kanji>foundation</kanji>, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with <reading>so</reading>ap (そ).

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>lid</radical>, and aiming it at the <radical>sun</radical> you <radical>kick</radical> it into the air and eventually it begins to <kanji>decline</kanji> and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun.
reading_mnemonic: As the lid begins to <kanji>decline</kanji> in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble.

meaning_mnemonic:
If a <radical>helicopter</radical> <radical>loiter</radical>s near a <radical>black hole</radical> then it's going to <kanji>capsize</kanji>. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down!

If you want to save it you better <kanji>cover</kanji> up the black hole! The only way to save it from capsizing is to cover it right up!
reading_mnemonic: You're doing your best to <kanji>cover</kanji> the black hole to stop the helicopter from <kanji>capsiz</kanji>ing but it's not working! “<reading>F**k</reading> you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing!

meaning_mnemonic: With your <radical>fingers</radical> under an <radical>axe</radical>, you <radical>say</radical> a <kanji>vow</kanji>. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off.
reading_mnemonic: When you finish your <kanji>vow</kanji>, you take out your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers.

meaning_mnemonic: Watch what you <radical>say</radical> to what appears to be a <radical>sweet</radical> <radical>tree</radical>, because that tree will 100% <kanji>conspire</kanji> against you.
reading_mnemonic: Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to <kanji>conspire</kanji> against you and take you down. Take your <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball and bowl it and all its friends down!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>foot</radical> <radical>capital</radical>, it's tough to be a <radical>dog</radical> because you're always getting <kanji>kick</kanji>ed.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine yourself <kanji>kick</kanji>ing a <reading>ke</reading>ttle (け). There's nothing that's more satisfying to kick than a good ol' kettle, you know?

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Compare</radical> a <radical>building</radical> to some <radical>dirt</radical> and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her <kanji>Highness</kanji>. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building.
reading_mnemonic: I bet His <kanji>Highness</kanji> has never had to sleep in <reading>hay</reading> (へい) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness.

meaning_mnemonic: The only type of <radical>can</radical> you'll be <radical>building</radical> in <radical>prison</radical> is one made of <kanji>pottery</kanji>. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way.
reading_mnemonic: You get so good at <kanji>pottery</kanji> that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. とうきょう is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>building</radical> that has a <radical>bully</radical> will <kanji>isolate</kanji> itself. Building have feelings like people, you know.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>isolate</kanji>d building only has one companion, and it's the <reading>cock</reading> (かく) that lives inside of it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>horse</radical> who can write a <radical>paragraph</radical> gets to be a <kanji>chess piece</kanji>. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor.
reading_mnemonic: Upon being told that he will never be a <kanji>chess piece</kanji>, the horse slips into a <reading>coma</reading> (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>roof</radical> there's some type of <radical>turkey</radical> <radical>bird</radical>, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a <kanji>crane</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>crane</kanji> leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "<reading>Too ru</reading>de (つる)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>restaurant</radical> radical and the <kanji>restaurant</kanji> kanji are the same! The meaning of this kanji also extends other resting places, like an <kanji>inn</kanji> or a <kanji>pavilion</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>restaurant</kanji> only serves <reading>tater</reading> (てい) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> <radical>cat pirate</radical> is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate <kanji>to look up to</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you <kanji>look up to</kanji>) its favorite food: <reading>gyo</reading>za (ぎょう).

visually_similar_kanji: 迫, 舶, 拍, 泊
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> all in <radical>white</radical> is the <kanji>chief</kanji>. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical>, Master <radical>Splinter</radical> (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone <kanji>accidentally</kanji> poured ooze on him.
reading_mnemonic: But really, if you do something <kanji>accidentally</kanji>, it's probably a <reading>goo</reading>d (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake!

meaning_mnemonic: You walk out on a <radical>cliff</radical>, where you find in the <radical>ground</radical> a <radical>mouth</radical> poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the <kanji>empress</kanji> of these lands!"
reading_mnemonic: When you finish unburying the <kanji>empress</kanji>, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち."

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>canopy</radical>, <radical>Wolverine</radical> opens his <radical>mouth</radical> and says, "<kanji>China</kanji>!" Why would he say China? It's all very <kanji>sudden</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>sudden</kanji> urge to shout "<kanji>China</kanji>" also came about because Wolverine woke up in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Outside of his pagoda-shaped canopy, Wolverine noticed the kanji and assumed he was in China.

visually_similar_kanji: 得, 撮, 提, 是
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>correct</radical> way to block the <radical>sun</radical> with <radical>dirt</radical> is with an <kanji>embankment</kanji>. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again!
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, building a correct <kanji>embankment</kanji> doesn't just take dirt, but <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> is making a <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>cage</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical>. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt <kanji>dam</kanji>. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway.
reading_mnemonic: Something about the woman working hard to build this <kanji>dam</kanji> makes her super <reading>sexy</reading> (せき) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows.

meaning_mnemonic: Sticking out of the <radical>dirt</radical>, there's a <radical>cross</radical> adorned with <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>shellfish</radical> shells. This is a <kanji>tomb</kanji>. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lie under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously.
reading_mnemonic: This is a <kanji>tomb</kanji>, but it feels really <reading>fun</reading> (ふん). Decorated with flowers and shellfish shells, it’s not a sad place at all. It's a fun place to remember all the fun times with people you loved.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> who can fight with <radical>icicle</radical>s on him is more <kanji>robust</kanji> than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body?
reading_mnemonic: You may think it's just his <kanji>robust</kanji> body, but it's actually the samurai's robust <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>big</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> in the <radical>rice paddy</radical> is getting all <kanji>stirred up</kanji>. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?
reading_mnemonic: While the turkey is <kanji>stirred up</kanji>, it also looks like it's having a lot of <reading>fun</reading> (ふん).

meaning_mnemonic: At the top of the <radical>mountain</radical> is a <radical>signpost</radical> to tell you you've reached the <kanji>summit</kanji>. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs.
reading_mnemonic: At the <kanji>summit</kanji>, you decide to build your new <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>construction</radical> of an under<radical>ground</radical> <radical>prison</radical> will be done by someone who is <kanji>adept</kanji> at it.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Adept</kanji> at constructing underground prisons, you've caught the eye of Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち, the royal underground prison enthusiast.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Yoga</radical> <radical>King</radical> presides over all <kanji>courts</kanji>: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>court</kanji> of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth.

meaning_mnemonic: You want to write a <radical>chapter</radical> about <radical>hair</radical> in your new book so you have to make sure it's really <kanji>clear</kanji>. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>clear</kanji> writing got the attention of the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) and now he's at your door once again. Although, this time he's angrier than usual. His hair also looks awful. He took your advice after reading the book and cut his entire ponytail off.

meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> on the <radical>bed</radical>, <kanji>grasp</kanji> the sheets and <kanji>bundle</kanji> them up. Now you can do the laundry!
reading_mnemonic: In between <kanji>grasp</kanji>ing and <kanji>bundle</kanji>-ing, you shout <reading>HA</reading> (は)! That's when the sheets come off the bed.

meaning_mnemonic: With your <radical>fingers</radical> you put some <radical>weapon</radical>s in a <radical>boat</radical> for <kanji>transport</kanji>. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another.
reading_mnemonic: Hey! You're <kanji>transport</kanji>ing weapons just like <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport.

visually_similar_kanji: 銅, 胴, 同, 可, 何, 司, 伺, 阿, 荷, 河, 句, 旬, 詞, 飼, 向
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is the <radical>same</radical> as a <kanji>cave</kanji>. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave!
reading_mnemonic: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (どう).

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming up over a <radical>cliff</radical> made of <radical>dirt</radical>. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the <kanji>horizon</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You squint into the <kanji>horizon</kanji> and see something else. There's some <reading>guy</reading> (がい) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>roof</radical> and then <radical>correct</radical>s itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an <kanji>eddy</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: There is a person trying to create an <kanji>eddy</kanji> with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how <reading>you do</reading> (よど) it."

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>helicopter</radical> while you are <radical>jackhammer</radical>ing, it will <kanji>drift</kanji> out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away!
reading_mnemonic: As it <kanji>drift</kanji>s away you shout, "<reading>Heyooo</reading>! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> crashes into the <radical>sun</radical>, which is then caught in a <radical>net</radical> and tied to a <radical>stool</radical>! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, it sounds really <kanji>comic</kanji>! That's because it's from that comic book about a pirate you're always reading!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Comic</kanji>s are <reading>man</reading>ga (まん) in Japan, whether they're comic or serious.

meaning_mnemonic: Turn a <radical>sick</radical>ness into a <radical>weapon</radical> and it becomes an <kanji>epidemic</kanji>. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply.
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>epidemic</kanji>s spread by <reading>駅</reading> (えき). Each train takes the sickness and shoots off in a different direction, spreading it further.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>tsunami</radical> uses its <radical>drop</radical>s to carry out its <radical>specialty</radical>, which is turning itself into <kanji>record book</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>record book</kanji> is a <reading>bo</reading>ok (ぼ), when it comes down to it.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>number</radical>ed <radical>feather</radical>. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to <kanji>flip</kanji> and <kanji>flip</kanji> over and over.
reading_mnemonic: You're pretty good at your <kanji>flip</kanji> technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and <reading>hone</reading> (ほん) your skills and get better.

meaning_mnemonic: This is an animal with an <radical>angle</radical>d <radical>sword</radical> claw that's filled with <radical>cow</radical> meat but looks like an <radical>insect</radical>. What kind of animal is that? It's a <kanji>crab</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the <reading>かに</reading> in WaniKani.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> on the <radical>street</radical> needs to be <kanji>revise</kanji>d. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again.
reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>revise</kanji> the song you wrote about <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising.

meaning_mnemonic: Watch what you <radical>say</radical> to the <radical>next</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> over, because they hired you to <kanji>consult</kanji> them.
reading_mnemonic: You panic, and <kanji>consult</kanji> the man into buying a <reading>shee</reading>p (し).

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>nine</radical> <radical>car</radical>s all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a <kanji>rut</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second <reading>key</reading> (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fang</radical> on a <radical>building</radical> shows that it's <kanji>wicked</kanji>. Something wicked probably lives in the building too.
reading_mnemonic: You peek inside the <kanji>wicked</kanji> building and a wicked <reading>ja</reading>guar (じゃ) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>name</radical> on this piece of wood is the <kanji>inscription</kanji> that shows the artist's signature.
reading_mnemonic: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names <reading>めい</reading>.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> that is <radical>fat</radical> is a <kanji>burdensome</kanji> animal.
reading_mnemonic: But you have to be nice to the <kanji>burdensome</kanji> horse because this horse is your <reading>da</reading>d (だ).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> <radical>can</radical> be a <radical>tree</radical>, but it can also be a <radical>psychopath</radical>. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to <kanji>gloom</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Then the tree switches from <kanji>gloom</kanji> to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. <reading>Uts</reading> (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fish</radical> with two <radical>mouth</radical>s has the number <radical>two</radical> on it because it's in <radical>prison</radical> (that's its prison number). Who put the poor two-mouthed fish in prison? An <kanji>alligator</kanji>. Because alligators hate two-mouthed fish.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the わに in "WaniKani." Ever heard of it?

meaning_mnemonic: There is a special type of meditation where you put a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and touch your <radical>forehead</radical> down to your <radical>legs</radical>. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely <kanji>clear</kanji>. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.
reading_mnemonic: Your mind is as <kanji>clear</kanji> as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>Korea</radical> is destined for <kanji>greatness</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>greatness</kanji> radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry.

meaning_mnemonic: You're sitting on your <radical>stool</radical> <kanji>again</kanji>!!?
reading_mnemonic: Your friends are starting to worry about you, because you're always sitting on that stool. "What is the <reading>matter</reading> (また) with you?" they scream! You might want to imagine that all your friends have Jamaican or British accents to make this one fit a bit better!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>call</radical> radical and the <kanji>call</kanji> kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean <kanji>eat</kanji>, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?!
reading_mnemonic: You are <kanji>call</kanji>ed to come <kanji>eat</kanji> by the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone.

meaning_mnemonic: What would your <radical>mouth</radical> do if you got caught in a <radical>prison</radical> for <radical>legs</radical>? It'd probably get real <radical>big</radical> — in other words, it would <kanji>scream</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>scream</kanji> and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> on the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>pig</radical> makes a small <kanji>mound</kanji>. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead.
reading_mnemonic: The pig's forehead dirt <kanji>mound</kanji> keeps getting bigger until it's the size of <reading>two cars</reading> (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over.

meaning_mnemonic: Everyone knows that when a <radical>woman</radical> plays <radical>football</radical> she becomes a <kanji>princess</kanji>. Thats how princesses are made.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the word 姫? It means <kanji>princess</kanji> too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too.

meaning_mnemonic: A person with <radical>horns</radical> has you on the <radical>ground</radical> and lets loose two <radical>poops</radical> over your <radical>heart</radical>. "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.
reading_mnemonic: As you shout "<kanji>Mercy</kanji>!" one more time, suddenly <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.

other_meanings: Get Between, Putting Between, Getting Between, Between, Hold Between
meaning_mnemonic: You run your <radical>fingers</radical> through your <radical>husband</radical>'s <radical>horns</radical>. His horns are what you love to <kanji>put between</kanji> your fingers.
reading_mnemonic: Why are your husband's horns what you always love to <kanji>put between</kanji> your fingers? Because he's a <reading>ho</reading>t <reading>ser</reading>geant (はさ)!

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>tree</radical> grows <radical>old</radical>, it will <kanji>wither</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>wither</kanji>ed tree's best friend is a human <reading>子</reading> (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree.

visually_similar_kanji: 弟, 弓, 第, 弔
meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>dollar</radical> the water will instantly start to <kanji>boil</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>boil</kanji>ing water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your <reading>foots</reading> (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots.

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to have a <radical>tsunami</radical> at your <radical>wedding</radical>, you need to make sure you have it at the <kanji>bay</kanji>. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.
reading_mnemonic: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the <kanji>bay</kanji> in the first place? By throwing a bunch of <reading>ura</reading>nium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.

visually_similar_kanji: 過, 鍋, 禍, 滑
meaning_mnemonic: If you put two <radical>mustache</radical>s on either side of a <radical>tsunami</radical> it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes a <kanji>whirlpool</kanji>. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>whirlpool</kanji> is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my <reading>ca</reading>r (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!

kunyomi: すす, ゆす, そそぐ
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, so you ask two <radical>Wolverine</radical>s to help you take your <radical>turkey</radical> out for a <kanji>wash</kanji>. Despite the obvious dangers, a giant wave is the only thing that'll wash a giant turkey, so you have no choice.
reading_mnemonic: To make sure your turkey won't get carried away by the tsunami while you <kanji>wash</kanji> it, you pin it down with a giant <reading>tack</reading> (たく). If you're washing a giant turkey inside a giant wave, only a giant tack will guarantee it doesn't get washed away.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>fire</radical> next to which you left some <radical>syrup</radical>, and it has all <kanji>dried up</kanji>! Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy.
reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>dry up</kanji> syrup like this, you're removing its <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it.

meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>horns</radical> on a <radical>lantern</radical> that can hold <radical>ten thousand</radical> <radical>drops</radical> of water sitting on the <radical>ground</radical>. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's actually a <kanji>bottle</kanji>. The horns are like a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle filled with water.
reading_mnemonic: Even though you're not the one who left this <kanji>bottle</kanji> here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash <reading>bin</reading> (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>plow</radical> and a (water) <radical>well</radical>. These are the two things you need in order to <kanji>plow</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Plow</kanji>ing all the fields are <reading>こう</reading>いちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use.

meaning_mnemonic: If you have an <radical>ear</radical> for the <radical>public</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>, you must be very <kanji>wise</kanji>. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well.
reading_mnemonic: All of these <kanji>wise</kanji> things are stored in your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live.

visually_similar_kanji: 族, 施, 妨, 訪, 坊, 旅, 旋, 紡, 放, 防
meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>moon</radical> faces the right <radical>direction</radical>, the <kanji>fat</kanji> in the bodies of people and animals all gets drawn to the surface and we all look weirdly greasy for a little while. You probably knew that the moon exerts a pull on water, but I bet you didn't know it exerted a pull on fat too!
reading_mnemonic: As long as you're covered in <kanji>fat</kanji>, you might as well go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). Imagine how smoothly that bowling ball's going to roll after you slather it with some of this fat!

meaning_mnemonic: We must <radical>stop</radical> the <radical>moon</radical>. That, at least, we can come to an <kanji>agreement</kanji> on.
reading_mnemonic: "We have <kanji>agreement</kanji>," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have <kanji>agreement</kanji> on who we will follow, Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: You ate the <radical>moon</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical>, and then the <radical>sun</radical> too, but man were they high in <kanji>fat</kanji>! In fact, you wanted to eat them with chopsticks, but they were so greasy with fat that the spoon was your only option.
reading_mnemonic: Unbeknownst to you, the moon and sun contained as much <kanji>fat</kanji> as an entire adult <reading>shee</reading>p (し)! Why didn't you check the nutrition facts first???

meaning_mnemonic: If you look in a <radical>tiger</radical>'s <radical>stomach</radical> you'll find a bunch of <kanji>skin</kanji>. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.
reading_mnemonic: The only person who would try to take <kanji>skin</kanji> from a tiger's stomach is a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that grow in a <radical>rice paddy</radical> only live to be <kanji>seedling</kanji>s. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>seedling</kanji>s try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as <reading>myou</reading> (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.

meaning_mnemonic: You put <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>car</radical> and your <radical>scooter</radical>. The flowers you put on them are <kanji>lotus</kanji> flowers.
reading_mnemonic: You're putting a <kanji>lotus</kanji> on both your scooter and car because they are <reading>ren</reading>tals (れん).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spirit</radical>s of the two <radical>tree</radical>s you destroyed with your <radical>jackhammer</radical> live on in the <kanji>collar</kanji> you made out of them.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>collar</kanji> keeps whispering, "<reading>Eri</reading>c (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird.

meaning_mnemonic: You try to put your <radical>toe</radical> inside a <radical>shellfish</radical>, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of <kanji>chastity</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Chastity</kanji> is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tot, I'll change my mind."

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>car</radical> that's <radical>lack</radical>ing is really <kanji>soft</kanji>. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.
reading_mnemonic: This car is probably so <kanji>soft</kanji> because it's made entirely of <reading>naan</reading> (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).

visually_similar_kanji: 抵, 低, 底, 紙
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is breaking <radical>ground</radical> and <radical>building</radical> your new <kanji>residence</kanji>. You're all working together to make you a new home!
reading_mnemonic: Your new <kanji>residence</kanji> is complete! You step closer and the smell of <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan!

visually_similar_kanji: 効, 較, 絞, 校
meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>mix</radical> a bunch of <radical>building</radical>s together, you have yourself a <kanji>suburb</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Suburb</kanji>s are what we need!" says Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>buddy</radical> <radical>building</radical> is in the next <kanji>county</kanji>. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>county</kanji> is everything you can reach when shooting a <reading>gun</reading> (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county.

meaning_mnemonic: If you use a <radical>sickle</radical> to kill a <radical>shrimp</radical> you'll need a really good <kanji>explanation</kanji> for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?
reading_mnemonic: In your <kanji>explanation</kanji> you blame everything on <reading>Shaq</reading> (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.

meaning_mnemonic: So my <radical>building</radical> has a big <radical>splinter</radical>, right in the <kanji>corner</kanji>. So what?
reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>corner</kanji> is dangerous, but what are you going to do, <reading>sue me</reading> (すみ)?

other_meanings: Counter For Ships, Ships, Counter For Vessels, Vessel Counter, Vessels, Fleets, Fleet Counter, Counter For Fleets, Number Of Ships, Number Of Vessels, Number Of Fleets
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>turkey</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal <kanji>ship counter</kanji> is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.
reading_mnemonic: Once you become the best <kanji>ship counter</kanji> in the world everyone will think you are super <reading>sexy</reading> (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.

meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>street</radical> all the way to that <radical>geoduck</radical>, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the <kanji>summit</kanji>. You <kanji>humbly</kanji> present the road to the geoduck and bow before it.
reading_mnemonic: You are at the top, the <kanji>summit</kanji> of everything! You <kanji>humbly</kanji> survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう), and she looks angry.

kunyomi: の, なんじ, すなわ
meaning_mnemonic: What do <radical>stairs</radical> do? They take you <kanji>from</kanji> where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get <kanji>from</kanji> place to place.
reading_mnemonic: If you're going <kanji>from</kanji> place to place, make sure you have some <reading>no</reading>ri (の) seaweed on you, in case you get hungry. Nori is a great source of energy.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> puts their <radical>hat</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to a <radical>bookshelf</radical>. This is a test in <kanji>ethics</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: To test your <kanji>ethics</kanji> even more, the leader puts down a <reading>rin</reading>g (りん) as well.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>library</radical> thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very <kanji>biased</kanji> person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to give in to his <kanji>biased</kanji> recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about <reading>hen</reading>s (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird.

meaning_mnemonic: I hope all you're doing in the <radical>bathtub</radical> is taking a <kanji>bath</kanji>. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths!
reading_mnemonic: When do you miss taking a <kanji>bath</kanji> the most? When you're on the <reading>ro</reading>ad (ろ). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath.

meaning_mnemonic: Beside your <radical>mouth</radical> is an evil <radical>spider</radical> that tries to <kanji>instigate</kanji> you into saying bad things and starting a riot. It's like the little silken puppet master of your mouth or something. Don't let it instigate you!
reading_mnemonic: You want the spider to stop instigating you into saying bad things and starting riots. So you pick up a <reading>saw</reading> (さ) and start cutting off the silken threads that are controlling your mouth.

meaning_mnemonic: From your <radical>mouth</radical> comes a <radical>cross</radical>, some <radical>flowers</radical>, and <radical>shellfish</radical>. It all <kanji>erupt</kanji>s from your mouth!
reading_mnemonic: When do inanimate objects <kanji>erupt</kanji> from your mouth? Mostly when you're having <reading>fun</reading> (ふん).

visually_similar_kanji: 爪, 瓜, 弧, 狐
meaning_mnemonic: There was once a <radical>melon</radical> <radical>child</radical>, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an <kanji>orphan</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>orphan</kanji> melon boy is but a <reading>子</reading> (こ).

meaning_mnemonic: If you give a <radical>machine</radical> a <radical>heart</radical> it will get <kanji>lazy</kanji>. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now.
reading_mnemonic: The machine is so <kanji>lazy</kanji> it won't even wear its <reading>tie</reading> (たい) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> is like the <radical>ground</radical> or the <radical>dawn</radical>. It is <kanji>constant</kanji>, never changing.
reading_mnemonic: Also <kanji>constant</kanji> is the Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち, who will surely rule for a thousand more years!

meaning_mnemonic: In its <radical>soul</radical>, a <radical>narwhal</radical> that's supposed to do <radical>construction</radical> under the <radical>moon</radical>, will be too <kanji>lazy</kanji> to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done.
reading_mnemonic: You can't tell the <kanji>lazy</kanji> narwhal he's being lazy because he's your <reading>da</reading>d (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right.

meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>soul</radical> is acting like the <radical>sun</radical> trapped in a <radical>net</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>, then people will <kanji>ridicule</kanji> you for your <kanji>laziness</kanji>. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving.
reading_mnemonic: When people <kanji>ridicule</kanji> you, when you can't stop the <kanji>laziness</kanji>, you read <reading>man</reading>ga (まん). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> grasp this <radical>lid</radical> and when you raise it you see a <radical>poop</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you <kanji>embrace</kanji> the turkey.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>embrace</kanji> the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it!

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>yakuza</radical> <radical>slide</radical> you into a <radical>jet</radical>, things are <kanji>especially</kanji> bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad.
reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>especially</kanji> worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where!

kunyomi: おぼ, しず, ない
meaning_mnemonic: If you figure out how to use a <radical>tsunami</radical> as a <radical>weapon</radical>, everyone is going to <kanji>die</kanji>. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all.
reading_mnemonic: The only way to maybe not <kanji>die</kanji> is to find <reading>boats</reading> (ぼつ). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning.

meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <radical>cow</radical>'s <radical>life</radical> you're turning it into an <kanji>offering</kanji>. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often.
reading_mnemonic: You prepare the <kanji>offering</kanji> with your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it.

meaning_mnemonic: There is an <radical>animal</radical> in the <radical>grass</radical> and your horrible <radical>task</radical> is to go <kanji>hunting</kanji> for it.
reading_mnemonic: You're currently <kanji>hunting</kanji> in a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away.

kunyomi: きざ, さいわ, つまび, よ
meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> lives in a <radical>sheep</radical> it becomes the most <kanji>auspicious</kanji> creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this.
reading_mnemonic: The spirit sheep is so <kanji>auspicious</kanji> that the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>grain</radical> has a <radical>fault</radical>, it needs to be put back in <kanji>order</kanji>. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their <kanji>regularity</kanji>. Keeping order is a tough job!
reading_mnemonic: You can always tell if a company keeps <kanji>order</kanji> or if it <reading>cheats</reading> (ちつ) just by looking at the grains.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice</radical> that's prepared at <radical>dawn</radical> by the <radical>village</radical> are <kanji>provisions</kanji> for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then.
reading_mnemonic: Once all of the <kanji>provisions</kanji> are ready, the soldiers show up in their <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need <reading>roe</reading> (ろう) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too.

meaning_mnemonic: You're sewing something with <radical>thread</radical> but you and your creation get <radical>frostbite</radical> while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty <kanji>design</kanji>. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands.
reading_mnemonic: As you watch the snowflake <kanji>design</kanji> form you see letters appearing in the corner! They form the name <reading>Aya</reading> (あや), our artist here at WaniKani. Somehow she's magically putting together this beautiful pattern!

meaning_mnemonic: Play your <radical>drum</radical> under the <radical>moon</radical> and your <radical>hair</radical> will <kanji>swell</kanji>! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell.
reading_mnemonic: Using this method, your hair <kanji>swell</kanji>s so much it looks like a giant <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits.

meaning_mnemonic: If you point a bunch of <radical>flowers</radical> in the same <radical>direction</radical>, you'll be able to smell their <kanji>aromatic</kanji> <kanji>fragrance</kanji>. The best way to bask in their fragrance is to make them all point in the same direction (preferably straight at you).
reading_mnemonic: You decide to bring this <kanji>aromatic</kanji> <kanji>fragrance</kanji> into your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). To do this, you plant flowers all the way around your home, all facing in toward it.

meaning_mnemonic: If you look at <radical>flowers</radical> the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the <radical>next</radical> thing you notice are the <kanji>briar</kanji>s. You never see <kanji>thorn</kanji>s first, only after you've looked at the flowers.
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>briar</kanji>s you can't help but yell, <reading>Eee! Ba riars</reading>! (いばら)! You sound funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch!

meaning_mnemonic: All you need are some <radical>flowers</radical>, <radical>fish</radical>, and <radical>grain</radical> and you've got yourself a potion that can <kanji>revive</kanji> just about anyone or anything!
reading_mnemonic: This potion able to <kanji>revive</kanji> any being just has one small downside: it tastes like <reading>so</reading>ap (そ).

meaning_mnemonic: Take a <radical>leather</radical> <radical>helicopter</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> to prove your excellent <kanji>leadership</kanji>. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space!
reading_mnemonic: Under your superior <kanji>leadership</kanji> you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "<reading>Ha</reading> (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely!

other_meanings: Sushi Counter, Counter For Sushi Pieces, Pieces Of Sushi, Piece Of Sushi, Sushi Piece Counter, Sushi Piece, Sushi Pieces, Number Of Sushi Pieces, Number Of Pieces Of Sushi, Sushi Pieces Counter, Counter For Sushi, Counter For Pieces Of Sushi
kunyomi: つらぬ, ぬき, ぬ
meaning_mnemonic:
Under the <radical>window</radical>, you place a <radical>shellfish</radical>, then slam the window shut to <kanji>pierce</kanji> its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.

This kanji also has a second meaning. That shellfish you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them <kanji>sushi counter</kanji>s!
reading_mnemonic: Now that your shellfish is properly <kanji>pierce</kanji>d and turned into <kanji>sushi counter</kanji>s, you can serve them to Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.

meaning_mnemonic: You give a bunch of <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>clown</radical> as <kanji>compensation</kanji>. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish.
reading_mnemonic: Once the clown has been properly <kanji>compensate</kanji>d, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "<reading>Bye</reading> (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye."

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to have your <radical>wedding</radical> in a <radical>car</radical> you're going to need a lot of <kanji>help</kanji>. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off.
reading_mnemonic: You can't just ask for <kanji>help</kanji> on the day of the wedding, either. You have to <reading>sche</reading>dule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so make sure you plan early!

meaning_mnemonic:
Your poor little <radical>scooter</radical> got a <radical>splinter</radical>, so make sure to give it extra nice <kanji>treatment</kanji>. 

This can also mean <kanji>encounter</kanji>. Makes sense when you think about how you first have to encounter someone before deciding how you're going to treat them!

Also, when this means "treatment," note that it doesn't refer to medical treatment, but rather about how you personally treat or receive people.
reading_mnemonic: Give your scooter only the best <kanji>treatment</kanji>, so it can feel real <reading>goo</reading>ooood (ぐう).

meaning_mnemonic: When you ride your <radical>scooter</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> listening to <radical>music</radical> under the <radical>sun</radical>, you're bound to <kanji>encounter</kanji> a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to <kanji>meet</kanji> you.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone you <kanji>encounter</kanji> wants to bare their <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them.

meaning_mnemonic: The famous <radical>gold</radical> <radical>triceratops</radical> <radical>shellfish</radical> is good for only one thing, and that's being made into <kanji>chain</kanji>s. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability.
reading_mnemonic: However, the only way to break the <kanji>chain</kanji> is to cut it open with a <reading>saw</reading> (さ). Once the golden triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> was a <radical>former</radical> <radical>prison</radical> until the <kanji>cave in</kanji>. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in.
reading_mnemonic: You keep picturing the <kanji>cave in</kanji> and you see Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next!

visually_similar_kanji: 練, 錬, 棟, 陣, 縛
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical> to the <radical>east</radical> is an <kanji>exhibit</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Right now the <kanji>exhibit</kanji> has a bunch of <reading>chin</reading>s (ちん) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit.

meaning_mnemonic: If you tie a <radical>cross</radical> to a <radical>turkey</radical> you can trick everyone into thinking it's a <kanji>falcon</kanji>. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there.

kunyomi: すべから, すべし, ひげ, まつ, もち, もと
meaning_mnemonic: Shaving the <radical>hair</radical> off a <radical>geoduck</radical> before you try to eat it is absolutely <kanji>necessary</kanji>. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair.
reading_mnemonic: It is also <kanji>necessary</kanji> that you wear a <reading>su</reading>it (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>stand</radical> in the <radical>wind</radical> it will be really <kanji>quick</kanji> to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up only to be knocked over again, just as quick.
reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>quick</kanji> wind is quicker than you can say <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ). And "Satsuki" is a pretty quick sounding name already. Go ahead, say "Satsuki" as quick as you can right now. Heck, try it a few times.

meaning_mnemonic: This is a <radical>boat</radical>, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks <kanji>rust colored</kanji>. In ancient Chinese literature, this rusty red color represented <kanji>sincerity</kanji>, and you'll often see this kanji take that meaning in jukugo words.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>rust colored</kanji> boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and <reading>tan</reading> (たん). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match.

meaning_mnemonic: There's so much <radical>grain</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> you need to use a <radical>knife</radical> to remove it. Only when there is a <kanji>surplus</kanji> can you put that much grain in your mouth.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>surplus</kanji> is thanks to the hard work of folks like <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year.

meaning_mnemonic: If you can find the <radical>door</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> shaped like a <radical>mouth</radical> it will <kanji>enlighten</kanji> you.
reading_mnemonic: The door <kanji>enlight</kanji>ened you by opening up and revealing the <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth."

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>nurse</radical> is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes <kanji>soil</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Soil</kanji> is a thing that <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the huge farmhand, works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>see</radical> everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of <kanji>tolerance</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Tolerance</kanji> is one thing that Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) had a surprising amount of.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>drop</radical> of <radical>bear</radical> on this <radical>towel</radical>. A true <kanji>commander</kanji> can notice little things like this.
reading_mnemonic: You watch the <kanji>commander</kanji> in all his glory... going back and forth on a <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい).

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around a <radical>surplus</radical> of anything, you need to be <kanji>gentle</kanji> and touch everything <kanji>gently</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You have to be <kanji>gentle</kanji> and handle these things <kanji>gently</kanji> because they belong to <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (じょ). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine).

kunyomi: みじ, いた, むご
visually_similar_kanji: 修, 診, 珍, 参
meaning_mnemonic: If you get a <radical>big</radical> <radical>hair</radical> stuck in your <radical>private</radical> <radical>soul</radical> it will be a <kanji>disaster</kanji>! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>disaster</kanji> is so huge that even <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん) left his vacation in <reading>Zan</reading>zibar (ざん) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san?

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cross</radical> carrying <radical>drunkard</radical> wants you to go to a <radical>rice paddy</radical> <radical>together</radical> so you can <kanji>receive</kanji> something from them.
reading_mnemonic: Against your better judgement, you decided to go and <kanji>receive</kanji> the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light <reading>tie</reading> (たい) being placed in them.

visually_similar_kanji: 破, 彼, 被, 疲, 波, 皮
meaning_mnemonic: Press your <radical>fingers</radical> in someone's <radical>skin</radical> to <kanji>expose</kanji> what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>expose</kanji> a small hole under their skin and <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat.

visually_similar_kanji: 堀, 塀, 掘, 握, 居, 屈, 届, 涙, 房, 戻, 泥, 遅, 漏
meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> to take down the <radical>old</radical> <radical>flag</radical> and <kanji>install</kanji> a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new one in its place.
reading_mnemonic: You've decided to <kanji>install</kanji> a <reading>su</reading>it (す) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often.

meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>fingers</radical> are <radical>flowers</radical> which really <radical>suit</radical> you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you <kanji>board</kanji> your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're <kanji>embark</kanji>ing on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>board</kanji> a ship to <reading>とう</reading>きょう, bound for your new life, of course!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is rising and there is a <radical>net</radical> covering <radical>someone</radical>, who's being forced to watch as <kanji>dawn</kanji> appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them.
reading_mnemonic: The someone who saw <kanji>dawn</kanji> for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ <reading>Akebono</reading> Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> of <radical>conflict</radical> will <kanji>cleanse</kanji> and <kanji>purify</kanji> the lands of people, homes, and culture.
reading_mnemonic: Who could possibly stop this <kanji>cleanse</kanji> of all lands?! The only person capable of this is, of course, <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the local farmhand. He’s so tall and burly that he can stop even the largest of tsunamis… right?

visually_similar_kanji: 爪, 狐, 孤, 弧
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>melon</radical> radical and the <kanji>melon</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
reading_mnemonic: What's the best use for a <kanji>melon</kanji>? Not eating it, but running over it in your <reading>ca</reading>r (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see.

meaning_mnemonic: When what you're writing is as <radical>tall</radical> as the <radical>grain</radical>s growing outside, you know you're done with your first <kanji>draft</kanji>. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains!
reading_mnemonic: Who asked you to write such a tall <kanji>draft</kanji> in the first place? Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical>s a <radical>criminal</radical> wears will always be <kanji>scarlet</kanji>. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>scarlet</kanji> color holds a lot of <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> that goes through <radical>Korea</radical> is the <kanji>latitude</kanji> line splitting up North and South Korea.
reading_mnemonic: The only way you can see this <kanji>latitude</kanji> line is to ride an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>cross</radical>es <radical>thread</radical> across special <radical>spikes</radical> to separate the <kanji>fiber</kanji>s. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves!
reading_mnemonic: You stare at the <kanji>fiber</kanji>s easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it...

visually_similar_kanji: 飽, 抱, 泡, 包, 砲
meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>moon</radical> and <radical>wrap</radical> it in a bag and it will look just like a <kanji>cell</kanji>. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening!
reading_mnemonic: As you learn about <kanji>cell</kanji>s you realize they're all over your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>old</radical> <radical>moon</radical> (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge <kanji>barbarian</kanji> floating in the sky.
reading_mnemonic: At least, this is the kind of story you told your <reading>子</reading> (こ) when they asked you where the moon came from.

meaning_mnemonic:
You want to have a quaint <radical>cottage</radical> <radical>wedding</radical>, so you have to go to the cottage wedding <kanji>shop</kanji> to get everything you need.

Unfortunately, there’s no road to the shop, so… you’ll just have to <kanji>pave</kanji> one yourself! Every shop needs a road, so get to paving.
reading_mnemonic: You're browsing everything in the <kanji>shop</kanji> when a garden <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>boat</radical> owned by a <radical>Yoga</radical> <radical>King</radical> needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a <kanji>rowboat</kanji>, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around.
reading_mnemonic: As he rows the <kanji>rowboat</kanji> with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're <reading>ta</reading>ter tots (てい). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water.

meaning_mnemonic: You cut the <radical>flowers</radical> off the <radical>grain</radical> with your <radical>knife</radical>. The flowers that fall off are <kanji>jasmine</kanji> flowers.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>jasmine</kanji> is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the <reading>ree</reading>ds (り)!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that are thought to be little <radical>tent</radical>s sent from <radical>heaven</radical> are <kanji>hollyhock</kanji>s. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Hollyhock</kanji>s are mostly <reading>あおい</reading> (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from.

kunyomi: おお, くら, こうむ
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> are growing out of the <radical>ground</radical> and over your pet <radical>pig</radical>'s <radical>forehead</radical> and it's causing the poor thing to live in total <kanji>darkness</kanji>. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it.
reading_mnemonic: To end the <kanji>darkness</kanji> you <reading>mow</reading> (もう) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again.

meaning_mnemonic: Whether you're a <radical>tiger</radical> or <radical>Wolverine</radical>, the anti-claw regime will want to <kanji>oppress</kanji> you. Too afraid of any potential violent rebellion, this oppressive regime is going to imprison and declaw every single clawed being.
reading_mnemonic: Tigers and other clawed beings like Wolverine are so <kanji>oppress</kanji>ed, they're forced to cover their claws with <reading>Gak</reading> (ぎゃく). You know, that weird silly putty they made us play with as kids? Well, it's now an instrument of anti-Wolverine, anti-tiger oppression.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>say</radical> something the same way they say it in the <radical>capital</radical>, everyone in the whole country will be able to <kanji>comprehend</kanji> what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it.
reading_mnemonic: Now that the townspeople finally <kanji>comprehend</kanji> what you were trying to say, they sell you the <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home.

meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <radical>say</radical> something to the <radical>Death Star</radical>, it would only <kanji>admonish</kanji> you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying.
reading_mnemonic: Right now you're being <kanji>admonish</kanji>ed about living in a <reading>yu</reading>rt (ゆ). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!"

visually_similar_kanji: 鈴, 銀, 録, 線, 綿
meaning_mnemonic: You weave <radical>gold</radical> and <radical>white</radical> patterns into this <radical>towel</radical>, turning it into <kanji>brocade</kanji>. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel.
reading_mnemonic: You want to keep your <kanji>brocade</kanji> fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a <reading>niche key</reading> (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing.

meaning_mnemonic: How many <radical>building</radical>s <radical>have</radical> <radical>scooter</radical>s? <kanji>All</kanji> of them!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: <reading>zuwee</reading> (ずい).

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>horse</radical> sees a <radical>spider</radical> it will start running at a <kanji>speed</kanji> no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast.
reading_mnemonic: Once people realize that they can increase the <kanji>speed</kanji> of their horses, <reading>soon</reading> (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner.

meaning_mnemonic: While the <radical>moon</radical> is out, a <radical>gladiator</radical> is riding a <radical>horse</radical>, yelling about <kanji>inflation</kanji>. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Inflation</kanji> rises the most in <reading>とう</reading>きょう, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die).

meaning_mnemonic: If you're in Japan, the <radical>fish</radical> in your <radical>village</radical> are <kanji>carp</kanji>. You may know them as <kanji>koi</kanji>, too.
