reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>pleasant</kanji> soul within the Death Star actually looks like a <reading>yu</reading>rt (ゆ), not a big angry, metal ball.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>hundred</radical> <radical>forehead</radical>s lower themselves to their <radical>heart</radical>s in <radical>winter</radical> in <kanji>grief</kanji>. There were once many of their kind, the forehead peoples, but now there are only a hundred left after this harsh winter took the rest of them. Their grief is immense.
reading_mnemonic: Their <kanji>grief</kanji> intensifies because all of the foreheads they lost belonged to <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう). Dead youths everywhere. Now there's no one left to repopulate the world.

meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>feeling</radical> a dead <radical>soul</radical> will have is <kanji>remorse</kanji>. Remorse for the people it left behind. <kanji>Regret</kanji>s for the things it did and didn't do.
reading_mnemonic: The soul with the most <kanji>regret</kanji>s is Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). Everyone knows to stay away from him in the spirit world because he's so sad. Not because of his own actions, but because of the state of his people now.

meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> in a <radical>jet</radical> if you want to <kanji>erase</kanji> them from existence. You aren't just chopping or burning them off. There's like, no trace of them at all. Your parents can't even remember if you were born with fingers or not. Jets are that powerful.
reading_mnemonic: You're almost done <kanji>eras</kanji>ing your fingers when the jet starts sucking all of you in. You would try to grab the closest thing to you, but your fingers don't exist anymore, so you hold onto the <reading>mats</reading> (まつ) at your feet with your toes. The mats are super strong (they're made for jets, after all) and you manage to save yourself!

kunyomi: あきら, あき, あさ, あした, ただし
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dawn</radical> radical and the <kanji>dawn</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Dawn</kanji> is <reading>dawn</reading> (だん)! It's also a great time to get a <reading>tan</reading> (たん). The sun is bright at dawn, but not so much that it will send skin cancer rays into you.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is the reason why crops grow and people can get out of bed in the morning. But on planets with two <radical>sun</radical>s, they can get even more done and it makes them way more <kanji>prosperous</kanji> than us. They work all day, then as the first sun sets, the second one rises and they get a new burst of energy. The whole planet lives in a state of <kanji>prosperity</kanji> because of the two suns.
reading_mnemonic: The person on this planet with two suns who benefits from the prosperity the most is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). Yes, this planet still has a shougun as their leader, but everything is going so well that they didn't see a need to change. The shogun will be in charge of this prosperous world forever. No one ever thinks of revolt when everyone has everything they could ever need.

kunyomi: えのき, ほう, ほお
meaning_mnemonic: You decide to carve a <radical>tree</radical> into a giant replica of your big <radical>toe</radical> because you think it will be really <kanji>simple</kanji>. Once you're done though, it looks like a really <kanji>crude</kanji> attempt at a fat, lumpy blob. Maybe carving isn't as simple as you thought.
reading_mnemonic: You're admiring your <kanji>simple</kanji> looking toe tree when a lumberjack runs up and asks who created it. <reading>ぼく</reading>, you say. As in "I" said it, in a manly dude, way. He doesn't seem to believe you, so you say it a few more times. ぼく ぼく ぼく!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>tree</radical> growing on a <radical>cliff</radical> and it has <radical>ten thousand</radical> <kanji>horse chestnut</kanji>s growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to take a bite of a <kanji>horse chestnut</kanji> because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like <reading>toe chee</reading>se (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> has a <radical>hat</radical> that's made from a <radical>tree</radical> but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big <kanji>cork</kanji>. It's a big, wooden <kanji>plug</kanji> that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat.
reading_mnemonic: It turned out this <kanji>cork</kanji> hat was given to him by a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> of the <radical>flowers</radical> in the <radical>center</radical> (of England, if you remember) has a special <kanji>crystal</kanji>. The king crystal.
reading_mnemonic: The king thinks everyone wants his <kanji>crystal</kanji> so he hides it in the giant <reading>a</reading>corn (えい) in the center of the flowers in England. There's a tiny hole in the bottom of the acorn, and that's where this crystal stays hidden.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sick</radical> <radical>Death Star</radical> needs its <radical>heart</radical> <kanji>cure</kanji>d. If it doesn't get <kanji>healing</kanji> soon, it will die.
reading_mnemonic: You realized that the only way to <kanji>cure</kanji> the Death Star is to turn it back into a <reading>yu</reading>rt (ゆ). Then it won't be able to do any more harm, and its outside will reflect its pleasant self on the inside!

visually_similar_kanji: 相, 阻, 租, 祖, 狙, 組
meaning_mnemonic: If you find some <radical>rice</radical> in a <radical>top hat</radical> it's going to be really <kanji>coarse</kanji> and <kanji>rough</kanji>. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten.
reading_mnemonic: You take the <kanji>coarse</kanji> rice and try to wash it with <reading>so</reading>ap (そ).

meaning_mnemonic: You start growing <radical>thread</radical> in your <radical>rice paddy</radical> to <kanji>accumulate</kanji> more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you.
reading_mnemonic: Sadly, this is a terrible way to <kanji>accumulate</kanji> anything thread related and you ended up <reading>rui</reading>ning (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it.

meaning_mnemonic: If you put <radical>two</radical> <radical>two</radical> pound weights on a <radical>person</radical> on the <radical>moon</radical> they'll increase in <kanji>stature</kanji> when they come back down. Everything is lighter on the moon so the person won't even feel the weights. Then when they come back to earth they'll have grown a whole two inches taller!
reading_mnemonic: Getting a taller <kanji>stature</kanji> will also make you seem super <reading>sexy</reading> (せき) on the moon and back home on earth. If you stay on the moon long enough, you'll be the tallest person in the galaxy and who wouldn't find that sexy?! Huh?

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>tiger</radical> meets a <radical>man</radical>, it becomes the man's <kanji>captive</kanji>. Men can be pretty mean like that. They see a tiger and they want to put it in a cage, so the poor tiger becomes the man's captive.
reading_mnemonic: The man takes his new tiger <kanji>captive</kanji> to <reading>Rio</reading> (りょ). Why Rio de Janeiro? Turns out you're allowed to keep tigers captive down in Rio.

meaning_mnemonic: You want to <radical>slice</radical> what you <radical>say</radical> in half so that people focus on <kanji>the above</kanji> text first. The above is what you want them to see! So slice what you say!
reading_mnemonic: As you focus on <kanji>the above</kanji> words you realize a <reading>guy</reading> (がい) is trying to push the rest of the things you're saying back up with the rest of them. No! The above text is all that matters! Go away guy!

meaning_mnemonic: Between the <radical>roof</radical> and the <radical>ground</radical> there are <radical>few</radical> <radical>shellfish</radical>. This is because we invited some <kanji>VIP</kanji> <kanji>guest</kanji>s into our home and they ate all our shellfish.
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>VIP</kanji> <kanji>guest</kanji>s are part of a <reading>Hin</reading>du (ひん) envoy.

meaning_mnemonic: You need to <radical>run</radical> on your <radical>toe</radical>s if you want to <kanji>proceed</kanji> down this road. If you can't run on your toes, well then you're out of luck, and you won't be able to <kanji>move on</kanji> at all. I didn't make this rule, I just enforce it. Now run!
reading_mnemonic: If you find that you can't <kanji>proceed</kanji>, you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). Everyone can run on their toes. Don't you know that? No? Then you're an even bigger fool, now get outta here!

meaning_mnemonic: You got off your <radical>scooter</radical> to load some <radical>charcoal</radical> onto it, when it suddenly took off to a <kanji>distant</kanji> place! That's some powerful charcoal.
reading_mnemonic: You chase the scooter to that <kanji>distant</kanji> place, but then you see it heading for a lake. Oh good, it should be stopped by the water. But wait! In the distance you see your scooter drive onto a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and... row itself through the water?! No!!

kunyomi: いかん, なに, なんぞ
meaning_mnemonic:
You're holding a <radical>sword</radical> in front of <radical>two</radical> <radical>building</radical>s. <kanji>What</kanji> will you do?

A. Stab the building on the left.

B. Stab the building on the right.

What do you choose?
reading_mnemonic:
A. <kanji>What</kanji> is, stab the building on the left? You stab the building on the left with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious <reading>na</reading>chos (な)!

B. <kanji>What</kanji> is, stab the building on the right? You stab the building on the right with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious <reading>na</reading>chos (な)!

meaning_mnemonic: You just <radical>receive</radical>d a <radical>building</radical>, so you want to surround it with an <kanji>enclosure</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>enclosure</kanji> felt a  bit quiet and lonely, so you decided to get yourself a pet <reading>cock</reading> (かく).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>reality</radical> of <radical>gold</radical> is that it has the power to <kanji>tranquilize</kanji> anyone who gets their hands on it. Gold may seem cool to have in movies and songs, but in reality, it has the power to mess you up!
reading_mnemonic: You've been <kanji>tranquilize</kanji>d and now drool is running down your <reading>chin</reading> (ちん). It's actually really gross. But you don't care, look at all this gold! No one will care about your chin when you're rich!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>bone</radical>s <radical>have</radical> a <radical>scooter</radical> that moves through the <kanji>bone marrow</kanji> inside them.
reading_mnemonic: If you put your ear really close to a bone with <kanji>marrow</kanji> still in it, you'll hear the scooters going <reading>zuwee</reading> (ずい) as they move the blood around inside there.

onyomi: りゅう, りょう, ろう
meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>imperial</radical> radical and the <kanji>imperial</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
reading_mnemonic: Who is the coolest <kanji>imperial</kanji> you know? <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know!

meaning_mnemonic: You're trying to open the <radical>lid</radical> of a manhole that's covered in <radical>ice</radical> by <radical>jackhammer</radical>ing it a bunch of <radical>times</radical> but it's not working because it's just too <kanji>cold</kanji>. It's so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time!
reading_mnemonic: Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing <kanji>cold</kanji> ice it makes a high pitched <reading>rin</reading>ging (りん) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it.

kunyomi: おうよ, およ, すべ
meaning_mnemonic: You go to buy a <radical>table</radical> but it looks like it has water damage from <radical>drop</radical>s of water hitting it. This makes it a pretty <kanji>mediocre</kanji> table. The water drops haven't really damaged it that much, it still stands and you can use it, but it's kinda ugly, so it's just mediocre.
reading_mnemonic: You weren't expecting to see such a <kanji>mediocre</kanji> table so you go up to the guy who's selling it and say, "Hey, I have a <reading>bone</reading> (ぼん) to pick with you!" But he doesn't think there is a bone to pick at all, he doesn't think the table is mediocre like you do.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>cage</radical> with an <radical>axe</radical> in it above your house to show that you are an <kanji>artisan</kanji>. All of the artisans have to have this special sign somewhere near where they live to show they make things.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Artisan</kanji>s have to be marked this way because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) says so. The Shougun doesn't want to have to put any effort into finding people to make things for him, so he created this new system.

meaning_mnemonic: You've learned that you can <radical>catapult</radical> things to <kanji>give</kanji> them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Give</kanji> food to your new friend <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry.

meaning_mnemonic: If when you speak it sounds like the <radical>power</radical> of a <radical>drum</radical> is coming out of your <radical>mouth</radical>, then people will hold you in high <kanji>esteem</kanji>. Anyone who has a loud, booming, powerful voice will be held in high esteem in this day and age. Look at all those awesome musicians who have booming voices!
reading_mnemonic: You hold them in such high <kanji>esteem</kanji> that you give them your <reading>ca</reading>r (か). I ... I said you give them your car! Give them your car. Hey, hey!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>roof</radical> is <radical>spicy</radical> because you're the <kanji>manager</kanji>. You're always testing new recipes in your house to share with everyone who works under you, but that makes all the spice stick to your roof (since it doesn't have good ventilation like a restaurant or a lab would).
reading_mnemonic: You've finally done it. You're now the <kanji>manager</kanji> of a bunch of spicy new <reading>cy</reading>borgs (さい). You've been toiling away for over a year, but you've finally replaced the cyborg you lost, and now you can manage them properly without anyone getting in the way.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>roof</radical> <radical>above</radical>, is a <radical>small</radical> <radical>stool</radical>. Anyone who sits in that stool will be <kanji>lonely</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You're so <kanji>lonely</kanji>, you make up an imaginary friend: <reading>Jack</reading> (じゃく). Jack doesn't get rid of the lonely feeling because he isn't real, but he is a distraction at least.

meaning_mnemonic: Who loves their <radical>flag</radical>, using <radical>jackhammer</radical>s, and precise <radical>measurement</radical>s? Your <kanji>military officer</kanji>! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be?
reading_mnemonic: That <kanji>military officer</kanji>'s favorite bird is an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for!

meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>canopy</radical> you have a <radical>brush</radical> (in its 肀 form) and a <radical>task</radical> to complete with it. This is totally <kanji>commonplace</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This is so <kanji>commonplace</kanji> and familiar to you that you finish your task early and eat some <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう) while you wait for the guy to come back.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Twenty</radical> <radical>penguin</radical>s together are always <kanji>evil</kanji>. Penguins are seen in groups a lot, sure, but did you know that any time there are exactly twenty penguins in a group they're plotting evil things? Evil things like global warming. And how to eat all the fish in the world so humans can't have any.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>evil</kanji> penguins can't let you tell the other human's what you've seen, so they murder you and hide your body in a <reading>hay</reading>stack (へい). Your family will never know what happened to you. The penguins will get away with their evil plans.

meaning_mnemonic:
This <radical>bow</radical> is <radical>mysterious</radical> because it's strung with a single <kanji>chord</kanji>. I guess that makes the chord both a musical instrument <kanji>string</kanji> as well as a <kanji>bowstring</kanji>. Pluck the chord and it shoots an arrow while making a perfect G note. So mysterious!

Note: We're using "chord" here as the fancy name for a musical instrument string (like in "the chords of a harp" or "strike a chord"). This kanji covers both musical strings and bowstrings!
reading_mnemonic: Turns out this bow strung with a mysterious <kanji>chord</kanji> belongs to <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). Of course! Only someone as elegant and dramatic as Genji would own a bow that plays music when you pluck its string.

meaning_mnemonic: When <radical>small</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s of water work <radical>together</radical> they gain <kanji>respect</kanji> for one another. If you end up working with someone long enough, and they end up being really great, you'll respect them too!
reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>respect</kanji> someone enough you'll even take up their hobbies. The person you respect most loves the Yankees. You don't really feel the same, but you respect that about them so you chant, "<reading>Ooh Ya</reading>nkees, <reading>Ooh Ya</reading>nkees!" (うやうや) with them during each game.

visually_similar_kanji: 税, 説, 脱, 鋭
meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>guard</radical> your <radical>soul</radical> from bad things you'll always feel <kanji>delight</kanji> and <kanji>joy</kanji>. It's hard to guard your soul from everything though, so take all the joy you can, while you can.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>delight</kanji> you feel is so great that it becomes permanently <reading>etch</reading>ed (えつ) in your soul and even your face.

visually_similar_kanji: 伯, 迫, 舶, 泊
meaning_mnemonic: You're tapping your <radical>fingers</radical> against a <radical>white</radical> wall when you realize the sound you're making is actually a sick <kanji>beat</kanji>. You keep going and start singing along. Boo boo boop. Boo do do do doop! Finger beats!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>beat</kanji> is sick, but as you tap you realize you're <reading>hack</reading>ing (はく) up the wall! Slowly but surely, your fingers are hacking out little bits of the wall. And the beats don't sound as good until you move to a new, clean white area.

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to fit your <radical>fingers</radical> into a <radical>key</radical> <radical>hole</radical>, you have to <kanji>squeeze</kanji> them in. Fingers aren't exactly supposed to fit in key holes... they're for keys, after all. But you want to squeeze your finger on in there anyway to unlock the door.
reading_mnemonic: Once you've <kanji>squeeze</kanji>d your finger in the key hole to unlock this door you squeeze all the money and jewels and treasures you can fit into your <reading>sack</reading> (さく). Your stealing sack.

meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> in your <radical>ear</radical>s when there's an <radical>explosion</radical> <kanji>in addition</kanji> to all the other things you were told to do. You have to crouch under a desk, you have to stay away from windows, you have to close your eyes. But in addition to that, you need to protect your ears!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>In addition</kanji> to all the steps you have to take to protect yourself, you can't forget that ears come in <reading>sets</reading> (せつ). You can't just stick one finger in one ear and have that be the end. You have a set of ears to worry about!

meaning_mnemonic: You shoot an <radical>arrow</radical> at the <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>sun</radical> so that it will grant you a gift of <kanji>wisdom</kanji>. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too.
reading_mnemonic: You're standing around waiting for the <kanji>wisdom</kanji> to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of <reading>chee</reading>se (ち)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And the key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese!

meaning_mnemonic: If you could <radical>stop</radical> <radical>spoon</radical>ing water onto that <radical>tree</radical> we could use it for <kanji>brushwood</kanji>. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already!
reading_mnemonic: You finally set the <kanji>brushwood</kanji> on fire and suddenly a <reading>Shiba</reading> (しば) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa?

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>together</radical> with another tsunami is going to cause a massive <kanji>flood</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: After the terrible <kanji>flood</kanji>, Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち comes to survey the destruction and offer hope to his people. But, instead he just tells the people that this flood happened because they didn't believe in the Crabigator's words, and because they weren't doing their kanji reviews.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>animal</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> is drinking our <radical>alcohol</radical>? <kanji>Still</kanji>?
reading_mnemonic: The animal with horns that is <kanji>still</kanji> drinking your alcohol is no animal at all. It is actually one of the local <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) dressed up like a horned animal so they can drink as long as they want and you'll be too scared to shoo them away.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>stone</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s from the sky into a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and then a <radical>cross</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s on top of it. They've combined to form a <kanji>tombstone</kanji>! Wait, does that mean a body fell from the sky first and you just didn't see it?
reading_mnemonic: Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the <kanji>tombstone</kanji> it's radiating with intense <reading>he</reading>at (ひ)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere!

visually_similar_kanji: 役, 投, 疫, 殿, 殻
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> hits the <radical>forehead</radical>s of <radical>grain</radical>s with his <radical>weapon</radical> so the <kanji>grain</kanji>s will pop off and into his mouth. He doesn't want to kill the plants, so he's just skimming the grain's foreheads so they'll fall off and he can eat them.
reading_mnemonic: Phew, all of this <kanji>grain</kanji> is making the samurai thirsty, so he reaches in his bag and pulls out an ice cold, refreshing <reading>Coke</reading> (こく).

meaning_mnemonic: Take a <radical>mole</radical> out of its <radical>hole</radical> and it will <kanji>suffocate</kanji>. They need to be in tight quarters, unlike us humans. So when you take one out of its nice, safe hole, it thinks it can't breathe and suffocates.
reading_mnemonic: As the mole <kanji>suffocate</kanji>s it <reading>cheats</reading> (ちつ) and shoves its head into your closed hand. You realize what it's doing and squeeze your hand tighter so it's more like a hole. You can feel the mole breathing again now.

meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>hole</radical> in someone's <radical>body</radical> with a <radical>bow</radical> and they'll become <kanji>destitute</kanji>. You put a hole in them. They can't work. They can't take care of their house or their kids. They've lost it all.
reading_mnemonic: You see this <kanji>destitute</kanji> person and decide to give them a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう). They don't even remember that they're supposed to eat those, so they shove it in the hole you made with your bow.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>thread</radical>s are <radical>humble</radical> and that makes you a perfect <kanji>gentleman</kanji>. You don't have to have fancy clothes to be a gentleman, just humble ones that don't stand out and show off too much. That shows how polite you are.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, as a <kanji>gentleman</kanji> who dresses humbly, you're always getting kicked in the <reading>shin</reading>s (しん) by rude kids (and occasionally rude adults).

visually_similar_kanji: 博, 錬, 練, 陳
meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>specialty</radical> is <radical>drop</radical>ping people with <radical>thread</radical> by <kanji>bind</kanji>ing them! You can drop anyone as long as you have enough thread to restrain them. It doesn't matter how much they fight, you'll get them to drop!
reading_mnemonic: If you're going to be a weirdo who likes to <kanji>bind</kanji> people, at least make sure that they land on their <reading>back</reading>s (ばく) when they DO drop. Landing on your head or your boobs really hurts. So please at least try to make them land on their backs!

meaning_mnemonic: You take some <radical>thread</radical>, put your <radical>scooter</radical> up to a <radical>signpost</radical>, and <kanji>sew</kanji> them together. You don't have a lock, so sewing your scooter up to the signpost to keep it safe is all you can think of.

They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> is stuck in a <radical>prison</radical> under the <radical>ground</radical> and it's starting to <kanji>rot</kanji> and <kanji>decay</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You get close to the <kanji>rot</kanji>ting tree and see some rotten <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう) hanging from its branches. No!

other_meanings: Evergreen Beech, Oak, Oak Tree, Beech
visually_similar_kanji: 権, 稚, 確, 進, 難, 雄, 雑, 誰, 離, 推, 維, 雅, 准, 唯
meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> has been sitting directly on your <kanji>spine</kanji> for weeks straight. The pain is starting to become unbearable, and it seems like no one wants to help you.
reading_mnemonic: Just as your <kanji>spine</kanji> seems to be getting used to the pressure, the tree turkey unleashes a cry: "<reading>TWEE</reading>T (つい)!" To your horror, a flock of tree turkeys emerge from the trees.

onyomi: かく, こく, ばい
meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> puts his <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>table</radical> next to his <radical>weapon</radical>. He is just a <kanji>husk</kanji> of his former self. This <kanji>shell</kanji> of a samurai has nothing left.
reading_mnemonic: The only way to bring a <kanji>husk</kanji> of a samurai back to life is to have a <reading>cock</reading> (かく) crow right in his ear.

meaning_mnemonic: You can only manage to avoid a <radical>tsunami</radical> by standing <radical>above</radical> it on a <radical>small</radical> <radical>stool</radical> if you are very <kanji>graceful</kanji>. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.
reading_mnemonic: No matter how <kanji>graceful</kanji> you are, the tsunami still <reading>shook</reading> (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> gets into a <radical>net</radical> that's im<radical>prison</radical>ing a bunch of <radical>insect</radical>s, the insects are going to get all <kanji>muddy</kanji>. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately for the insects, these <kanji>muddy</kanji> conditions have created the perfect habitat for <reading>duck</reading>s (だく). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> <radical>rake</radical>d all the <radical>mountain</radical>s down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your <kanji>congratulations</kanji> with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.
reading_mnemonic: The moment you say "<kanji>Congratulations</kanji>!" you've already started to <reading>miss</reading> (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>king</radical> will send his men with <radical>sword</radical>s into your <radical>private</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> if you come across <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji>. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.

If you've never taken an art history class (or played Minecraft) you may never have come across lapis lazuli, but think of it as a pretty, blue precious stone that people really, really liked in the olden days.
reading_mnemonic: You run up and ask how this <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji> thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "<reading>Loo</reading>phole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> wants you to make a <radical>rocket</radical> that looks <kanji>glassy</kanji>. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve.
reading_mnemonic: You take the <kanji>glassy</kanji> rocket and try to stuff some thin <reading>reed</reading>s (り) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>stone</radical>s that smell like <radical>trash</radical> in the <radical>river</radical>. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of <kanji>sulfur</kanji>. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks.
reading_mnemonic: You throw the <kanji>sulfur</kanji> rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there.

meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>seven</radical> <radical>sword</radical>s just sitting in a <radical>hole</radical> and so you decide to <kanji>steal</kanji> them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right?
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>steal</kanji> the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword <reading>sets</reading> (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>triceratops</radical> standing in front of a full <radical>moon</radical> and you can't help but see a really strong <kanji>resemblance</kanji>. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon!
reading_mnemonic: The first person to see this <kanji>resemblance</kanji> was the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> that grow on your <radical>roof</radical> that look like a sleeping <radical>bear</radical> is <kanji>sedge</kanji>. Sedge grow all over the world!
reading_mnemonic: The next time you see a <kanji>sedge</kanji> bite into it. It tastes like <reading>suga</reading>r (すが)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to reach a certain <radical>number</radical> of <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>tsunami</radical>s hits to become a legitimate <kanji>fiefdom</kanji>. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.
reading_mnemonic: The most famous <kanji>fiefdom</kanji> checker is <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <radical>say</radical> the <radical>lineup</radical> of your family members that have lived on this earth under the <radical>sun</radical>, you're really explaining your <kanji>genealogy</kanji>.

This kanji has a second meaning too. It means score, as in a musical score or sheet music. So if your sheet music <radical>say</radical>s the <radical>line up</radical> of chords, especially <radical>sun</radical>nny notes, that's the <kanji>score</kanji> of a song. Those sunny notes are loved by your ancestors.
reading_mnemonic: If you can't tell the difference between your <kanji>genealogy</kanji> and a musical <kanji>score</kanji>, you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.

meaning_mnemonic: If you spill something <radical>red</radical> on yourself in <radical>winter</radical> you should <kanji>pardon</kanji> yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of!
reading_mnemonic: If you don't <kanji>pardon</kanji> yourself fast enough the winter <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked!

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>scooter</radical> has a <radical>fault</radical>, you need to get an <kanji>alternate</kanji>. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>alternate</kanji> scooter is made entirely of <reading>鉄</reading> (てつ). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter.

visually_similar_kanji: 酸, 酔, 酎, 酢, 配
meaning_mnemonic: Pour all of your <radical>alcohol</radical> in the <radical>pool</radical> to <kanji>serve</kanji> all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>serve</kanji> your guests (and yourself) you look over and see <reading>Shaq</reading> (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.

meaning_mnemonic: This is a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>roof</radical>, <radical>correct</radical>? Better put a <kanji>lock</kanji> on it, then.
reading_mnemonic: The person who put the <kanji>lock</kanji> on the gold roof was none other than... <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう)?!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical> <radical>clown</radical> is the only clown allowed to <kanji>accompany</kanji> you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together.
reading_mnemonic: He can only <kanji>accompany</kanji> you for so long though and soon it's time to say <reading>bye</reading> (ばい) again.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>husband</radical> was wearing his <radical>cleat</radical>s when he accidentally stepped on a <radical>bird</radical>. Luckily this particular bird is a <kanji>chicken</kanji>, and chickens are really durable!
reading_mnemonic: The only way to stop the <kanji>chicken</kanji> from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい) you were making.

other_meanings: Sub-, Sub, Demi, Demi-, Second-Rate, Inferior
meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>Asia</kanji>. 

This can also mean <kanji>sub-</kanji>. As in subtropics, subspecies, subhuman… That kind of sub-! When it's not in a place name, 亜 will usually be using its sub- meaning.
reading_mnemonic: What's the first sound in <kanji>Asia</kanji>? It's <reading>A</reading> (あ). Nice and easy!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>leader</radical> will come to <kanji>despise</kanji> their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.
reading_mnemonic: The more you <kanji>despise</kanji> them, the more <reading>boo</reading>ze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>drop</radical> to the ground in a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and then <radical>drop</radical> down in front of the <radical>cross</radical> you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as <kanji>lowly</kanji> as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that.
reading_mnemonic: The only problem about being <kanji>lowly</kanji> is the <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?

meaning_mnemonic: We want you to say things with your <radical>mouth</radical> right <radical>now</radical> because it's <kanji>recital</kanji> time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!
reading_mnemonic: Here, if you are too afraid to start the <kanji>recital</kanji> now drink this <reading>gin</reading> (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!

meaning_mnemonic: If there is <radical>dirt</radical> in a <radical>crab trap</radical>, it's a lot for the crabs to <kanji>endure</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to make the little crab that <kanji>endure</kanji>d being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a <reading>colla</reading>r (こら) round its little neck.

meaning_mnemonic: You meet a <radical>woman</radical> whose <radical>mouth</radical> is <radical>big</radical> and you instantly know this is the person you want to <kanji>marry</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>marry</kanji> this woman right away and you both go straight to an <reading>inn</reading> (いん) together!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>barracks</radical> radical and the <kanji>barracks</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Barracks</kanji> are pretty big, so they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (とん). And they probably take tons of materials to build.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>mountain</radical> in the shape of a <radical>turtle shell</radical> sticking out into the ocean. It's a <kanji>cape</kanji>! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
reading_mnemonic: You decide to walk along this <kanji>cape</kanji> because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old <reading>me</reading>at <reading>sack</reading> (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).

other_meanings: The Worst, Ridge, Peak, Height, Toughest Moment, Mountain Trail
meaning_mnemonic: If there are <radical>mountain</radical>s <radical>above</radical> and <radical>below</radical> you, that means you're on a <kanji>mountain pass</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: It's only on this type of <kanji>mountain pass</kanji> that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable <reading>To</reading>kyo <reading>ge</reading>cko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>mountain</radical>'s <radical>roof</radical> are people using <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to <kanji>worship</kanji> the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others <kanji>worship</kanji> in the mountain and they're going to <reading>sue</reading> (すう) you for the noise.

meaning_mnemonic: If you only let <radical>oneself</radical> (yourself) into your <radical>heart</radical>, you'll end up <kanji>mourning</kanji> all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in.
reading_mnemonic: While you're in <kanji>mourning</kanji>, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A <reading>key</reading> (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning?

meaning_mnemonic: If a pilot manages to land under a <radical>canopy</radical> with a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's pierced with a sideways <radical>barb</radical> in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> you should <kanji>congratulate</kanji> them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Congratulate</kanji> the pilot with <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)!

meaning_mnemonic: You have to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to make an <radical>exit</radical> because you're so <kanji>clumsy</kanji>. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the knob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave.
reading_mnemonic: After you make your <kanji>clumsy</kanji> mistake you realize that these doors come in <reading>sets</reading> (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors!

meaning_mnemonic: You try to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cast <radical>doubt</radical> on people by using them to <kanji>imitate</kanji> each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others.
reading_mnemonic: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to <kanji>imitate</kanji> is the imitation now and they have them in a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation.

kunyomi: つかさ, ともがら, へや
meaning_mnemonic: When under<radical>ground</radical> <radical>music</radical> makes it out into the light of the <radical>sun</radical> (the public), it finally becomes <kanji>official</kanji>. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.
reading_mnemonic: Once the music is <kanji>official</kanji>, you'll feel it in your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too.

other_meanings: Birch, Wood Block, Japanese Birch Tree
meaning_mnemonic: What kind of <radical>tree</radical> is <radical>spicy</radical>? A <kanji>Japanese birch</kanji>, or <kanji>birch</kanji>, obviously. There's nothing spicier than a Japanese birch!
reading_mnemonic: You can only cut down a <kanji>Japanese birch</kanji> using <reading>a zoo saw</reading> (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these trees are.

kunyomi: おご, にご, よな
meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>tsunami</radical> that's heading for your village is <radical>fat</radical> you should try to <kanji>select</kanji> a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.
reading_mnemonic: If you're having trouble <kanji>select</kanji>ing which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating <reading>ta</reading>cos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.

meaning_mnemonic: People think <radical>tsunami</radical>s are only made of water but they have a <radical>few</radical> pieces of <kanji>sand</kanji> in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.
reading_mnemonic: You already learnt the reading for 砂, the other kanji for <kanji>sand</kanji>. It should be easy to remember this one too, since it's also さ!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>good</radical>. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you <kanji>wander</kanji> the lands in search of it.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>wander</kanji>, you come across a clue. It is fish <reading>roe</reading> (ろう).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>tree</radical> and your <radical>hat</radical> protects you from the <radical>water</radical>, but the hat itself is now covered in <kanji>lacquer</kanji>. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to scoop up the rest of the <kanji>lacquer</kanji> water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore!

meaning_mnemonic: Making a mnemonic for a <radical>crab trap</radical> is <kanji>VERY</kanji> hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!
reading_mnemonic: You know what else is <kanji>very</kanji> something? <reading>Jean</reading>s (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.

meaning_mnemonic: If you see someone <radical>eye</radical>ing your <radical>womb</radical> you're probably going to be weirded out by how <kanji>friendly</kanji> they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>friendly</kanji> guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "<reading>ぼく</reading>-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>stone</radical> that looks like a <radical>turkey</radical> <radical>boil</radical>ing underwater is just a <kanji>reef</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>reef</kanji> is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spirit</radical> wearing two <radical>mustache</radical>s must be <kanji>evil</kanji>. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil.
reading_mnemonic: You're watching the <kanji>evil</kanji> mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your <reading>ca</reading>r (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil!

meaning_mnemonic: If someone makes a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>horse</radical>, you know it's <kanji>deliberate</kanji>. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo.
reading_mnemonic: As you admire all the <kanji>deliberate</kanji> details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions."

visually_similar_kanji: 族, 施, 妨, 訪, 坊, 旅, 旋, 放, 防, 肪
meaning_mnemonic: Move <radical>thread</radical> in the right <radical>direction</radical> and you'll end up <kanji>spinning</kanji> it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!
reading_mnemonic: While you're <kanji>spinning</kanji> you realize that you've always wanted to make your own <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes.

meaning_mnemonic: If you stay up so long that you see the <radical>moon</radical> go down and the <radical>dawn</radical> come, people will say you have serious <kanji>guts</kanji>. It takes guts to stay up that late. More specifically, it takes a powerful <kanji>gallbladder</kanji>. Your gallbladder is sensitive to sleep changes, you know, so you risk a lot by staying up like that.
reading_mnemonic: You stayed awake outside for so long, just to prove you had <kanji>guts</kanji> and powerful <kanji>gallbladder</kanji>, that you also got a sweet <reading>tan</reading> (たん) out of it!

meaning_mnemonic: By putting <radical>flowers</radical> in a <radical>net</radical>, you manage to catch a <radical>canine</radical>! But this just makes everyone <kanji>scorn</kanji> you.
reading_mnemonic: You notice everyone's <kanji>scorn</kanji> and respond by saying: "I <reading>bets</reading> (べつ) you I can catch me another one. I bets you I can."

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>say</radical> how <radical>eternity</radical> sounds you have to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. <kanji>Recite</kanji> those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it.
reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>compose</kanji> a poem about an <reading>a</reading>corn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you.

meaning_mnemonic: Going from a <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>helicopter</radical> that's <radical>big</radical> even for yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), is a huge <kanji>transition</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You decide one <kanji>transition</kanji> isn't enough, so you transition to a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better.

meaning_mnemonic: You can only give a <radical>kiss</radical> of <radical>alcohol</radical> to <kanji>dairy</kanji>. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Dairy</kanji> isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a <reading>rack</reading> (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!

meaning_mnemonic: Take <radical>three</radical> <radical>measurement</radical>s of <radical>gold</radical> and <radical>slide</radical> them into a mold to make a <kanji>cast</kanji>! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.
reading_mnemonic: You open the <kanji>cast</kanji> to reveal your gold statue of <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.

visually_similar_kanji: 閉, 閣, 聞, 間, 問, 関, 開
meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>tree</radical> growing through it and it reminds you that you need more <kanji>leisure</kanji> time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>leisure</kanji>ly nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you.

meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>stop</radical> a <radical>turkey</radical> by putting a <radical>spoon</radical> in its face you'll know it's a <kanji>female</kanji> turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>female</kanji> turkey then runs around making a <reading>mess</reading> (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> <radical>squid</radical> tells all of its squid people to be <kanji>thrifty</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Who is a <kanji>thrifty</kanji> squid? <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent.

meaning_mnemonic: You go outside to bask your <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical>, but then you see these creatures with <radical>lid</radical>s for heads and <radical>fins</radical> for feet. Uh… where did they come from? From the <kanji>underworld</kanji>. Nothing like them exists in this world. They obviously came from the underworld.
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>underworld</kanji> creatures must be out and about because it's <reading>May</reading> (めい), and the weather is so fantastic and sunny right now. They don't get to see the sun down there in the underworld, so every May they turn up in droves to experience it.

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>slice</radical> the <radical>power</radical> out of someone just <kanji>censure</kanji> them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested.
reading_mnemonic: Once you <kanji>censure</kanji> them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another <reading>guy</reading> (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>cage</radical> is full of <radical>flowers</radical> on the <radical>right</radical> side to <kanji>hide</kanji> the fact that you're in here too.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>hide</kanji> the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?"

meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>twenty</radical> <radical>slide</radical>s lined up like a <kanji>grid</kanji>. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper?
reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the slide <kanji>grid</kanji> you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass <reading>maths</reading> (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later!

meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>mouth</radical> to sing and a <radical>shellfish</radical> to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a <kanji>shamisen song</kanji> just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time!
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>shamisen song</kanji> is just an <reading>歌</reading> (うた) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical>, you find a <radical>lid</radical> under the <radical>table</radical>. You lift it to reveal a deep <kanji>pit</kanji>. Why is there a <kanji>hole</kanji> under your table?
reading_mnemonic: When you reach the bottom of the <kanji>pit</kanji>, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see <reading>こう</reading>いち, starved and chained in a pit under your table.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>death</radical> of a <radical>woman</radical> occurs it's because she was being <kanji>reckless</kanji>. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right.
reading_mnemonic: As you watch the news about this <kanji>reckless</kanji> woman you find out that she died from <reading>mow</reading>ing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it.

meaning_mnemonic: Have you heard the tale of the <radical>woman</radical> who fell in love with a <radical>coat rack</radical> during a full <radical>moon</radical> and made him her <kanji>groom</kanji>? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the groom's side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things.
reading_mnemonic: Since their wedding happened under the full moon, the <kanji>groom</kanji> wore his special <reading>moon coa</reading>t (むこ) to the ceremony. This is the ideal coat for a groom to wear, since they can keep wearing it all through their honeymoon.

meaning_mnemonic: Under your own <radical>roof</radical>, a <radical>geoduck</radical> jumps out of the <radical>ground</radical> with a <radical>sword</radical> and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a <kanji>widow</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You may be a <kanji>widow</kanji>, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your <reading>ca</reading>r (か), and run your entire house and the geoduck over.

meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>canopy</radical> is the <radical>Mona Lisa</radical>, being sold for cheap, what a great <kanji>bargain</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: This Mona Lisa is such a <kanji>bargain</kanji> because it's just a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん)!

visually_similar_kanji: 募, 幕, 暮, 墓
meaning_mnemonic: You're walking in a <radical>greenhouse</radical> when you see a <radical>small</radical> <radical>drop</radical> of water fall and it makes you <kanji>yearn for</kanji> the person you <kanji>adore</kanji>. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>yearn for</kanji> that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... <reading>Bo</reading>bo (ぼ) the clown?! Ugh. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water.

meaning_mnemonic: You put your <radical>fingers</radical> in the <radical>coffin</radical> to tickle the <radical>beggar</radical> inside. What you're doing is a new form of <kanji>torture</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The beggar you will coffin tickle <kanji>torture</kanji> is none other than old Grandpa <reading>ごう</reading>いち. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled.

kunyomi: それがし, なにがし
meaning_mnemonic: If you think a <radical>tree</radical> looks <radical>sweet</radical> you have to be <kanji>certain</kanji> before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching.
reading_mnemonic: If you really want to be <kanji>certain</kanji>, and not just guess, take out your <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you.

meaning_mnemonic: You grab a <radical>tree</radical> to help you reach the <radical>bar</radical> out in the ocean, using it as a <kanji>jetty</kanji> leading straight to it. Now you can walk out on your makeshift <kanji>pier</kanji> and go get drinks without needing a boat or getting wet.
reading_mnemonic: You also made this <kanji>jetty</kanji> so it would be easier for <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, and he wants a refreshing drink after delivering all those presents. You get extra presents for making him a jetty, so win-win.

meaning_mnemonic: "For the  <radical>samurai</radical>, it is a <radical>jackhammer</radical> that they will <radical>lack</radical>." That is the latest <kanji>article</kanji> of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great <kanji>sincerity</kanji> by the government.
reading_mnemonic: The one who wrote these <kanji>article</kanji>s with such <kanji>sincerity</kanji> was Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん).

meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>yakuza</radical> member in a <radical>prison</radical> on the <radical>sun</radical> and he'll become a <kanji>martyr</kanji> to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison.
reading_mnemonic: The only reason he ended up a <kanji>martyr</kanji> in the first place is because they put him up there in <reading>June</reading> (じゅん). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical>'s have a <radical>certain</radical> tendency to <kanji>secrete</kanji> things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving.
reading_mnemonic: Most tsunami's <kanji>secrete</kanji> <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> swept away one of the <radical>cleat</radical>s your <radical>husband</radical> just bought and creates an entire <kanji>valley</kanji> with it.
reading_mnemonic: When the water clears, you and your husband go to the <kanji>valley</kanji> to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut."

meaning_mnemonic: As the <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical>, it alters the wave, creating <kanji>ripples</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Ripples</kanji> come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were <reading>ren</reading>tals (れん), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami.

meaning_mnemonic: You're stuck in your <radical>car</radical> during a <radical>tsunami</radical> and all you have to break out is an <radical>axe</radical>. You whack and whack but you're only <kanji>gradually</kanji> making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown.
reading_mnemonic: As you're <kanji>gradually</kanji> making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "<reading>YO YA</reading>NKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open.

meaning_mnemonic: Set <radical>fire</radical> to a <radical>geoduck</radical> if you want to <kanji>annoy</kanji> it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly.
reading_mnemonic: You know who loves <kanji>annoying</kanji> geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun.

kunyomi: あぜ, くろ, ほとり
meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Half</radical> of a <radical>rice paddy</radical> is always on the <kanji>shore</kanji>. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right?
reading_mnemonic: You decide to walk along this <kanji>shore</kanji> when you see <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lie on the shore with Han!!

meaning_mnemonic: You ate some <radical>grain</radical>s that made you so <radical>sick</radical> it feels like a <radical>knife</radical> is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called <kanji>diarrhea</kanji>. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>diarrhea</kanji> is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow <reading>reed</reading>s (り) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>arrow </radical>is shot from <radical>heaven</radical> and hits right between your <radical>mouth</radical> and your <radical>mustache</radical> to <kanji>correct</kanji> your crooked smile. It also <kanji>straighten</kanji>s your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you.
reading_mnemonic: These heavenly <kanji>correct</kanji>ing arrows actually come from <reading>きょう</reading>と. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky.

meaning_mnemonic: You're in a <radical>net</radical> but you have the <radical>ability</radical> to <kanji>quit</kanji> playing along and <kanji>leave</kanji> at any time.
reading_mnemonic: You don't know if you want to <kanji>quit</kanji> this charade until you feel an uncomfortable <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> that you <radical>oversee</radical> are always <kanji>indigo</kanji>. You aren't sure why though...
reading_mnemonic: Wait, maybe these flowers are only <kanji>indigo</kanji> because there is something wrong with your <reading>eye</reading>s (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> that wash up on shore in <radical>tsunami</radical>s that we make into <radical>syrup</radical> is <kanji>seaweed</kanji>. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Seaweed</kanji> is true <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul.

meaning_mnemonic: If, <radical>again</radical> and again, you behave like an <radical>insect</radical>, you might as well be a <kanji>barbarian</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "<reading>BAN</reading> (ばん) the barbarians! Ban them, I say!," you loudly declare as the lord of these lands.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something to a <radical>boot</radical> when you want to be <kanji>humble</kanji>. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more <kanji>discreet</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You're being <kanji>humble</kanji> like this because those boots belong to the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse!

meaning_mnemonic: If you ride a <radical>scooter</radical> with your <radical>fingers</radical> around an <radical>axe</radical> you're going to <kanji>die</kanji>. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die.
reading_mnemonic:
You slip. The axe collides with your face. You <kanji>die</kanji>. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead.

Wait, no!

It shatters.

meaning_mnemonic: Give <radical>alcohol</radical> to a <radical>demon</radical> and you'll see how <kanji>ugly</kanji> it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>ugly</kanji> demon is drunk and taking off his <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes.
